fields.headline: Double delight for Shearer
fields.trailText: The Premiership struck back last night as Newcastle United stayed on course - just - for a third consecutive FA Cup final appearance. After a weekend of merrymaking by Nationwide clubs at the expense of their perceived better, First Division Blackburn Rovers paid a predictably high price for the inhospitable welcome afforded to an old friend.
fields.body:
The Premiership struck back last night as Newcastle United stayed on course - just - for a third consecutive FA Cup final appearance. After a weekend of merrymaking by Nationwide clubs at the expense of their perceived better, First Division Blackburn Rovers paid a predictably high price for the inhospitable welcome afforded to an old friend.

Alan Shearer continues to pen his own colourful scripts and as a finally-balanced fifth-round tie neared its climax he it was who steered home a cross by the substitute Didier Domi at the far post, his second goal of the evening.

Newcastle's reward is an unenviable trip to the Worthington Cup finalists Tranmere Rovers. Invigorating and rejuvenating though the arrival of Bobby Robson on Tyneside may have proved to be, Newcastle do still find somewhat less than appealing the prospect of moving beyond the confines of the north-east.

If this fondness for home comforts is both familiar and understandable, travel sickness, in its countless guises, can prove to be a side's nemesis, an unpalatable truth to which Robson had referred before last night's game.

Rather sadly for Blackburn, the hamstring injury which had been troubling Duncan Ferguson in the previous few days was deemed insufficiently serious to warrant an evening off and he was invited to inflict punishment upon a defence which, many would argue, does suffer from soft-centre syndrome.

Indeed, it is fair to say that both these teams attack better than they defend something which provided a formula for an intriguing, at times intoxicating, blend of cavalier counter-thrusts and, of course, schoolboy errors deep inside the penalty area.

The game always flowed nicely enough, Newcastle seeking to pick out Ferguson's highly productive forehead at every opportunity, Blackburn threading passes through a back-line which never once looked truly at ease with itself.

Predictably, the evening's first chance of any real merit fell to Shearer, jeered from first whistle to last by those who once would have had statutes erected in his honour on every corner of every Blackburn street.

Rising smartly at the far post Shearer reached first Alessandro Pistone's free-kick but his header was wayward and lacked power. Blackburn's riposte was swift, Simon Grayson swinging over a fine cross from the right only for Nathan Blake to head tamely into the arms of the Newcastle goalkeeper Steve Harper.

Many of the Lancastrians were still chuckling at Shearer's profligacy when he was presented with, and duly converted, his second chance of the tie.

It was classic Shearer, racing clear of a leaden-footed defender to calmly steer home after Ferguson had flicked on Harper's enormous clearance. If the goal was memorable the manner of Shearer's celebration most certainly was not as he foolishly, childishly, knelt on one knee to point and stare at his detractors.

But, protecting an advantage does not come easily for Newcastle and within six minutes Blackburn were level. After Darren Peacock had ended Kieron Dyer's spirited dash forwards with a timely tackle, Per Frandsen belted the ball forwards into the space between defence and goalkeeper. Harper raced out gamely but Matt Jansen was first to the ball to slip home smartly from 18 yards.

Newcastle were suddenly faced by a dilemma. Should they seek a replay or chase glory, should they stick or twist? They fell somewhere between the two alternatives, thus providing their hosts with just enough encouragement to effect a subtle change in the overall balance of power.

Blackburn's attacks in a more physically robust second half were always measured and patiently constructed even if they did lack genuine menace; what they needed was a Shearer.

webTitle: Even Ferguson wants a more peaceful accommodation

fields.headline: Even Ferguson wants a more peaceful accommodation
fields.trailText: Even Sir Alex Ferguson reckons that Manchester United players went too far on Saturday in disputing the penalty Andy d'Urso awarded Middlesbrough.
fields.body:
Even Sir Alex Ferguson reckons that Manchester United players went too far on Saturday in disputing the penalty Andy d'Urso awarded Middlesbrough.

D'Urso, above left, claimed that he feared for his safety after a posse of United players, led by the captain Roy Keane, rushed at him.

Ferguson defended his players at the time but after watching the incident on television he says that the referee and the players were all in the wrong. D'Urso was wrong to award the penalty because Jaap Stam had tackled Juninho fairly; and United's players overreacted.

"I thought our players went too far, I must say that, and I've had a word with them this morning," Ferguson told Piccadilly Radio yesterday.

"I've watched it on television and I can understand the ref's reasons for giving the penalty because from behind it might have looked that Jaap had taken his legs. But in fact he got the ball first and then followed through and caught the boy's legs."

Ferguson also disputed D'Urso's claim that he might have been knocked over in the rush had he not backed off the pitch. "Hardly, in front of 60,000 witnesses," the United manager said.

Ferguson also criticised media coverage of the controversy. "I saw an incident in the game at Chelsea between Chelsea and Leicester yesterday when a player went right over the ball," he said of Dennis Wise's tackle on Steve Walsh, "and it didn't get the fraction of the headlines of what happened in our game.

"So you have to wonder what is more serious - a career-threatening tackle or abuse to the ref."

Keane was booked for dissent but that is the only punishment United players will suffer. D'Urso did not include the incident in his report and the Football Association has decided to take no action.

fields.headline: Owen in doubt for Euro 2000
fields.trailText: Liverpool and England will learn later this week whether Michael's Owen's already fractured season will be prematurely ended by injury.
fields.body:
Liverpool and England will learn later this week whether Michael's Owen's already fractured season will be prematurely ended by injury.

Not for the first time in recent weeks, the England striker is anxiously awaiting a specialist's verdict on a hamstring injury.

Owen has suffered six such injuries in just over a year and as prolonged rest is the accepted cure for such a problem, there is genuine fear that he may not be available for the summer's European Championship finals in Belgium and the Netherlands.

"Michael has not been training, he has been resting," said the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier. "He will continue to rest until we have the results of his latest examination."

Owen's latest comeback attempt ended in painful failure 10 days ago when he limped out of the Premiership meeting with Middlesbrough at Anfield after 28 minutes.

As his team-mates travelled to a training camp in Malta last week, Owen was dispatched to London to seek the advice of an expert in sports injuries. His verdict is expected within the next 48 hours and may represent untimely news both for Houllier and the England coach Kevin Keegan.

Houllier conceded this month that he was worried about Owen's seeming inability to shake off an injury that recurs with alarming regularity. "Michael has a problem and it is something we need to sort out immediately," he said.

It is a measure of Houllier's concern that he spent the past week attempting to secure a goalscorer of experience and ability on loan. With late March an optimistic comeback date for Robbie Fowler, Owen's preferred partner who is recovering from ankle surgery, Houllier has scoured the substitutes' benches of Europe in the hope of finding a partner for Titi Camara.

But despite courting several famous names he has failed to find an answer. He had hoped to convince the Italian international Fabrizio Ravanelli to return to England 2 years after he left Middlesbrough. Ravanelli, who recently joined Lazio from Marseille, was keen on a move to Anfield until his wife rebelled against the prospect of living on Merseyside.

Houllier checked on the availability of another Italian, Rangers' Marco Negri, and is even thought to have considered re-signing the former German international Karlheinz Riedle, who swapped Liverpool for Fulham just three months ago.

fields.headline: New sponsor for Old Trafford
fields.trailText: Manchester United are poised to consolidate their status as the world's richest football club by clinching the most lucrative sponsorship deal in the history of the English game.
fields.body:
Manchester United are poised to consolidate their status as the world's richest football club by clinching the most lucrative sponsorship deal in the history of the English game.

The Premiership leaders are expected to announce details of a £30m-plus agreement, believed to be with Vodafone, in the next 48 hours.

United's long-running deal with Sharp expires in the summer and the club have been locked in negotiations with several potential successors. British Airways and Emirates have both been linked, along with various internet companies, but Vodafone is the strong favourite.

 Enzo Maresca has completed his £4m move to Juventus from West Bromwich 18 months after leaving Italy on a free transfer from Cagliari.

 Michael Johansen is returning to Denmark to join AB Copenhagen after three years with Bolton. The forward will move at the end of the season.

 Sunderland's Kevin Phillips is expected to agree a £20,000-a-week deal that will keep him at the club until 2004. "I don't see why I can't fulfil all my footballing ambitions here," he said.

 Alen Boksic, Lazio's striker, has registered his disgust at a banner held aloft during Sunday's 3-1 win against Bari paying tribute to the recently assassinated Serb warlord Arkan. Fans also displayed a portrait of Italy's wartime fascist dictator Benito Mussolini.

"I'm feeling bad, really bad," said the Croatian, who missed the game with injury. "I would have taken my shirt off and left the stadium [if I had played]."

webTitle: Claridge in trouble over bet on Pompey

fields.headline: Claridge in trouble over bet on Pompey
fields.trailText: Steve Claridge and five of his Portsmouth team-mates face a Football Association inquiry after placing a £250 bet on their side to beat Barnsley at Fratton Park on Saturday.
fields.body:
Steve Claridge and five of his Portsmouth team-mates face a Football Association inquiry after placing a £250 bet on their side to beat Barnsley at Fratton Park on Saturday.

Claridge, a renowned gambler whose habit has cost him around £300,000, said he felt insulted by the 3-1 odds offered by the club's official bookmaker Flutters. He promptly scored a hat-trick to ensure Pompey's first win in 15 games and a £750 pay-out.

Betting of any kind by players on football is forbidden. But Claridge said: "I didn't know we had done anything wrong; we were all backing ourselves to win the game.

"It was just a bit of fun and there was nothing sinister or underhand in it at all. We made a bit of money but we're not going to be able to retire on it. Let's not turn this into something it's not."

Flutters ran out of money at Fratton Park after the 3-0 victory and were still paying out yesterday.

The FA spokesman Steve Double said: "Nobody connected directly with the game is permitted to bet on football, full stop. That means players, managers and coaching staff. They cannot bet on their own games or on others. We will be making enquiries about this later this week and we will be speaking to Steve Claridge."

The FA wrote to the Spurs defender John Scales in 1997 to remind him of the rules after he told on television of how he had won £800 on a game.

Scales said he and some of his Wimbledon team-mates backed him to score the first goal in an FA Cup match against Sunderland in 1994. "It was typical of what we used to do at Wimbledon," he said.

 Leicester's midfielder Muzzy Izzet intends to turn his back on a career with England and play for Turkey in this summer's European Championship after being repeatedly overlooked by Kevin Keegan.

Izzet has established himself as one of the Premiership's most impressive players but has had no direct contact with Keegan despite the Leicester manager Martin O'Neill orchestrating a vigorous campaign on the player's behalf.

Born in south London, Izzet qualifies for Turkey through his father Mehmet and the 25-year-old has been offered a provisional place in Euro 2000 by the national manager Mustafa Denizli.

"I've spent the last few months wrestling with the biggest decision of my life," said Izzet. "I've turned down Turkey twice before and if I said no again it might have been my last chance of international football. That's something I would have regretted for the rest of my career.

"Now I have made up my mind, I am looking forward to it as long as I get it in writing and confirmed properly."

In the past, Izzet would have been required to undertake between six months and two years of national service, but the Turkish authorities have now relaxed that condition.

 Marcus Stewart was last night discussing a move from Huddersfield to their promotion rivals Ipswich after the clubs agreed a £3m fee, one of the highest ever between Nationwide League clubs.

The 27-year-old striker, who scored twice in Huddersfield's 2-2 draw at Crystal Palace on Saturday, has hit 15 goals this season.

Stewart's move comes as Huddersfield hope to conclude the £300,000 signing of of Sheffield United's forward Martin Smith today.

 Ukraine will meet England at Wembley on May 31, according to the Ukrainian football federation's president. "In the next few days we will fax the official reply to the English, that we have accepted their offer," Valery Pustovoitenko said yesterday.

fields.headline: World Cup a hit - official
fields.trailText: Interest in last year's World Cup tapered off following England's early exit but the tournament remained popular with ethnic minorities and women, helping generate a £30m profit.
fields.body:
Interest in last year's World Cup tapered off following England's early exit but the tournament remained popular with ethnic minorities and women, helping generate a £30m profit.

A report by the England and Wales Cricket Board also claims the tournament was watched by 2.3 billion television viewers in 29 countries.

England's failure resulted in less sponsorship income than anticipated but the organisers say the presence of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh helped maintain public interest and ensured the World Cup remained popular with Britain's ethnic minorities.

Terry Blake, the tournament director, says in the report: "The ECB achieved most of its objectives in delivering a well-organised, profitable event that left a lasting legacy for the game both in this country and around the world."

Fears that the scheduling of the tournament early in the year would lead to delays and abandonments because of bad weather also proved unfounded. The weather determined the result of only one of 42 matches; only one extra day was required to achieve a result. Unfortunately for the organisers, this was the match in which India knocked out England.

fields.headline: Hussain backs floodlight age
fields.standfirst: The England captain points the one-day way forward
fields.trailText: Those who argue that English cricket has entered the twilight zone were given a degree of official approval yesterday when the captain Nasser Hussain said that he considered floodlights to be the future of the one-day game.
fields.body:
Those who argue that English cricket has entered the twilight zone were given a degree of official approval yesterday when the captain Nasser Hussain said that he considered floodlights to be the future of the one-day game.

Hussain said: "In one-day cricket this is the future, for spectators, players and sponsors. There was a great atmosphere when we played South Africa at Newlands and the more of these matches we play the better. We are going to have to play under lights and more experience would help."

He reflects the current thinking at Lord's. Two of the four matches England have played in this triangular series with South Africa and Zimbabwe have been under lights and the fact that they lost both has done nothing to dampen official enthusiasm.

Next season three one-day internationals - at Birmingham, Bristol and Manchester - will be floodlit affairs, using six (not four) points of illumination, and 16 of the 18 counties will also play that form of the game.

It is expected that most of the matches in the 2003 World Cup, in South Africa, will be under lights. Dominic van den Bergh, the England and Wales Cricket Board's marketing services manager, is over here now picking up tips.

In England the obvious problem is the climate. Watching cricket with a woolly hat pulled down over one's ears and a fistful of hot chocolate is not the same as viewing the proceedings in T-shirt and shorts with a glass of chardonnay in hand, as we see here and in Australia.

Clubs need to insure against the weather and after a particularly wet summer it is easy to see premiums rising higher than the pylons that support the lights.

The extended period of twilight is another problem in England. In other cricket-playing countries darkness seems to fall like a curtain, minimising that difficult period of adjustment for the players.

However, the ECB is aware that, while cricket is not dying, it has withered. Fewer people now take an active interest in the traditional form of the game, as either players or spectators, and only Asia and Australia buck the trend.

It also knows that about 10% of the spectators who watched what little floodlit cricket has already been staged in England had never watched the game before. It is tapping into a fresh market.

Still on the subject of twilight, Graeme Swann arrives back in England today wondering whether his international career is over before it got started properly.

The 20-year-old, who has been on one-day stand-by for the fit-again Ashley Giles, took one first-class wicket for 210 runs and scored 13 in his one innings. Internationally, he bowled five overs for 24 runs in the one-day match against South Africa in Bloemfontein.

Off the field it has not been any better. He was fined £250 for twice missing the team bus, once when on 12th-man duty at Centurion, and although names were not named it is understood he was one of those the coach Duncan Fletcher had in mind when he said young cricketers must work harder. Chris Read and Andrew Flintoff were the others.

Chris Adams, for other reasons, must also be wondering whether he will play for England again. Unlike Swann he has been given a good run this winter but fluffed his chance with 104 runs in five Tests.

Hussain said: "We've given Chris opportunities. He's played in nearly every game but we had to look at our batting."

Adams, essentially a front-foot player, has been given a ruthless working over by the bowlers. First, they pushed him on to the back foot and then they bowled wide to him, exposing a lack of footwork and poor shot selection. He still has a chance, though. Sussex play under lights at Hove.

It also knows that about 10% of the spectators who watched what little floodlit cricket has already been staged in England had never watched the game before. It is tapping into a fresh market. Still on the subject of twilight, Graeme Swann arrives back in England today wondering whether his international career is over before it got started properly. The 20-year-old, who has been on one-day stand-by for the fit-again Ashley Giles, took one first-class wicket for 210 runs and scored 13 in his one innings. Internationally, he bowled five overs for 24 runs in the one-day match against South Africa in Bloemfontein. Off the field it has not been any better. He was fined £250 for twice missing the team bus, once when on 12th-man duty at Centurion, and although names were not named it is understood he was one of those the coach Duncan Fletcher had in mind when he said young cricketers must work harder. Chris Read and Andrew Flintoff were the others. Chris Adams, for other reasons, must also be wondering whether he will play for England again. Unlike Swann he has been given a good run this winter but fluffed his chance with 104 runs in five Tests. Hussain said: "We've given Chris opportunities. He's played in nearly every game but we had to look at our batting." Adams, essentially a front-foot player, has been given a ruthless working over by the bowlers. First, they pushed him on to the back foot and then they bowled wide to him, exposing a lack of footwork and poor shot selection. He still has a chance, though. Sussex play under lights at Hove.

fields.headline: 'In plain speaking you murdered her'
fields.standfirst: Harold Shipman is questioned by the police
fields.trailText: Police officers question Dr Shipman over the death of Winifred Mellor.
fields.body:
On October 5 1998, detective sergeant Mark Wareing and detective constable Marie Snitynski questioned Dr Harold Shipman over the death of Winifred Mellor. Dr Shipman had falsified her medical records to show she had a history of heart trouble but a later post mortem showed a fatal level of morphine.

DC Marie Snitynski: Can you indicate to me how severe the angina was at all?
Harold Shipman: The severity of angina doesn't indicate the likelihood of a coronary. I'm sure your medical experts would agree that. Erm she only, she had no signs of congestive heart failure, and she only got the pain of she rushed, but it was lasting two to three minutes. How does one grade angina, severe angina you don't even get out of bed.
DC Marie Snitynski: But from the progression you've noted on your records this was not something that was going to be unexpected.
Harold Shipman: This was a progressive angina, and people do die of coronaries with no proceeding history of angina.
DC Marie Snitynski: Well there are certain facts I need to make you aware of at this stage. I don't think there can be any dispute in a lot of them. Mrs Mellor's body was buried on the 18th May 1998 at Highfield cemetery, Stockport. Would you accept that from me?
Harold Shipman: If you say.
DC Marie Snitynski: Now would you accept that the body of Mrs Mellor was exhumed with the consent of the coroner on the 22nd September this year? [1998]
Harold Shipman: If you say so.
DC Marie Snitynski: And I think from what you were saying earlier that you were aware that a post-mortem examination was subsequently undertaken. Certain samples were taken at the post mortem for forensic analysis. Would you accept that?
Harold Shipman: You're telling the story, of course.
DC Marie Snitynski: A home office pathologist, Dr Rutherford carried out that post mortem examination. I think that as you were going to mention, his findings do not support that this lady died of a coronary thrombosis as you've diagnosed. Would you like to comment on that, that finding?
Harold Shipman: Doctors don't always diagnose a heart attack as a heart attack, they'll call it coronary thrombosis or miscardiaschema, micardienfarcture to the average run of the mill GP. They are all the same, the patient's dead. With a coronary thrombosis you would expect there would be a bit of heart muscle damaged but you can't have just an electrical disorganisation of the heart which kills you just as effectively and leaves no symptoms at all. No signs sorry. Signs at all.
DC Marie Snitynski: Well in his expert opinion there was nothing to support your diagnosis is what I'm saying.
Harold Shipman: But he couldn't rule out a disorganised electric, electrical activity of the heart.
DC Marie Snitynski: Forensic examination of the samples taken, including muscle tissue at that post mortem have been examined. These are the samples taken from Mrs Mellor and there's certainly a high level of morphine still contained in her body. A fatal level to be precise. Can you account for that?
Harold Shipman: No.
DC Marie Snitynski: Well I've got to put it to you doctor that you are the person who administered that lady with the drug, aren't you?
Harold Shipman: No.
DC Marie Snitynski: The levels were such that this woman actually died from toxicity of morphine, not as you wrongly diagnosed. In plain speaking you murdered her  One feature of these statements from the family was that they couldn't believe their own mother had chest pains, angina and hadn't been informed.
Harold Shipman: By, by whom?
DC Marie Snitynski: By her
Harold Shipman: By her, thank you.
DC Marie Snitynski: They also found it hard to believe that she would refuse any treatment she was given in relation to this diagnosis and I think now that we can answer why that was. Because she didn't have a history of chest complaints and heart disease and angina, did she doctor?
Harold Shipman: If it's written on the records then she had the history and therefore
DC Marie Snitynski: The simple truth is you've fabricated a history to cover what you've done, you'd murdered her and you make up a history of angina and chest pains so you could issue a death certificate and placate this poor woman's family didn't you?
Harold Shipman: No.
DC Marie Snitynski: We've got a statement from a detective sergeant John Ashley who works in the field of computers. He has made a thorough examination of your computer, doctor, and the medical records contained on it. First of all he's produced a medical summary report which is that document. I'll put in on the table in front of me. It has a police reference of JFA41 and in essence it's what you've been looking at already on this lady's medical records. A copy of the records as they stand on the computer, but because this man's an expert he's able to interrogate computers and he has gone into this computer in some depth and what he's found is that there are a number of entries that have been incorrectly placed on this record to falsely mislead and to indicate this woman had a history of angina and chest pains. What have you got to say about that doctor?
Harold Shipman: Nothing.

webTitle: Blunt Blair to tell farmers 'uncomfortable truth'

fields.headline: Blunt Blair to tell farmers 'uncomfortable truth'
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today tell farmers "the uncomfortable truth" that they must change to survive the worst agricultural depression since the 1930s.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today tell farmers "the uncomfortable truth" that they must change to survive the worst agricultural depression since the 1930s.

He will acknowledge the crisis - confirmed in official statistics published yesterday - but insist there can be no short-term fixes when he addresses the National Farmers' Union conference in London.

Mr Blair has been warned he can expect "a robust reception" after insisting that the government will not bale out the industry "at any cost". He will cite the provision of £435m in special aid since Labour came to power, plans for a £1.6bn phased programme of development in rural areas and cuts in red tape as proof of the government's support and admit that the price of sterling is helping to worsen a crisis "which is biting very hard".

But farming faces the same challenges as other businesses - consumer and environmental pressures, globalisation, new technologies and e-commerce - Mr Blair will argue. "While this is an uncomfortable truth, it is far better for the government to be honest than pretend it can solve all the industry's problems.

Government ministers and officials point out that farm incomes doubled in the early 1990s before falling back by more than 60% in the second half of the decade. They believe farmers must diversify into other businesses - including growing industrial crops and tourism - as well as tap into the growing demands for locally-grown produce and organic foods.

The Tory leader William Hague is expected to hit back against "token gestures" when he addresses the conference tomorrow.

Mr Blair's blunt approach kicks off a government campaign seeking to prove it is not neglecting countryside issues, provide an upbeat assessment of rural education and employment, and detail measures on preserving local transport links, village halls and post offices. He is to travel to the south-west to spread the messages later this week. Net incomes are thought to have fallen by 16% last year with pig and poultry businesses in the red for the second year, losing about £8,000, lowland livestock farms making £1,500 and hill farms making just £2,500.

The NFU president Ben Gill said: "The reality is that the industry is on its knees. Farmers are working longer and longer hours, 70-hour weeks are common, and year after year that is not sustainable."

A paper for the New Policy Institute, the New Labour-leaning think tank, warned that a new emphasis on making market towns the focus for regenerating the countryside might be misguided.

Journalist and commentator Ken Jones, writing in Changing Views of Rural Britain, said strong ties of work, leisure and family that bonded towns to their surrounding villages and the farming community no longer existed.

fields.headline: Portillo back as shadow chancellor
fields.standfirst: Hague brings ex-minister back on board
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo made a dramatic return to frontline politics tonight when he was installed as shadow chancellor by Tory leader William Hague.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo made a dramatic return to frontline politics tonight when he was installed as shadow chancellor by Tory leader William Hague.

Mr Hague shoved aside Francis Maude and brought in Mr Portillo just weeks after he returned to the Commons in the Chelsea and Kensington byelection.

In a dramatic overhaul of his shadow cabinet, shadow environment secretary John Redwood has been axed completely from the front bench, as has foreign affairs spokesman John Maples.

Though Mr Portillo is widely regarded as a leadership threat to Mr Hague, the Conservative leader has chosen to tie him in to his team by giving him this key role. Mr Hague hailed him as a "proven political heavyweight".

Former Asda chairman Archie Norman, who entered parliament in 1997, has been appointed shadow environment secretary in Mr Redwood's place. He has promised Mr Hague he will sort out potential conflicts of interest in relation to policy on out of town shopping centres and, as a director of Railtrack, with transport. Mr Hague said he was "one of the most successful businessmen in the whole country".

Mr Hague said: "I have brought in two people of great and proven ability. I think it will add tremendously to the ability and talent and enthusiasm of the shadow cabinet."

But for his surprise defeat in the Enfield Southgate seat in May 1997, Mr Portillo may well have become party leader instead of Mr Hague. Many Tory MPs wish that had happened.

Instead he has been absent from Westminster until he took over Kensington and Chelsea last November after the death of Alan Clark, for whom a memorial service was held today.

Out of parliament, Mr Portillo, a former defence secretary and chief secretary to the treasury, urged the Tories to be more tolerant of people's private lives and admitted he had homosexual experiences when a student.

It is a bitter fall from grace for Mr Redwood, who quit the cabinet to challenge John Major in 1995, then fought again for the leadership after the election.

John Maples will also be dismayed to be out, having been promoted fast by Mr Hague on his return to the Commons in 1997. But he performed poorly in the three posts - health, defence and foreign affairs - he moved between.

With prime minister Tony Blair in some trouble, Mr Hague wants a fresher team to step up the attack against Labour. Mr Portillo will certainly be a more formidable opponent for chancellor Gordon Brown, who has won credit for dominating the economic policy agenda.

webTitle: Computer problem delays Endeavour launch for a week

fields.headline: Computer problem delays Endeavour launch for a week
fields.trailText: Nasa delayed space shuttle Endeavour's launch by more than a week Tuesday in order to replace a critical computer that malfunctioned during the final minutes of the countdown.
fields.body:
Nasa delayed space shuttle Endeavour's launch by more than a week Tuesday in order to replace a critical computer that malfunctioned during the final minutes of the countdown.

Engineers could not figure out why the computerised unit sent bad signals on Monday, even though it passed a subsequent test.

Nasa spokesman George Diller said shuttle managers are convinced there is something wrong with the unit "and it must be replaced". Lift-off is postponed until at least February 9, he said.

The mission to create the finest map of Earth ever produced is already four months late because of damaged wiring that had to be fixed on Endeavour and the other shuttles.

The decision came just before Nasa was to begin fueling Endeavour for a launch attempt. The six astronauts had yet to board the shuttle; in fact, three of them were still asleep. They plan to return to Houston on Wednesday.

On Monday evening, shuttle program manager Ron Dittemore stressed that safety was paramount.

"If we don't understand it to the point where we know we are safe then we will not launch," Dittemore told reporters. "We can always take the time out to change the box."

The computerised unit, known as a master events controller, is a critical component. Two identical controllers are on board, and both are needed to send signals to ignite the two solid rocket boosters at lift-off and to later separate the boosters and external fuel tank from the shuttle.

About the size of a microwave oven, the 65-pound (29-kilogram) controller is not hard to replace. But the job is complicated by all the required tests and the hook-ups of explosive charges for the separation of the boosters and tank.

The computer trouble cropped up with less than a half-hour remaining in the countdown Monday. Even without the problem, Endeavour could not have lifted off because of rain and thick, dark clouds.

webTitle: Doctor's name joins ranks of world's worst murderers

fields.headline: Doctor's name joins ranks of world's worst murderers
fields.standfirst:
Serial killers: Lack of violence distinguishes GP in catalogue of brutality
Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: The conviction of Harold Shipman for the murder of 15 of his patients confirms him as one of the the most prolific serial killers of the modern era.
fields.body:
The conviction of Harold Shipman for the murder of 15 of his patients confirms him as one of the the most prolific serial killers of the modern era.

Only Dennis Nilsen is known to have killed as many in Britain, although the exact number of men he strangled and mutilated at his flat at Cranley Gardens in Muswell Hill, London - thought to be between 12 and 16 - is still a matter of conjecture. Shipman's case is different because detectives, who investigated 130 deaths, believe he killed at least 15 and more charges are expected.

But Shipman, unlike most serial killers, did not kill with violence. His modus operandi, a swift injection of a lethal dose of morphine, distinguishes him from the brutality and bloodshed that usually marks out a murderer.

The list of Britain's most prolific killers also contains the Yorkshire Ripper, Peter Sutcliffe, who was found guilty in 1981 of murdering 13 women, aged from 16 to 47.

His murder spree started in October 1975 when he beat and stabbed a prostitute. He later claimed he wanted to rid the world of prostitutes and described the murders as "just cleaning up streets". Sutcliffe was captured five years later.

More recently Fred West is thought to have killed 12 people at 25 Cromwell Street, Gloucester. West committed suicide in prison before standing trial but his wife, Rosemary, was convicted in 1995 of murdering 10 women and girls. The victims were tortured, raped and murdered and then buried at Cromwell Street.

Detective Superintendent John Bennett, who led the investigation, said: "This was a terrible case. It is quite clear that Mrs West must be a psychopath. She and Frederick West were a perfect pair for each other."

But there have been cases of even more prolific murderers in other parts of the world.

If convicted by the Chinese courts, Hu Wanlin could be the most prolific killer yet known. He claimed he was a healer who possessed a mysterious force of qi, or vital energy. He is said to have set up hospitals in two Chinese provinces several years ago, but his treatments allegedly killed 146 patients. He is awaiting trial.

Last March Anatoly Onoprienko was convicted by a Ukrainian court of murdering 52 people, 10 of them children.

The former forestry student - nicknamed "the Terminator" by local newspapers - would burst into homes at random and kill entire families with his sawn-off hunting gun. Before his trial, he told reporters: "I have no regrets, no remorse and I would do it again if I could."

A Russian cannibalistic killer, Andrei Chikatilo, admitted murdering 55 people in an 11-year period. At his trial, he blamed a deprived childhood and a lack of motherly love for his obsession. "I am a freak of nature, a mad beast," Chikatilo told the court. He was executed in 1994.

In the US, Jeffrey Dahmer was jailed in 1992 for murdering 17 teenagers in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Two years after his conviction he was killed by a fellow jail inmate who used a mop handle to stab him in the eye.

"You think you have seen it all, then something like this happens," said a police officer who was among the first to enter Dahmer's apartment. When they broke in police discovered that the killer kept severed heads at his home; two were found in the fridge. He had crammed the torsos of four men into a barrel and other body parts were strewn around the floor or stored in jars.

Dahmer later told detectives: "I knew I was sick or evil or both."

Bewildering body counts

Hu Wanlin, a healer in China arrested last year, charged with killing 146 patients

Andrei Chikatilo, a Russian who admitted 55 murders. Executed six years ago

Anatoly Onoprienko, a Ukrainian convicted of killing 52, including 10 children

Jeffrey Dahmer, jailed in 1992 for murdering 17 teenagers in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Killed by fellow prisoner two years after conviction

Burke and Hare, the Edinburgh murderers, who killed 16, selling human organs to medical schools in the 1850s

Harold Shipman, convicted of 15 murders, but with 23 cases outstanding

Dennis Nilsen, believed to have killed up to 16 people in the early 80s.

Peter Sutcliffe, the Yorkshire Ripper, killed 13

Fred West, accused of 12 murders

Only Dennis Nilsen is known to have killed as many in Britain, although the exact number of men he strangled and mutilated at his flat at Cranley Gardens in Muswell Hill, London - thought to be between 12 and 16 - is still a matter of conjecture. Shipman's case is different because detectives, who investigated 130 deaths, believe he killed at least 15 and more charges are expected. But Shipman, unlike most serial killers, did not kill with violence. His modus operandi, a swift injection of a lethal dose of morphine, distinguishes him from the brutality and bloodshed that usually marks out a murderer. The list of Britain's most prolific killers also contains the Yorkshire Ripper, Peter Sutcliffe, who was found guilty in 1981 of murdering 13 women, aged from 16 to 47. His murder spree started in October 1975 when he beat and stabbed a prostitute. He later claimed he wanted to rid the world of prostitutes and described the murders as "just cleaning up streets". Sutcliffe was captured five years later. More recently Fred West is thought to have killed 12 people at 25 Cromwell Street, Gloucester. West committed suicide in prison before standing trial but his wife, Rosemary, was convicted in 1995 of murdering 10 women and girls. The victims were tortured, raped and murdered and then buried at Cromwell Street. Detective Superintendent John Bennett, who led the investigation, said: "This was a terrible case. It is quite clear that Mrs West must be a psychopath. She and Frederick West were a perfect pair for each other." But there have been cases of even more prolific murderers in other parts of the world. If convicted by the Chinese courts, Hu Wanlin could be the most prolific killer yet known. He claimed he was a healer who possessed a mysterious force of qi, or vital energy. He is said to have set up hospitals in two Chinese provinces several years ago, but his treatments allegedly killed 146 patients. He is awaiting trial. Last March Anatoly Onoprienko was convicted by a Ukrainian court of murdering 52 people, 10 of them children. The former forestry student - nicknamed "the Terminator" by local newspapers - would burst into homes at random and kill entire families with his sawn-off hunting gun. Before his trial, he told reporters: "I have no regrets, no remorse and I would do it again if I could." A Russian cannibalistic killer, Andrei Chikatilo, admitted murdering 55 people in an 11-year period. At his trial, he blamed a deprived childhood and a lack of motherly love for his obsession. "I am a freak of nature, a mad beast," Chikatilo told the court. He was executed in 1994. In the US, Jeffrey Dahmer was jailed in 1992 for murdering 17 teenagers in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Two years after his conviction he was killed by a fellow jail inmate who used a mop handle to stab him in the eye. "You think you have seen it all, then something like this happens," said a police officer who was among the first to enter Dahmer's apartment. When they broke in police discovered that the killer kept severed heads at his home; two were found in the fridge. He had crammed the torsos of four men into a barrel and other body parts were strewn around the floor or stored in jars. Dahmer later told detectives: "I knew I was sick or evil or both." Bewildering body counts Hu Wanlin, a healer in China arrested last year, charged with killing 146 patients Andrei Chikatilo, a Russian who admitted 55 murders. Executed six years ago Anatoly Onoprienko, a Ukrainian convicted of killing 52, including 10 children Jeffrey Dahmer, jailed in 1992 for murdering 17 teenagers in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Killed by fellow prisoner two years after conviction Burke and Hare, the Edinburgh murderers, who killed 16, selling human organs to medical schools in the 1850s Harold Shipman, convicted of 15 murders, but with 23 cases outstanding Dennis Nilsen, believed to have killed up to 16 people in the early 80s. Peter Sutcliffe, the Yorkshire Ripper, killed 13 Fred West, accused of 12 murders

fields.headline: Marking crisis hits A-levels
fields.standfirst:
Shortage of examiners could force switch to multiple choice testing

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government's exam chiefs think they may have to introduce multiple choice questioning at GCSE and A-level as a solution to a growing shortage of experienced examiners competent to mark traditional essay-type answers.
fields.body:
The government's exam chiefs think they may have to introduce multiple choice questioning at GCSE and A-level as a solution to a growing shortage of experienced examiners competent to mark traditional essay-type answers.

Exam boards have recently made little use of the US-style multiple choice technique which gives candidates a series of possible answers to a question and asks them to select one. It has commonly been regarded by British teachers as simplistic.

But Nick Tate, chief executive of the qualifications and curriculum authority, is calling for a fresh look at how the approach could be used without reducing the academic rigour of exams.

"Maybe the biggest issue facing the exam system is how best to recruit enough high quality markers," he says in an article in today's Guardian Education.

"The challenge is all the greater now that students will be doing even more exams following recent reforms. Long-term solutions may have to include greater use of computer marking."

Dr Tate has called in an American computer company to advise on how multiple choice techniques could be used for the new "world class tests" proposed by the government.

The British arm of National Computing Subsidiaries is working on systems for electronically marking questions to measure the mathematical and problem-solving abilities of the ablest children at ages nine and 13.

Dr Tate's investigation into multiple choice follows criticism by the heads of independent schools about declining standards of marking and delays by exam boards in responding to complaints. The Headmasters and Headmistresses Conference estimates that independent and state schools questioned the results of 50,000 candidates last summer, and some appeals are still outstanding.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "The problem is basically incompetence, involving wrong marking and giving wrong grades to students who should be receiving better."

Graham Able, master of Dulwich College, said the boards faced a shortage of good examiners. Too much of the work was done by teachers at the end of a hard day at school, marking scripts at speed, without professional back-up.

Ron McLone, director of policy at the Oxford, Cambridge and RSA exam board, said multiple choice questions were dropped from exams after they were criticised by the school inspectorate in the 1980s. It was worth looking at reintroducing them in subjects where they were appropriate, but it would be a "counsel of despair" to use them just to solve problems of examiner recruitment.

Dr Tate announced a package of measures to tighten up exam board performance. Next month he will publish the first performance tables.

fields.headline: Ministers back universal schooling drive
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Guardian's "read the world" campaign gathered momentum yesterday when two cabinet ministers threw their weight behind the provision of universal basic education for developing countries.
fields.body:
The Guardian's "read the world" campaign gathered momentum yesterday when two cabinet ministers threw their weight behind the provision of universal basic education for developing countries.

Clare Short, the international development secretary, is taking the lead and is being backed by the education secretary, David Blunkett. The foreign office minister, Peter Hain, who is on a visit to South Africa, is to make an impassioned plea in Capetown on Thursday, warning: "Africa cannot compete globally unless it is competitive. That means education, education, education."

The target date set by world leaders of universal basic eduation by 2015 looks increasingly doubtful, especially in Africa where predictions are of a rise rather than a fall in the numbers without access to schooling. Tony Blair has still to be persuaded to make the campaign a priority in the way that the chancellor, Gordon Brown, did with debt relief. It would require Mr Blair to persuade the G8 leading industrialised nations, to pour billions into education programmes for developing countries.

There is debate within government circles over whether a cash injection, as advocated by Oxfam, is the best way forward or whether the internet offers a cheap solution.

The Guardian campaign is aimed at persuading western countries to set a goal of providing every child with the opportunity of primary education in a school that has walls and a roof, and in a classroom that has desks and books.

Ms Short, who along with the chancellor backed the campaign for a reduction of third world debt, has already raised the amount of British funding for education from £500m to £800m: "The debt campaign has led the way in bringing together an unprecedented coalition across the globe and from all walks of life. We must maintain this momentum and secure primary education for all as the next great challenge. "

In Capetown Mr Hain will say: "The internet and the information technology revolution offer possibilities undreamed of by the freedom fighters who fought apartheid." Oxfam and others question the stress put on the internet, arguing many villages have no access to electricity. Mr Blunkett says that high and low-tech strategies are compatible - and both are essential.

fields.headline: 'A way of fighting poverty'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: 'Most aid donors and many third world governments still invest more money and give higher political priority to schooling the rich than to meeting the learning needs of the poor. But encouragingly, in countries like Ghana, Brazil and Nepal we are seeing the beginnings of grassroots movements to demand equity, quality and accountability right across the public education system'
fields.body:
'Most aid donors and many third world governments still invest more money and give higher political priority to schooling the rich than to meeting the learning needs of the poor. But encouragingly, in countries like Ghana, Brazil and Nepal we are seeing the beginnings of grassroots movements to demand equity, quality and accountability right across the public education system'

Salil Shetty, chief executive, ActionAid

'Education is not a way of escaping the country's poverty, it is a way of fighting it'

Julius Nyerere, late president of Tanzania

'Education is a right which should be guaranteed by the state within the framework of public service and not subject to market laws'

Ulf Fredriksson, education coordinator, Education International, Belgium

'A new education system for all, one that increases the capacity for human development and global citizenship'

Ricardo Morales, president, Foro Educativo, Peru

'Education denied is future denied. No country can afford to join the mainstream of the present century of economic information globalisation without making education available for all'

Kailash Satyarthi, chair of Global March against Child Labour, India

'Many African governments have made concerted efforts to fulfil the promises of the Jomtien declaration - Education for All - but despite this Africa remains the least educated continent'

Fulgence Swai, Tanzania Education Network/MET, Tanzania

'Investing in the education of children, rather than investing in the military, is the best defence of any country anywhere'

Rasheda K Choudhury, director of CAMPE, Bangladesh

webTitle: Where the young learn,all of society benefits

fields.headline: Where the young learn,all of society benefits
fields.standfirst:
The right to education

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Today, more children are enrolled in more schools around the globe than at any time in history. This fact reflects the sacrifices of millions of parents and teachers in the developing world, and the visionary commitments and bold actions of many political leaders.
fields.body:
Today, more children are enrolled in more schools around the globe than at any time in history. This fact reflects the sacrifices of millions of parents and teachers in the developing world, and the visionary commitments and bold actions of many political leaders.

Yet the accomplishment barely taps into the potential of education as perhaps the single most critical factor in a child's well-being and in the economic and social development of a nation. And it is only the first step in a worldwide campaign to ensure that all children on the planet receive a basic, good quality education as is their due under the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

Clearly, greater investment in education produces benefits beyond the gains for children. One only has to compare the rapid economic development of south-east Asia, where education has been a budget priority, with poverty's stranglehold in south Asia, where education has not received adequate resources.

In country after country, a strong education system that reaches girls and boys alike has proved significant in countering patterns of poverty, community violence, civil conflict, gender discrimination and HIV/Aids. And for countries racked by turmoil and war, education has been a crucial factor in re-establishing stability and a sense of normality for children in an uncertain world.

Despite these multiple returns on investments, money for education remains hard to come by, with budget purse strings and assistance packages getting tighter even as the need for educational reforms grows.

Aggregated national statistics often hide the fact that access to school is blocked for many children, especially girls, ethnic minorities, children with disabilities and those affected by HIV/Aids. More than 125m children in the world, the majority girls, are not enrolled in school. For millions of children, exploitative and hazardous labour replaces studying long before graduation day. Changing family fortunes force hundreds of thousands of primary school students to lose days, weeks and sometimes months of school. Political instability and armed conflicts, such as those in Kosovo, East Timor and Sudan, keep children in hiding, in camps or on the run rather than at their desks and in their playgrounds.

Even if universal access is achieved, as it could be with an estimated $8bn (£5bn) a year in additional funding, changes will be needed in what children learn, and how and where they learn. A basic education means more than learning to read and count, and more than developing the technical skills to succeed in the 21st century. It means being exposed to experiences that build self-esteem, inculcate a respect for the rights of girls and boys alike and for children of different cultures and social groups, while interacting in ways that improve decision-making skills and foster non-violent ways to solve conflicts.

For this to happen, curriculums must be modernised, teachers retrained and new ones recruited. Classrooms have to be transformed into "child-friendly" spaces in places that are safe and healthy, where the human rights of children, including the rights to self-expression and to have their opinions count, are respected. Places where the best interests of children are paramount.

And if societies are serious about helping children to succeed in school, they must start paying more attention to children long before they start primary school - during the early years, when their healthy growth and development depends on healthy mothers and supportive families, good nutrition and comprehensive and coordinated health services, safe drinking water, uncontaminated food and unpolluted air, as well as on care that enhances the child's cognitive, physical and emotional development, and on the precious opportunities to play and laugh - to be a child.

The obligation to ensure every child's right to education lies with the national governments of the 191 countries which have signed the Convention on the Rights of the Child. But the challenge of transforming education into a process that is integral to individual wellbeing and social progress cannot be met by ministries of education alone. The task depends not only on the financial and political commitment of governments, but on stronger ties between schools, families and community. Ultimately, the responsibility sits with each of us.

webTitle: Crash course in chaos shocks the minister

fields.headline: Crash course in chaos shocks the minister
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: On the first day of South Africa's new school year, the education minister, Kader Asmal, descended on a Soweto school with one of the worst records in the country. Meadowlands high school had a 13% pass rate in last year's leaving exam, the matric.
fields.body:
On the first day of South Africa's new school year, the education minister, Kader Asmal, descended on a Soweto school with one of the worst records in the country. Meadowlands high school had a 13% pass rate in last year's leaving exam, the matric.

In an effort to demonstrate a more robust commitment to education, President Thabo Mbeki had ordered schools to open on time on the first day of term, and to begin classes immediately.

But when Mr Asmal arrived at Meadowlands he found pupils milling in the street, empty classrooms and teachers absent.

Chairs and desks left outside through the Christmas holidays were buried in long grass. Almost everyone commented on the stench from the toilets.

The minister marched unannounced into the office of the vice-principal, William Maumela, and demanded an explanation.

Mr Maumela said the school had been without a headmaster for three years.

The education minister pledged to dock a day's pay from the missing teachers.

Mr Asmal then insisted on checking the storeroom for stationery and text books. The cupboard was almost bare. The stationary was there, although the minister was upset to find it still packed in boxes instead of being distributed to the pupils.

There were no textbooks. Mr Maumela said teachers had failed to retrieve them from pupils the previous term.

Mr Asmal asked the vice-principal to call an assembly. The minister told about 100 pupils that he was "disappointed and shamed" at the "appalling" conditions at the school.

"This is nonsense. I will not tolerate it," he said.

But after what amounted to an apology to the pupils, Mr Asmal told them that South African children had been deprived of education for many years and they should not throw away opportunities, however difficult the conditions.

Then the minister called a staff meeting. He blamed the 20 teachers present for a lack of discipline and organisation: "Obviously, not having a principal to lead the school creates problems. But you need to take the initiative and put the school back in order."

The teachers' union protested that the minister got the wrong impression because he came in lunch hour. His visit began at 11am.

fields.headline: Fee-free zone
fields.standfirst: Scotland's rebellion over tuition payments could turn into a major election issue. Who will be next?  Donald MacLeod  examines the fallout so far
fields.trailText: Scotland's rebellion over tuition payments could turn into a major election issue. Who will be next? Donald MacLeod examines the fallout so far
fields.body:
The Scottish reform of tuition fees will cross the Border as the next election approaches, student leaders believe. The deal that exists between Labour and Liberal Democrats in the Scottish Executive to preserve the coalition means Scottish students will not pay fees in advance unlike students in the rest of the UK. If they leave Scotland to study they will be liable for upfront fees - and so will students from England, Wales and Northern Ireland who attend Scottish universities.

To complicate the picture further, students from the rest of Europe will not pay fees in Scotland from September: the Northumbrian student from across the Tweed must find more than £4,000 in fees during a degree while his or her classmate from Umbria would not have to do so. Scottish (and European) graduates will be required to pay £2,000 into an endowment fund for future students, starting when they are earning £10,000 a year.

The next step could come in Northern Ireland where the higher education minister, Sean Farren, has announced he will look at the proposals of the Cubie committee in Scotland and study the effect of fees.

Andrew Pakes, president of the National Union of Students, said devolution handed more power to the student movement. "You are dealing with smaller units of democracy and it is easier to put across student opinion. We are well on the way to forcing Westminster to make changes."

In Northern Ireland normal student patterns of study have been affected by the abolition of fees in the Republic and by the imposition of fees in the UK - four years' worth at Scottish universities, a favoured destination for young people from the province.

The Welsh assembly does not have control of the education budget but Pakes is confident pressure will grow in England and Wales as it becomes clear that student funding is a geographical lottery. The NUS is gearing up for a lobby of Parliament on March 7 to demand a Cubie-style consultation for the rest of the UK.

"The anomaly will become an absurdity. I don't think having different systems in Scotland and the rest of the country is sustainable, particularly as we get closer to a general election. In marginal seats students and middle-class parents are important voters."

But the fallout from the report produced by Edinburgh lawyer Andrew Cubie and the debate that preceded it has already been considerable. With an eye to heading off unrest south of the Border, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, brought forward a £68m package of measures targeted at poor students, including bursaries that looked remarkably like small maintenance grants. This was hailed by Pakes as a the beginning of a thaw in government policy on fees.

Sir Graeme Davies, principal of Glasgow University, is sceptical. The alarming cost of scrapping fees for European students would deter any government. He is happy with the extra help for poor and mature students, including bursaries of up to £2,000 for those from low income families. He believes this could open up higher education and cut drop-out rates because students could reduce paid work during term-time.

"The higher education sector in Scotland is better off as a result of what's happened, there is help for underprivileged students, and universities should be comfortable with the assurance that we will be compensated for the loss of tuition fee income. That was explicitly in the statement and I do not expect the Scottish Parliament to welsh on it," said Sir Graeme.

Fellow members of the Committee of Scottish Higher Education Principals are far less happy, worried that instead of the independent endowment fund proposed by Cubie they are now back to the mercy of the annual political battles over budgets.

Ian Graham-Bryce, the convener, told the lifelong learning minister, Henry McLeish, that promising to preserve the status quo was not good enough. The Dearing inquiry (and its Scottish offshoot, the Garrick committee) had concluded the sector was seriously underfunded and the situation was getting worse, he said in a letter last week.

"A consensus developed that it was important to provide the sector with an income stream that not only represented a net increase in funding but was distinct from the traditional public funding route and therefore not as vulnerable to short-term pressures." Tuition fees, it was hoped, would have achieved this and now they were abolished it was essential to link the endowment explicitly with funding for universities and colleges, he said.

Like many in Scotland, Michael Thorne, vice-principal of Napier University, Edinburgh, was disappointed the threshhold for paying into the graduate endowment fund had been set as low as £10,000 - "That's what an Edinburgh bus driver earns" - but is more concerned about confusion over admissions.

"Rebuilding Hadrian's Wall has the potential to destabilise the higher education sector in Scotland." New universities like Napier are worried that big names like Edinburgh or St Andrews will find applications from England falling off and fill their gaps with students who would have gone to their neighbours. On the other side of Hadrian's Wall, Newcastle and Northumbria universities have more than 800 Scottish students between them. Newcastle's applications are down even before the disincentive kicks in but is putting a brave face on being able to retain its cross border flows.

Last week's UCAS figures showed applications to Scottish universities for 2000 have fallen more than the average across the UK. There is a fall in applications from England to Scottish institutions of 2.8%, compared with a fall of 1.4% in English students wanting to remain within England - possibly a response to the prospect of four years of fees.

webTitle: A school triumphs amid the shacks

fields.headline: A school triumphs amid the shacks
fields.standfirst:
South Africa: In a former squatter camp, pupils achieve 100% pass rate
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Moeketsi Molelekoa began turning potential pupils away from his school after the number of new applicants topped 300. The headmaster of Leshata secondary school had room for only half that number.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Orange Farm, near Johannesburg
fields.body:
Moeketsi Molelekoa began turning potential pupils away from his school after the number of new applicants topped 300. The headmaster of Leshata secondary school had room for only half that number.

There were places at other schools in the area - but Leshata's reputation had spread rapidly after it achieved the near impossible. Last year, every one of its entrants passed the school leaving exam, the matric. At nearby Sayaphambili school not a single student passed. Across South Africa, fewer than half of all school leavers gained the precious certificate.

Leshata's achievement is all the more remarkable, because it is situated in Orange Farm, a sprawling former squatter camp south of Johannesburg.

These days it is more permanent and known as an "informal settlement". But the poverty is as dire as ever.

"It's a matter of sacrifice by the learners, by the teachers and the principal," said Mr Molelekoa.

"There is no library in the area. These learners are living in shacks, some without electricity. They study by candle. Some of them have to help bring money home because their families are the poorest of the poor. About three quarters of the fathers are unemployed."

Leshata secondary school (motto: "Let your loins be girded and your lamps be burning") has come a long way in a short time. In 1997, only one third of its pupils passed their matric. A year later, the success rate shot up to 93%.

Mr Molelekoa attributes part of the turnaround to the school getting its own buildings. For years, Leshata had to share premises with two other schools. Children learned in shifts.

With their own premises, Leshata's pupils are encouraged to continue working after regular school hours, which run from 7.30am to 2.45pm.

"We do not knock off until five o'clock," Mr Molelekoa said. "Poverty affects the activity of the mind. Each and every matric subject is given double time daily."

Many teachers in South African state schools are poorly paid and unmotivated. Some take second jobs to survive. A generation after pupils led an anti-apartheid boycott of schools to demand "liberation before education", indiscipline is the rule in many classrooms. Some teachers live in fear of pupils who carry guns to school.

But Leshata has a different philosophy. "The important thing here is the learner, not the teacher," Mr Molelekoa said. "It's very easy to motivate poor children. They live in shacks. You can tell them that the only way they are ever going to live in the rich suburbs is through education.

"I tell them that we have to live with the parents God has given us, and if they are poor that is not their fault. But you can chose your future. You can make things different."

Leshata has few resources. There are no computers, scientific equipment or musical instruments. It puts the school at a huge disadvantage compared to the private institutions attended by many white children in Johannesburg.

But Mr Molelekoa says his pupils are far better off than the black children educated under apartheid.

"We have a new school. The government does not have much money but it is really trying to help us," he said.

Leshata wages a constant battle against burglary and vandalism - not by pupils but by local residents. There is no electricity in classrooms because all the junction boxes and fittings have been stolen. The school built a strongroom to store the photocopier and typewriters. Thieves cut their way through the thick metal door.

"The community around us does not always value education. It's our biggest problem. People want bread to survive, not education - so they come and take what little we have," Mr Molelekoa said.

The parents of most of the pupils face the same struggle for survival. All state schools in South Africa have fees. It costs 80 rand (£8) a year to go to Leshata, among the cheapest in the country. But many families in Orange Farm still have trouble finding the money.

However good their results, most pupils cannot afford higher education. Last year, one went to medical school. Leshata paid for his first year at university, but it cannot afford to do that for all pupils. The school has launched a trust to help others.

"They have to go to work after matric. They don't have the money for anything else. Some have ailing parents or they're orphans," said Mr Molelekoa.

"But having your matric is a big opportunity. It means you have a tool, a weapon to go out with and fight for your place in society. Then maybe their children will be able to go to university."

webTitle: Internet promises salvation - or an even bigger knowledge gap

fields.headline: Internet promises salvation - or an even bigger knowledge gap
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The gap between schools in the developing world and schools in the west used to be measured in terms of textbooks, teachers, blackboards and desks - the basic tools of education. Now technology is entering the equation, and the UN has warned that as computers spread throughout western classrooms, the knowledge gap is widening.
fields.body:
The gap between schools in the developing world and schools in the west used to be measured in terms of textbooks, teachers, blackboards and desks - the basic tools of education. Now technology is entering the equation, and the UN has warned that as computers spread throughout western classrooms, the knowledge gap is widening.

Last year's UN human development report talked of a new digital divide, with poor countries facing the prospect of being further marginalised in an increasingly knowledge-based global economy.

The internet, the world's fastest growing communications tool, is still largely a western phenomenon - so being connected to the web is becoming a new demarcation line between the rich and the poor.

In the US, President Bill Clinton has pledged that every American classroom will be hooked up to the internet by the end of this year; there are already more computers in America than all the rest of the world put together. Tony Blair has similar aspirations for Britain.

Meanwhile, south Asia, which is to home to 23% of the world's people, has less than 1% of the world's internet users. And in Africa, there are seven internet hosts for every 1m people, and 40% of people in developing countries have never made a phone call.

At a conference last year in Florence on the so-called Third Way - the political school of thought that seeks to chart a course between the traditional ideologies of the left and right - Mr Clinton suggested that technology itself could be the key to reducing global inequality. "The people in Africa are no different than the people in America," he told fellow social democrat leaders. "If you give people access to technology, a lot of smart people will figure out how to make a lot of money."

Mr Clinton agrees with the UN: the technological gap between the developed and developing world can only reinforce global inequality. His solution, therefore, is to get schools in Africa and Asia on to the net, just like those in the west.

There is a powerful distance-learning lobby pressuring Tony Blair to put technology at the heart of Britain's contribution to solving the third world education crisis. The net's enthusiasts believe it could solve many under-resourcing problems in third world schools; textbooks could be replaced by web pages and poorly qualified teachers by a long-distance tutor who could look after many more students.

But some development groups see a danger of looking for an easy techno-fix and ignoring the realities on the ground. There is no point putting African classrooms on the net when some of them lack roofs and electricity, according to one Oxfam official. Technological solutions are premature, he believes.

"The first challenge is to provide children with a decent quality, basic education and the scale of this challenge appears to have escaped internet advocates," he says.

Access to the net requires a telephone line, another utility in short supply in the developing world. In Bangladesh, there are fewer than three telephone lines for every 1,000 people; in Afghanistan, the ratio is less than one in 1,000. And the barriers are not just physical - a net user has to be literate.

"Even if telecommunications systems are installed and accessible, without literacy and basic computer skills, people will have little access to the network society," according to the latest UN development report. "In 1995, adult literacy was less than 40% in 16 countries."

As cost is the single biggest barrier to tackling these problems in the third world, a return to basics is required. Until governments switch resources from military spending and debt servicing, school fees will remain the only way to keep third world schools open.

Most aid officials believe technology can play a part in ending the third world education crisis, "but no number of internet hosts and mobile phones can compensate for mass illiteracy", says one.

fields.headline: Economic crisis = empty desks
fields.standfirst:
Indonesia: Just as school attendance was recovering, a new recession forced children out of the classroom to work
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: "Stay in school" was the urgent appeal from the Indonesian government and aid organisations when the Asian economic crisis erupted in 1998.
fields.body:
"Stay in school" was the urgent appeal from the Indonesian government and aid organisations when the Asian economic crisis erupted in 1998.

Everyone remembered what had happened in 1986-87 after a much smaller economic shock: it took almost a decade for school enrolment to reach previous levels. The entire decline was attributable to poor children dropping out because parents could not afford fees and materials, or because family life was disrupted.

In 1998, the gains that had been registered were in danger of being lost again.

Seven-year-old Makmun would like to go to school - and stay there. "He asks his dad when he can go," says Makmun's mother, "but we don't have the money".

Makmun's family lives in one of the well-established urban slums of east Jakarta. Their two-room wooden shack is an improvement on the single room in which entire families often eat and sleep.

Makmun's father, Pak Sul, works as a gardener, earning 72,000 rupiahs (£5.50) a week. But the real value of his wage has gone down while basic costs - including schooling - have risen.

Rochmat, Makmun's elder brother, is at school but keeping him there is a constant effort. His fees are paid by a community action group, but Pak Sul has had to borrow from his employers to buy books, a uniform, shoes and school bag.

The loan is deducted from his weekly earnings, affecting the family budget. They already owe more than 250,000 rupiahs, a forbidding sum for a family already living on the margin of poverty. What this means is that the idea of Makmun going to school is out of the question.

The task for Indonesia in education - as in every other branch of social policy - is to find ways of insulating the system from the economic and political disruption which threatens to undermine the very real progress which had been made.

Recent surveys, says Oxfam, show enrolment has fallen by 4-5%. "This represents about 1.3m children who are being deprived of access to the education they need to escape a life in poverty," Oxfam says.

The rate of decline for girls' enrolment is twice that for boys, and the most serious reductions have been registered at junior secondary level - the area which had previously made the most gains.

From 1969 to 1994, participation rates in junior secondary education increased from 39% to 54%. The number of those in senior secondary education also rose from 9% to 34%.

A World Bank scheme to train more secondary teachers had been launched shortly before the current economic crisis erupted in 1998.

"Now the quality of education will suffer further, as government, schools and parents struggle to minimise education costs. Poor communities will be especially hard-hit," the World Bank warns.

School heads have reported higher absences as children help their parents make ends meet. Some say that children appear to be eating less at home, arriving at school weak and undernourished.

Children as young as seven or eight work on food stalls or in backyard factories. A typical job for a young boy or girl is to soak empty bottles - scavenged from city refuse - to remove the labels, or sort through rags and paper.

Others join the packs of beggars who swarm hopefully around cars at traffic lights.

The stay-in-school programme, launched in June 1998, targeted the poorest 2.6m junior secondary children with scholarships and subsidies. The programme was backed by publicity campaign mounted by the United Nations children's agency (Unicef) and financed by Australia.

More than 80,000 primary pupils and junior secondaries were to receive block grants to compensate for the reduction in parental contributions and increased costs of supplies.

Measuring the success of these programmes is difficult. Oxfam warns that experience has shown "targeting during periods of economic crisis is a hazardous affair in Indonesia".

It says that the World Bank schemes have been hampered locally by "corruption and weak administrative systems", and that scholarship schemes have frequently missed their target.

This tallies with experience elsewhere in poverty alleviation schemes, where subsidised rice has been diverted by local officials or sold to those least in need of it.

Harmful effects on education in times of crisis may be less noticed because, unlike a decline in health and nutrition, they are not immediately visible. But the long-term effects on human development can be even more devastating.

Indonesia did well before the crisis in investing proportionately more in education on the basis of lower income levels than many other countries.

It will be a long struggle to recapture that ground.
