fields.headline: Good enough to eat?
fields.standfirst: Will Meg Mathews' implants prove too much for her baby?  Luisa Dillner  on breastfeeding after cosmetic surgery
fields.trailText: Noel Gallagher's wife, Meg Mathews, gave birth to their first child, a daughter, six days ago. Meg celebrated with champagne, Noel with a pint of Guinness. But what, you may ask, is Baby Anais' (named after the French erotic novelist, poor lamb) favourite tipple? Breast milk, or shiny tinned formula?
fields.body:
Noel Gallagher's wife, Meg Mathews, gave birth to their first child, a daughter, six days ago. Meg celebrated with champagne, Noel with a pint of Guinness. But what, you may ask, is Baby Anais' (named after the French erotic novelist, poor lamb) favourite tipple? Breast milk, or shiny tinned formula?

The question is all the more intriguing because of Mathews' well-publicised breast implants. Can you breastfeed after cosmetic enhancement? Will the baby get a mouthful of silicone along with nature's best?

Christopher Khoo, a consultant plastic surgeon at Heatherwood and Wexham Park NHS trust, says that implants should not affect a woman's ability to breastfeed. "The implants are not involved in disrupting the structure of the breast. They have nothing to do with the milk duct tissue," he says.

"Operations such as breast reduction may disrupt the ducts, although a proportion of women do manage to breastfeed because the ducts sometimes seem to be able to rejoin," says Khoo.

The main problem with implants during breastfeeding may be the discomfort of having breasts that suddenly become enormous. "During breastfeeding breasts get larger and if a woman has an implant then they will get very large." There's also the issue of drooping afterwards. "If you expand the volume of your breast by breastfeeding then the skin has to stretch to accommodate," he says. "The skin isn't that stretchy. If you blow up a balloon a little bit and let out the air then the balloon is left roughly the same size, but if you blow it up as hard as you can and let out the air the balloon is left bigger. The breast is similar."

Silicone is now regarded as safe in both the US and UK after extensive studies showed that it was unlikely that leakage caused connective tissue disease. Khoo says: "There have been over 20 papers, since the issue was raised in the US in 1992, showing silicone is safe. There was a scare about silicone found in breast milk but it is also found in the same amounts of breast milk of women without implants."

The La Leche League, which offers advice on breastfeeding, sees no reason why implants should stop anyone breastfeeding, but questions whether they are really necessary.

Nick James, consultant plastic surgeon at the Lister Hospital in Stevenage, says that there are broadly two groups of women who request implants. Women who have had children and are left with empty, saggy breasts and those in their early 20s who are flat-chested. "When you see them in the clinic they tell you they look like a man," says James. The risks of implants are fully explained: "We go through everything with them. The independent review group set up by the government in 1998 has a list of things we have to discuss with women before they have implants and it takes an hour to go through it all."

While Khoo and James see no reason why women should wait to have children before having implants, they say if a baby is imminently planned, it may make sense to delay the procedure. As James warns: "All sorts of things can happen to your breasts after pregnancy."

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: Will fish help aches?
fields.body:
Will fish help aches?

Q My father is in his early 80s. He suffers from aches and pains in the joints, particularly in his wrists and ankles. I was wondering what dietary recommendations there may be to help with arthritis/rheumatism - I've read that oily fish may be beneficial.

A Your dad is most likely to be suffering from osteoarthritis, which is wear and tear of the joints that affects most of us as we get older. He should try to lose weight if he's overweight to take pressure off his knees, ankles and back. Unfortunately, there is no good evidence that oily fish or any other kind of dietary supplement really help in osteoarthritis, though they do in rheumatoid arthritis.

Paracetamol in quite high doses (up to eight tablets or 4g a day) is best for pain relief. If they aren't strong enough, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as Brufen are worth a try but may cause side effects of indigestion, bruising, even stomach ulcers. If his joints swell up, fluid can be drained by the GP to give relief. Injection of steroids into the joint may help. There's hope that injections of hyaluronic acid into arthritic knees will protect the cartilage and relieve pain.

Only joint specialists or rheumatologists offer this treatment. Physiotherapists can help improve joint movements. An occupational therapist can visit to suggest aids and hoists that will help him cope better and avoid falls. Using a stick and replacing thin-soled shoes with cushioned trainers can make a huge difference. An appointment with an orthopaedic surgeon to discuss surgical options may also be useful.

Antidepressants

Q About 10 years ago I was prescribed an antidepressant, amitriptyline, which I have been using ever since. When I enquired about side effects I was told there were none. A few days ago I was looking through a medical book and was horrified to discover that there was a list half a page long - including heart and blood problems and impotence. Are these effects reversible if I stop using the medicine?

A If you were to read the potential side effects, you'd probably flush any prescribed drug down the loo. Of course, you do need to take note of the warnings. A frank discussion with a pharmacist is a good way of getting an informed perspective.

Amitriptyline is effective and safe, so long as you don't overdose on it. Its side effects are largely predictable: it tends to make you tired, but that can be a good thing given that you usually take it at night and that sleep disturbance is often a feature of depression; if you suffer from heart disease, glaucoma or prostate trouble, you probably shouldn't be on it.

Baldness and hormones

Q For the last four years my hair has been thinning at the sides and top and my hairline has been receding. My blood tests have been normal, but my doctor refuses to check my hormone levels as my periods have been OK. However, I have read that female baldness/hair loss can be caused by an increase in the level of testosterone. Have you any advice?

A Your hair loss sounds like it is the type known as male pattern baldness. In men, this is linked to the male hormones, androgens. In women, it is unclear whether hormones play a part. It's often an inherited tendency. The most practical solution is to take the oral contraceptive pill, Dianette, which blocks the male hormones and so can help prevent further hair loss.

If you can't take the pill because you've had a thrombosis or you prefer not to, you could try Minoxidil lotion, marketed as Regaine, available over the counter. You have to keep using it or any hair regrowth tends to fall out again. If you are approaching the menopause then you may want to consider HRT which may restore hair thickness and halt the process. A blood test won't tell you much but can let you know whether you're approaching the menopause despite regular periods. I'd go for Dianette myself.

Facial veins

Q I'm in my late 20s, and I've begun to get fine thread veins on my cheeks. They're not too bad at the moment, but the probability that they are going to get worse is worrying. Is there anything I can do to stop them getting worse (and possibly remove the ones I already have)?

A Tiny thread veins in the cheeks come on with age and sunbathing makes them worse. Rosacea, a skin condition causing facial flushing and tiny pustules, can result in lots of thread veins, as can prolonged steroid treatment. But most of us just get a few tiny ones on the cheeks, starting in our late 20s, and increasing with age. You can get them treated with a pulsatile laser by a dermatologist or cosmetic surgeon. One treatment is usually enough. You'll never get it done on the NHS unless it's due to rosacea or steroids because it will be deemed a cosmetic procedure. Expect to pay at least £175 for consultation and one-off treatment.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dirco.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

webTitle: Millennium Wheel proves worth the wait

fields.headline: Millennium Wheel proves worth the wait
fields.trailText: After a series of false starts, engineering problems and all-too-public delays, the £35 million  Millennium Wheel was finally up and running today - and the first passengers were unequivocally  enthusiastic.
fields.body:
After a series of false starts, engineering problems and all-too-public delays, the £35 million Millennium Wheel was finally up and running today - and the first passengers were unequivocally enthusiastic.

From some 450ft above London in nine-tonne capsules, the select few enjoyed unprecedented views of the capital's landmarks and beyond, to the rim of the Home Counties.

Overcast conditions failed to spoil the day out for the passengers - competition winners who would have travelled on New Year's Eve until a clutch problem on one of the capsules led to a postponement of the wheel's opening.

Jenny Walker, from Croydon, south London, said: "It was unbelievable. Even on a relatively poor day for visibility we had wonderful views over London. It was just magnificent."

Another competition winner, Suzanne Blackford, from Mitcham, Surrey, with her two children, even promised: "I shall come back again and pay to go on."

The 2,100-tonne wheel - officially called the British Airways London Eye - stands on the south bank of the Thames opposite the Houses of Parliament.

When the wheel opens for business, adults will have to pay £7.45 for the 30-minute ride.

One of the first to take a ride today was British Airways chief executive Bob Ayling. Mr Ayling said: "Now the wheel is finally opening with people on it, I am very happy indeed" - and no doubt relieved that BA's massive underwriting of the project appears finally to be heading for public relations success.

BA has planning permission for the wheel for five years but it is expected that the attraction could become a permanent feature.

The wheel should have opened around the third week of January but the clutch problem meant the public opening was put back, first to the beginning of February and then until the beginning of March.

Last year, the dragging of the wheel from a flat position on the Thames into its upright stance was delayed for four weeks after a supporting cable snapped.

There are 32 passenger-carrying capsules on the wheel and each can take up to 25 passengers. This means that there can be as many as 800 passengers on the wheel at any one time and the giant structure can cater for 15,000 passengers a day.

BA hopes to accommodate 2.5 million passengers in the first year of operation, although independent research suggests as many as four million could take rides. More than 600,000 tickets have already been sold and BA is also offering a turn-up-and-go service for people on the day.

The wheel is open from 9am until 6pm until April 1 and then summer opening times of 9am until 10pm come into effect until the beginning of October.

Tickets cost £7.45 for adults, £5.95 for senior citizens, and £4.95 for children, with under-5s going free.

fields.headline: Spinning the soaps
fields.standfirst:
David McKie on government spin doctors trying to influence the content of soap operas
Plus: The spirit of Bolsover
fields.trailText: Government spin doctors, it was reported this weekend, may start trying to persuade writers of soap operas to work in episodes favourable to the government.
fields.body:
Government spin doctors, it was reported this weekend, may start trying to persuade writers of soap operas to work in episodes favourable to the government.

A Downing Street spokesman was quoted as saying: "People may say this sounds terribly political - and it is. But it's also a perfectly good storyline for them. We're not expecting Joe Grundy" (a character in the Radio 4 show the Archers, in case you're not an addict) "to say 'thanks to the wonderful Tony Blair, I've got more money'.

"[But] they could write it in a way that informed their listeners, who might be in the same position as Joe Grundy, while fulfilling their remit as public service broadcasters." (These last eight words should be read in a tone of snarling menace. Never forget that it's governments which fix the BBC licence fee.)

The spin doctors' need for this kind of assistance has rarely been stronger than it is this week, with Tony Blair's big speech on rural affairs today and his tour of Devon and Cornwall at the end of the week.

The trouble with today's performance, in government PR terms, is that it seems very likely to leave Joe Grundy saying: "Thanks to the wonderful Tony Blair, I've got less money than ever."

The prime minister's message is that although times are tough for many, there is no way out through heavier government subsidy, and farmers must learn to diversify. At a time when farm incomes are calculated to have fallen by 16% year on year (by 35% for hill farmers), and when even farmers who have diversified till the smoke came out of their ears are no better off for doing so, Mr Blair's response seems doomed to make farmers feel even more bitter and hopeless.

Perhaps a sequence in tomorrow night's script in which one of the Archer family comes to Blair's defence ("Say what you like about Tony; he's an honest man and a realist") would help to cushion the blow. It will need to be someone sympathetic, though, and certainly not Debbie's creepy Canadian boyfriend Simon.

Even that, however, won't save Mr Blair from the fury of Cornwall. Two of the Sunday papers quoted a Downing Street spokesman as saying that the prime minister had been surprised to discover recently that Cornwall was the poorest county in Britain.

Cornwall, since the election, has had one Labour MP - Candy Atherton, who turned out Sebastian Coe at Falmouth and Camborne - and a crop of vociferous Liberal Democrats (there is not one Tory MP left in the county.) They have hardly been mute about the county's condition over the past two and a half years. Downing Street can't have been listening.

And then there was last August's eclipse. The papers were full of stories beforehand of a coming invasion of Cornwall which would block its country lanes and make its public services creak. People were apprehensive, reporters said - but Cornwall knew even so that the county needed the money the invaders would bring, because of its poverty. Did no one in Downing Street notice?

The candour of this confession was astonishing, especially in a world where so much is spun. But I trembled as I read it for the spokesman who said it. By now they may have invited the sort of vengeance which would leave them in search of another job. Any vacancies for scriptwriters on the Archers?

The Archers
National Farmers' Union

The spirit of Bolsover

Dennis Skinner, the former miner who is Labour MP for the Derbyshire constituency of Bolsover, was back in the Commons yesterday after treatment for cancer. He prides himself as being the hardest man in the house. He will not drink in its bars, he refuses all the junkets on offer to members, he will not even "pair" with Tory MPs to avoid having to vote. The last thing he has ever wanted to be is a loveable institution.

Yet that, as his welcome back yesterday showed, is what he has become. However much he thunders against them, many Tories adore him. That very grand Tory, the late Alan Clark, though very expensive cheese to Dennis's chalk, was devoted to him and ever solicitous for his welfare.

If every MP were like Skinner, the Commons would be an austere, unforgiving place. But a bit more spirit of Skinner among the pushy, self-regarding careerists who throng the green benches on either side of the Commons would restore some of the institution's gravely diminished respect.

webTitle: McQueen reinvents suit for modern mobile man

fields.headline: McQueen reinvents suit for modern mobile man
fields.trailText: Alexander McQueen has unveiled the suit that will take men into the future.
fields.body:
Alexander McQueen has unveiled the suit that will take men into the future.

A week after accountancy firm Arther Andersen dismissed the 130-year-old garment as too formal for today's increasingly casual workplace, the top British designer has restructured its key features.

Why? To better accommodate the accessory no modern man can live without - his mobile phone.

In a collaboration with the phone manufacturer NEC, the suits, which will be available in McQueen's London store for a limited period, dispense with bulky pockets and instead offer slim ones of snug mobile phone dimensions, along with discreet loops to thread hands-free ear sets through.

Will they catch on? In black cotton or grey wool, they should prove adaptable to any wardrobe, although one has a three-quarter length jacket which might scare the more conservative man.

"With one in two men owning a mobile phone, we believe it's high time tailors re-evaluated the function of the suit and took account of today's technology," said NEC's head of marketing, Andy Press.

McQueen, 30, explained his new product: "Nowadays, a mobile phone is a necessity, not a fashion accessory.

"I've tried to blend it in with the suits so that it doesn't stand out, so it acts as one." The designer will return to London Fashion Week to show his ready to wear collection later this month, after defecting to New York last season.

webTitle: Good Friday pact heads for the freezer

fields.headline: Good Friday pact heads for the freezer
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown, former Northern Ireland correspondent for the Guardian, analyses the latest developments in the aftermath of the De Chastelain report
fields.trailText: Derek Brown, former Northern Ireland correspondent for the Guardian, analyses the latest developments in the aftermath of the De Chastelain report.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland peace process is about to be frozen, First Minister David Trimble predicted this afternoon. Accusing the republican movement of reneging on its promise to begin disarming, he signalled that his own Unionist party was no longer prepared to take part in the fledgling power-sharing provincial government.

"My expectation is that we will be moving fairly soon now to the suspension of the agreement," he said.

Signficantly, however, Trimble has not yet resigned as First Minister, raising a modest hope that even now the peace process can be rescued from final collapse.

As Trimble made his doom-laden announcement, a frantic four-way dialogue was still going on, involving the British and Irish governments, the Ulster Unionists, and Sinn Fein.

They were picking over the report presented to the two governments late on Monday night by Jean de Chastelain, the Canadian general who is supposed to be overseeing paramilitary disarmament.

Though the text has not yet been published, the report is said to offer a bleak assessment of the IRA's willingness - or lack of it - to surrender its weapons.

This afternoon, Trimble seemed to be taking for granted the imminent demise of his embryonic administration. He rejected any suggestion that a new form of words can be cobbled together to disguise the IRA's refusal to disarm.

"We have had forms of words over the years. What we actually need is something more than that," he said.

The Unionist leader is clearly angered by what he sees as a blatant breach of promise. In December, against the wishes of a large proportion of his own party, he agreed to head a power-sharing administration including two Sinn Fein ministers, in the belief that the IRA had promised to start disarming by the end of January.

Trimble promised his own party then that he would resign if there was no progress towards disarmament. Now, he will face a humiliating chorus of "we told you so" from Unionist diehards.

Sinn Fein has also been holed below the waterline by the intransigence of the IRA, which threatens to break the republican movement's first tenuous hold on political power. Party leaders have blustered that they have no authority over the paramilitary wing of the movement (an embarrassing admission in itself) and have accused the Unionists of laying down an arbitrary and provocative deadline. The political part of the process, they argue, is not linked to disarmament.

However, the two strands of the Good Friday deal are intimately intertwined, as indeed are Sinn Fein and the IRA. The republican movement stands accused of duplicity not just by unionists, but by the mainstream nationalist Social Democratic and Labour Party. Seamus Mallon, SDLP leader and deputy First Minister, today urged the republicans to deliver on their promises. "You have a responsibility to jump as well," he told them.

Trimble is clinging to the hope that neither his resignation, nor the suspension of devolution, will fatally wound the overall peace process. "If the worst comes to the worst this week, and the institutions go into temporary abeyance, the (Good Friday) agreement hasn't gone," he claimed.

But the IRA has said repeatedly that if without power sharing and other political moves - notably the formation of all-Ireland political bodies and a radical reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary - there will be no disarmament. The wider peace process took seven years to inch its way, falteringly and painfully, to the power-sharing deal brokered in December by US Senator George Mitchell. Now it has come to a dead stop, and the deadly danger is that it might start to reverse.

webTitle: Europe issues Haider ultimatum to Austria

fields.headline: Europe issues Haider ultimatum to Austria
fields.trailText: European Union members entered uncharted political waters last night by threatening to boycott Austria if Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party joins a new government.
fields.body:
European Union members entered uncharted political waters last night by threatening to boycott Austria if Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party joins a new government.

Portugal, the current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, issued an unprecedented statement saying that all member states, with the obvious exception of Austria, would refuse all bilateral contacts with Vienna if that happened.

Risking charges of interfering in the internal affairs of a member state, the 14 acted outside the EU, which has no constitutional mechanism for issuing such threats - though it could, theoretically, act later.

The members also served notice they they would not back any Austrian candidate seeking a position with an international organisation and that Austrian ambassadors would only be received in EU capitals "at a technical level".

In a move reflecting deep concern across Europe about legitimising the sort of extremism espoused by Mr Haider, Portugal said it had told Austria "there would be no business as usual" in bilateral relations with a government that included the Freedom party.

"If a party which has expressed xenophobic views, and which does not abide by the essential values of the European family, comes to power, naturally we won't be able to continue the same relations as in the past, however much we regret it," said the Portuguese prime minister, Antonio Guterres. "Nothing will be as before."

The move was designed to exert maximum pressure on Austria's foreign minister, the conservative People's party leader, Wolfgang Schüssel, who is negotiating with Mr Haider on forming a coalition government.

Mr Guterres said he had expressed the fears of EU members to other Austrian political leaders.

"I hope [Haider's participation] can be avoided," he said.

Alarm has been rising in EU capitals over the past few days. Austria was the main point of discussion when the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, met his French, German and Italian colleagues last Thursday for what should have been a meeting about the Balkans.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, backed the EU's drive to signal its dismay at a right-wing extremist joining a coalition in Vienna that would "have a bearing on discussions in the EU".

Downing Street hopes to steer the coalition negotiations away from Mr Haider and his party. Though the EU 14 have no collective ability to intervene, they are coordinating their responses.

"In the end, the domestic political situation is for the Austrians to resolve," Mr Blair's spokesman said, but Mr Haider's views could not be ignored, as they "offended" the EU's "system of principles".

Momentum for action began building at the end of last week and Belgium's foreign minister, Louis Michel, exchanged abuse with Mr Haider over the weekend.

Mr Michel said yesterday that the Freedom party leader was a "dangerous man". "Europe must know that if Haider gains a place in government the extreme right will cease to be something out of the ordinary. That would be a very serious precedent," he told Le Soir newspaper.

Hubert Vedrine, the French foreign minister, warned that Franco-Austrian relations faced a "difficult phase" if the Freedom party joined a ruling coalition, adding that he found the movement's political platform "repugnant".

"Europe is no longer in the 1930s. It has mechanisms which allow a state to be suspended [from the EU] if found guilty of constant, serious human rights violations - but we are still far from any such situation," Mr Vedrine told France-Inter radio.

"What we want is for them to give up [bringing the Freedom party into government]. But if they don't, then Austria will be under surveillance as no country has ever been in the European Union."

Under the EU's 1997 Amsterdam treaty, a member state can be suspended if heads of government decide that it is in "serious and persistent breach" of the principles of liberty, democracy, respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law.

But under the bilateral moves threatened yesterday, Austria could continue to take part in all official EU events.

Austrian leaders were said last night to be stunned by the move, which came amid continuing negotiations in Vienna over the formation of a new government led by the People's party.

Mr Haider said last night that the EU was showing a lack of respect for democracy.

"I am somewhat appalled at the lack of seriousness with which people take democracy in a country like Austria which has made a clear electoral choice," he told ORF television, adding that Austria should not bow to the pressure.

fields.headline: Austria called to account
fields.standfirst: Haider's advance is an affront to all
fields.trailText: Austria's mission statement on its current, year-long chairmanship of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe lays great stress on the importance of promoting human rights in less enlightened parts of the continent. Quite how this noble commitment will be squared with the anti-foreigner, anti-immigrant policies fervently espoused at home by Jörg Haider is merely one of many embarrassing and massively damaging questions which the Austrian people cannot dodge for much longer.
fields.body:
Austria's mission statement on its current, year-long chairmanship of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe lays great stress on the importance of promoting human rights in less enlightened parts of the continent. Quite how this noble commitment will be squared with the anti-foreigner, anti-immigrant policies fervently espoused at home by Jörg Haider is merely one of many embarrassing and massively damaging questions which the Austrian people cannot dodge for much longer. For the prospect that Mr Haider's Freedom party, an ugly coalition of neo-Nazis, chauvinists, xenophobes, anti-semites, petit-bourgeois nationalists and protest voters, will help form the next Austrian government grows ineluctably.

For this sorry state of affairs, many are to blame. Chancellor Viktor Klima, whose Social Democrats won the most parliamentary seats in last October's general elections, has given up his attempt to form a minority government. He told President Thomas Klestil last week that it would be "irresponsible" to persist. On the contrary, given the alternative, it was irresponsible to chuck in the towel. Wolfgang Schüssel, leader of the conservative People's party, vowed not to return to government after coming a close third last autumn. Now he is leading the negotiations with Mr Haider. "Schüssel is apparently prepared to pay any price so that he can become chancellor," snarled Rudolf Edlinger, the Social Democrat finance minister. Fingers may be pointed in other directions, too - at the too-cosy, two-party consensus which has dominated Austria since the Allies withdrew and the 1955 state treaty came into force; at endemic patronage and croneyism; and, as in neighbouring Germany, at a compliant press which failed in its duty to keep politicians up to the mark. But in the end, it is the Austrian electorate which must bear prime responsibility for tolerating and encouraging Mr Haider's rise and rise, from 5% public support in 1986 to 27% last October.

Even if the misnamed Freedom party takes office with the conservatives, Mr Haider says he himself will stay outside the cabinet. Yet the damage his proximity to power can do has already been demonstrated. Furious rows have erupted with France and Belgium, which expressed concern and were told by Mr Haider to mind their own business; Israel has threatened to break off relations; and the EU, which Austria joined in 1995, has agreed punitive, pre-emptive measures. If Mr Haider gets the nod, Austria will plunge into a period of ostracism and isolation rendering Kurt Waldheim's presidency unremarkable by comparison. The penalties for this flouting of international opinion will range from official and diplomatic boycotts to costly problems for its lucrative tourism, conference and holiday sector. Two-thirds of Austria's foreign trade is with Europe; in these interconnected days to say Europe should have no say in its affairs is the politics of winter wonderland.

President Klestil can yet head off this calamity, even if the politicians cannot. Under article 29 of the 1920 federal constitution, he can annul last October's results and call a fresh election. Over 70% of Austrians did not support the Freedom party last time around. And those who did, now more fully aware perhaps of the awful consequences for their country if Mr Haider advances, should also be given the chance to think again, and think very hard. Whatever the system's failings, Mr Haider's brand of hate has no place in the councils of Europe. It disfigures Austria. It besmirches its citizens. His is the patriotism of the bierkeller.

webTitle: Teachers in line for above-inflation pay rise

fields.headline: Teachers in line for above-inflation pay rise
fields.trailText: Teachers in England and Wales are to receive an annual pay rise of 3.3% from April, the government said today.
fields.body:
Teachers in England and Wales are to receive an annual pay rise of 3.3% from April, the government said today.

Education secretary David Blunkett accepted a recommendation from the School Teachers' Review Body (STRB), which also endorsed controversial proposals for performance-related pay (PRP) for teachers.

Under this plan, "good" teachers who satisfy a set of criteria - still being drafted, but certain to include targets for their children's progress - will receive an extra £2,000 and access a new pay scale, up to a maximum £30,000.

Mr Blunkett said the annual rise was "a good settlement for teachers - well above inflation and not staged". He dismissed claims by local education authorities that they will not be able to afford it.

"The cost will be £420m in England and Wales. This will be affordable within the resources available to local authorities," he said.

The "performance-related promotion" scheme, due to operate from September, was a "something for something" deal which would be "challenging but fair", Mr Blunkett added.

The government has set aside £1bn over two years to pay for the scheme, which ministers have said will guarantee rises for the majority of eligible teachers.

Mr Blunkett said: "I want to see as many teachers benefitting from our reforms as soon as possible. I plan to make application packs available by the end of March for teachers who want to be assessed for the new upper pay range.

"This will ensure that good teachers who want to stay in the classroom, helping to raise standards, will be able to earn at least £2,000 more."

However, Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said the criteria for accessing the higher pay were still being drafted amidst "fierce controversy".

"From the confidential drafts I have seen, I fear the criteria, besides retaining the controversial and deeply unpopular payment by results, also threaten to turn the whole process into a bureaucratic bullshitters charter."

Mr de Gruchy added that while the annual pay rise beat inflation, it still fell below the average earnings rise "and so takes teaching down a further notch or two in the salaries league table".

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "Although higher than inflation, this leaves teachers worse off relative to other groups. This minimal increase offers no hope of overcoming the recruitment crisis and leaves existing teachers underpaid, under-valued and overwhelmed by their ever-increasing workload and the excessive demands of government."

Mr McAvoy accused the STRB of "collaborating" in imposing on teachers a "divisive system of payment by results". He predicted: "Teacher will challenge teacher over who has been ... responsible for pupils' achievement."

He added that the promise of higher salaries through PRP was a "deception" and that not all would benefit.

fields.headline: Who is Jack Straw?
fields.standfirst: Guardian home affairs editor Alan Travis (below) on the man with the one heavyweight cabinet job which breaks far more politicians than it makes
fields.trailText: Guardian home affairs editor Alan Travis (left) on the man with the one heavyweight cabinet job which breaks far more politicians than it makes.
fields.body:
As the home secretary, Jack Straw occupies the one heavyweight job in the Cabinet which breaks far more politicians than it makes. Most home secretaries last only a couple of years at most in the job as they are worn down by the repeated, but unpredictable, volcanic eruptions that constantly threaten to engulf them. Few go on to greater things.

Compared with his predecessor Michael Howard, Mr Straw enjoyed a relatively trouble free first 18 months in the job. There were none of the escapes of IRA prisoners or armed robbers from maximum security jails or high level sackings of prisons directors that troubled his Tory predecessor. His actions have yet to provoke the entire legal establishment, the police and the rest of the criminal justice system into open revolt against him. "He hasn't really been tested," said senior Whitehall civil servants when asked how they thought Straw was getting on.

Well, if that was the case, then the new year has certainly finally put Straw through the mill. His decisions to send Pinochet back to Chile, to allow Mike Tyson into Britain despite his rape convictions, to deport a Nazi war criminal and the big battles with the house of lords over his plans to restrict the right to jury trial and extend the race relations laws all combined to give him his toughest time yet. Jack Straw has had to put into practice Labour's famous 'tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime' catchphrase first developed in opposition by Tony Blair when he was the shadow home secretary.

The authoritarian edge to his 'crusade against crime' - whether in developing child curfews, anti-social behaviour orders, or pressing ahead with child jails and private prisons - has infuriated his critics on what he attacks as the 'liberal left'. He claims that the 'Hampstead liberals' he vilifies for attacking his Daily Mail knee-jerk response to law and order have no interest in protecting the civil rights of those who are victims of the burglars and vandals on Britain's worst run-down inner city estates. Although crime is once again going up his approach has left his personal popularity ratings above even those of Tony Blair.

He has thrived on the pressure: "I have no complaints at all. I sleep well. I eat well and I go to the gym regularly," he replied when he was asked if he wasn't having a hard time.

Yet at times it seems this ex-Islington councillor and former 1960s radical student leader who still makes jokes about 'dialectical materialism' has a love-hate relationship with those he claims to despise. He will often say that his proudest achievement to date is the incorporation of the European Convention of Human Rights into British law, which will spark a civil liberties revolution in our courts later this year. His record on racism, particularly in ordering the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, and ensuring that Whitehall and the police confront the racism in their ranks has been applauded even by his critics.

But his now famous lack of generosity in his approach to freedom of information, to trial by jury, and in the treatment of asylum seekers, as well as his tough policy on drugs have all angered his Labour and Liberal critics. Unlike many of his cabinet colleagues though, Jack Straw rarely shrinks from taking on his critics in open debate. Whether it is his regular spots on his soapbox outside Marks and Spencer's in his Blackburn constituency or on the Guardian Unlimited network, you can expect a straight answer however direct the question.

webTitle: Belgium to challenge ruling as judge rejects right to see Pinochet report appeal

fields.headline: Belgium to challenge ruling as judge rejects right to see Pinochet report appeal
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Augusto Pinochet's 15-month enforced exile in Britain could last for at least another week after the Belgian government yesterday appealed against a ruling which rejected an application to force the release of the general's medical reports.
fields.body:
Augusto Pinochet's 15-month enforced exile in Britain could last for at least another week after the Belgian government yesterday appealed against a ruling which rejected an application to force the release of the general's medical reports.

The Belgian authorities and six human rights groups had been refused leave to seek judicial review of the home secretary's decision on the medical reports, by a judge who dismissed the argument that Jack Straw had acted "unlawfully, unfairly or irrationally".

But Belgium has now announced it intends to renew its legal challenge before a panel of two or three judges, and yesterday afternoon lodged papers with the crown office. The hearing will take place on Monday.

Mr Straw has undertaken not to make a decision on the case before tomorrow. Yesterday a home office spokeswoman said that in general terms it was "unlikely" he would make a decision while the matter was still before the courts.

However, lawyers for Belgium indicated that they would be prepared if necessary to seek an emergency order to prevent Mr Straw from sending the former dictator of Chile home before Monday's appeal hearing.

In a 37-page ruling Mr Justice Maurice Kay rejected arguments proposed by lawyers for the Belgian authorities and the human rights groups that Mr Straw should have released the medical reports that led him to announce he was "minded" to halt extradition proceedings against the general.

"In my judgment, neither Amnesty International and the other human rights groups, nor Belgium, have arguable grounds for judicial review and accordingly I shall refuse both applications," the judge said. "I do so after careful consideration, conscious that my decision is unavoidably adverse to, on the one hand, people who have suffered greatly in Chile's recent history and, in the case of Belgium, to a friendly state and its judicial authorities."

In a damning rebuke of the human rights organisations, Mr Justice Kay described their suggestion that the home secretary should refuse to consider releasing Pinochet until he agreed to undergo further medical tests, as "utterly without merit" and a "surprising" argument to come from human rights groups.

Having concluded that the groups did not have a case to demand access to the reports, they could not seek leave for a judicial review. "In legal, if somewhat peremptory terms, it is none of their business," he said.

The judge said that in his view Belgium was in no stronger position to challenge the non-disclosure of the reports than the human rights groups. He also expressed grave doubts as to whether the Belgian extradition request contained extraditable crimes.

After the hearing Amnesty International said the "fairness and transparency" of the procedure followed by Mr Straw to assess Pinochet's mental condition remained in doubt. Last night the human rights group said it was still considering its legal options over whether or not to appeal.

fields.headline: This calls for a celebration!
fields.trailText: Who knows who suggested it to him? Perhaps it was his wife, his mother or even the person who sorts out those 'ironic' McDonalds adverts. Whatever, Alan Shearer shocked the world last night by coming up with not one but two new goal celebrations.
fields.body:
Who knows who suggested it to him? Perhaps it was his wife, his mother or even the person who sorts out those 'ironic' McDonalds adverts. Whatever, Alan Shearer shocked the world last night by coming up with not one but two new goal celebrations.

The first, after he had fired the ball from just inside the area under a flailing Alan Kelly, was a Saturday Night Fever style-number - right arm folded across the body, left arm pointing up to some imaginary glitterball in the sky. The second, following a simple tap-in from a pin-point Didier Domi cross, was an enactment of the Jurgen Klinsmann divebomber routine - carried out with all the customary Shearer panache.

You could tell from the smile on the England captain's face that he was enjoying himself. And why not? But Football Unlimited want you to make him even happier - by coming up with some more celebrations for Shearer. They can be in words or pictures or even animations. Send your imaginative routines to the.boss@theguardian.com and the best will win a copy of the chart-topping LMA Manager for the PlayStation.

fields.headline: Uncomfortable truth
fields.standfirst: Celia Rees' Truth Or Dare is a compelling examination of the wreckage resulting from a determination to force conformity on an individual.
fields.trailText: Celia Rees' Truth Or Dare is a compelling examination of the wreckage resulting from a determination to force conformity on an individual.
fields.body:
Truth or Dare
By Celia Rees
Published by Macmillan
Price £9.99
Age 10+

Joshua has been given no choice but to accompany his mother to visit his grandmother following her stroke. The holiday ahead looks bleak, and even bleaker when he discovers how ill his grandmother is.

Her eventual death and its aftermath lead Josh and his mother on separate searches to make sense of the facts at their disposal. The focus of the unease is the fate of Josh's uncle, Patrick, whose name generates such tension amongst his surviving family. In threading the narrative strands together, Rees recounts a terrible human tragedy - the denial of a child to the extent that his death is faked. For various reasons this has taken a terrible toll on those left in ignorance.

Patrick did not die. It was simply not convenient, in his father's eyes, for him to live. A difficult child - and the implication is that Asberger's Syndrome caused the dislocation with his surroundings - he was institutionalised for years, before being rehabilitated by someone who recognised in him an extraordinary, creative talent.

This is a compelling examination of the wreckage resulting from a determination to force conformity on an individual.

fields.headline: Commission plays down Haider split
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: Haider's far-right Freedom party
fields.trailText: The European Commission declared "business as usual" with Austria today in the wake of 14 member countries threatening to sever diplomatic ties with the country if Jorg Haider's far-right Freedom party forms part of a new government.
fields.body:
The European Commission declared "business as usual" with Austria today in the wake of 14 member countries threatening to sever diplomatic ties with the country if Jorg Haider's far-right Freedom party forms part of a new government.

Commission president Mr Prodi said they shared the concerns of 14 member states who have threatened to refuse all bilateral contacts with Vienna if Mr Haider becomes part of a coalition government in Austria.

But Mr Prodi made it clear that until and unless the Freedom party gains power and acts in some way to undermine freedom and democracy in Europe, the commission will not take a stand.

"At this stage the working of the European Union is not affected," said Mr Prodi. "In this context the commission, in close contact with EU governments, will follow the situation closely, maintaining its own working relations with the Austrian authorities."

The threat of the 14 to break diplomatic and political ties with their own EU partner was designed to exert pressure on Austrian politicians not to form a coalition government with Mr Haider, who has praised Hitler's economic policies and won 52 seats in the country's elections four months ago under the slogan 'Austria First'.

Within Austria, there has been shocked reaction to the threats from its EU partners, with commentators describing it as the worst political crisis in decades.

The Austrian opposition leader described the crisis as the "biggest foreign policy debacle" since the end of World War II and called for the resignation of People's Party leader and foreign minister Wolfgang Schuessel, who has invited power-sharing with Mr Haider.

But defence minister Werner Fasslabend said it was unacceptable for foreigners to dictate how Austrians govern themselves and that the country should "in no way bend to pressure from abroad". Other commentators have warned that hostility and scepticism towards the EU will rise within Austria.

Mr Haider won international notoriety about 10 years ago by praising Hitler's "orderly" employment policies and lauding veterans of the murderous Waffen SS as "men of honour". Mr Haider has also spoken out against EU expansion, saying it would threaten jobs in Austria. He has predicted that the new government would impose a nearly complete ban on immigration.

The fact that the 14 acted without consulting the commission first raised concerns today over a serious constitutional split between the member states and the EU executive.

Mr Prodi's spokesman Ricardo Levi said: "The decision of the member states was outside the domain of responsibility of the European commission, so I think it was absolutely proper for the 14 member states to decide by themselves and then make the president of the commission a party to the decision before making it public."

Italy's prime minister Massimo D'Alema was unrepentant. He said: "Europe has certain criteria and values that unite it. If these are thrown into question, Europe has a right to speak its mind."

The Austrian opposition leader described the crisis as the "biggest foreign policy debacle" since the end of World War II and called for the resignation of People's Party leader and foreign minister Wolfgang Schuessel, who has invited power-sharing with Mr Haider. But defence minister Werner Fasslabend said it was unacceptable for foreigners to dictate how Austrians govern themselves and that the country should "in no way bend to pressure from abroad". Other commentators have warned that hostility and scepticism towards the EU will rise within Austria. Mr Haider won international notoriety about 10 years ago by praising Hitler's "orderly" employment policies and lauding veterans of the murderous Waffen SS as "men of honour". Mr Haider has also spoken out against EU expansion, saying it would threaten jobs in Austria. He has predicted that the new government would impose a nearly complete ban on immigration. The fact that the 14 acted without consulting the commission first raised concerns today over a serious constitutional split between the member states and the EU executive. Mr Prodi's spokesman Ricardo Levi said: "The decision of the member states was outside the domain of responsibility of the European commission, so I think it was absolutely proper for the 14 member states to decide by themselves and then make the president of the commission a party to the decision before making it public." Italy's prime minister Massimo D'Alema was unrepentant. He said: "Europe has certain criteria and values that unite it. If these are thrown into question, Europe has a right to speak its mind."

fields.headline: Policing GPs
fields.trailText:
What checks are there on doctors?
Deaths in GPs' surgeries have to be reported to the coroner. Cremation certificates require the signature of a second doctor.
fields.body:
What checks are there on doctors?
Deaths in GPs' surgeries have to be reported to the coroner. Cremation certificates require the signature of a second doctor.

What are the limitations on the current system?
In general, doctors in single-handed practices like Harold Shipman can operate pretty much independently. There are 2,847 single-handed practices in England and Wales. There was no official way the health authority could have known about the high death rate among Shipman's elderly women patients, or that he had stockpiled huge quantities of diamorphine (although they were aware of the high cost of his overall drug budget and met him regularly to discuss that). Doctors do not have to keep records of drugs they obtain from pharmacists and administer directly to patients. They are expected to destroy unused drugs handed over by relatives when a patient dies - but they are not legally required to do so. There is no legal requirement for doctors to notify a coroner in the event of a sudden or unexplained death. Shipman was able to cover his tracks by signing death certificates. When a patient dies at home, there are no automatic checks on the certificate. When the patient is elderly and the cause is convincing, coroners are reluctant to prolong a family's grief by investigating that.

The General Medical Council was not required to tell Shipman's health authority that he had a previous conviction for misusing drugs.

Why did it take so long to catch him?
Shipman was careful to share out requests for other doctors to sign cremation certificates. He had a friendly manner and was trusted by his patients. When alerted by a suspicious GP who was concerned by the number of cremation certificates she was asked to sign, police were slow to act. They failed to check for any criminal record - he was convicted of obtaining drugs by deception and forgery in 1976 - failed to link up with the General Medical Council, and initially failed to discover that Shipman had tampered with computerised records of his patients.

What is being done to improve the system?
Health secretary Alan Milburn is today announcing an inquiry into the deaths. The chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, issued a consultation document in November on a new system of audit and appraisal of doctors. Health authorities would have the power to suspend doctors if it was suspected they could be a danger to their patients. But some doctors fear the restrictions would limit their powers too far.

The government is also suggesting "smart cards" for every health service employer indicating details of their previous record. A commission for health improvement is planning to inspect every GPs' surgery. The West Pennine health authority has suspended its medical adviser, Dr Alan Banks, "to make it easier to investigate past concerns about Shipman".

What further improvements are being suggested?
Angela Woodruff, who alerted the police after her mother was murdered and her will forged, said a second doctor should sign all death certificates after checking medical records.

The West Pennine health authority says GPs should be prevented from writing prescriptions for the terminally ill or take drugs from dead patients. The supply of controlled drugs to GPs should be more carefully monitored. Second doctors asked to sign cremation certificate should check medical notes against the cause of death, check the bodies of patients and when possible speak to relatives to confirm the cause. It says surgery computer systems should be set up to prevent records being backdated and a whistleblowers.

Ian Bogle, the chairman of the British Medical Association said today doctors and coroners should be given computer training to spot unusual trends in records. The BMA wants clearer definitions of the types of deaths which coroners are required to investigate. But it said in a statement: "It is important to acknowledge that it is difficult to conceive of any set of laws or regulations that could have prevented the offences of which Harold Shipman has been convicted."

fields.headline: Don't talk Maloney
fields.standfirst: A new book accuses Martin Maloney of representing the worst aspects of Britart. But  Adrian Searle says the artist's simple style is not simple-minded
fields.trailText: A new book accuses Martin Maloney of representing the worst aspects of Britart. But Adrian Searle says the artist's simple style is not simple-minded
fields.body:
Smart gallery, bright lights, big paintings. The Anthony d'Offay Gallery is hung with portraits of young mums with their babies, someone with a Yorkshire terrier under each arm, a New Zealand women's rugby team and two group portraits of schoolkids. The paintings have titles like We Are Family, Equal Opportunities and Community Association, and they are loosely based on photographs from newspapers and magazines.

They are painted with a rumbustuous panache - or, looked at another way, with a gauche lack of sophistication. One moment you think they are truly terrible, the next you are won over by their high-key colour, their gawky, wonky drawing. The oil paint is slapped and slicked on and pawed about at speed, to overcome the inertia and intractability of the medium. The artist has a problem with ears, eyes, noses and hands; hair seems to be made from marmalade or foam rubber. The dogs look like Gnasher from the Beano.

It must be the paintings of Martin Maloney. When everything is a problem, it begins to turn into a style, and after a while you get used to it. The awkwardness begins to have a kind of emotional tenor and expressiveness. All the figures are painted as individuals; each one is a problem to be resolved. No one is a cipher, and Maloney tries to give his subjects a character, a singular demeanour and poise. Sometimes the results are laughable, but you also find yourself laughing with him.

There's nothing new in this clownish tightrope walk, but it is quite compelling to watch. You want the artist to fail and fall, but at the same time you're even more pleased when he doesn't. Maloney's work may not be saying anything terribly deep, but then watching someone wallowing in profundity can be embarrassing. It isn't given to every writer or artist to be able to articulate the riddle of life.

Maloney gained some notoriety for his Sex Club paintings in Saatchi's New Neurotic Realism show last year, but the big question was not so much their outré subject matter - scenes of fuck-rooms, desolate, anonymous sex and nocturnal escapades in the bushes - as their heroic ineptitude. Maloney's presence here, in the same gallery that sells work by substantial figures such as Gerhard Richter, Joseph Beuys, Rachel Whiteread and, currently in another part of the gallery, Gwen John, isn't just some kind of awful lapse, unlike d'Offay's show last year of sculptor Ron Mueck. Instead, it just feels a little premature. It may even be cynical - but dealers are dealers.

Maloney talks about his work in terms of "an expressive painted language", and a daring to aspire to the "wildness and restraint" of Willem de Kooning and Francis Bacon. He also gives a shout for Jean Edouard Vuillard, Richard Dadd (the Victorian fairy painter), Georg Baselitz, Vasili Kandinsky, Franz Marc and Ian Davenport's poured paintings, as though to name-drop his way into the pantheon. But he also, tellingly, talks about Pedro Almodovar and Alan Bennett, and you sort of know what he's getting at.

The difference is that Maloney's paintings aspire to more than they achieve. Still, at least he isn't worthy in the way so many British painters are, or afflicted with that awful combination of the three Bs - Baselitz, Basquiat and Bullshit. Maloney "joked to a friend that I was painting men I wanted to fuck and girls I wanted to be. The more I paint, the more I am learning about my fantasies and the reality of who I am and who I want to be." At least he'd like to be himself, whoever that is, and the bullshit is worn lightly.

Hype, self-promotion and the market clearly have a lot to do with an artist's visibility, and need to be disentangled from whatever merits the art might have on its own account. Julian Stallabrass's new book, High Art Lite, attempts to unpick the larger social forces at work in the now decade-long enthusiasm for new British art. High Art Lite may at first appear to be an apt description of Maloney's paintings, and indeed his paintings are used as illustrations, and his writings are quoted at some length in the book.

One of the larger questions raised in Stallabrass's book is what, precisely, so much of contemporary, young British art is saying, beyond its appeal to popular culture, its cosying up to advertising, to tabloid and soap culture, and most importantly to Charles Saatchi. "For Martin Maloney," Stallabras says, "who owns up to 'playing with shallowness', making childishly sweet and banal figure paintings, it is not that the work comments on the media, but that the media has made the work and its author what they are."

Stallabrass asks whether "YBA" art is truly popular, and in some way anti-elitist, or in fact plays into the hands of market forces, and buoys up a culture that is more divisive than inclusive on just about every level. Once, he says, he hoped that the public might eventually come to believe in contemporary art.

But I get the feeling he now thinks that, like New Labour's third way, it is all a sham and its popularity over the past 10 years a terrible mistake. Stallabrass, a Marxist, regards the "wallowing in abjection" of certain strands of Britart, such as the work of Richard Billingham, as a cynical exploitation of the "lumpen underclass". Maloney, on the other hand, regards his own paintings as "enjoying the ordinariness of people". "In culture, the working-class single mother is usually seen as a victim plagued with social problems. I wanted to paint the opposite of that," he says of one of the new works.

Stallabrass seems alienated from the labour of his fellow workers. His problem, as a critic and an analyst, is that, like many Courtauld Institute-trained art historians, he's curiously disengaged when it comes to discussing the things artists actually make. He comes on like an auditor, balancing the books between the artist's stated intentions and the things they produce, which he tends to read as documents. There's a deadness about his expositions that makes me wonder whether he actually likes art. But no - he's far too serious to like things, and is more interested in "taking on the art world as a whole, showing how it is thoroughly entangled with the society, its economy and politics". This is laudable, but I think that's what he'd like artists to do too.

Stallabrass wants us to smell the whiff of corruption. The book drags along, even when he has good points to make, and leans too heavily on secondary sources and quotations (another trait of the historian), rather than returning to the things artists make and do. Most of the artists he does seem to approve of - Michael Landy, Tomoko Takahashi, Angela Bulloch - are to my mind a trifle dull. But then again, I always thought John Berger frequently got art woefully wrong too, though in other respects he is an inspiring writer. Stallabrass criticises artists for not achieving what they never set out to do in the first place, or for achieving the wrong thing, and this always leads to terrible misjudgments.

Stallabrass's book, with Jake and Dinos Chapman on the pink-edged cover, and a layout that owes a lot to Matthew Collings's Blimey and This Is Modern Art, might be mistaken for yet another breezy commentary on the last decade of hot Britart. But the pop look disguises a dense, somewhat smug and holier-than-thou critique. Stallabrass wants to occupy the high ground. "The artists of the Saatchi collection," he writes, "have finally made a very smooth ride for themselves." Most of the ones who are any good, I believe, are troubled by doubt, and are ambitious for their art. The rest will rightly be forgotten.

Stallabrass says that Maloney's painting "can stand as an emblem for the movement. It looks critical but the teeth of its gears have no purchase and spin in the air." Maloney's paintings might simplify what they engage with, but they're not simple-minded. They reach for affect and want to be filled with life and to communicate a kind of enthusiasm and empathy and humour. This seems to me to be worthwhile, and one of the better reasons to spend all those hours in the studio.

Martin Maloney is at Anthony d'Offay, London W1 (0171-499 4100) till March 11. High Art Lite by Julian Stallabrass is published by Verso at £22.

fields.headline:
No: 1568
 Arthur C Clarke
fields.trailText: Status: The world's best-selling science fiction writer. Author of 2001: A Space Odyssey. He apparently inspired both Star Trek and the satellite revolution.
fields.body:
Status: The world's best-selling science fiction writer. Author of 2001: A Space Odyssey. He apparently inspired both Star Trek and the satellite revolution.

Any other achievements? He's very kindly sponsored the traffic lights in Sri Lanka's capital Colombo, his home for the past 43 years.

Appearance: Like other famous English intellectuals, such as David Beckham, the wheelchair-bound 82 year old enjoys the practicality and avant-garde chic of a sarong.

Does he ever come back to visit old Blighty? On January 1 2001 he will be back in his hometown of Taunton in Somerset to open a futuristic exhibition centre, Arthur C Clarke's World of the Future. The centre, backed by astronaut Buzz Aldrin, will include "interactive visions of the next century".

And what is his vision of the future? A single world time-zone, contact with intelligent life on other planets by 2030 and the secret of immortality by 2090.

Why should we trust him? Well, he's the man who predicted communications satellites, the millennium bug, laptop computers, videophones . . .

How does the great scientific visionary spend his days? Like the rest of us really, responding to emails from "fans, friends and nutters".

Doesn't it get lonely living so far from home? Sticky subject, but it is rumoured that Mr Clarke is a popular character among Sri Lanka's fashionable young chaps.

A real wit then? On reading of a plane crash survivor who had been rescued clutching one of his books, Clarke sent the cutting to his friend and rival sci-fi author Isaac Asimov. "He should have been reading one of yours," he wrote. "Then he could have slept through the whole thing." Not to be outdone, Asimov wrote back: "It should have been one of yours, Arthur. Then, if he had died, it would have been a merciful release."

Do say: "I think Sri Lanka with its civil unrest and terror is a perfectly reasonable place to live."

Don't say: "Are you a genius or just a bloody good guesser?"

fields.headline: Nell' ombra del volcano
fields.trailText: Beginners' Italian
fields.body:
Il 24 agosto del 79 d.C. i venticinquemila abitanti di Pompei videro una nube nera alzarsi sul Vesuvio. Quando la nube collassò, li soffocò senza scampo.

Il Vesuvio, infatti, imprigiona la lava in profondità per anni. Quando il "tappo" di roccia che la chiude cede, il vulcano esplode.

Esplose nuovamente nel 1631 causando 5000 morti.

L'ultima eruzione del secolo, nel 1944, fu meno violenta.

Oggi settecentomila persone vivono alle falde del Vesuvio. La popolazione ha la più alta densità in Europa. Molti hanno dimenticato le tragedie del passato. Ma il 9 ottobre 1999, con un tremore più forte, il Vesuvio ha ricordato a tutti che è un vulcano. Non c'è rischio immediato, dicono gli esperti, ma è necessario organizzarsi.

Luca Monfregola,16 anni, studente di Portici, una cittadina della zona vesuviana, dice: "Le notizie recenti mi mostrano il Vesuvio sotto un'altra faccia. Spero di non vederlo mai in azione".

"Il Vesuvio non mi fa paura", osserva la sua compagna di scuola Tonia Malatesta, "ci convivo, è un po' come il nostro papà, gli siamo affezionati. Vogliamo però essere informati e preparati. A scuola abbiamo fatto prove d'evacuazione".

I vulcanologi controllano il Vesuvio 24 ore su 24. Assicurano che ci saranno segni precursori prima di un'eruzione. La Protezione Civile ha preparato piani d'evacuazione, ma "bisogna lavorare seriamente, investire in scelte finanziarie e politiche, a livello nazionale e soprattutto locale", come dice il Sindaco di Portici, Leopoldo Spedaliere. Il suo comune lavora perché le tragedie del passato non si ripetano.

Glossario/Glossary

convivere to live together
correre un pericolo (coll) to be in danger
le falde (di montagna) the slopes/the foot (of a mountain)
senza scampo with no chance of escaping
sotto un'altra faccia (coll) in a different light
tenere d'occhio (coll) to keep an eye on
un po' come (coll) almost like

Il Vesuvio, infatti, imprigiona la lava in profondità per anni. Quando il "tappo" di roccia che la chiude cede, il vulcano esplode. Esplose nuovamente nel 1631 causando 5000 morti. L'ultima eruzione del secolo, nel 1944, fu meno violenta. Oggi settecentomila persone vivono alle falde del Vesuvio. La popolazione ha la più alta densità in Europa. Molti hanno dimenticato le tragedie del passato. Ma il 9 ottobre 1999, con un tremore più forte, il Vesuvio ha ricordato a tutti che è un vulcano. Non c'è rischio immediato, dicono gli esperti, ma è necessario organizzarsi. Luca Monfregola,16 anni, studente di Portici, una cittadina della zona vesuviana, dice: "Le notizie recenti mi mostrano il Vesuvio sotto un'altra faccia. Spero di non vederlo mai in azione". "Il Vesuvio non mi fa paura", osserva la sua compagna di scuola Tonia Malatesta, "ci convivo, è un po' come il nostro papà, gli siamo affezionati. Vogliamo però essere informati e preparati. A scuola abbiamo fatto prove d'evacuazione". I vulcanologi controllano il Vesuvio 24 ore su 24. Assicurano che ci saranno segni precursori prima di un'eruzione. La Protezione Civile ha preparato piani d'evacuazione, ma "bisogna lavorare seriamente, investire in scelte finanziarie e politiche, a livello nazionale e soprattutto locale", come dice il Sindaco di Portici, Leopoldo Spedaliere. Il suo comune lavora perché le tragedie del passato non si ripetano. Glossario/Glossary convivere to live together correre un pericolo (coll) to be in danger le falde (di montagna) the slopes/the foot (of a mountain) senza scampo with no chance of escaping sotto un'altra faccia (coll) in a different light tenere d'occhio (coll) to keep an eye on un po' come (coll) almost like

fields.headline: Se il Vesuvio esplode
fields.standfirst: The threat of an explosion of Vesuvius has resurfaced with October's tremor. Mariacarla Pavoni talks to the mayor of Portici, in the shadow of the volcano, and local students
fields.trailText: Secondary Italian
fields.body:
Emergenza Vesuvio: che fare? In attesa del Big One alle falde del Vesuvio. La recente scossa di terremoto, con epicentro il Vesuvio, fa riparlare dell'emergenza eruzione.

"Non è un evento anomalo... per parlare d'emergenza occorrono cambiamenti significativi di diversi indicatori fisici e chimici", dichiara Lucia Civetta, direttrice dell'Osservatorio vesuviano che monitorizza il vulcano 24 ore su 24. Tuttavia il tremore ha ricordato alla popolazione che la montagna può fare il botto.

Il Vesuvio, infatti, non uccide con la lava, ma è un vulcano grigio, a rischio d'esplosione, un enorme serbatoio di magma ostruito da un tappo di roccia. Dall'ultima eruzione del 1944 il magma si è addensato: tanto più lungo sarà il periodo di riposo, tanto più violenta l'esplosione. I due Big Ones del Vesuvio risalgono al 79 d.C., quando il vulcano distrusse Ercolano e Pompei e, dopo una calma di cinquecento anni, al 1631.

Oggi ben 18 comuni circondano il vulcano. Seicentomila abitanti vivono in una fascia costiera con la maggior densità in Europa. L'abusivismo edilizio è diffuso. Questa è la vera emergenza.

Cosa significa vivere sotto il Vesuvio? Lo chiediamo al Sindaco di Portici, una delle città in cui si lavora attivamente alla prevenzione e alla protezione civile, e agli studenti del locale Liceo Scientifico.

Esiste oggi un'emergenza Vesuvio?

Leopoldo Spedaliere, Sindaco di Portici - Il Vesuvio oggi è come era 50 anni fa, dopo l'eruzione del 1944, quando si spense il folcloristico pennacchio. In geologia 50 anni sono un amen, quindi non parlerei d'emergenza immediata. È invece grave quello che è successo in questi anni: la fascia costiera è cresciuta a 700mila abitanti. Sono persone che vivono addossate, tra la montagna e il mare. È un rischio quotidiano. L'ipotesi coraggiosa che bisognerebbe quindi fare è limitare drasticamente la popolazione agli addetti ai servizi dei musei, degli alberghi, degli stabilimenti balneari e nel solo orario di lavoro. Verrà l'eruzione? Perderemo strutture e vestigia del passato. Sarà grave, ma non avremo morti.

Come vi state attrezzando?

Leopoldo Spedaliere - Ecco il problema vero: dei 18 comuni dell'area vesuviana solo 6 hanno il piano d'evacuazione, fra cui Portici. Qui abbiamo anche una struttura di Protezione Civile, in cui facciamo formazione, programmiamo, ci organizziamo. È presidiata 24 ore su 24 e in contatto con l'Osservatorio. I precedenti ci dicono che un'eruzione del Vesuvio avrà una serie di precursori e potremo quindi essere informati, nella peggiore delle ipotesi, quindici giorni prima dell'evento. A Portici abbiamo un piano che prevede l'evacuazione in 5 giorni, o anche solo 3, ma come faremo se le città attorno sono prive di un piano?

Qual è il vostro raporto con il Vesuvio

Ciro Dentale, 17 - Il Vesuvio è una presenza. Le scosse recenti, lo fanno considerare anche un fenomeno. Vorremmo tutti essere informati e sapere come comportarci in caso di pericolo.

Mario Guerriero, 18 - Dopo le scosse di ottobre, a Portici poniamo più attenzione al problema Vesuvio, a come organizzare un'eventuale evacuazione. A scuola studiamo il fenomeno dal punto di vista geologico. Purtroppo esiste una diffusa ignoranza in materia e l'ignoranza causa panico. Bisogna educare la popolazione.

Giuseppe Cozzolino, 15 - Il Vesuvio è un vulcano: non deve essere preso sotto gamba. Gli esperti lo controllano ma se, facendo i dovuti scongiuri, fosse imminente un'eruzione, come dire a 600mila persone che da un momento all'altro non avranno più una casa e un lavoro?

Rosanna Fontana 16 - Non ho paura del Vesuvio. Credo negli esperti e penso che in presenza di segnali premonitori ci avvertiranno; questo mi dà sicurezza.

Siete preparati ad un'evacuazione come cittadini?

Ciro - So dove la popolazione di Portici dovrebbe trasferirsi, però le modalità mi sono ignote. Sono state fatte prove d'evacuazione in altri paesi vesuviani, ma la realtà è una cosa, la finzione un'altra. Temo il fattore panico.

Mario - Faccio parte del gruppo di Protezione Civile di Portici. Il comune ha un piano d'evacuazione, ma ci sono delle difficoltà. Viviamo in una zona ad altissima densità di popolazione. L'arteria di fuga realizzata dopo il 1944 è diventata una strada fiancheggiata da abitazioni. Rimane la ferrovia che ci collegherà con il nord. Il piano d'evacuazione nazionale prevede per ogni comune vesuviano il trasferimento in una regione italiana, per Portici sarà l'Emilia Romagna.

Giuseppe - I miei genitori appartengono alla Protezione Civile quindi sono informato. I piani ci sono, ma renderli possibili è un altro paio di maniche.

Irene Bonadies, 16 - Anche nelle scuole abbiamo fatto prove, ma le strutture non sono adatte. Le difficoltà sorgono anche per le caratteristiche della nostra città: strade strette, edifici senza scale d'emergenza, strutture fatiscenti. Su questo bisogna agire. Regolare la città affinché sia pronta per un eventuale rischio, informare ed educare.

Glossario/Glossary

un altro paio di maniche (coll) quite another matter
un amen (coll) a very short period
l'abusivismo edilizio unauthorised building
l'arteria di fuga /B>escape road
il botto (regional) explosion/firework
il comune municipal district
da un momento all'altro at any moment
fare gli scongiuri (coll) touch wood
il pennacchio plume of smoke
prendere sotto gamba (coll) to underestimate

fields.headline: The best Who scene
fields.standfirst: Summer of Sam
fields.trailText: The Bronx, 1977. Richie (Adrien Brody) plugs in his new Fender, then drops the needle of his stereo on to The Who's Baba O'Riley. As the synth-driven intro begins, we cut to a couple making out in a car. Out of the darkness a figure fires two shots through the passenger window.
fields.body:
The Bronx, 1977. Richie (Adrien Brody) plugs in his new Fender, then drops the needle of his stereo on to The Who's Baba O'Riley. As the synth-driven intro begins, we cut to a couple making out in a car. Out of the darkness a figure fires two shots through the passenger window.

Keith Moon's drums kick in; cut back to Richie, dancing in his room. Cut to the car's driver, falling bloody from his seat.

" Out here in the fields ..."

Cut to Richie, dancing at a gay strip joint. Cut to a newsreader, sombrely explaining that: "The .44 calibre killer who calls himself Son of Sam struck again last night ..."

Cut to Richie in a guitar store, clasping hands with the owner. Cut to Richie at the strip joint, leading a middle-aged man into a private room.

" Teenage wasteland / It's only teenage wasteland. "

Now a series of faster cuts as the song builds to its climax: Richie in his room, his arm twirling in imitation of Pete Townshend; neighbourhood junkie Woodstock, fixing up; small-time mobster Joey T, his eyes rolling from too many Qualuudes; Richie and his friend Vinny at Yankee Stadium; Vinny kneeling in church; David Berkowitz sobbing in his apartment; punks dancing at CBGBs; the audience at the strip joint giving Richie a wild round of applause; and, finally, a single bead of sweat running down Richie's forehead.

See also: Quadrophenia, Jerry Maguire, The Kids Are Alright

Don't see: Tommy

Pointless trivia: In the last year, The Who have also featured on the soundtracks of Rushmore, The Limey and Bringing Out The Dead.
