webTitle: Hall keeps his nerve for Gauteng

fields.headline: Hall keeps his nerve for Gauteng
fields.trailText: South Africa
fields.body:
South Africa

Fast bowler Andrew Hall shone with the bat as Gauteng triumphed in the five-day final of the SuperSport Series against Border at Johannesburg. Set 182 to win in the fourth innings, Gauteng stumbled to 112 for 7, but Hall clubbed 57* from 71 balls, with eight fours and two sixes, to guide them home by three wickets. Hall had earlier claimed 5-67 as Border began the game with a healthy 346, having recovered from 205 for 8 thanks to 81 from No.10 Tyron Henderson and 34* from last man Makhaya Ntini; they were also indebted to 88 from Pieter Strydom, fresh from his Test debut at Centurion. Gauteng replied with 387, with 120 for Daryll Cullinan and 79 from ex-New Zealand captain Ken Rutherford, and Kenny Benjamin then claimed 6-48 (for match figures of 10-150) in Border's second innings of 222, which included 112 from Mark Boucher. Vasbert Drakes picked up three quick wickets to shake Gauteng and move past 60 for the season and set a new South African domestic record, before Hall turned the final innings on its head.

Border 346 (Benjamin 4-102) and 222
Gauteng 387 and 182 for 7
Gauteng won by seven wickets

India

A swashbuckling 106 from just 87 balls by opener Vikram Rathour helped North Zone win the limited-overs Deodhar Trophy by pipping opponents South Zone to first place in the table. Rathour, who hit 19 fours, helped North make light work of South's total of 278 for 8, in which Sridharan Sharath hit 104.

South Zone 278 for 8 in 50 overs
North Zone 279 for 3 in 44.4 overs (Ajay Jadeja 60*)
North Zone won by seven wickets

Earlier in the competition, North had been beaten by Central Zone at Poona, as Gagan Khoda made 71. South Zone were inspired by a whirlwind 148* off just 147 deliveries by Arun Kumar at Ahmedabad in the eight-wicket win over East Zone, for whom Rashmi Parida made 106*. Sridharan Sharath then scored 113 to steer South to a more nerve-wracking two-wicket victory against Central Zone in Mumbai.

North Zone 237 for 8 in 50 overs (Mithun Minhas 72)
Central Zone 241 for 7 in 47.5 overs (Robin Singh jnr 4-45)
Central Zone won by three wickets

East Zone 275 for 7 in 50 overs
South Zone 276 for 2 in 44.5 overs
South Zone won by eight wickets

Central Zone 272 for 4 in 50 overs (Jyoti Yadav 76, Gagan Khoda 69)
South Zone 276 for 8 in 49.4 overs (Mohammad Azharuddin 64)
South Zone won by two wickets

In the other games, Abhijit Kale made 68* as West Zone successfully chased 208 to beat Central in Mumbai, and 98 from wicketkeeper Syed Karim helped East overhaul West, despite 100 from opener Shitanshu Kotak.

Central Zone 207 for 8 in 50 overs (Devendra Bundela 78*)
West Zone 211 for 5 in 50 overs
West Zone won by five wickets

West Zone 262 for 7 in 50 overs (Vinod Kambli 82)
East Zone 263 for 6 in 48.2 overs (Nikhil Haldipur 67)
East Zone won by four wickets

Australia

A fine allround performance from Michael Kasprowicz helped Queensland overcome Victoria in the top-of-the-table Pura Milk Cup clash at Melbourne by nine wickets. Kasprowicz began by taking 4-49 as Victoria struggled to 222, and then hit 50 in an eighth-wicket partnership of 118 with wicketkeeper Wade Seccombe, who made a career-best 151, in Queensland's reply of 455. He followed this with 4-65 in the second-innings as Victoria folded from 140 for 1 to 266 all out, despite 88 from Matthew Elliott. Queensland knocked off the runs with ease, and opened up a six-point gap over Victoria in second place.

Victoria 222 (Jason Arnberger 81, Ashley Noffke 4-46) and 266
Queensland 455 (Matthew Hayden 83) and 37 for 1
Queensland won by nine wickets

A double-century from Somerset captain Jamie Cox condemned New South Wales to yet another defeat, this time by Tasmania at Hobart. Cox made 245, and shared in a second-wicket stand of 294 with Michael Di Venuto, who struck 136, as Tasmania ran up 510 for 5 declared. That was in reply to NSW's first-innings 84, in which seamer Mark Ridgway claimed 6-38, and Colin Miller, opening the bowling, 4-24. NSW fared better in their second innings, with centuries from Corey Richards (111) and Matthew Phelps (192), but collapsed from 440 for 3 to 496 all out. Tasmania raced to victory and moved ahead of Western Australia in fourth. NSW, for whom Stuart MacGill nursed match figures of 41-8-166-2, remained rooted to the bottom, with just one win.

New South Wales 84 and 496 (Michael Clarke 73)
Tasmania 510 for 5 declared and 74 for 0
Tasmania won by 10 wickets

Darren Lehmann set South Australia on the road to a comfortable win over Canberra in the week's only game in the one-day Mercantile Mutual Cup at the Manuka Oval, Canberra. Lehmann made 83*, and added a crucial unbeaten 64 for the eighth wicket with Brett Swain (35*). Canberra were dismissed for 186 in reply, with opener Anthony McQuire offering the only real resistance. SA moved second, one point behind WA, and ahead of NSW on run-rate. Canberra are yet to win a game.

South Australia 226 for 7 in 50 overs
Canberra 186 in 47 overs (Paul Wilson 4-23, Peter MacIntyre 4-39)
South Australia won by 40 runs

New Zealand

A remarkable spell of bowling from Adams helped set up a one-wicket win for Auckland over Northern Districts in the semi-final of the Shell Cup. Adams took 5-7 from 6 overs as ND were dismissed for 150, having reached 73 for 1. But Auckland almost made a hash of things themselves, collapsing to 129 for 9 with 19 balls remaining, before Dion Nash kept his head and steered them home with 44*, the winning runs coming off the final ball of the innings.

Northern Districts 150 in 36.2 overs
Auckland 151 for 9 in 50 overs (Daniel Vettori 3-24)
Auckland won by one wicket

Auckland's opponents in the best-of-three final will be Canterbury, who beat them at Eden Park in the final round of group matches to finish top of the league and thus qualify automatically for the final. Victory for Auckland would have meant automatic qualification as well, but Canterbury triumphed by four wickets.

Auckland 208 for 8 in 50 overs (AC Barnes 76, Dion Nash 53*, Anderson 4-33)
Canterbury 212 for 6 in 49.1 overs
Canterbury won by four wickets

Scott Styris blew away Central Districts as they were thrashed by Northern Districts at Palmerston. He followed an innings of 50 with figures of 3-25 as ND claimed the second semi-final place, finishing third in the table. In the other game, Otago bowled out Wellington for 78 to deny them the chance of pipping ND to third.

Northern Districts 207 for 8 in 50 overs
Central Districts 105 in 42.5 overs (Daryl Tuffey 3-11, Simon Doull 2-7)
Northern Districts won by 102 runs

Otago 134 for 7 in 34 overs (Mark Richardson 67*)
Wellington 79 in 28 overs
Otago won by 54 runs (D/L method)

Pakistan

A massive 240 from former Test player Asif Mujtaba was the basis of Pakistan International Airlines' innings thrashing of Lahore Division Cricket Association at the Sheikhupura Stadium in the Quaid-e-Azam Trophy. Helped by 163 from Shoaib Muhammad, Mujtaba allowed PIA to declare on 550 for 4, before their bowlers dismissed LDCA twice for less than 250. PIA moved up to fourth in Pool A.

PIA 550 for 4 declared
LDCA 238 (Maqsood Raza 65*, Nadeem Khan 5-78) and 231
PIA won by an innings and 81 runs

Twin centuries from Younis Khan set up Habib Bank Limited's 125-run victory over hosts Peshawar. Khan followed a first-innings 132, during which he added 195 for the third wicket with Moin-ul-Atiq (91), with 142*, including a fourth-wicket stand of 170* with Farhan Adil (58*). Akram Raza took 6-83 in Peshawar's first innings.

HBL 339 and 268 for 3 declared
Peshawar 276 and 206 (Yasir Hameed 88)
HBL won by 125 runs

Sarfaraz Ahmed had a match analysis of 10-92 as Water and Power Development Authority crushed Pakistan National Shipping Corporation by ten wickets in Karachi. After WAPDA had run up 378, Sarfaraz took 7-50 as PNSC struggled to 138, and then 3-42 in a second-innings total of 254.

WAPDA 378 (Adil Nisar 82, Hassan Adnan 81, Iqbal Imam 5-76) and 15 for 0
PNSC 138 and 254 (Muhammad Ramzan 108, Farhan Rasheed 5-90)
WAPDA won by ten wickets

Nine wickets for Imranullah were enough for Karachi Blues to see off Sargodha Division Cricket Association. The other six games in the competition were all drawn.

SDCA 138 (Ahmed Hayat 64, Imranullah 5-54) and 175 (Imranullah 4-54)
Karachi Blues 249 (Tanvir Ahmed 55) and 65 for 2
Karachi Blues won by eight wickets

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: England's women go the way of the men Down Under

fields.headline: England's women go the way of the men Down Under
fields.trailText: Don't go to page 347 of Ceefax today - unless you have a sturdy constitution or swagman roots. The scoreboard of the third ODI between England Women and Australia Women is displayed, and it is horrible. England all out for 106 in 24.5 overs, Australia 108-0 in 24.5 overs, with Belinda Clark, feted in Australia's New Year Honours, unbeaten on 66.
fields.body:
Don't go to page 347 of Ceefax today - unless you have a sturdy constitution or swagman roots. The scoreboard of the third ODI between England Women and Australia Women is displayed, and it is horrible. England all out for 106 in 24.5 overs, Australia 108-0 in 24.5 overs, with Belinda Clark, feted in Australia's New Year Honours, unbeaten on 66.

This was England's fifth defeat of the tour in five matches. So far they have lost by five wickets, nine runs, 86 runs, 87 runs and now ten wickets. This is not what was supposed to happen. No-one was expecting England to have an easy time. Australia and New Zealand (who they play later on this month) are the undisputed top two in Women's cricket; England, though not bargain basement, lost at home to India last summer. But English women's cricket, through the absorption of the WCA by the ECB, is better funded than ever before. The coaches are more specialist, the training more vigorous, and though the players aren't paid thousands of pounds, they do at least now get their expenses paid. And they are having to take a more professional approach to the game. Sue Redfern was dropped from the squad in November when she failed to reach the required fitness levels. England were expected to go to Australia and at least perform.

But, not yet two weeks into the tour, England have already lost the five-match series against Australia. Paul Farbrace, England coach and a genuinely genial, nice bloke, spoke of England's performance after their second tour game, against the NSW reserve side. "Use whatever words you like, they're playing crap. Graham Dilley and I have done all we can. But there's no more we can do if they won't listen to what we tell them." The words of a desperate man.

Assistant coach Graham Dilley, a survivor of the Can't Bat, Can't Bowl, Can't Field 1986 tour of Australia, was slightly more upbeat before the series began. But even he must be coming to terms with the fact that England's women in 2000 are not quite in the league of Gatting's miracle-workers.

Australia are in a different league. More athletic, more skilled, more weathered - the usual story. But there is one consolation for the English women. That 1986 tour is now widely regarded as the turning point in Australian cricket history - Border's boys went from strength to strength. The all-conquering Englishmen on the other hand have been going downhill ever since.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: High-pressure matches will test the revolution

fields.headline: High-pressure matches will test the revolution
fields.standfirst: The ultimate responsibility for discipline lies with those who play the game
fields.trailText: The ultimate responsibility for discipline lies with those who play the game.
fields.body:
In football, as elsewhere, the peace process is ongoing. The latest attempt to reconcile players and managers with referees is undoubtedly worthy but unless its good intentions survive the realpolitik of the season's run-in, when the struggle to go up, stay up or win Champions League and Uefa Cup places reaches its height, yesterday's meeting will have meant little.

In fact its thunder had already been stolen by the referees themselves, with the annual reining-in of cautions and dismissals. The reality is that soothing words in cosy meeting rooms will count for less if the sort of scene witnessed at Old Trafford on Saturday is accepted as part and parcel of the game.

After Andy D'Urso had awarded Middlesbrough a penalty when Jaap Stam brought down Juninho, the Billericay referee was mobbed by Manchester United players with Roy Keane, the United captain, asking to be sent off for violent conduct.

Certainly Stam, as the last defender, should have gone but maybe D'Urso overlooked this in the confusion. That, after all, is one of the purposes of gang-slanging referees.

A week ago, by contrast, Paul Durkin was widely praised for his sympathetic handling of United's match against Arsenal. This is always a highly-charged occasion but Durkin controlled it in the old-fashioned way, that is to say with a nod, a wink and strong words when necessary. There was only one yellow card.

If this is to be the way of it from now on then all well and good. Even the Premier League's Phil Don (book 'em all, the long and the short and the tall) has said that officials should be allowed to communicate with players and man-manage them.

Should there be an umpteenth refs' revolution, however, it will only work if three conditions are satisfied: a more consistent application of the laws than at present; refereeing which keeps faith with the spirit of Fifa's edicts without becoming a slave to them; and a greater responsibility by players in accepting decisions.

It is 10 years since the cynicism of the 1990 World Cup in Italy persuaded Fifa to appoint a task force, headed by Michel Platini, to come up with ways of making football more acceptable as a spectacle.

Some of the ideas were plain daft - outlawing tackling for example - but the practice of bringing down an attacker just outside the penalty area, the 'professional foul', is far less prevalent, the challenge which takes the man as well as or instead of the ball is on the way out, and a defender risks a caution if he gives an opponent so much as a dirty look from behind.

All this has been accomodated in the laws of the game as they stand. It has simply needed a sensible interpretation to bring football the benefits Fifa was seeking and in many European countries referees have done just that.

England, however, is a nation of jobsworths and in this spirit some officials have racked up the numbers of yellow and red cards to record heights. A point has been reached when teams who rely on strong but fair tackling to break up the superior passing rhythms of sides like Chelsea, United and Arsenal, are discriminated against.

In the mid-90s Fifa tried to make decisions easier for referees by taking the question of intent out of all foul play except handball. Some referees have taken this as a licence to book or send off players for mistimed tackles. If, from now on, they could make a secret pact with themselves to err on the side of leniency, as Durkin did last week, relationships with players and benches would surely improve.

Ultimately, however, the responsibility for the way the game is conducted lies with those who play it. Twice at Highbury this season Graham Poll, the Tring referee, has adopted Durkin's hands-off approach, first when Arsenal met United in August and again when they played Leeds just after Christmas. Initially he kept his cards sheathed but in both instances was forced to bring them out because the players' behaviour deteriorated.

A referee should never need to resort to cards to establish his authority. Those who do quickly lose the respect of the players and whatever authority they might have had.

But a generation of card-carrying refs have been brought up this way and it is going to take more than declarations of intent to get them whistling a different tune.

Bookings

Referees have been too quick to caution the first foul, making themselves a hostage to fortune and exposing matches to unjustified dismissals. Initially a verbal warning should be enough.

Sendings-off

These spoil games for spectators because the team which loses a player usually resorts to defending with eight men. Players should be dismissed for serious foul play or persistent dissent but not for purely technical offences.

Dissent

The rugby 10-yard rule should be applied both for arguing and failing to retreat the proper distance at free-kicks. If this takes the player into the penalty area then so be it, a penalty should be given.

Offside

The return to the original spirit of the offside law, especially regarding players who are not interfering with play, has been a welcome move but the law is still not being applied properly. Witness the first Leeds goal against Aston Villa in Sunday's FA Cup-tie which was allowed to stand despite Harry Kewell walking in front of the goalkeeper from an offside position.

Full-time officials

This might produce fitter referees better able to keep up with the modern game and making them professional could persuade former players to go into the whistling business. But that would not guarantee better refereeing, although the idea of Dennis Wise reaching for his red card is appealing.

Technical aids

By all means have electric eyes in the goalposts to indicate whether or not the ball has crossed the line but spare us video evidence on offsides, which usually leaves a doubt anyway, handballs, fouls and the rest. Football has had enough problems of late with robot referees.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's transfer gossip digested for you
fields.trailText: The Sun George Graham will attempt to sign Roberto Baggio from Internazionale. The Tottenham boss wants to pair the Divine Ponytail with Steffan Iversen and is prepared to offer him £2.1m a year. Graham's bid comes less than a week after Baggio turned down a loan move to Liverpool.
fields.body:
The Sun George Graham will attempt to sign Roberto Baggio from Internazionale. The Tottenham boss wants to pair the Divine Ponytail with Steffan Iversen and is prepared to offer him £2.1m a year. Graham's bid comes less than a week after Baggio turned down a loan move to Liverpool.

Daily Mail Manchester United's Teddy Sheringham is a target for West Ham. The 33-year-old striker has admitted he "hates" his role as Old Trafford super sub, and Harry Redknapp is interested. "Ted is a class act and I've got to be interested in someone of his calibre," said the Hammers manager.

Everton will sign £2m Preston midfielder Sean Gregan if Don Hutchison's contract talks break down. Hutch is stalling on a pay deal and has expressed a desire to play for Newcastle. However, Teamtalk suggests that Walter Smith will bid £1.5m for Arsenal's Stephen Hughes should the Scottish international return to the north-east.

Gianluca Vialli played for the first time this season last night as Chelsea reserves drew 2-2 with Leicester. The Stamford Bridge boss refused to explain his motives for the run-out, which puts the futures of Chris Sutton and Gianfranco Zola in doubt.

Teamtalk Tottenham and Celtic are interested in Manchester United forward Jonathan Greening. United will listen to offers of £2m for the transfer-listed 21-year-old.

Huddersfield's Marcus Stewart has headed to East Anglia for talks with Ipswich, after the two clubs agreed a fee of £3 million.

fields.headline: Cut and thrust
fields.standfirst: Is Ralph's rear in The End Of The Affair a bottom too far?  Veronica Horwell  considers censorship
fields.trailText: Is Ralph's rear in The End Of The Affair a bottom too far? Veronica Horwell considers censorship
fields.body:
Oh, not again! Not another film-maker complaining to the censor how dare he cut/certify as unsuitable for teens a sexual scene, when under-18s are permitted - nope, make that encouraged - to pay six quid to see dismemberments, spewings of gizzards etc. This time the complainant is Stephen Woolley, producer of the adaptation of Grahame Greene's novel The End Of The Affair, disgruntled that the British Board of Film Classification, under its director Robin Duval, has awarded the film an 18 certificate, mostly because, to quote correspondence between Woolley and Duval, "Ralph's [Fiennes] bottom was pumping too many times".

I like that "too many times". That is so much the authentic criterion of the BBFC during its 88 years of invigilating, a very masculine response based on quantification, on mechanics and hydraulics. Not how do we feel about the characters on screen and why they are doing what they are doing, but how many times are they doing it. Upon what count does the Board determine how many is too many? Twenty? Twenty-one? There's an actual number? A stopwatched duration?

The exchange reminds me of the true confessions, published a year ago in the Guardian Friday Review, of Ros Hodgkiss, who censored for the BBFC during the regime of James Ferman, previous Board chief. She described her mad life, rating porn (not just incidental sex in a movie but porn made and sold as such, on the plot-what-plot principle) first thing in the morning, to get it over with so she could move on to the truly repulsive stuff, like Teletubbies or Barney The Dinosaur.

Hodgkiss wrote with such sense about the Board's unspoken demand on its staff: that to do the job it was essential to put aside emotion, personal feelings of arousal or disgust - which were the very feelings "on which notions of taste and decency depend". Board employees, taking their cue from Ferman, used ritual euphemisms (Hodgkiss loathed most the wholly male "Peter meter", calibrating the degree of arousal occasioned by a rape scene) and peculiar professional "measurements" to determine what might be shown, how many ccs of gore are too far o'er in blood for an under-12, what angle of penis makes it a "Harry hard", to be cut immediately (if you'll forgive the verb), rather than a passable "Sid soft".

In the end, Hodgkiss resigned because the Board's resultant judgments, reluctantly arrived at upon a collective pretence of an emotionless basis, "had no relevance to the real world". She believed the Board underestimated the ability of the public - of any age - to watch critically and especially to choose for its families. Toy Story had been passed PG because it was a mite scary, but she knew a three-year-old who could recite every word of it happily and she recalled an eight-year-old who delighted in the vid of The Full Monty, classified 15 for swearing. The families of those kids (my guess is actually their mothers) seemed to have decided that the emotional content of those fab films mattered enough to justify any toybox frights and the language and -well, relatively unthrusting - bare bums of the bloke strippers.

Woolley said this week of The End Of The Affair that "any parent with a 16-year-old would love them to see it" because of the awareness of emotional responsibility that is at the heart of this story of passion. Woolley is making an interestingly female plea for sexual scenes to be judged in an emotional context and crediting under-18s with an ability to respond to that. (My biased guess is that girls would respond and boys, who are not taught by our culture to associate sex with feeling, would not.) Duval the censor replied that the Board's present rules don't permit those under 18 to see simulated sex, but that it was currently consulting movie-goers on its draft revised code, to be made public later this year.

I'd love to know exactly what questions the Board is putting to its consultant movie-goers about what is unacceptable. Is it asking what they find demeaning or dehumanising to their race or sex, or cynically exploitative, especially of the young? Or is it just asking the public to set the future permissible number of thrusts?

Board employees, taking their cue from Ferman, used ritual euphemisms (Hodgkiss loathed most the wholly male "Peter meter", calibrating the degree of arousal occasioned by a rape scene) and peculiar professional "measurements" to determine what might be shown, how many ccs of gore are too far o'er in blood for an under-12, what angle of penis makes it a "Harry hard", to be cut immediately (if you'll forgive the verb), rather than a passable "Sid soft". In the end, Hodgkiss resigned because the Board's resultant judgments, reluctantly arrived at upon a collective pretence of an emotionless basis, "had no relevance to the real world". She believed the Board underestimated the ability of the public - of any age - to watch critically and especially to choose for its families. Toy Story had been passed PG because it was a mite scary, but she knew a three-year-old who could recite every word of it happily and she recalled an eight-year-old who delighted in the vid of The Full Monty, classified 15 for swearing. The families of those kids (my guess is actually their mothers) seemed to have decided that the emotional content of those fab films mattered enough to justify any toybox frights and the language and -well, relatively unthrusting - bare bums of the bloke strippers. Woolley said this week of The End Of The Affair that "any parent with a 16-year-old would love them to see it" because of the awareness of emotional responsibility that is at the heart of this story of passion. Woolley is making an interestingly female plea for sexual scenes to be judged in an emotional context and crediting under-18s with an ability to respond to that. (My biased guess is that girls would respond and boys, who are not taught by our culture to associate sex with feeling, would not.) Duval the censor replied that the Board's present rules don't permit those under 18 to see simulated sex, but that it was currently consulting movie-goers on its draft revised code, to be made public later this year. I'd love to know exactly what questions the Board is putting to its consultant movie-goers about what is unacceptable. Is it asking what they find demeaning or dehumanising to their race or sex, or cynically exploitative, especially of the young? Or is it just asking the public to set the future permissible number of thrusts?

fields.headline: End of Affair stars attack 'hypocrisy'
fields.standfirst: End of Affair stars attack 'hypocrisy'
fields.trailText: End of Affair stars attack 'hypocrisy'
fields.body:
The director, producer and stars of The End of the Affair yesterday accused the censor of double standards after it was given an 18 certificate when a film they felt was misogynistic was passed as suitable for 15-year-olds.

Ralph Fiennes and Julianne Moore, the stars of the adaptation of the Graham Greene novel, joined with the director Neil Jordan and producer Stephen Woolley to heighten the row over the 18 certificate given by the British Board of Film Classification because it contains a screen simulation of wartime lovers having a fling.

The decision means that 16- and 17-year-olds, entitled to marry, have sex, and drive a car, cannot watch the film, which opens next Friday and which has been tipped as Britain's best chance of an Oscar. The New York Times and the film industry bible Variety have called it "the best Graham Greene adaptation since the Third Man".

American teenagers can see the film so long as they are accompanied by an adult. In Ireland, notoriously censorious, the film got a 15 certificate.

Mr Woolley said that the decision was shocking, particularly when the sex scenes were very short and not particularly graphic. He compared the classification to the 15 certificate given to Peter Greenaway's 8 Women, which was criticised for being misogynistic and used posters which "hinted at anal sex".

He said: "There's nothing in our film except for a bit of bottom. In the love-making scene they said there was too much movement from Ralph. In the second love-making scene they are semi-clothed.

"There is a double standard operating in that violence has become acceptable on screen. It's OK to show your children explicit violence like in the Bond films where we have murder, mayhem and death. And then we have a scene of making love and they are not allowed to see it."

Mr Woolley said there was probably about two or three minutes of nudity in the whole film and the censors had advised that they be left uncut.

Mr Fiennes said: "In this particular instance I think it's absurd, completely absurd. I don't think the sexuality in it is sadistic or abusive or based on violence. It's mutually consenting adults making love which is why we are all here."

Ms Moore said the film was not lascivious, her grandparents had seen it, love scenes and all, and approved. "They were not upset at all," she said.

Mr Jordan said: "I think they should publish those guidelines so that we know how to have sex ourselves."

The BBFC defended its decisions yesterday saying the sex scenes in the film were too strong. Spokeswoman Sue Clark said: "The sex scenes in it are not permissible at 15 because of the nature of the sex."

She added that the guidelines would soon be going out to consultation to see if the board was still in touch with the public.

The End of the Affair was previously filmed in 1954. The new version has had rave reviews in the United States. The New York Times called it intoxicating and critics pronounced it Jordan's best film.

Nudity and film certificates

15 certificate

Nudity There are no constraints on nudity in a non-sexual context

Sex Simulated sexual activity may be portrayed but without genital images. Sex scenes will normally be based on responsible relationships. Casual sex scenes may only be briefly shown. There may be occasional strong verbal references to sexual behaviour. Aggressive sexual references are unacceptable

18 certificate

Nudity Full nudity allowed

Sex Graphic portrayal of sexual activity permitted, but excluding explicit images of aroused genitalia, penetration, masturbation. Graphic portrayal of sexual activity accompanied by coercion or violence, or threatening or humiliating language or behaviour is not acceptable. Exceptions may be made where they can be justified in the strong public interest or where there are strong considerations of context

fields.headline: Chechens announce Grozny pull-out
fields.trailText: Chechen rebels have pulled out of Grozny, after months of heavy  fighting that has seen the Chechen capital reduced largely to rubble.
fields.body:
Chechen rebels have pulled out of Grozny, after months of heavy fighting that has seen the Chechen capital reduced largely to rubble.

When the battle for Grozny began last year, Chechen forces vowed to resist Russian troops until the bitter end. Today though, spokesman Movladi Udugov said all rebel fighters had left the city rather than incur any more losses to Russia's overwhelming military superiority. Instead, the Chechens have chosen to retreat to the mountains where they can resort to guerrilla tactics.

Mr Udugov said he had been told by rebel field commander Shamil Basayev that the withdrawal had been conducted "in accordance with an agreed plan to defend our state. The redeployment was successful. All army units withdrew along pre-arranged routes, complete with all weapons and ammunition."

He gave no figures for the number of fighters pulled out of the city, which has been under sustained Russian attack since just before the New Year. Russian forces first raked the city with artillery fire and aerial bombardment, before ground troops moved in to take the city street by street.

There was no immediate confirmation from Russian officials of Mr Udugov's comments. But the withdrawal will have come as a huge relief to Moscow, where acting president Vladimir Putin was beginning to come under criticism as Russian casualties mounted in fierce hand to hand fighting in the shattered streets of Grozny. Russia has been condemned internationally for inflicting heavy civilian casualties during the battle for the city.

The Russian military yesterday said it had taken control of Minutka Square, a strategic roundabout giving access to the centre of the devastated city. Russia launched its advance against Chechen rebels last September and moved quickly through lowlands in the separatist territory before running up into stubborn resistance in Grozny. The rebels still control many mountain areas to the south of the regional capital.

Grozny has been a potent symbol of Chechen resistance. But despite its capture, the rebels will be hoping for a repeat of the previous conflict, when Russian forces were forced into a humiliating retreat after the capture of Grozny.

The present campaign has played a key role in boosting the popularity of Mr Putin, Boris Yeltsin's handpicked successor. Dismissed as a classic apparatchik before he was appointed prime minister, Mr Putin has emerged as a strong and decisive figure largely through the ruthless Chechnya campaign.

Russian forces began their sweep through the rebel province last September, following Russian accusations that Chechen terrorists were behind several explosions in Russian apartment buildings that left hundreds dead. But there have been reports that the bombings were conducted by Russian security forces to give Moscow a pretext for the latest offensive in Chechnya.

fields.headline: Welcome to the Knowledge Society
fields.standfirst: "The way ahead is not to navigate a middle course between the old left and the  new right, the community and the market. The way ahead is to adopt a different  destination altogether."
fields.trailText: Three forces are driving modern economies - finance, knowledge and social capital. It is no coincidence that all are intangible: they cannot be weighed or touched, they do not travel in railway wagons and cannot be stockpiled in ports. The critical factors of production of this new economy are not oil, raw materials, armies of cheap labour or physical plant and equipment. These traditional assets still matter, but they are a source of competitive advantage only when they are vehicles for ideas and intelligence which give them value.
fields.body:
Three forces are driving modern economies - finance, knowledge and social capital. It is no coincidence that all are intangible: they cannot be weighed or touched, they do not travel in railway wagons and cannot be stockpiled in ports. The critical factors of production of this new economy are not oil, raw materials, armies of cheap labour or physical plant and equipment. These traditional assets still matter, but they are a source of competitive advantage only when they are vehicles for ideas and intelligence which give them value.

When the three forces of modern economic growth work together the economy hums, and society seems strong and creative. When they are at odds, as they have seemed to be for much of the last twenty years, society seems in danger of fragmenting and becoming more volatile. The task is to combine finance, knowledge and social capital in a virtuous circle of innovation, growth and social progress. There are three ways this could be done: by organizing society around the leadership of the market, the community or knowledge and creativity.

Those who believe that self-interest and the search for profit are the main motive force for economic growth argue that the market and private companies should primarily organise the economy. That was the argument of the new right for much of the 1980s and 1990s: that society should be rationalised, restructured and ultimately revitalised by unleashing self-interest and extending the market. The more people looked after their income, housing welfare, education, health, the better-off we would all be.

This free-market argument is still influential but has run its course. A free-market society would put us at the mercy of the impersonal, capricious forces of the financial markets, widen inequalities under-invest in the long term and the public goods on which we all rely. The rise of the knowledge economy will force us to revise many of the claims of the new right which have passed into conventional wisdom, for example that something's value can be read from its price, as set by an open market.

In the 1990s, most critics of free markets have chosen to prioritise social capital, often with the ambiguous but superficially appealing rallying cry that we should strengthen our sense of 'community'. The argument that society should be organised to maximize a sense unity comes in many guises. Stakeholder economists, such as Will Hutton, argue that we need to regulate market capitalism by enforcing upon companies obligations to communities and employees as well as shareholders. Communitarians, such as John Gray and Amitai Etzioni, argue that individuals can only realise themselves within a strong, supportive community. They share the belief that global capitalism is the enemy of community and that we need to make our societies more caring and compassionate.

The communitarian critique of market capitalism is superficially appealing but eventually disappointing. Strong communities can be pockets of intolerance and prejudice. Settled, stable communities are the enemies of innovation, talent, creativity, diversity and experimentation. They are often hostile to outsiders, dissenters, young upstarts and immigrants. Community can too quickly become a rallying cry for nostalgia; that kind of community is the enemy of knowledge creation, which is the well-spring of economic growth.

This battle between market and community has been central to the politics of the 1990s. The clash between market and community encouraged a string of attempts, none entirely convincing, to reconcile them: Tony Blair's and Bill Clinton's Third Way, Gerhard Schroeder's radical centre in Germany, Lionel Jospin's hope to create a market economy but not a market society in France, George Bush Jnr's compassionate conservatism, were all attempts to marry the market and community, efficiency and social justice. Governments of the right and the left have continued with broadly pro-market policies, while also strengthening social institutions.

This middle way is better than the market extremism which went before. But too often this course, tacking between the demands of market and community, is reduced to a balancing act. Politics with a compromise built into its core unsurprisingly leads to piecemeal, cautious reform: one step forward, half a step back. It does not produce a new vision of how society should be organised, nor a radically new kind of politics, with a new uplifting, inspirational goal and new means to achieve it.

The emergence of the Third Way and its continental variants marked the end of free-market dominance. But the way ahead is not to navigate a middle course between the old left and the new right, the community and the market. The way ahead is to adopt a different destination altogether. The goal of politics in the twenty-first century should be to create societies which maximise knowledge, the wellspring of economic growth and democratic self-governance. Markets and communities, companies and social institutions should be devoted to that larger goal. Finance and social capital should be harnessed to the goal of advancing and spreading knowledge. That will make us better off, put us more in charge of our lives and make us better able to look after ourselves.

The free-market agenda has run out of steam. Communitarianism is fraught with difficulty: when it is not vague it sounds authoritarian. The goal of becoming a knowledge-driven society, however, is radical and emancipatory. It has far-reaching implications for how companies are owned, organised and managed; the ways in which rewards are distributed to match talent, creativity and contribution; how education, learning and research is organised; the constitution of the welfare state and the political system. Knowledge is our most precious resource: we should organise society to maximise its creation and use. Our aim should not be a Third Way to balance the demands of the market against those of the community. Our aim should be to harness the power of markets and community to the more fundamental goal of creating and spreading knowledge.

webTitle: Ocean search for survivors as up to 86 feared dead in jet crash

fields.headline: Ocean search for survivors as up to 86 feared dead in jet crash
fields.standfirst: Oil slick marks spot where plane vanished from radar screens
fields.trailText: Rescue helicopters and US naval vessels were searching for survivors of an Alaska airlines flight that crashed into the Pacific Ocean 20 miles off the the Californian coast as the sun went down last night. Up to 86 people were feared dead in the crash, and two bodies were reported to have been recovered early today.
fields.body:
Rescue helicopters and US naval vessels were searching for survivors of an Alaska airlines flight that crashed into the Pacific Ocean 20 miles off the the Californian coast as the sun went down last night. Up to 86 people were feared dead in the crash, and two bodies were reported to have been recovered early today.

A large oil slick marked the spot in the sea where the MD-80 en route from Puerto Vallarta in Mexico to San Francisco.

There were reports this morning that the pilot had asked permission to make an emergency landing at Los Angeles airport.

At the time the plane was 50 miles north-west of Los Angeles international airport and it is believed that the pilot was attempting to turn back because of mechanical problems.

The flight, Alaska Airlines 261, was en route for Seattle after stopping at San Francisco. The coast guard received a report at 4.26 pm local time that a jet was going down 10 miles off the coast near Port Mugu and Oxnard in southern California.

The search was hampered by the fading light and there were fears that any survivors would not survive long in the very cold water. A park ranger was the first to spot the crash which he reported to the coastguard.

A US Navy sea hawk hov ered over the scene looking for any signs of life as boats from all areas on the coast headed to the scene.

Debris was scattered throughout the area. Officials at San Francisco airport where the plane was due to stop for a customs check were attempting to draw up a list of the 80 passengers and six crew on board the plane which is capable of carrying nearly twice that number.

Searchlights were being used as news helicopters hovered in the area and were asked to maintain their distance. The swell was not too heavy and the coast guard said that there was still hope that some might have survived.

Early reports suggested that the plane was upside down as it hit the water.

The last major US disaster was in October. EgyptAir Flight 990 plummeted into the ocean 60 miles (100 kilometers) south of the Massachusetts island of Nantucket. All 217 people aboard the Boeing 767 were killed.

The twin-engined MD-80 can carry 144 passengers, and is a successor to the popular DC-9 twinjet.

The National Transportation Safety Board said it was assembling a "go-team" to investigate the crash.

"The NTSB is assembling an investigative go-team as part of its investigation into the crash of an Alaska Airlines flight this evening off the coast of California," the NTSB said in a statement.

"Information is very sketchy at this point."

Fishing vessels with lights for night fishing joined the search for survivors as anxious relatives gathered at the aiports in Seattle and San Francisco.

It is thought that the plane carried a number of holiday-makers returning from a winter break in the sun.

webTitle: Jet crashes into Pacific with 88 on board

fields.headline: Jet crashes into Pacific with 88 on board
fields.trailText: An Alaska Airlines jet carrying 88 people plummeted into the Pacific last night after the pilot reported mechanical problems.
fields.body:
An Alaska Airlines jet carrying 88 people plummeted into the Pacific last night after the pilot reported mechanical problems.

Several bodies were recovered from the chilly water, but there was no sign of survivors hours after the crash, which occurred 40 miles north-west of Los Angeles airport. Flight 261, heading from Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, to San Francisco and later to Seattle, went down at 4:36pm local time.

A National Park Service ranger on Anacapa Island, near the crash site, saw the jet going down "nose first".

A large field of debris rolled in big swells about 10 miles offshore as aircraft and small boats converged on the site just before sunset. Hours later, the high-power lights of commercial squid boats illuminated the darkness as a cutter and small boats continued the search.

Deckhands on a fishing boat collected body parts, Mexican toys, a stuffed animal, a shoe, cushions and aircraft insulation. Several bodies were found, Coast Guard Lt. Chuck Diorio said, but he could not give a specific number.

The weather was clear at the crash site, where the water is between 300 and 750 feet deep, the coast guard said.

"Every resource is out there to find people," said coast guard Capt. George Wright. "We're actively searching for survivors. ... In 58-degree water temperature, people can survive. We're not going to quit until we're positive there's absolutely no chance."

If a plane lost its horizontal stabiliser, it would be unable to keep the nose pointed at the proper angle up or down, and the plane would begin an uncontrollable dive.

fields.headline: Five steps to nowhere
fields.standfirst:
The government has set a series of tests for joining the euro; by any measure, they don't add up to much

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The government has set a series of tests for joining the euro; by any measure, they don't add up to much.
fields.body:
The treasury website, stating the current version of the five pre-conditions for sterling's entry into the euro, asks the following questions:

1. Would joining Emu create better working conditions for firms making long-term decisions to invest in the UK?

2. How would adopting the single currency affect our financial services?

3. Are business cycles and economic structures compatible so that we and others in Europe could live comfortably with euro interest rates on a permanent basis?

4. If problems do emerge, is there sufficient flexibility to deal with them?

5. Will joining Emu help to promote higher growth, stability and a lasting increase in jobs?

Too often these words are edited to suit the conclusion - usually a sceptic one - that the presenter wants to prove. The answers will always be, to some extent, subjective - which was no doubt the politicians' intention from the start.

But the questions are real, and if the answers come out badly, we can say there is force in the idea that joining Emu would be bad for Mondeo Man. Alternatively, if they do not come out badly, it is difficult to see how a sane person can genuinely believe that joining a large, effective currency area can do other than benefit the single most important objective: the long term growth of national productivity.

1. Inward investment. The debaters are currently having a field day on this. The great American economic miracle is pulling much global investment towards the dollar - one of the reasons for the current "weakness" of the euro. If that tendency were judged to be irreversible, there is a case for saying that the UK could escape some of the adverse effects by staying out. Actually, it is most unlikely to be irreversible. And what is certain - indeed, already audible in the remarks of Asian businesses - is that, if the UK were on course for a prolonged and indefinite exclusion from the euro, investors would begin to lose interest in the UK. Perhaps the larger point, though, is that foreign investment has limited effects on domestic productivity. The great weight of effect will come from the brains and capital of the local people.

2. Financial services. How much does Mondeo Man or Northern Woman benefit from the prosperity of the City of London? To my knowledge, that question has never been researched. But even confining the issue to the City, there is only one way Emu could seriously damage its transactions and reduce those lovely bonuses: namely, if the predictions of such persons as Nobel prize winner Robert Mundell and myself prove correct, that there will soon be only three significant currencies in the world - the dollar, the euro and an Asian currency based on the yen.

If sterling stayed out, our currency would become the repository of large amounts of short-term funds, unwanted at any particular time in the other three. It would become unstable. There would be lots of transactions, and lots of bonuses. But the rest of our society and economy would be seriously damaged.

3 and 4. Comfort and Flexibility. These two conditions essentially tie together, and some people think they are to do with the "docking" process of the UK and euro economies. The common inference is that because British short-term interest rates are two points higher than euro rates, and because we currently have much lower unemployment, going down to euro rates would launch a raging inflation. But almost every recent forecast based on a link between inflation and the labour market has proved wrong. Searching for other proofs, economists turn to the house-price boom which would follow lower rates, leading to a consumer boom. As Mr Duisenberg has himself pointed out, however, inside Emu the British economy will change and behaviour patterns will be absorbed in the wider system.

In any case, even if UK inflation gained a point or two in the first years after entry, how much harm would that do to productivity? Statistically speaking, the true current rate is closer to zero than the official figure. In the vaunted US, regional inflation levels vary without damage or even much notice. I suggest that "comfortable" means living with a satisfactory performance on the single overriding criterion: national long-term productivity growth.

5. Higher growth, stability and motherhood. The most subjective test of all, this will be the basis of the political decision, whenever it is made.

The missing Ghost in this drama is the exchange rate at which the pound entered. I suggest it would be good if the government could ease our rate down by 10%, but entering at the present rate would probably not damage the lodestar: the long term growth of national productivity.

The convergence achieved by all the current members of the euro occurred after they had formed the solemn intention to create the single currency. Then came the interest-rate and exchange-rate consequences. Only after the decision, will real convergence start to happen. Can Tony Blair and Gordon Brown change the terms in which the famous five conditions are thus considered?

 Robin Marris is emeritus professor of economics at Birkbeck College

webTitle: Time to plan for being outside the zone

fields.headline: Time to plan for being outside the zone
fields.standfirst:
Currency debate is unwinnable
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is Britain's most pro-European prime minister since Ted Heath. Instinctively, he would like to be at the heart of decision-making in Europe rather than stuck on the periphery. Yet here he is, almost three years into his premiership, presiding over possibly the biggest crisis in Anglo-European relations for 30 years.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is Britain's most pro-European prime minister since Ted Heath. Instinctively, he would like to be at the heart of decision-making in Europe rather than stuck on the periphery. Yet here he is, almost three years into his premiership, presiding over possibly the biggest crisis in Anglo-European relations for 30 years.

The word crisis is overused, especially in newspapers. Yet there is a growing sense that Britain's entire approach to Europe is being coloured by the debate about the pros and cons of joining monetary union. The feeling that Britain and its European partners have been drifting further apart has been highlighted this weekend by the CBI's reluctance to go out and campaign for the single currency, the comments from Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Cental Bank, that Britain's entry into the single currency is years away at best, the ongoing weakness of the euro against the pound and the dollar, and the accusations of sleaze aimed at Helmut Kohl, the father of the euro project.

The latest opinion polls show almost seven out of 10 people are against Britain joining the single currency and more than a third would support leaving the EU altogether.

This is serious stuff, yet at this stage of the political cycle there is not a lot the government can do. Supporters of the euro say Mr Blair missed a golden opportunity in the immediate aftermath of his landslide victory, when he could have won a personal mandate for the principle of entry into monetary union. Now, with the next election probably no more than 18 months away, the prime minister and his advisers know that to go against the tide of public opinion on the single currency issue would hand the opposition the one issue with which it could deny Labour a second term.

Nor has Mr Blair's policy of constructive engagement in Europe brought much in the way of dividends. The withholding tax row rumbles on, amid mutterings that the veto over tax matters must go. Britain played by the EU book on BSE, only to see the French thumb their noses at the rules.

The costs of kicking the euro debate into the long grass until after the election should not be underestimated. Uncertainty over the government's attitude is actually contributing to the strength of sterling because London is seen as a safe haven from an ailing euro. There is a risk that inward investors might start to lose their enthusiasm for the UK if the likely timescale for entry is delayed much longer, although anybody for whom the exchange rate is such a fundamental factor in profitability should be having second thoughts about their entire strategy.

However, this is the wrong debate and it is being carried out on the basis of questionable assumptions. Unlike many other actual and putative members of the EU, Britain has never really bought into the political arguments for a united Europe. Rightly or wrongly, its view has always focused on economics - whether the UK would be better off in terms of growth, jobs, investment, living standards as part of a bigger economic unit.

In the 1960s there was no question that Britain thought it had much to learn from the economic success being enjoyed by the likes of Germany and France. Having ended the war as the world's second most important economy, the UK rapidly fell down the league table. Even as late as the early 90s, when John Major signed up to the Maastricht treaty, albeit with a British opt-out, the continent could still offer lower interest rates and lower inflation.

At the start of the 21st century, the economics are far less clear cut. Since Britain left the ERM it has been the second fastest growing economy in the G7 and has the lowest inflation rate on a harmonised basis. Unemployment is considerably lower than in Germany and France, and, although short-term interest rates are double those in the euro zone, long-term rates are broadly the same. Across Euroland there are calls for the sort of re forms to labour markets and welfare states that Britain went through under Mrs Thatcher and is still enduring today.

The combination of short-term political expediency and the medium-term economic outlook makes it difficult to see who could mount an effective campaign against the prevailing tide of euroscepticism. A mixture of growth and reform in Euroland might close the gap in economic performance but is hardly likely to provide a dramatic shift in opinion. Recession in the UK, particularly if accompanied by withdrawal of investment by high-profile companies, might turn the tide. But it is hard to see any combination of factors likely to cause a fundamental swing in public opinion in the next five years. Any organisation worth its salt should start to include long-term British exclusion from the euro zone in its contingency planning. And that includes the government.

fields.headline: Arms report gloom
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: General John de Chastelain handed his long-awaited report on IRA disarmament to the British and Irish governments late last night.
fields.body:
General John de Chastelain handed his long-awaited report on IRA disarmament to the British and Irish governments late last night.

Shortly before midnight the report was passed simultaneously to Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, in Belfast and to the Irish foreign minister Brian Cowen in Dublin.

The two ministers are expected to meet in Dublin today to formulate a joint response to the report which is understood to indicate that the IRA is not yet ready to disarm.

Political leaders on both sides of the Irish border fear that the general's report could trigger the most serious crisis in the peace process. David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader, signed a post-dated resignation last year which will come into effect next week if the IRA fails to disarm.

Mr Mandelson is expected to try to protect Mr Trimble by suspending the Northern Ireland executive. Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister, last night spoke of his concern.

fields.headline: Pressure builds on IRA
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Intensive discussions were continuing on both sides of the Irish border through the night as the British and Irish governments tried to broker a deal over IRA disarmament.
fields.body:
Intensive discussions were continuing on both sides of the Irish border through the night as the British and Irish governments tried to broker a deal over IRA disarmament.

Republicans were said to be coming under strong pressure from the Irish foreign minister, Brian Cowen, to make a gesture on decommissioning to save the peace process.

Across the border the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, and officials held lengthy talks with Unionists.

The Anglo-Irish discussions became more urgent last night after it became clear through the day that the IRA was refusing to begin the process of decommissioning its weapons. John de Chastelain, the Canadian general charged with overseeing disarmament, was expected to declare in his long-awaited report that the IRA has not even agreed to a timetable.

fields.headline: A E van Vogt
fields.standfirst: Master science-fiction writer who brought psychology to bear on his tales of aliens and inter-galactic struggle
fields.trailText: The author AE van Vogt, who has died aged 87, spearheaded a golden age of science fiction - along with such writers as Isaac Asimov and Robert Heinlein.
fields.body:
The author AE van Vogt, who has died aged 87, spearheaded a golden age of science fiction - along with such writers as Isaac Asimov and Robert Heinlein.

In his early writing, van Vogt displayed a wild talent, creating stories of vivid imagery and sudden, dream-like twists of plot and perspective that found an appreciative audience in a genre trying to shake off its image of rockets and ray guns. Encouraged by editor John W Campbell, van Vogt brought his interest in psychology and language to traditional science-fiction themes such as alien contact, interstellar war, time travel and its paradoxes, immortality and the superhuman.

Although critics often found his plots complex, others saw him stretching the possibilities of the field while retaining the sense of wonder vital to imaginative fiction.

AE van Vogt was born in Canada, and educated at var ious schools in Manitoba, graduating to the University of Ottawa in 1928. His first story sales were to "true story" confession magazines in the early 1930s while he was working as a census clerk and representative of Maclean Trade Papers. It was here that he honed a unique style, based on his reading of John W Gallishaw's The Only Two Ways To Write a Short Story, which included what van Vogt called "a hang-up" - some piece of missing information which the reader's imagination had to supply.

Later, he developed a system to cope with story problems: he forced himself to wake up every 1 hours to think about a solution, and found that his subconscious would often have the problem resolved by morning.

It was after a period of writing plays for Canadian radio that van Vogt rediscovered his early love of science fiction pulps, and, in 1939, he began submitting stories and serials to Astounding Science Fiction. Of his 38 novels, his earliest are still regarded as classics. His first, Slan, dealt with a persecuted race of human-bred mutants and attempts to bring peace between "normals" and their physical and mental superiors; The Weapon Shops Of Isher mixed future politics, immortality and galactic-scale space opera; The World of Null-A, and its sequel The Pawns of Null-A, introduced Alfred Kotzybski's general semantics - a system through which the higher levels of the mind could be accessed via non-Aristotelian (or null-A) teaching - into a galaxy-spanning political intrigue; the four stories that made up The Voyage Of The Space Beagle revolved around "nexialist" scientist Elliot Grosvenor, and how he and the crew of an intergalactic spacecraft coped with a variety of alien attackers. One sequence in this tale is a remarkable foreshadow of the movie, Alien, produced 36 years later.

When, in 1948, The World Of Null-A was published in book form, it was the first SF magazine serial to appear in hardcover from a major publisher (earlier titles had appeared from specialist houses). In France, it was translated by surrealist Boris Vian and created a market for science fiction.

However, van Vogt's interest in disciplines that would focus latent talent led him to dianetics, the memory auditing system developed by fellow SF writer L Ron Hubbard, which became the cornerstone of scientology. Although not interested in the mystical/religious aspects of scientology, van Vogt maintained the Los Angeles Hubbard Dianetic Centre from 1950 until 1961, partly financing the gesture by gathering together and reworking earlier stories into novels.

He also worked on his only non-SF novel, The Violent Man (1982), about communist China. At the invitation of editor Frederick Pohl, he then returned to science fiction, producing a string of well-received stories for the magazine If.

However, while some novels, notably The Silkie and The Battle Of Forever, were well-paced and well-written, van Vogt's fiction over the next two decades rarely achieved the critical acclaim his earlier work had earned. Some of his later novels only appeared in France, where he was championed by Jacques Sadoul, the editor at J'ai Lu, although many of his earlier novels remain in print.

In later years, van Vogt suffered from Alzheimer's disease. His first wife, the writer E Mayne Hull, died in 1975. He is survived by his second wife, Lydia Brayman.

Steve Holland

His first, Slan, dealt with a persecuted race of human-bred mutants and attempts to bring peace between "normals" and their physical and mental superiors; The Weapon Shops Of Isher mixed future politics, immortality and galactic-scale space opera; The World of Null-A, and its sequel The Pawns of Null-A, introduced Alfred Kotzybski's general semantics - a system through which the higher levels of the mind could be accessed via non-Aristotelian (or null-A) teaching - into a galaxy-spanning political intrigue; the four stories that made up The Voyage Of The Space Beagle revolved around "nexialist" scientist Elliot Grosvenor, and how he and the crew of an intergalactic spacecraft coped with a variety of alien attackers. One sequence in this tale is a remarkable foreshadow of the movie, Alien, produced 36 years later. When, in 1948, The World Of Null-A was published in book form, it was the first SF magazine serial to appear in hardcover from a major publisher (earlier titles had appeared from specialist houses). In France, it was translated by surrealist Boris Vian and created a market for science fiction. However, van Vogt's interest in disciplines that would focus latent talent led him to dianetics, the memory auditing system developed by fellow SF writer L Ron Hubbard, which became the cornerstone of scientology. Although not interested in the mystical/religious aspects of scientology, van Vogt maintained the Los Angeles Hubbard Dianetic Centre from 1950 until 1961, partly financing the gesture by gathering together and reworking earlier stories into novels. He also worked on his only non-SF novel, The Violent Man (1982), about communist China. At the invitation of editor Frederick Pohl, he then returned to science fiction, producing a string of well-received stories for the magazine If. However, while some novels, notably The Silkie and The Battle Of Forever, were well-paced and well-written, van Vogt's fiction over the next two decades rarely achieved the critical acclaim his earlier work had earned. Some of his later novels only appeared in France, where he was championed by Jacques Sadoul, the editor at J'ai Lu, although many of his earlier novels remain in print. In later years, van Vogt suffered from Alzheimer's disease. His first wife, the writer E Mayne Hull, died in 1975. He is survived by his second wife, Lydia Brayman. fields.headline: £35m wheel takes first passengers
fields.trailText: The trouble-plagued Millennium Wheel passed its final safety check last night and was declared ready to take its first passengers.
fields.body:
The trouble-plagued Millennium Wheel passed its final safety check last night and was declared ready to take its first passengers.

Engineers turned the £35m wheel yesterday to check that all was well. Preview rides were due to begin this morning for competition prize winners and the media.

But the 450ft-high attraction on the banks of the Thames in London will not be fully open to the public until the beginning of March.

The wheel's operators British Airways described this morning's event as a "soft opening".

Some disappointed customers who pre-booked rides for February were contacted two weeks ago to be told their trips were being postponed until March.

The delay-hit wheel's first setback came when a clutch problem emerged just after Christmas last year.

After that, safety inspectors ruled that the 1,500-tonne structure was not ready to take passengers on New Year's Eve, when it was officially opened amid fireworks and lasers, by the prime minister Tony Blair.

Subsequent investigations revealed that the clutch problem was a manufacturing fault and that clutches on all 32 of the wheel's capsules, from which passengers will be afforded some of the best views in the capital, needed to be replaced.

BA expects 2.5m people to take a ride on the wheel, which is situated on the south bank of the Thames opposite the Houses of Parliament, this year.

fields.headline: Photo A-level saved
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government has backed down from controversial plans to introduce a watered down A-level photography syllabus this year, after protests from teachers and practitioners.
fields.body:
The government has backed down from controversial plans to introduce a watered down A-level photography syllabus this year, after protests from teachers and practitioners.

Although photography will be studied as part of a new-look, broader art and design course from September, the government has agreed to the critics' key demand that students should be able to sit a written paper covering the scientific, historical and technical aspects of the subject.

The climbdown was welcomed yesterday by art colleges and universities, who had backed a high-profile campaign for an academic component to be retained. Practitioners also feared that ministers were trying to downgrade the subject, despite huge interest. GCSE photography has already been scrapped.

The campaign has been co-ordinated by Ashley la Grange, head of photography at Rickmansworth school in Hertfordshire, who enlisted the support of the leading lights in the photographic world to press for a proper review of the subject. They include photographers such as Eve Arnold and Don McCullin and representatives of Britain's most prestigious photographic organisations, including the V&A, the Royal College of Art and the Royal Photographic Society.

Yesterday the qualifications and curriculum authority confirmed that it had now decided to allow examining boards to offer an optional written exam.

Mr la Grange said: "This will ensure that candidates will have a broad-based understanding of the subject."

Andy Golding, head of photography at the University of Westminster, added: "It is essential that students have more than just a practical grounding".

fields.headline: Black on track
fields.standfirst: Race discrimination in colleges can be cured without drastic legislation, says  Mike Peters
fields.trailText: Race discrimination in colleges can be cured without drastic legislation, says Mike Peters
fields.body:
Fewer than one in 50 college principals are black. Of the entire ethnic minority employees in further education, only African Caribbean and Indian heritage people are in sufficient numbers to register as one percentage point each. Outside London the numbers of black college governors are pitifully small... Yet the numbers of black students in further education account for about 13% of the total student body.

Institutional and personal prejudice are knotty problems that will not go away. Despite the findings of the Macpherson report into the killing of Stephen Lawrence, general acceptance that organisations can of themselves be racist is difficult to achieve.

Do the TUC findings about the lack of black people in senior positions and the fact that the position has worsened in the last 10 years surprise you? Never underestimate an organisation's ability to resist change.

We are a new Commission for Black Staff in Further Education. We are sponsored by key organisations in further education, the Further Education Funding Council, the Association of Colleges, Natfhe and the Network of Black Managers. Each one of this heady mix of organisations is committed at the very highest levels to removing practices in colleges that are cumulatively racist in outcome. My job as commission chair is to help them realise their commitment.

This will be achieved in partnership with a formidable team of commission members. Together we will identify and analyse the current employment profile of black staff in further education, and look at the factors that dissuade or encourage black people into careers in further education. We will consider the institutional factors that undermine the progression of black people throughout the sector. We intend to celebrate good practice and will look at success factors in implementing change.

Some people fear that more controls resulting from legislation will only alienate employers from employing and promoting non-white people. What all employers, public and private, need to understand is the simple business case for having a diverse workforce. In the USA projections point to the white population totalling just 13% by 2050. Ethnically diverse organisations at all levels will be those best placed to survive.

Education has a special role in tackling racism and promoting diversity, firstly because of its role in promoting social and moral inclusion and secondly because of its role in enabling future economic strength.

Intractable national issues like this require big and brave attempts to shine spotlights on the problems. A drastic solution now being put forward by the government is to outlaw indirect discrimination. Ours will be to effect organisational change in further education that will render new legislative proposals unnecessary.

Our vision of an effective further education service is one that delivers lifelong learning to all students through a diverse workforce that gives inspiration to students wherever they are from. Our vision seeks to change practices by making them more transparent, and to secure accountability and target setting through inspection and funding.

The Commission will look at strategies to encourage communication, debate, collective ownership and responsibility for good practice and its implementation, and suggest ways in which training and development needs of staff and governors are prioritised to realise the talents of students and staff.

This is a tall order but I am encouraged by the sense of purpose and direction the Commission has gathered after only one meeting last week and by the number of people across the country who have offered to be expert witnesses and to provide assistance. The agenda is large and the time short. We will prepare an interim report by September 2000, with the final report by January 2001 for implementation from April 2001.

Further education is poised for the next stage of radical change, and the Commission has a unique opportunity to influence that change.

Sam Allen, Natfhe

Dame Lorna Borland, Chair of Governors, Lambeth College

Wally Brown, Principal, Liverpool Community College

Ahmed Choonara, Principal, South Nottingham College

Christine Farley, Principal, Hackney Community College

Stuart Gardner, FEFC, representing David Melville, Chief Executive

Asquith Gibbes, Chair of Governors, Lewisham College

David Gibson, Chief Executive of the Association of Colleges

Tony Henry, City College, Birmingham

Tejo Kaur, Wolverhampton College

Robin Landman, Network for Black Managers

Paul Mackney, General Secretary, Natfhe

Rajinder Mann, Network of Black Managers

Christina McAnea, Unison

Michael Peters, Director of Educational Services, City of York Council (chair)

Joel Whittle, St Helen's College
