fields.headline: Another scandal surfaces
fields.standfirst: Colleges seem unable to kick the muck from their boots, as an old report comes to light and a victimisation tribunal begins
fields.trailText: Colleges seem unable to kick the muck from their boots, as an old report comes to light and a victimisation tribunal begins
fields.body:
The most depressing thing about the scandal at Cricklade College in Hampshire is that the college governors have reacted to the crisis in the usual way. They commissioned a report on the troubles from accountants PricewaterhouseCooper, then kept it secret for more than a year, and would still be doing so if they could. The lecturer they suspected had blown the whistle was made redundant - his claim of victimisation was due to start at an employment tribunal yesterday. Will they never learn?

Back in 1994-5 Cricklade College entered into a trading agreement with a company called Extras Ltd. The European Social Fund agreed to pay 45% of the cost of IT training provided to the college by Extras Ltd, so long as the college agreed in writing to pay the other 55%. But in 1996 DfEE officials investigated the training and the claims made for it from the European Social Fund.

We now know that the Cricklade College principal, Richard Evans, and two of his top executives had been working a remarkable scheme. According to the PricewaterhouseCooper report, the college "declared an intention to provide funding which it clearly had no intention of actually providing."

It even got its hands on a substantial portion of the 45% which the European Social Fund paid to Extras Ltd, because Extras Ltd agreed to pay the college £109,053 for assessment and registration costs. But, say the accountants, "the college has no record of providing this service, or of having entered candidates for any qualifications."

Extras Ltd also agreed to pay £414,436 for IT facilities, but there is no evidence that the college bought any IT equipment, and "it is difficult to understand how the college provided this level of IT facilities."

The director of enterprise, Bob Bradshaw, wrote to his colleagues on November 22 1993: "If we can run European Social Fund courses on less than the funding received, good for us."

If the European Social Fund seeks the repayment to which it is probably entitled, the college could face a bill of £1,694,875, says PricewaterhouseCoopers.

The accountancy firm's investigators clearly felt frustrated at what they saw as obfuscation. They complain that the college provided incomplete committee minutes and incomplete documentation, and add that it also failed to provide computerised records "due to the director of enterprise's computer crashing at an inopportune time"!

The report says: "The principal states that (the relationship with Extras Ltd) was regularly reported to the (governors) and the finance committee. However, this is supported neither by the formal records now available to us, nor by our discussions with governors and members of staff."

Then there was the fact that "the governor who was chairman of the corporation through much of the relevant period was on holiday during the main period of our review, and is now in hospital."

The three executives responsible were Mr Evans; the director of enterprise, Bob Bradshaw; and the director of finance, Mike Clark. They all "declined the opportunity" to be interviewed by the investigators. Mr Evans gave them a formal statement and met them with a view to sharing documentation, and Mr Bradshaw gave a formal statement through his solicitors.

In January 1998, when the governors started to see that they were in serious trouble, the chair and vice-chair saw Mr Evans, who promptly went off on sick leave. A few days later the governors suspended him on full pay; he is still suspended. Later, both Mr Bradshaw and Mr Clark were allowed to take early retirement with enhanced pensions (the exact terms of these pension deals is one of the college's many secrets).

PricewaterhouseCooper recommended that the college "consider using the disciplinary process now to clarify the position of the suspended principal".

They also suggested that the college consider reassessing the leaving packages of the other two.

These recommendations were made secretly to the governors more than a year ago, and as far as anyone knows, nothing has been done about them.

The contrast with the treatment of business studies lecturer Andy Murray could not be more stark.

During 1998 college authorities accused Mr Murray of shopping them to the press. In September 1998 he was made redundant after 12 years.

Mr Murray was the secretary of the Cricklade branch of Natfhe, the college lecturers' union. Natfhe accuses the college of selecting him for redundancy for his union activities and his whistleblowing. Education Secretary David Blunkett has asked the former chairman of the Advisory Conciliation and Arbitration Service, Sir Pat Lowry, to investigate "whether the affairs of the college have been mismanaged", and the allegation of victimisation of Mr Murray.

And that, in truth is the most depressing thing. We are seeing the same behaviour pattern as in all the other college scandals since colleges were cut free from local authorities in 1993: Halton, Stoke on Trent, Derby Wilmorton and the rest.

As always, a weak board of governors gathers protectively around the senior executives who created the problem, and awkward junior members of staff appear to be brutally dealt with.

Colleges, with the enthusiastic encouragement of the Further Education Funding Council, are trying to put the scandal-ridden post-incorporation phase of their lives behind them, but there is at least one more college scandal, and probably several more, about which we still do not know anything like the full story. We can be pretty sure that they, too, will exhibit these characteristics.

At Cricklade, little has been learned yet. Neither Mr Evans nor acting principal, Elizabeth Blakemore, returned my telephone calls last week.

webTitle: Colleges could face claims for millions

fields.headline: Colleges could face claims for millions
fields.standfirst: Verdict looms in lecturers' crucial seven-year contract battle
fields.trailText: Verdict looms in lecturers' crucial seven-year contract battle
fields.body:
A key employment tribunal decision, which could trigger a flood of lawsuits against colleges for millions of pounds by lecturers, for loss of earnings since 1993, is due within days.

The tribunal in London is considering claims by a group of lecturers at Havering college that they have received no pay rises in seven years. They say this was for refusing to sign new contracts after incorporation when the Essex college and the other 400 plus further education institutions were freed from local authority control.

The claimants, who are backed by the new lecturers' union, LEAF, maintain that under European law their terms and conditions of employment under the old "Silver Book" contract should not have been changed in the transfer from local authority to further education corporations.

They say that despite the transfer, colleges remained "emanations of the state" because they continued being publicly funded and under government control and as such, their employees enjoyed protection under the European Acquired Rights Directive.

The hearing's final three days in December, devoted to legal arguments, indicate how important this decision will be. Indeed, the tribunal panel indicated their likely intention of passing the matter on to the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg.

Lawyers for Havering college, which has been backed by the Association of Colleges (AoC), made two key concessions. They agreed that the college was an emanation of the state, and the change of control in 1993 was a "relevant transfer" for the purposes of the European directive.

LEAF's general secretary, David Evans, predicts that a win would lay colleges all over the country open to claims which could run to millions.

"A Point 14 lecturer on about £20,000 under the Silver Book, who has been on that since 1994, would be owed about £50,000 for loss of earnings and interest and for the additional work done," he said.

David Gibson, the Association of College's chief executive, reckons the college will win. But even if it doesn't "the number of people whom this would apply to is pretty small".

If the lecturers win, other colleges could claim that Havering's admission that it is an "emanation of the state" does not mean that they are. But this could be difficult to sustain, in the view of one education lawyer who has been following the case.

Colleges also might take comfort from the three-month time limit on launching this sort of legal claim, which passed years ago. But, says the lawyer, the courts might waive that limit because the law in this case would only just have been clarified.

In his opinion the most significant result of a win by the lecturers would be to prevent colleges in future acting as many did post-incorporation in pressurising their staff to change their contracts and working conditions.

fields.headline: Happy clap-trap!
fields.standfirst: Beware claims that most part-time lecturer are purring, says  Cecilia McKelvey
fields.trailText: Beware claims that most part-time lecturer are purring, says Cecilia McKelvey
fields.body:
Many of the part-time lecturers who read of the unpublished research commissioned by the Further Education Development Agency (Guardian Further Jan 18) must have been more than a little surprised at their reported "happiness" with their lot. Was all the unrest, and concern over the growing casualisation of further education lecturers since 1993 over nothing?

Of course, there will always be people who are willing to earn less to enjoy more flexibility. The key issues here are choice and equality. Lumping all part-timers together, whether on permanent, temporary or hourly-paid contracts, as if they were one category, as this research appears to do, obscures these issues.

Our own research, at the University of Greenwich, into the working lives of 120 newly qualified lecturers suggests that the biggest difference in satisfaction levels arose from the type of contract lecturers had.

Those on permanent contracts, whether full-time or part-time, were far more content than those on temporary, hourly-paid or agency contracts. Part-timers on permanent contracts had equal access to staff development and other resources and were more likely to have actively chosen to work part-time.

Far from enjoying "flexibility and more time with their families", 33% of the hourly-paid workers taught more than 16 hours a week at more than one institution. Despite their lack of staff development they frequently performed roles of considerable responsibility, for instance, as course tutor.

And, there may be more cause for concern than is presently obvious. When asked about their ambitions, those on hourly-paid contracts wanted permanent work, and would seek other jobs if they did not obtain it, while new lecturers on permanent contracts saw the future in terms of promotion to management positions. These ambitions are problematic in a service which, with its flat structure offers few opportunities for advancement.

Staffing policies have already resulted in a situation in which it is almost impossible to recruit lecturers in some curriculum areas. In June (Guardian Education, June 15, 99) the Further Education Funding Council refused to publish its own statistics on the high staff turnover in the sector.

The rhetoric of Learning to Succeed and of lifelong learning are dependent on the quality of the post-16 teaching force. The well qualified, highly motivated graduates of the class of 1998 are in there and they are committed, but for how long? £17 per hour forever won't do.

 Cecilia McKelvey is Senior Lecturer in the School of Post-Compulsory Education and Training, University of Greenwich.

Of course, there will always be people who are willing to earn less to enjoy more flexibility. The key issues here are choice and equality. fields.headline: Word perfect
fields.standfirst: Education is increasingly infested by feelgood language, but what does any of it mean?
fields.trailText: Education is increasingly infested by feelgood language, but what does any of it mean?
fields.body:
"Dear Mr Beckett, Good news!" I throw away at once all letters beginning like that. I know they will inform me that someone's coffee granules are 3.14 % tastier. We're used to advertising material which uses words, not for their real purpose of giving information, but as feelgood noises.

We're becoming used to politicians doing it, too. "The gud news" Frank Dobson used to shout out from my radio in the mornings, in a voice that put me in mind of a rotweiler trying to sound like a St Bernard. It was usually the prelude to an announcement that the rate of decline of some aspect of the health service was marginally slower, so long as you looked at the figures in a certain way.

Under New Labour, words like new, and community, and new, and innovative, and partnership, and new are all used to convey a feeling of comfort rather than an exact meaning (especially new).

In further education the favourite feelgood word is excellence. Every college I speak to seems to purvey this commodity, which is very odd, for two reasons. First, there's no such commodity. Excellent is an adjective; not a noun. To talk of excellence as though it comes out of a bottle is nonsense. And second, it can't be true that all colleges are excellent. For some colleges to excel, others must fail to excel.

But this year's award for cramming the largest number of feelgood words into the smallest amount of meaning goes to the authors of the Greenwich bid for an Education Action Zone. They have already received their prize, which is between £500,000 and £750,000 a year of taxpayers' money for three to five years, starting at once (everyone else must wait until next year).

So theirs is the formula that charms money out of ministers. The formula involves listing the "strategic intent" in a series of bullet points, like this:

 promote high quality teaching and learning

 significantly raise standards in literacy and numeracy

 raise standards generally.

This will come as a relief to anyone who thought they wanted to lower standards. But then the "strategic intent" becomes lyrical:

 join schools together in a dynamic partnership with the community, parents, young people and business

 raise expectations and empower parents to support their children in raising achievement

 secure a climate of continual improvement through constant innovation, evaluation and development

 be at the very frontiers of learning made possible by IT and ICT developments
 empower partners to respond flexibly to identified local need.

Join together, dynamic, partnership, community, empower, support, achievement, innovation, frontiers of learning and there's only one feelgood word missing: "challenge", which is in the previous paragraph.

There are pages and pages of this bid, but not a single original idea, not a single aspiration that means more than "we want to do well." The words aren't intended to convey meaning, but to leave the reader warm, reassured, and entirely ignorant about the intentions of the authors. It's a comfort zone. And it was rewarded, instantly. When the DfEE rewards educators for writing meaningless rubbish in the correct feelgood words, there is no hope of stopping educators from debasing the language they are supposed to be teaching.

fields.headline: A show of primary colors
fields.standfirst: Whoever wins the presidential race in America will need to tackle the crisis in education. Where do the candidates stand?
fields.trailText: Whoever wins the presidential race in America will need to tackle the crisis in education. Where do the candidates stand?
fields.body:
With voting under way in the primaries and caucuses, the race is on for what is commonly described as the most powerful job in the world. Yet the next president of the US will be woefully weak in respect of one of his country's most pressing problems - reforming schools.

American presidents have none of the levers for educational change available to British prime ministers. Indeed, Americans are amazed by the centralised power British governments hold over schools.

Education will be a key issue in the presidential campaign 2000. In a recent Washington Post/ABC opinion poll, 79% of voters said education was "very important" in the presidential contest, the highest rating for any issue.

Yet this emphasis is a triumph of hope over experience. Presidents Clinton and Bush tried, and failed, to grab the mantle of "education president". A decade on, Bush's Education Goals 2000 remains a statement of aspirations rather than a basis for federal policy.

Unlike Whitehall, Washington has no role in setting the school curriculum or tests, has no say in teacher education and provides only around 8% of spending on schools. Local control is the American way.

Yet America, like Britain, has fallen into a crisis of confidence. So it is perhaps no surprise that many of the leading presidential candidates appear to be looking at ideas already being tried in Britain.

The leading Democrat contender, Vice-President Al Gore, is positively Blairite. He, too, wants nursery education for all three- and four-year-olds, smaller classes, a "fresh-start" for failing schools and pay rises for "master teachers".

However, Gore must overcome much greater hostility to the idea of national government involvement in running schools. Republicans accuse Gore of desiring "a national school board".

Gore's challenger for the Democratic nomination, the popular former basketball star Bill Bradley, takes a more conventional American approach to education, believing schools are a local issue.

However, Bradley is astute enough to realise he cannot ignore education. The "public schools" (that's public as in "of the people", not the perverse British sense of "open to a few") are the centrepiece of American communities. Education is the guarantor of equal opportunities in the American tradition; Bill Bradley endorses that view, believing "education is the key to fulfilling the American dream".

Lacking a developed education programme, Bradley's TV commercials have focused instead on his school days at Crystal City High, a Missouri public school. He has promised an extra 60,000 teachers, a payment-for-volunteers scheme to encourage the elderly to help in schools, and a combined early-years care and education programme.

By contrast, the Republican front-runner, Texas governor George W Bush, has built a reputation as an "education governor". George W, as he is known to avoid confusion with his father, has presented himself as a "compassionate conservative" with a commitment to improving public schools whilst also encouraging choice.

Bush resists typecasting on education. His twin daughters attend a racially mixed, 2,200-pupil public high school. Before that, though, they attended a private school.

Texas led the way in the standards-based reform movement that has spread to virtually all other states. The reforms impose accountability through performance in state-wide tests. As such, they resemble Britain's obsession with national testing and targets.

Bush's Texas reforms include clear state curriculum guidelines and regular testing of pupils in reading and maths. Bush's proud boast is that, during each of his years as governor, all ethnic groups, in all age groups, have improved their test scores.

Bush's presidential platform includes a controversial plan to make schools accountable for their results. If schools in poor areas fail to improve their test results, they risk having their federal funds taken away and given instead to parents to spend on alternative forms of education. Schools that improve their results would get additional grants.

The logical extension of standards-based reforms in individual states is the creation of a national curriculum and national standards. But America is not ready for that level of centralisation. Even Bush's plans for accountability are based on local or state tests.

Although Bush leads the Republican race, former Vietnam prisoner-of-war John McCain has emerged as leader of the following pack. He shares the conventional American belief that "parents, educators and local communities" should decide school policy, not Washington or teacher unions.

He opposes use of federal money to develop national tests or standards, and favours right-wing responses to public concerns over public schools: voucher schemes and a stronger mechanism for sacking poor teachers.

Confidence in America's public schools has been at a low ebb since the mid-1980s. Racial segregation, inner-city social exclusion, drugs and violence in schools and "shopping mall" high schools where students are free to choose non-challenging subjects have together created a sense of crisis.

Both George Bush Senior and Clinton have tried, and largely failed, to make any impact on educational reform. The result is that whoever emerges as presidential victor next November will have little leverage over education policy in a country which badly needs national leadership to implement effective and lasting school reform.

 Mike Baker is education correspondent for BBC News. He spent last term on a fellowship at the University of Michigan.

fields.headline: ...Interior design
fields.trailText: What is it? I'm frightfully sorry, but I'm not sure I can commune with someone who has to ask that question.
fields.body:
What is it? I'm frightfully sorry, but I'm not sure I can commune with someone who has to ask that question.

Don't bother, I already know. It's what you do with the stuff you've bought in B & Q. Ohhh! Pulleeeze! I really can't be expected to work under these conditions.

Look, don't get your swatches in a twist. I'm only kidding. Desist! The art of the interior designer must be no joking matter.

Pardon. Let me plump this cushion. Park yourself down and tell us all about it. Oh dear! It screams a bit, and those antimacassars... well, never mind. You should have come for professional advice. We're easy to find. Interior designers usually work freelance or in conjunction with architects.

What do they do? Squillions of things. The interior designer has to cover everything from the lighting and plumbing to the colour scheme.

What busy bunnies! Ooh, you don't know the half. Rushed off their toes from noon to night, poor things. They are responsible for sub-contracting (the choice of company, overseeing the workmen etc) and providing the detailed drawings which are used by every member of the team. They spend a great deal of time at the worksite and travelling to meet prospective clients. They organise the available space, furnishings and interior decorating to meet the client's requirements.

I expect some clients can be a bit difficult. You said it, duckie. Let's just say that the interior designer has to be able to use the client's criticism constructively, as it may need several designs before the desired effect is attained.

They've got to be able to draw? It does help, although these days designs are often drawn using computer software packages such as AutoCAD release 14. And some designers - mention no names - may choose to hire a draughtsperson.

So, what does the would-be designer need? Drawing ability definitely helps, and good communication and presentation skills are vital. Also creative talent and imagination, which should go without saying, but you do see some horrors. I mean, where did you get those curtains? And good colour vision, of course.

I suppose it's a changing buiness. Oh, yes. A designer must understand and keep up with latest trends, and that's on top of all the related professional practices such as costing, insurance requirements and all regulations regarding building and construction.

And there are niches? Over my dead body. I can't stand them. So kitsch!

No, I mean, is there scope for specialising? Oh, see what you mean. Yes, there's plenty of chance for that. You might branch out into theatre and set design. Then there's exhibition or display design. Some people get into historical styles in a big way. Then you might just do furnishing or even colour schemes.

How do you get into it? There are many different routes. Most interior designers have an HNC/HND or degree in interior design practice/spatial design/design (three-dimensional studies) from institutes which specialise in art and design. A portfolio of work is an essential entrance requirement to a course, as it shows potential and the necessary skills. You usually present that at an interview. Entry requirements vary: after A levels, either a one-year foundation course or advanced GNVQ in art and design can be taken; or it is possible to take an art and design access course.

Any more? It is also possible to take City &Guilds 7900 Creative Studies: Interior Design Techniques, or a BTEC or an NVQ level 2 in Interior Design.

 The Chartered Society of Designers (CSD), 32-38 Saffron Hill, London EC1N 8FH, Telephone: 0171 831-9777 Email csd@csd.org.uk

 The National Society of Education in Art and Design (NSEAD), The Gatehouse, Corsham Court, Corsham, Wiltshire SN13 0BZ Telephone: 01249 714825

 learndirect 0800 100 900 may be able to give further information and advice

fields.headline: Make mine an A*
fields.standfirst: The examination system is drawing criticism from all sides about the accuracy of marking and the appeals process
fields.trailText: The examination system is drawing criticism from all sides about the accuracy of marking and the appeals process
fields.body:
Exam boards for England and Wales are facing an unprecedented volume of complaint that they are failing to pass basic tests of efficiency, speed and accuracy in the marking of GCSE and A-level scripts.

A grassroots mutiny against their standard of performance is being led by the heads of independent schools, whose reputation and financial strength depend on demonstrating superior grades, particularly at A level, on which university places depend. State schools are unhappy, too.

This is coming to the boil now because of irritation about delays in appeals against grades awarded last summer. The schools and colleges also fear the system may not be strong enough to survive the introduction of new A-level courses in September that will involve many students in an extra round of exams at the end of their first year in the sixth form.

Many of the independent heads are speaking contemptuously of the exam boards' performance since a wave of mergers over the last few years has organised the system into three rival consortia, each handling a broad mix of academic and vocational qualifications.

The three are Edexcel, AQA and OCR. Most of the venom is directed at OCR, which incorporated the old Oxford and Cambridge exam board that was commonly used by candidates from the independent sector.

Some of the complaints concern allegations of administrative breakdown. Alan Rogers, headmaster of Wellington School in Somerset, said 27 of his candidates received no results for an economic A-level module on the due date in August. It eventually emerged that the scripts had not been returned by the examiner assigned to mark them. Rogers said the OCR board had to threaten legal action against the examiner before the papers were returned and the results given in October.

This was an extreme case, but the heads are concerned about what they regard as evidence of a more general problem of declining standards of marking.

Vivian Anthony, secretary of the Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference, said a survey of independent schools showed 16% of entries got results worse than expected and 4% were seriously worse. "We'd put a substantial proportion of that down to the fact that the examining of those candidates is questionable," he said.

After discussion with the boards, the Conference estimates there were 50,000 complaints from independent and state schools and colleges last summer. Naturally, there were none about grades that may have been implausibly high.

Tony Evans, headmaster of King's College School, Wimbledon and a former HMC chairman, said the extent of exam board error was a national scandal. "Fairness is what matters to children as much as anything else. If the exam boards are failing to deliver accurate results, we are destroying the faith of young people, as well as jeopardising their careers. We should not have exams at all if we cannot have faith in the system," he said.

Criticism is not confined to the independent sector. John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "There is a general feeling among state schools and colleges that the situation needs to be brought under control - quickly. Examining needs to be more efficient and consistent. And the appeals process needs to be improved. The length of time boards are taking on appeals is deplorable. In Scotland they turn the whole thing round in a fortnight."

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "After complaints about the handling of the 1998 exams, I had a categoric assurance that the merger of the boards would lead to a better service. It's now clear from reports I'm getting about the 1999 exams that they still haven't got it right. The problem is basically incompetence, involving wrong marking and giving wrong grades to students who clearly should be receiving better."

Sue Singer, headmistress of Guildford High School, said: "It's a vicious circle. More people are questioning results and that is leading to a greater number of changes in grade. That in turn is encouraging more people to complain."

Graham Able, master of Dulwich College, said part of the problem was organisational, stemming from the merger of boards with different traditions. But the underlying difficulty was a shortage of good examiners. Too much of the work was done by teachers at the end of a hard day at school, marking scripts at speed, without professional back-up.

He called for large-scale experiments in "residential marking", releasing examiners from other duties to work full-time for a week marking scripts under the supervision of senior examiners.

"Examining will never be popular and the boards will never be able to pay enough to attract people in for the money. What will attract is if examining becomes part of a teacher's career development. If it was a requirement for becoming a head of department, you might bring more good young teachers into the marking pool."

Those ideas find favour with Ron McLone, OCR director of policy, the exam board at the eye of the storm of protest. He said heads and principals used to want their teachers to have examining experience. It gave them insight into what was required of students and raised their classroom performance.

But the boards were now more open with this information and teachers did not have to become examiners to peer behind the curtain of a secret system. "Demands on examiners are getting greater and we are not getting the influx to replace those retiring... We have to get government to understand that examining must take a more prominent role in teacher development." Teachers might not be allowed to reach senior positions unless they had done service as examiners.

McLone rejected the heads' allegation that marking standards deteriorated last year. Inquiries from schools asking for results to be checked or remarked were less than 1% of entries. At OCR, the number fell from 16,528 in 1998 to 10,182 last year, although these numbers are hard to interpret. A complaint about the marks of a whole class counts as one inquiry, as does a challenge to a candidate's marks in a single module.

He said the board's administrative difficulties in 1998 were the result of pressures from the last government pushing the speed of merger. "Organisational change became hurried instead of bedding down at a more natural pace." There were problems integrating IT facilities.

McLone said these were now sorted, but suggested the AQA consortium might have similar problems when it integrates its constituent operations this year. This charge is vehemently denied by AQA.

"The system has to be careful over the next few years because there are major pressures outside the boards' control. Some say: we will get through it. But I'm trying to be realistic. The key to examining is the quality of the marking. If you can't get people who can mark properly, you are stuck," McLone said.

fields.bodyText: Exam boards for England and Wales are facing an unprecedented volume of complaint that they are failing to pass basic tests of efficiency, speed and accuracy in the marking of GCSE and A-level scripts. A grassroots mutiny against their standard of performance is being led by the heads of independent schools, whose reputation and financial strength depend on demonstrating superior grades, particularly at A level, on which university places depend. State schools are unhappy, too. This is coming to the boil now because of irritation about delays in appeals against grades awarded last summer. The schools and colleges also fear the system may not be strong enough to survive the introduction of new A-level courses in September that will involve many students in an extra round of exams at the end of their first year in the sixth form. Many of the independent heads are speaking contemptuously of the exam boards' performance since a wave of mergers over the last few years has organised the system into three rival consortia, each handling a broad mix of academic and vocational qualifications. The three are Edexcel, AQA and OCR. Most of the venom is directed at OCR, which incorporated the old Oxford and Cambridge exam board that was commonly used by candidates from the independent sector. Some of the complaints concern allegations of administrative breakdown. Alan Rogers, headmaster of Wellington School in Somerset, said 27 of his candidates received no results for an economic A-level module on the due date in August. It eventually emerged that the scripts had not been returned by the examiner assigned to mark them. Rogers said the OCR board had to threaten legal action against the examiner before the papers were returned and the results given in October. This was an extreme case, but the heads are concerned about what they regard as evidence of a more general problem of declining standards of marking. Vivian Anthony, secretary of the Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference, said a survey of independent schools showed 16% of entries got results worse than expected and 4% were seriously worse. "We'd put a substantial proportion of that down to the fact that the examining of those candidates is questionable," he said. After discussion with the boards, the Conference estimates there were 50,000 complaints from independent and state schools and colleges last summer. Naturally, there were none about grades that may have been implausibly high. Tony Evans, headmaster of King's College School, Wimbledon and a former HMC chairman, said the extent of exam board error was a national scandal. "Fairness is what matters to children as much as anything else. If the exam boards are failing to deliver accurate results, we are destroying the faith of young people, as well as jeopardising their careers. We should not have exams at all if we cannot have faith in the system," he said. Criticism is not confined to the independent sector. John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "There is a general feeling among state schools and colleges that the situation needs to be brought under control - quickly. Examining needs to be more efficient and consistent. And the appeals process needs to be improved. The length of time boards are taking on appeals is deplorable. In Scotland they turn the whole thing round in a fortnight." David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "After complaints about the handling of the 1998 exams, I had a categoric assurance that the merger of the boards would lead to a better service. It's now clear from reports I'm getting about the 1999 exams that they still haven't got it right. The problem is basically incompetence, involving wrong marking and giving wrong grades to students who clearly should be receiving better." Sue Singer, headmistress of Guildford High School, said: "It's a vicious circle. More people are questioning results and that is leading to a greater number of changes in grade. That in turn is encouraging more people to complain." But the underlying difficulty was a shortage of good examiners. Too much of the work was done by teachers at the end of a hard day at school, marking scripts at speed, without professional back-up. He called for large-scale experiments in "residential marking", releasing examiners from other duties to work full-time for a week marking scripts under the supervision of senior examiners. fields.headline: Could do better
fields.standfirst: Nick Tate, chief executive of the QCA, warns that computer marking and super examiners may be needed
fields.trailText: Nick Tate, chief executive of the QCA, warns that computer marking and super examiners may be needed
fields.body:
As a society we are preoccupied with assessment. Never have so many been tested, for so long, and under such public scrutiny. There are formal assessments for five-, seven-, 11- and 14-year-olds, GCSEs, A and AS levels, GNVQs, NVQs, university degrees, not to mention thousands of other qualifications.

So it is not surprising that the awarding bodies are under the spotlight. It isn't just that more people are now being examined. It is also that the stakes are getting higher. This is especially true of A levels at a time of increasing participation in higher education. We also live in a world that is increasingly litigious. Forty years ago, when I first took public examinations, there were more awarding bodies, fewer quality controls and limited mechanisms for ensuring comparability - and yet hardly anyone ever thought of contesting their grades.

Awarding bodies today conduct their business much more openly and are constantly monitored by the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority. Problems therefore inevitably loom larger. Whether and to what extent they are greater is difficult to say, though recent mergers between awarding bodies have clearly added to the strain.

Despite an unprecedented level of queries, only 0.5% of all GCSE or A-level grades awarded are subsequently changed. But this represents a large number of individuals and gives no room for complacency. Errors and difficulties in ensuring consistent assessment also have a bigger effect on some subjects than others. At A level in particular, the matter is very serious: university places and life chances are at stake.

A lot of effort has already gone into picking up problems at an early stage, putting them right, and analysing how best to improve on previous practice. Markers are closely supervised; large numbers of scripts on grade borderlines are double-checked; consistency of standards between awarding bodies, syllabuses and years is carefully monitored; and QCA, as exams regulator, scrutinises every aspect of the process.

But even more can be done, and new measures are being introduced.

First, best practice in examining has been incorporated in a new mandatory common code that comes into force this month and will apply to all qualifications.

Second, awarding bodies will now be required to issue customer service statements specifying performance measures against which they will be held to account.

Third, to ensure public account ability, QCA later this year will start making publicly available its monitoring reports on individual awarding bodies and qualifications.

Fourth, targets have been set to ensure that awarding bodies process queries about results with due speed. The first report showing the extent to which these targets have been met will be issued in March. As a final court of appeal, the government has set up a new independent Examinations Appeals Board. In addition, all A-level and some GCSE candidates, following a recent decision by David Blunkett, will have access to their marked scripts for the first time.

Finally, awarding will only become more consistent if we keep numbers of qualifications to a sensible minimum. There is a firm remit in this area from government. The first step will be to reduce the number of A-level syllabuses next September from 250 to 150.

Two further challenges remain. The first is how best to make use of new technology. Not only has progress in this area been slow, but some recent difficulties can be attributed to teething problems in using information and communication technology. And yet ICT is potentially a solution to a range of issues, through ICT-based examinations, computer marking and greater use of electronic communication between markers, awarding bodies and centres. QCA is exploring several approaches, including ICT-based tests and the electronic return of marked A-level and GCSE scripts to centres.

The second, and maybe biggest, issue facing the exam system is how best to recruit enough high-quality markers. The challenge is all the greater now that students will be doing even more exams following recent reforms. Long-term solutions may have to include greater use of computer marking, increased expenditure on building up a cadre of experienced markers, and tough-minded decisions about whether current levels of external assessment are indefinitely sustainable. In the short term, getting across the message that exam marking is a valuable part of teachers' professional development must be a top priority. It would be a good start to the new decade if current initiatives in professional development and appraisal stimulated renewed interest in this crucial part of a teacher's role.

 Dr Nicholas Tate is chief executive of the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority.

fields.headline: Count me in
fields.standfirst: All children have got to get to grips with maths - this is the message at the start of Maths Year 2000 - and parents can help a lot
fields.trailText: All children have got to get to grips with maths - this is the message at the start of Maths Year 2000 - and parents can help a lot
fields.body:
Maths is everywhere and we use it all the time. That is the message being put out in no uncertain terms by the government at the start of Maths Year 2000. Reading between the lines, the more gloomy prognosis is that anyone who fails to get to grips with the subject will be at a serious disadvantage throughout their lives.

Parents have a key role to play in helping their children with maths, and one of the most important aims of Maths Year 2000 - a year of specially targeted activities designed to underpin the national numeracy strategy - is convincing them that they can make a positive difference. Youngsters who get off to a bad start with maths may take their fear or lack of confidence through into adulthood, and parents can encourage familiarity with numbers while their offspring are still babies, counting their fingers and toes and using numerical rhymes.

Then throughout primary school and even into secondary school, they can help their children use and enjoy maths in everyday situations such as driving, shopping and playing games. Other household activities such as gardening, sewing, DIY, car maintenance and mechanics and cooking all use maths in the form of weighing, measuring, estimating, budgeting, timing and calculating at different levels. Rather than hamper more formal learning at school, this kind of regular experience will complement it and build on it. Working closely with schools, they can prepare their children for the challenge of maths ahead in life as well as exams.

Alan Newland, the headteacher of an east London primary school, explains that there is a real uphill struggle to counter the many phobias, negative preconceptions and fears about maths which adults carry round with them like emotional baggage. For many, passing mathematics GCSE or O level at school, which is still the standard passport to other courses and jobs, is the means to an end, which they could put behind them - an attitude that invariably rubs off onto their children. The widespread use of calculators has inevitably made people lazy about mental arithmetic. And the perceived difficulty of A-level maths means that many people never stretch themselves by progressing beyond GCSE.

So by the time our children are teenagers, they see maths as an "unfashionable" subject in which it is acceptable to under-achieve. Our generally poor standards of maths are reflected in international league tables, which show that Britain lags behind other European countries in mental arithmetic and calculations, although we do better on shape and space. And how many times have ministers and education chiefs been pilloried for failing to be able to do simple calculations?

Newland explained that parents often didn't know how they could help their children and did not want to interfere. "While it is easy for parents to sit down with their children at night and read a book, with maths there are many more barriers. Parents are often worried that the maths they did years ago is out of date. There are techniques and procedures around maths which seem to be very didactic. They may see unfamiliar layout for sums in their children's exercise books, and comments like 'my teacher doesn't do it like that' clearly don't help. This may sap their confidence, and make them think they should leave everything to the school."

Instead, the Department for Education and Employment's twin-pronged approach with Maths Year 2000 is to try and encourage partnership between schools and parents, while raising the visibility of maths for parents. After all, parents have a huge store of maths knowledge. "Maths is often invisible to the untrained eye," said Newland. "But you only have to go into a supermarket to see it is absolutely everywhere. It is not just about counting and weighing, but about seeing things packaged in groups, and working out discounts on prices. For many parents, shopping is a chore when they want their child not to be a nuisance, when in fact it can be an educative experience. Familiarity with number can be helped in all these everyday situations."

Teachers are also being encouraged to use supermarkets as a learning facility, with the supermarket giant Asda, for example, offering a scheme called "The Big Sum" involving "numeracy trails" in selected stores. Tesco has a similar project called "It All Adds Up".

Parents also worry about not having the right resources for helping their children with maths when, again, there are useful tools in our homes and elsewhere. A useful first exercise to try with youngsters, for example, is to measure them on the floor with spoons. You can try different lengths of spoons and ask them if they could do the same thing with other cutlery. This teaches them about non-standard measurements by using familiar objects.

If partnership between schools and parents is key to the new approach, there are already many good examples of good practice. The now well-established Impact project (Maths with Parents, Children and Teachers), based at the University of North London, uses homework materials designed to be shared between parents and children using the resources of the home. It is now being regularly used by around a quarter of all primary schools.

Parents are advised to look out for maths events and projects at their children's schools in the coming year, which may include maths evenings, chess and board-game clubs for children, and even parent groups designed to help boost maths skills. And you can always take the initiative and volunteer your own services! Watch out for the many regional Maths Year 2000 MathFests, too.

And bear in mind that, despite its name, Maths Year 2000 is not a one-off. Instead, it is part of an on-going drive to raise standards of numeracy across all age groups and within all sections of the community, and will underpin the national numeracy strategy.

Hagley school takes away the fear of maths

Youngsters at Hagley First school near Kidderminster in the West Midlands have no fear of maths, and their parents - predominantly "professionals" - show a keen interest in their teaching.

Headteacher Kerry Morgan once taught maths at the University of Warwick, and he believes in stretching his pupils by making the subject fun, without pushing them beyond their abilities. The school, which introduced the compulsory numeracy hour early, uses the Impact scheme, and parents can buy a homework kit for between £3 and £5.

New entrants to the school - which takes 350 children aged between four and nine - are given the chance to play with "giant calculators" and squidgy dice before moving on to laptop computers and spreadsheets. A weekly drop-in class gives pupils the chance to try out more advanced maths without being "hothoused" or removed from their peers.

fields.headline: Be prepared
fields.standfirst: Unlike postgrads in the arts, students doing PhDs in life sciences may soon be compelled to complete a research Masters before embarking on the lonely road to a doctorate.  Lee Elliot Major explains that students will learn molecular biology, management - and a dose of realism
fields.trailText: Unlike postgrads in the arts, students doing PhDs in life sciences may soon be compelled to complete a research Masters before embarking on the lonely road to a doctorate. Lee Elliot Major explains that students will learn molecular biology, management - and a dose of realism
fields.body:
A cultural divide between the sciences and arts could emerge in postgraduate training in universities as a result of proposals from two sets of leading academics. Less than a week after an arts and humanities report poured cold water on the need for PhD students to first take research Masters degrees, a group representing the life sciences community called for an expansion of the one-year postgraduate qualification, which aims to teach students vocational and research skills.

The two reports, published last month, add to the continuing debate in government and academic circles over the need for reforms to the financing and organisation of PhD training. Concerns over falling quality in students applying for PhD places have prompted calls from the research councils for higher stipends, despite the recent increase in minimum annual grants for science PhDs by £1,000 to £6,445.

The Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council, meanwhile, is consulting on proposals which will for the first time allow universities to decide the level and duration of grants for research students as part of overall PhD training packages.

The government, though, has developed a reputation in the past decade for much discussion but little action in the area of postgraduate training. One problem is that it is the responsibility of two departments - the Office of Science and Technology and the Department for Education and Employment - and ends up being addressed by neither. But the issue is now being treated more seriously, with growing recognition that the vast majority of PhDs no longer end up in academic jobs.

A report commissioned by the UK Life Sciences Committee resurrects one of the central debates over research training: should all PhD students first undertake a research Masters degree? After much deliberation, the group of academic and industry representatives from the biological sciences came up with a resounding "yes".

The group wants an immediate expansion of the research Masters scheme for the same reasons as the government when it first suggested the new qualification in the 1993 science white paper. The aim of the Masters is to introduce students to what few understand when signing four years of their life away for a PhD: what a research career is actually about. For those who realise that academia is not for them, the MRes degree offers a respected vocational route for improving job opportunities.

For those who do take the PhD plunge, the group say that the MRes provides a grounding in the fundamentals of modern molecular biology and management skills - both likely to be needed in industry or universities. "We recommend a 3+1+3-year structure for the training of most life scientists to the PhD level. This is best achieved by significant expansion in MRes provision," says the report. "In contrast with the situation in the physical sciences, there is little support for a lengthened undergraduate degree in the life sciences."

But what is right for biologists is not necessarily right for those in arts and humanities, suggests a separate report for the UK Council for Graduate Education. With the formation of the first overarching national body for the community, the Arts and Humanities Research Board, these are exciting times for research policy makers in the arts and humanities. But suggestions from the AHRB that it, too, might promote the MRes degree as a precursor to PhD study have been met with opposition.

"The working group agreed that Masters programmes have an important role in preparation for a research degree, and welcomes AHRB's 1+3 funding model," concludes the report. "But the working group recommends the AHRB should not see Masters programmes as providing all the training, development and support a prospective research student will need."

The academics, from a broad range of disciplines in the arts and humanities, argue for a "needs based" approach to research training, with each PhD student agreeing their own unique training schedule. The report says: "The AHRB should not establish a system to recognise specific Masters programmes as a preparation for research, but should put in place procedures to assure itself that the "needs based" approach advocated in this report is provided to all humanities research students."

Intriguingly, the life scientists also propose a "one size does not fit all" approach to PhD training: "Universities and research institutes would bid for training grants, the packages covering all cost elements. They would allow for flexibility in both stipend and duration of training (subject to minimal standards)," says the report. "This would pass much more responsibility to the universities, who can assess local markets and conditions. The aim is to tailor far more precisely postgraduate training to the needs of the student."

It remains to be seen if the research councils, or the AHRB, will be convinced by a new free-market approach to PhD training, particularly as this has been resisted in universities for both recruitment of undergraduates and lecturers.

 Dr Lee Elliot is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

The Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council, meanwhile, is consulting on proposals which will for the first time allow universities to decide the level and duration of grants for research students as part of overall PhD training packages. The government, though, has developed a reputation in the past decade for much discussion but little action in the area of postgraduate training. One problem is that it is the responsibility of two departments - the Office of Science and Technology and the Department for Education and Employment - and ends up being addressed by neither. But the issue is now being treated more seriously, with growing recognition that the vast majority of PhDs no longer end up in academic jobs. A report commissioned by the UK Life Sciences Committee resurrects one of the central debates over research training: should all PhD students first undertake a research Masters degree? After much deliberation, the group of academic and industry representatives from the biological sciences came up with a resounding "yes". The group wants an immediate expansion of the research Masters scheme for the same reasons as the government when it first suggested the new qualification in the 1993 science white paper. The aim of the Masters is to introduce students to what few understand when signing four years of their life away for a PhD: what a research career is actually about. For those who realise that academia is not for them, the MRes degree offers a respected vocational route for improving job opportunities. For those who do take the PhD plunge, the group say that the MRes provides a grounding in the fundamentals of modern molecular biology and management skills - both likely to be needed in industry or universities. "We recommend a 3+1+3-year structure for the training of most life scientists to the PhD level. This is best achieved by significant expansion in MRes provision," says the report. "In contrast with the situation in the physical sciences, there is little support for a lengthened undergraduate degree in the life sciences." But what is right for biologists is not necessarily right for those in arts and humanities, suggests a separate report for the UK Council for Graduate Education. With the formation of the first overarching national body for the community, the Arts and Humanities Research Board, these are exciting times for research policy makers in the arts and humanities. But suggestions from the AHRB that it, too, might promote the MRes degree as a precursor to PhD study have been met with opposition. "The working group agreed that Masters programmes have an important role in preparation for a research degree, and welcomes AHRB's 1+3 funding model," concludes the report. "But the working group recommends the AHRB should not see Masters programmes as providing all the training, development and support a prospective research student will need." The academics, from a broad range of disciplines in the arts and humanities, argue for a "needs based" approach to research training, with each PhD student agreeing their own unique training schedule. The report says: "The AHRB should not establish a system to recognise specific Masters programmes as a preparation for research, but should put in place procedures to assure itself that the "needs based" approach advocated in this report is provided to all humanities research students." Intriguingly, the life scientists also propose a "one size does not fit all" approach to PhD training: "Universities and research institutes would bid for training grants, the packages covering all cost elements. They would allow for flexibility in both stipend and duration of training (subject to minimal standards)," says the report. "This would pass much more responsibility to the universities, who can assess local markets and conditions. The aim is to tailor far more precisely postgraduate training to the needs of the student." It remains to be seen if the research councils, or the AHRB, will be convinced by a new free-market approach to PhD training, particularly as this has been resisted in universities for both recruitment of undergraduates and lecturers.  Dr Lee Elliot is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

fields.headline: Cool Britannia
fields.standfirst: A government drive to attract more foreign students aims to ditch Britain's pompous, cold image for good
fields.trailText: A government drive to attract more foreign students aims to ditch Britain's pompous, cold image for good
fields.body:
Overseas students may stay on and work in this country after finishing their degrees, Baroness Blackstone announced as part of a drive to shed Britain's unfriendly image.

Speaking at the launch of UK Education - a brand image to market universities, colleges and independent schools abroad - she said the government was reassessing the whole work permit system to back up its worldwide campaign to attract more students.

The campaign follows research for the British Council which found the positive image of quality and tradition had a negative flipside of British people being seen "as cold as their climate". At a practical level there were complaints about the lack of scholarships compared with north America, criticism of student welfare and accommodation and difficulties over part-time working during the course and work after it finished.

Inadequate investment in facilities was seen as a sign of complacency.

Baroness Blackstone said the government took these matters seriously. Entry and visa procedures were being streamlined. New arrangements were in place in New Delhi and being extended to Islamabad and Beijing. Immigration officials would now normally give students permission to stay for the full duration of the course rather than six months when they arrived. Overseas students would not now have to seek permission from job centres to work part-time during terms or full-time in the vacations. Spouses and dependants would also be able to work here.

Students would be able to stay until the end of October following their course and would also be permitted to work for up to two years in a job related to their degree to gain experience - working in video production following a media studies course, for instance.

"We are sharpening our response to the needs of international students. Changes have been introduced to improve our welcome and the affordability of UK study," she told the launch at King's College London.

A £5m marketing campaign to help recruit 50,000 extra higher education students and 25,000 more into further education colleges by 2005 will be based on the new brand. Baroness Blackstone stressed that welcoming more international students would not mean home students being excluded.

In marketing-speak the "brand footprint" of UK Education is supposed to mean "a dynamic tradition, the new world class, being the best I can be". It is to be "responsive, welcoming, alive with possibilities". The Brand Report for the British Council says the brand footprint currently involves quality and confidence but is also set in its ways.

Australian education is seen as accessible, relaxed and matey - the image purveyed by Crocodile Dundee and soaps. The US is seen as forward-thinking and the land of opportunity. For young people Hollywood strongly influences their view of the British - "loveably eccentric but also pompous stuffed shirts who are complacent within their rigid class system".

Blair's vision of Britain as a modern-minded country with a more positive attitude to Europe provides an "unmissable opportunity" to redress these negative images in their minds, argues the report.

The UK Education campaign is a response to aggressive marketing by Australia, particularly in Asia. A one-stop shop in Singapore, for instance, provides information on applications, visas, accommodation, counselling on study options and pre-departure orientation. It also reflects the success of Scottish universities and colleges combining to market themselves abroad.

webTitle: Academics move to reclaim the web

fields.headline: Academics move to reclaim the web
fields.standfirst: A mega-merger between internet research services can only make life easier
fields.trailText: A mega-merger between internet research services can only make life easier
fields.body:
As the closing date for the current research assessment exercise gets closer, many academics are frantically seeking opportunities to get into print.

But keeping up with all the new publications and ensuring you are being seen is being made ever easier. "The internet was started by academics and I see this as a way they can reclaim it," says businessman Mark Rowse, chief executive of ingenta, and now also owner of the Bath Information and Data Services (Bids).

Last week ingenta merged with UnCover in the US to create the world's largest service for websearch and delivery of research articles. The merger gives one million librarians and researchers access to the full text of 750,000 articles from over 2,300 journals.

Rowse has deals with important academic publishers to put their journals online, linking original published work and its citation elsewhere. At www.ingenta.com, rather than looking at all publishers' websites, researchers and students can not only look at all the major publications in a field in one place, but also be referred to journals outside their own discipline.

Figures produced by the independent Database Resources Research Group show that in both the 1992 and 1996 research assessment exercises, there was a high degree of correlation (0.83) between departments graded as 4-, 5- or 5-star and the amount they used the Bids database.

Last month ingenta announced that Elsevier Science is to integrate its 1,000 titles into Bids Academic Services. Among those signed up are Oxford University Press, Blackwell's, the Economist Intelligence Unit and the Royal Geographical and Pharmaceutical Societies. Academic publishing worldwide is estimated to be worth $4.5bn, with a readership of between 50 and 100 million, most of whom will have web access. Some 12,000 publishers of all sizes produce 168,000 titles, although only 2,500 titles are seen as "core" publications across all disciplines.

ingenta began in September 1998 by taking over Bids, a national bibliographic online research resource set up in Bath by the Higher Education Funding Council in 1991. Bids took a 25% stake in ingenta and a contract to host the expanded service which has 350,000 users accessing 20 million summaries a month in 500,000 sessions. There are 500,000 full-text articles online, and 20 million extracts going back to 1973.

Bath hosts the ISI Citation Indexes, covering science, social sciences, arts, humanities and technical subjects; Excerpta Medica, covering 3,000 journals relating to pharmacology and biomedicine; Compendex*Plus with 1,800 engineering journals and conferences and EcoFlora, covering British plants. ISI is moving to Manchester next year, and ingenta will replace it with the more Euro-centred Pascal dataset from September.

ingenta is not the only such service provider, but by signing up the publishers who pay ingenta, it can offer academics a supermarket and access to all the products in a discipline, not just those of one publisher.

In the medical field, say, a children's disease might be accessed by a researcher in a medical publication, but with a reference to research into the social and economic background to the condition. Summaries are often up to 10% of the whole length, and if you want a paper for which you don't have a subscription it can be bought online with a credit card.

In an electronic world, special interest groups - high-energy physicists, for instance - communicate directly with each other. There are also specialist online publications in areas like molecular chemistry, where visuals are critical and can only be viewed usefully with computer graphics.

In some cases online publishing is increasing sales of the printed versions of the same journals. MCB University Press, Bradford, who produce a specialist list of management publications such as The European Journal of Marketing, has recently signed up with ingenta. Online access to all MCB publications can be bought for under £10,000, whereas one journal might cost more than £2,000 a year for just five issues.

"By paying to make our content available, we have reached a much wider audience than with the printed material," says brand manager Mathew Wills. "We are seeing much more use of our publications and their being cited more often. This has generated new revenues for the printed versions."

fields.headline: Simply impossible
fields.standfirst: Whitehall is desperate for academic researchers to substitute clarity for jargon
fields.trailText: Whitehall is desperate for academic researchers to substitute clarity for jargon
fields.body:
Education secretary David Blunkett will this week urge university researchers to do away with academic jargon and make their findings more accessible to government officials to help them deliver more effective policies.

The speech is part of wider government reforms to modernise the workings of Whitehall, guided by New Labour's declaration that "what works is what counts", and aimed at developing policies based on relevant evidence rather than political ideals.

But Cabinet Office civil servants have identified a major obstacle to the newfound thirst for knowledge: Whitehall mandarins find it hard to understand what experts are saying.

"Where technical and scientific research does exist it is important to ensure that it is in a form which is accessible to generalist policy makers," a recent investigation into current departmental practices by the Cabinet Office concluded. "But our interviews revealed anecdotal evidence that little of the research commissioned by departments or other academic research was used by policy makers."

While Blunkett's talk, organised by the Economic and Social Research Council, does not exclusively concern educational researchers, they are at the forefront of efforts to translate academic jargon into plain English. This week academics are discussing proposals for "user reviews" of research papers to present findings to a lay audience. The need for such reviews was highlighted by the government's chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, when he said that he no longer wasted time "decoding unintelligible prose" in academic journals.

But the reputation of academics in general as the culprits of pompous gobbledygook was sealed in 1998, when a Birmingham University professor won the plain English campaign's Golden Bull Award for a research project entitled The Measurement of Consumer Criteria for Manufacturer Parameter Values in Biscuit Texture. It turned out that the project aimed to tell whether crunchy biscuits tasted nice. The campaign say that unlike most recipients of the award, the professor took it badly, accusing them of being Luddites.

Five years ago the social sciences suffered a major embarrassment in the miscommunication stakes, when New York University physics professor Alan Sokal got a hoax paper on "Transgressing the Boundaries: towards a transformative hermeneutics of quantum gravity" accepted by a sociology journal. Later Sokal said that the paper was made up of "syntactically correct sentences that have no meaning whatsoever".

With public concerns over issues such as food safety and genetic science, a major failing of many government departments is that they are not organised or prepared to make the best possible use of science and technology, concluded Cabinet Office investigators. "Our evidence suggests that the same is true of social and economic research," says the report.

"While there is plenty of research available in areas such as education, social services and criminal justice, the coverage is patchy and there is little consensus amongst the research community about the appropriateness of particular methodologies or how research evidence should be used to inform policy and practice," says the group's report. "Although there are examples of good practice, in some areas of policy the generation and use of information and research in policy making is not as strong as it needs to be to support the government's pragmatic approach."

Apart from a campaign to get researchers to present findings more clearly, the government is introducing a number of schemes to improve civil servants' skills in making the best use of research.

A new centre for management and policy studies in the Cabinet Office "will provide a window at the heart of government for the best new thinking from the academic community". And officials are to borrow one of the defining features of the academic world - peer review - when drafting new policies. Under the plans, officials will for the first time be able to comment on the work of other departments.

Some senior civil servants remain sceptical about the pragmatic approach. Research produces as many questions as answers, and often makes decisions more difficult, they say. And as Blunkett has found, academic findings often run counter to received wisdom. Last year he said that "no one with the slightest commonsense could take seriously" suggestions by Durham University researchers that homework is bad for you.

 Dr Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

webTitle: Losing our tongues just when we need them

fields.headline: Losing our tongues just when we need them
fields.standfirst: As applications for languages fall once more,  Hilary Footitt calls for action
fields.trailText: As applications for languages fall once more, Hilary Footitt calls for action
fields.body:
A black-dog fatalism is settling over the whole issue of languages in higher education. We know that the number of students taking A level languages has been declining. At the end of December, the Higher Education Funding Council for England (HEFCE) wrote to vice-chancellors, pointing out that recruitment trends to modern languages degrees were indeed changing and asking what responses they were intending to make.

Officially it seems, then, that languages have become a "problem area", perhaps replacing physics or engineering as the subject whose recruitment patterns cause deep concern. As we turn the millennium corner into our new globalised world, it seems young people are more reluctant to study languages at university, and that there is nothing much anyone feels can or should be done about this.

Yet if you look at it from the other end, from the employment market, you find that language graduates have one of the lowest unemployment rates - 4.2% for German, 4.3% for French - of any subject. It is lower than computing, 6%, business administration, 6.3%, and media studies, 7.5% (source: HESA 1999, table 2f). London First, the organisation responsible for attracting inward investment to the capital, has argued that it is because employers can find multilingual skills in London that they will relocate there. The importance of being able to communicate in a foreign language, and understand foreign cultures, far from being dismissed by employers, is already highly prized.

Ironically, again, whilst some university linguists may face declining numbers of post-A-level candidates, they often find themselves submerged by students from other disciplines adding to their portfolio of skills, using the university in effect as a last-chance saloon to fill gaps in their language-learning: the engineering student whose school wasn't in a position to offer Spanish, the first-year law student who never got round to German.

Language learning in HE has never been more vital to the economy, and language graduates have seldom been more in demand. This is why it would be a grave mistake to see the "problem" of languages in HE as divorced from the wider issues of the future language needs of our population in the 21st century, and the ways in which we organise language-learning.

First of all, the climate in which we are operating is moving fast. Historic A-level data takes no account of the rapidly developing environment in which the structure of post-16 education is changing, and providing potentially increased opportunities for students to do languages post-GCSE.

Secondly, there is growing evidence that our national competitors believe that language competence is a key skill for every graduate. 2001 is to be the European Year of Languages. The European Commission is arguing that "solid language skills are crucial for enterprises' ability to exploit the potential of the Single Market and to remain competitive in an increasingly globalised and mobile economy". Far from being irrelevant to the next five years, language departments in HE should be poised to become key players in developing the linguistic and cultural resources that are nationally needed.

But what is to happen now? Clearly language departments in universities and language associations in HE have a responsibility to talk together about the future of languages, and have begun to do this. They have a responsibility to talk to employers and teachers about the opportunities language-learning represents, and are doing this. But language learning in universities is a national issue which universities alone, and their financially hard-pressed vice-chancellors, cannot deal with in isolation.

If universities cannot produce the future language teachers for secondary, let alone primary schools - and there are now golden hellos to get linguists into teaching - we will be in a spiral of language decline. What is urgently needed is joined-up thinking that sees language learning as a national all-through provision, from school, to university, to continuing education.

At least now we have a National Languages Inquiry, backed by Nuffield, whose remit - they report in the spring - is to stimulate a more holistic understanding of how the country can acquire its language skills and its informed openness to other cultures.

It is excellent that our prime minister leads from the front by speaking a foreign language. It would be even better if languages and the importance of language-learning were to move to the forefront of our national debates this year, in preparation for the 2001 Year of Languages.

 Hilary Footitt is chair of the University Council of Modern Languages.
