fields.headline: Queer as friends
fields.standfirst: A new series of Queer As Folk is about to hit the small screen and if the last run is anything to go by, the majority of its audience will be female.  Jenny Madden examines women's relationships with gay men
fields.trailText: Later this month, the much anticipated sequel to Queer As Folk will air on Channel 4. When the first series was shown last year, it provoked much controversy, both inside and outside the gay community.
fields.body:
Later this month, the much anticipated sequel to Queer As Folk will air on Channel 4. When the first series was shown last year, it provoked much controversy, both inside and outside the gay community. While gay rights campaigners complained that it portrayed gay men as sex maniacs, the tabloids dubbed the show "Eastbenders!" which is odd considering it's set over 200 miles from the East End, in Manchester.

The first series of the deviant drama was very popular in the gay community but, much to the apparent surprise of the show's producer, the largest audience share, at over 50%, was made up of women. While some may say the viewing figures point to nothing more staggering than the fact that there are more women than gay men in the country, others have suggested that women's enjoyment of Queer As Folk is symptomatic of something more complex in the female psyche. In a recent interview, Nicky Schindler, the show's producer, said: "Women love to watch men who feel safe. It's the same reason boy bands are popular with young girls - it's the hint of sex without anyone having a penis."

For anyone who has watched the programme, the assertion that the sex involved amounts to a "hint" will seem odd. Do three-in-a-bed romps, masturbation, shower scenes, sex in a toilet, sex on the internet and sex perpetually on the brains of the cast really constitute only a hint?

If women's enjoyment of QAF is about sex, then isn't it simply for the God-I-can't-believe-they're-showing- this-on-TV-it's-so-graphic sex? After all, should it be so surprising that women have fantasies about fit, tanned men writhing around in bed together? So hard to believe that women can get the same kind of thrill watching this series as a man can get watching a lesbian skin flick?

But Schindler has put forward another reason as to why QAF holds a special appeal to women: its central theme of unrequited love. "I can totally see why women loved it. It's about unrequited love, something all of us have experienced countless times."

This Brontë-esque theme is an appealing one but if it is a theme more attractive to women, it is probably simply because it makes a refreshing change to see a man playing the part of the angst-ridden heroine pining after the heart of the cold distant hero, rather than the usual woman doing the old "He's a bastard but I love him" routine.

It is unsurprising that women's interest in Queer As Folk has prompted cod psychologising. There is an idea that women and gay men enjoy a particular type of bond, an idea that, if it is backed up at all rather than being left hanging in the air as one of those things you're just supposed to agree with, is done through the use of generalisations. These range from the insulting ("They are as soppy and emotional/ interested in their appearance as each other") to the standard ("Gay men are more glamorous/fun/open/ easy to talk to and they don't go on about football and beer the way straight men do"). All are ill thought-out notions that pigeonhole gay men, insult straight men and will seem daft to most women who have enjoyed friendships with either.

Then there is the idea that women and gay men are close because they are both oppressed, a particularly victimy kind of theory used by the particularly victimy Bridget Jones and her gay friend Tom who believes that single women in their 30s and gay men are close because both are accustomed to disappointing their parents and being regarded by society as freaks. This notion, that women and gay men are joined together by the chains of their oppression, serves only to provide women with another chance to identify themselves as victims. Excellent - exactly what we needed.

There are no universal laws about women's relationships with gay men precisely because there are no universal laws about why women choose any of the friends they do. A friend of mine lived with a gay guy at university because they were doing the same subjects and helped each other out. Another became friendly with a guy who was gay because they ended up in the same flatshare and started going down to the pub together. Lager, you could say, was what held them together.

Legendary theatrical agent Peggy Ramsay was best friends with gay actor Simon Callow for 10 years, not because sex was subtracted from the equation. In fact Ramsay laboured long under the impression that Callow was heterosexual, going so far as to make the embarrassing faux pas of trying to seduce him before she found out he wasn't. Their mutual love of the arts, theatre and bitchy gossip provided enough reason to remain close.

Mary Austin, Freddie Mercury's girlfriend for six years, until he decided he preferred men, remained the star's closest friend and confidante until his death, upon which he left her a 50% share of his wealth. She had initially been attracted to the star by his confidence - a trait she felt lacking in herself.

Aside from the much derided fag hags - the small minority of women who seek out an especially camp, drama queenish type of gay man in order to have someone to dance with on a club podium - most women choose their friends for their qualities as human beings, not for their sexual persuasion. Women enjoyed Queer As Folk because women like well-acted, well-written drama, with the added bonus of a bit of attractive male flesh. I know that's what I'll be tuning in for.

fields.headline: Bush could lose first primary
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Republican John McCain is poised to score a political upset today by defeating the frontrunner for his party's presidential nomination, George W Bush, in the New Hampshire primary vote, three polls showed yesterday.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Concord, New Hampshire
fields.body:
Republican John McCain is poised to score a political upset today by defeating the frontrunner for his party's presidential nomination, George W Bush, in the New Hampshire primary vote, three polls showed yesterday.

Among the Democratic hopefuls, Vice-President Al Gore is favourite to defeat Bill Bradley in the New Hampshire contest, the same polls predict.

Three daily tracking polls in the state give Mr McCain, an Arizona senator, an average of 38%, ahead of Mr Bush on 35%. Millionaire publisher Steve Forbes trails a distant third on 15%. The largest poll, by Gallup for CNN, shows Mr McCain heading towards a crushing 42% to win. With just hours to go before the first votes are cast in the first primary contest of the presidential race, the Bush-McCain race continued to underscore that the Republican battle is a contest between two rival political cultures.

Mr Bush is the anointed choice of a free-spending corporate Republican hierarchy which has invested unlimited dollars in the Texas governor as the man to take revenge on Bill Clinton's Democrats, who ousted Mr Bush's father from the presidency in 1992.

Mr Bush has run a perfectly scripted campaign, and for a week has been surrounded by Republican grandees including his parents and Elizabeth Dole, who is campaigning for the vice-presidential spot on the Bush ticket.

Yesterday several photo set-ups were designed to convey his matey, middle-of-the-road appeal for the voters. In Manchester, Mr Bush was accompanied by wife Laura as he flipped pancakes in a restaurant, before a lunchtime walkabout in Exeter. In the evening he was due to visit the local bowling alley, where he was sure to bowl a strike or two in front of the cameras.

Mr McCain, by contrast, is increasingly the anti-establishment candidate, detested by Mr Bush's backers. He spent yesterday criss-crossing New Hampshire for the last time in his Straight Talk Express bus, stopping in five towns to conduct the unscripted chats with voters and reporters that have become the hallmark of his freewheeling campaign.

At a campaign stop with military veterans at Franklin, the former Vietnam war pilot and prisoner told supporters: "Let's go down to the old soldiers' home and blow the cavalry charge again. Let's get fired up."

Mr McCain told his audience: "We've had everything going against us. The organisation, the money, all the big names, all of that kind of stuff. The party establishment wants to finish me off, because I will break the iron triangle in Washington of money, lobbying and legislation."

With the polls showing that up to a third of voters could change their minds in the last hours, and another bout of wintry weather in New Hampshire yesterday, both camps claimed it would be a close contest. Mr McCain needs a win here to have any chance of carrying his rebel army into the primaries elsewhere.

In the Democratic race, meanwhile, Mr Gore appeared to be heading for a second victory after last week's success in the Iowa caucuses. The latest Gallup poll gave him a 51% to 45% margin over Mr Bradley, but there were signs that the gap was narrowing.

After weeks in which both candidates had praised each other politely, the gloves came off at the weekend with Mr Bradley accusing Mr Gore of being inconsistent on abortion rights. Mr Gore accused his challenger of "personal vilification" and "manipulative, negative politics".

He spent yesterday criss-crossing New Hampshire for the last time in his Straight Talk Express bus, stopping in five towns to conduct the unscripted chats with voters and reporters that have become the hallmark of his freewheeling campaign. At a campaign stop with military veterans at Franklin, the former Vietnam war pilot and prisoner told supporters: "Let's go down to the old soldiers' home and blow the cavalry charge again. Let's get fired up." Mr McCain told his audience: "We've had everything going against us. The organisation, the money, all the big names, all of that kind of stuff. The party establishment wants to finish me off, because I will break the iron triangle in Washington of money, lobbying and legislation." With the polls showing that up to a third of voters could change their minds in the last hours, and another bout of wintry weather in New Hampshire yesterday, both camps claimed it would be a close contest. Mr McCain needs a win here to have any chance of carrying his rebel army into the primaries elsewhere. In the Democratic race, meanwhile, Mr Gore appeared to be heading for a second victory after last week's success in the Iowa caucuses. The latest Gallup poll gave him a 51% to 45% margin over Mr Bradley, but there were signs that the gap was narrowing. After weeks in which both candidates had praised each other politely, the gloves came off at the weekend with Mr Bradley accusing Mr Gore of being inconsistent on abortion rights. Mr Gore accused his challenger of "personal vilification" and "manipulative, negative politics".

webTitle: Women who work and drink hard

fields.headline: Women who work and drink hard
fields.trailText: Drinking into the night is the favourite form of stress relief for 20-something women looking for relaxation after work, according to figures published by Company magazine
fields.body:
Drinking into the night is the favourite form of stress relief for 20-something women looking for relaxation after work, according to figures published by Company magazine

The time when partying was restricted to Friday and Saturday nights is in the past, with one in three people choosing to go out late on Thursdays and a fifth admitting to going out late on a Monday.

The trend is led by 20-something women, with 53% in London admitting they regularly go out for a drink after work.

Dubbed the After Hours Home Avoiders, AH-HAs, these women are committed to working and playing hard, enjoying a packed social life and relishing their freedom.

The magazine cites the change in the average age of women having children as one of the main reasons for the phenomenon.

It states that women in their 20s have more time to socialise because they are not looking to have children until their 30s.

Jim Murphy, director of Model Reasoning, a company that forecasts social trends, said the phenomenon was also due to the need for escape after a long day.

"People in the UK work the longest hours in Europe," he said. "Not only does this mean that they have to cram their socialising into a shorter period of time, they also want a quick escape from work and their pressured lifestyles."

However, Justine Long, team leader at the Women's Alcohol Centre in London, warned that the lifestyle could have very damaging effects.

"A lot of women we see started drinking after work to alleviate the stresses of the day," she said. "The problem is that it doesn't help. You feel hungover the next day, it's harder to cope with your job so you feel more stressed and need to go down the pub even more."

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: How many of you working mothers have been naughty girls, then? Have you been reading stories to your child before you go to work? Or, worse, washed your hair?
fields.body:
How many of you working mothers have been naughty girls, then? Have you been reading stories to your child before you go to work? Or, worse, washed your hair? If so, says Shirley Conran, you are a "lunatic". The unsympathetic author of 60s book Superwoman expressed her frustration with this generation of women in the Sunday Times, saying that today, working is every woman's personal decision. The words planet and earth are obviously filed in different folders of Shirley's Psion.

Remember, dear readers, the 1986 music video that had an ageing rocker in a suit strutting in front of a group of women in identical minis, red lipstick and slicked-back hair? Well, Robert Palmer "didn't have anything to do with it". No, the Addicted To Love video that has come to exemplify a representation of women as robotic objects was photographer Terence Donovan's idea. All poor old Palmer did was perform to camera, then scoot back to the Bahamas, he told the Mail on Sunday. Donovan must have hit Palmer's spot, however: he went on to make two more videos with him.

webTitle: Man killed wife and three children, then hanged himself

fields.headline: Man killed wife and three children, then hanged himself
fields.trailText: A man depressed by his mother's lung cancer and his own financial problems bludgeoned his wife and three children with a hammer before killing them with a knife and then hanging himself, an inquest was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A man depressed by his mother's lung cancer and his own financial problems bludgeoned his wife and three children with a hammer before killing them with a knife and then hanging himself, an inquest was told yesterday.

Police broke into the home of Peter Stafford, 33, in Sparkhill, Birmingham, after being alerted because his wife, Helen, had failed to drop one of the children off at her father's house.

Officers found seven-year-old Kelly and her two-year-old brother, Joe, lying dead in their pyjamas in a downstairs room. Their brother Danny, six, was also dead lying near toys in an upstairs bedroom.

Mrs Stafford was found dead in the couple's bedroom and Mr Stafford was hanging from a bannister by a nylon rope.

A home office pathologist told the Birmingham inquest that Mrs Stafford and the children had been knocked unconscious with a lump hammer and stabbed with a kitchen knife.

The Birmingham coroner, Richard Whittington, recorded that they were unlawfully killed and that Mr Stafford committed suicide.

Mr Stafford's brother Paul said he had been depressed by a combination of factors, including their mother Jacqueline's lung cancer and his financial difficulties. "Our mother was undergoing chemotherapy. He was upset, as we all were. I went to work with him on one occasion and he cried and said he was depressed and felt suicidal."

Just before the killings last October Mr Stafford learned that he could lose about 60% of his window cleaning business from a block of flats in Solihull, Birmingham, and he was worried about keeping his house after being declared bankrupt previously.

He had told his mother that he thought he was a manic depressive, like his father, and was being treated for depression.

His doctor, Ajay Singhal, told the inquest: "Mr Stafford mentioned he was depressed and stressed he was in a vicious circle where he worked and got money then would slacken off which would get him into financial problems."

fields.headline: £30 fare for pets crossing Channel
fields.trailText: Owners will be able to take their pets across the Channel for a return fare of £30 when trials for the relaxation of quarantine laws are launched on February 28.
fields.body:
Owners will be able to take their pets across the Channel for a return fare of £30 when trials for the relaxation of quarantine laws are launched on February 28.

The fare was announced by travel companies yesterday as ministers launched an advertising campaign for the pet travel scheme explaining the tests, jabs, microchipping and paperwork.

The charge is designed to cover the costs of checking that the rules have been followed. Owners risk having to leave their pets abroad or put them in quarantine if they fail.

Owners will have to pay about £150 for blood tests six months before travel, anti-rabies vaccines and microchips - plus £30 for annual boosters - before they can take animals abroad. Up to 350,000 animals a year may be travelling to and from Britain in a few years.

Britanny Ferries, Hoverspeed, P&O European, P&O Stena, SeaFrance and Eurotunnel have all been approved for services from Dover and Portsmouth. Talks are under way with six airlines about air services between Heathrow and selected airports.

Baroness Hayman, the agriculture minister, said the government would see whether it could simplify some requirements later. "Quarantine was simple but brutal. This change is to make sure we have the same level of protection."

Travel companies expect the changes to encourage tourism both in Britons going abroad and in foreign visitors.

fields.headline: Student 'kidnapped and left to drown'
fields.trailText: An A-level student was left to drown in a stream after being kidnapped, beaten and robbed by a gang of youths, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
An A-level student was left to drown in a stream after being kidnapped, beaten and robbed by a gang of youths, a court heard yesterday.

The body of 18-year-old Jonathan Coles, of Wendover, Buckinghamshire, was recovered from the River Ouse six days after he was allegedly murdered following a confrontation outside a nightclub in Milton Keynes last June.

Dwayne Dawkins, 20, Brian Alleyne, 19, Jason Canepe, 20, all of Milton Keynes, and a 17-year-old who cannot be named for legal reasons, are standing trial at Luton crown court for murder, and on charges of kidnap and robbery.

William Coker QC, prosecuting, said they had captured Mr Coles after he became involved in a seemingly unprovoked dispute outside the Empire nightclub shortly after it closed. They drove him to a cashpoint machine where they tried to withdraw money but when it became clear the account was empty they took him to Tyringham Bridge, near Newport Pagnell, stripped him of his glasses and pushed him in the water, Mr Coker said.

Mr Coles had gone to the club to celebrate the birthday of a friend and left at about 2am with two other friends, Brett Horton and Stuart Smith, to hail a taxi. He was approached by a youth acting aggressively. When the youth told his friends to back him up, Mr Coles and his friends fled but became separated.

Mr Coker said: "Jonathan, Stuart Smith and Brett Horton felt themselves the target in the middle of a growing crowd, and decided they would be outnumbered and ran away." The crowd included all four defendants.

The case continues today.

webTitle: Ministers urged to aid arms smuggler

fields.headline: Ministers urged to aid arms smuggler
fields.trailText: The government was yesterday urged to intervene in the case of a former British army intelligence officer found guilty of conspiring to commit offences against the state of India.
fields.body:
The government was yesterday urged to intervene in the case of a former British army intelligence officer found guilty of conspiring to commit offences against the state of India.

Peter Bleach, 48, who will be sentenced tomorrow with five Latvians, was also found guilty of explosives offences. The Calcutta court acquitted them of "abetting the waging of war with India", an offence which carries the death penalty. Bleach immediately appealed against the verdicts.

A former arms dealer, Bleach has been in a Calcutta jail for the past five years since a plane in which he was travelling was seen dropping crates of Bulgarian arms and ammunition over Purulia in west Bengal. India's central bureau of investigations said the 500 AK-47 rifles, 250,000 rounds of ammunition, a dozen rocket launchers and 100 anti-tank grenades - were destined for the Hindu cult, Ananda Marga.

Bleach insists he informed British intelligence after he was approached by a man who called himself Kim Davy, later identified as Neils Christian from the Netherlands, a member of Ananda Marga (path of bliss) which was opposed to the then communist government of West Bengal.

Davy bought a Russian Antonov cargo plane from the Latvian state airline. He fled from the plane after it was intercepted by Indian air force jets and forced to land in Bombay as it tried to make its way back to Bulgaria. Bleach and the plane's Latvian crew were arrested, but Davy has not been heard of since.

According to a document seen by the Guardian, Bleach told the ministry of defence about the arms deal in August 1995, four months before the arms drop. He told Colin Allkins, of the ministry's defence sales organisation, that his company, Aeroserve UK, had been asked to supply the weapons in "an illicit deal".

Whitehall sources insisted yesterday that Bleach was told to have nothing more to do with the plan. Bleach denies this and says he was told to go ahead and keep in touch with British intelligence. "It is not at all true that I was categorically instructed to back off," he told the Metropolitan police special branch after his arrest. He said he assumed his information would then be passed to the Indian authorities.

The Conservative MP, Sir Teddy Taylor, yesterday called on the home secretary to disclose all the evidence relating to Bleach's contacts with the intelligence agencies. The home office did give some documents to the Calcutta court. However, part of a record of a meeting with Bleach and two special branch officers at his home in Howdale, North Yorkshire in 1995, was removed.

Sir Teddy said yesterday: "The document had had the top and bottom cut off. I obtained a full copy and took it and the version shown in court to Jack Straw, and he said it was an administrative error. There is no doubt that Peter was involved with dropping the arms, but he believed he was doing this with the full knowledge of both governments."

webTitle: Stop and search lessons for Met

fields.headline: Stop and search lessons for Met
fields.trailText: Thousands of Metropolitan police officers will be trained to carry out stop and searches as part of radical plans to change the force under the new commissioner.
fields.body:
Thousands of Metropolitan police officers will be trained to carry out stop and searches as part of radical plans to change the force under the new commissioner.

Sir John Stevens, who succeeded Sir Paul Condon at midnight, believes the Met cannot fight rising crime in the capital without the tactic but has learned from his own uncomfortable experience that officers must be taught politeness when dealing with potential suspects.

During a briefing at Scotland Yard yesterday he revealed he had been stopped twice in recent years and had "bristled" at the way he was treated. He described how he was stopped in London three years ago as he walked home at 1am after an evening out. At the time he was working for Her Majesty's inspectorate of constabulary.

Sir John, who is 6ft 3in and has a fearsome temper when riled, did not take kindly to the aggressive way he was spoken to. "I could feel my hackles rising. I was not doing anything remotely suspicious but he still stopped me. Eventually I had to stop him and have a word with him about the way he was going about things. We had a meaningful discussion."

Seven months ago he was stopped again by an officer in the midlands. Sir John said he had just landed an aircraft - he is a qualified pilot - and was driving away in a car, still dressed in his flying suit.

Sir John did not report the officers, but was angered "not by the fact that I was stopped, but the attitude of the officer".

Sir John has asked Assistant Commissioner Denis O'Connor to draw up "principles of practice for the use of stop and search with a view to introducing on-the-job training. At the moment officers do not receive specialist instruction.

Sir John also revealed that the force needed to recruit 180 officers a month to keep up to strength, but figures for the last three months were 108, 89 and 85. For the next two months they are likely to be 55 and 50.

"I think these must be the lowest numbers ever," said Sir John. "It is extremely worrying." He believes potential recruits have been put off because of the hammering the force has taken since last year's Macpherson report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence. Poor pay for officers has also been a disincentive, especially as the housing market in London had rocketed, he said.

He said he was also committed to "high profile policing", putting as many officers on the street as possible, and investing in technology such as CCTV.

Sir John pioneered many of the systems when he was chief constable of Northumbria. During his spell the force cut crime dramatically.

webTitle: It's so unusual as Tom Jones vies for Brit award

fields.headline: It's so unusual as Tom Jones vies for Brit award
fields.standfirst: Brits 2000
fields.trailText: It's not unusual for singer Tom Jones to be pelted with silk knickers when he steps on stage - but until now the old knee-trembler has never exactly been showered with accolades by the music industry.
fields.body:
It's not unusual for singer Tom Jones to be pelted with silk knickers when he steps on stage - but until now the old knee-trembler has never exactly been showered with accolades by the music industry.

Last night, Jones, who turns 60 this year, was shortlisted for a Brit award for the first time alongside such hot young things as Macy Gray, Britney Spears and Robbie Williams, the young pretender who models himself on the man they call "the Voice".

Jones, who rose from Welsh working men's clubs to a perennial spot at the top of the bill in Las Vegas through such hits as Delilah and Green Green Grass Of Home, was shooting a video in the Utah desert for his new single with the Cardiff group Stereophonics when the news came through.

Jones said last night that it was "a fantastic feeling" to be still up there. "To start recording in the 1960s being nominated for awards alongside the likes of the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and The Who, and then to think that in the year 2000 I am being nominated for a Brit award for something I enjoy doing now as much as ever, is a fantastic feeling."

His album of cover versions, Reload, with the new wave of Welsh pop icons like Cerys Matthews of Catatonia and the Manic Street Preachers went to number one last year.

Jones lines up against Van Morrison, David Bowie, Sting and Ian Brown in the best British male solo artist category.

While rock wrinklies dominated that category, generally the new generation of dance acts dominated other sections, with The Chemical Brothers picking up four nominations, Fatboy Slim and Basement Jaxx collecting three apiece and Club favourites Shanks & Bigfoot shortlisted twice.

The Scottish band Travis did best among the more mainstream rockers, with three nominations, including best single for their song Why Does It Always Rain On Me. Blur, Gomez and Stereophonics (all with two nominations each) will contest best British band.

Apart from Jones, the other big surprise is that former Spice Girl, Geri Halliwell - whose autobiography, Geri, has done just as well as her debut solo records - is in the running for two Brits. She is up against her old Spice mate Melanie C in the best homegrown female singer slot.

Macy Gray, the American soul diva, whose debut album was the biggest critical rave of the year, is hot favourite for the best international newcomer award.

The awards will be presented on March 3.

Stars in the running

Best British group: Blur, Gomez, Stereophonics, Texas, Travis

Mastercard best British album: Basement Jaxx, Remedy; The Chemical Brothers, Surrender; Gomez, Liquid Skin; Stereophonics, Performance & Cocktails; Travis, The Man Who

Best British newcomer: Adam Rickett, Ann Lee, Charlotte Church, Martine McCutcheon, S Club 7, Groove Armada, Phats & Small, Shanks & Bigfoot, Spacedust, Wamdue Project, Fierce, Glamma Kid, Honeyz, Kele Le Roc, Jamelia, Beta Band, Death In Vegas, Gay Dad, Unkle, Wiseguys

Best British dance act: Basement Jaxx, The Chemical Brothers, Fatboy Slim, Jamiroquai, Leftfield

Best international group: Beastie Boys, The Cardigans, Mercury Rev, Red Hot Chilli Peppers, TLC

Best international newcomer: Britney Spears, Eminem, Jennifer Lopez, Macy Gray, Semisonic

Best international male artist: Beck, Eminem, Moby, Ricky Martin, Will Smith

Best international female artist: Britney Spears, Jennifer Lopez, Macy Gray, Mary J Blige, Whitney Houston

Best British male solo artist: David Bowie, Ian Brown, Sting, Tom Jones, Van Morrison

Best British female solo artist: Beth Orton, Beverley Knight, Gabrielle, Geri Halliwell, Melanie C

Best British single: Basement Jaxx, Red Alert; Supergrass, Moving; Moloko, Sing It Back; Blur, Tender; Robbie Williams, She's The One; Travis, Why Does It Always Rain On Me?; Fatboy Slim, Praise You; Manic Street Preachers, You Stole The Sun From My Heart; The Chemical Brothers, Hey Boy Hey Girl; Shanks & Bigfoot, Sweet Like Chocolate

webTitle: Bungled raid by police led to IRA suspect's death

fields.headline: Bungled raid by police led to IRA suspect's death
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: An unarmed suspected IRA terrorist was shot dead in a chaotic police operation intended to prevent a huge bombing campaign, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
An unarmed suspected IRA terrorist was shot dead in a chaotic police operation intended to prevent a huge bombing campaign, an inquest heard yesterday.

Dairmuid O'Neill, 27, was killed in a dawn raid by armed police on a bed and breakfast hostel in Hammersmith, west London, on September 23 1996, the inquest at Kingston crown court heard.

John Burton, the west London coroner, told the jury of five men and five women: "It's no secret at all that part of the operation went wrong in that the police opened fire and O'Neill was killed."

A series of attempts to break in to O'Neill's room had failed and most of the officers in the raid, including the commanding officer and the one who fired the fatal shot (codename Kilo) were incapacitated when CS spray was used. Many of the officers were not wearing protective masks.

Dr Burton said: "The intention was to try and take people by surprise in the middle of the night. [The police] wanted to get in with a duplicate key without making a noise but the key didn't work. They then tried to break the lock using a battering ram that went straight through the door. The next thing that happens is teargas is fired into the room, and shots fired, there is shouting, swearing and shooting. It was chaotic."

No guns or explosives were found in the hostel room after the raid, which had taken place against a background of IRA bombings in Manchester and Docklands, London.

Detective Superintendent John Bunn, acting head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch at the time of the raid and the officer with overall responsibility for the operation, said the raid had been the culmination of a two-month operation. More than 400 officers were involved in 24-hour surveillance of the suspected gang of up to seven people. As well as the hostel in Hammersmith, officers trailed a lorry and watched a north London storage facility where more than six tonnes of explosives, enough for six lorry bombs, were found by police three days before the bungled raid.

Det Supt Bunn, under questioning by Michael Mansfield QC, accepted that the operation had gone wrong. "Nowhere in our planning did we want someone we were going to arrest to get shot ... in that sense, yes, it went wrong."

The original plan had been to arrest the suspects at the arms cache, Det Supt Bunn said, but new information had led him to sanction a dawn raid. "Some of the surveillance teams were beginning to get edgy, and the decision was taken to arrest the suspects at their home addresses."

Mr Bunn denied that at a 3am briefing before the raid he had unnecessarily "hyped" the situation by showing police officers footage of the Docklands bomb and its aftermath.

Asked if there was anything he would have done differently at the time, he said: "I'm not unaffected by what happened on the day. I made the plans which I believed were right and thought them to be the best in the circumstances. The reality is that someone was shot and that should not have happened."

The inquest continues.

fields.headline: Ulster plea to Mitchell
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland's power-sharing assembly facing collapse as breakthrough on terrorist arms decommissioning proves elusive
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland's political leaders yesterday issued powerful appeals to the former American senator George Mitchell to return to Belfast to save the peace process.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland's political leaders yesterday issued powerful appeals to the former American senator George Mitchell to return to Belfast to save the peace process.

As fears rose of an imminent collapse of the search for peace over IRA disarmament, Mr Mitchell faced intense pressure throughout the day to "work his magic" once again. President Clinton's former envoy to the province, who saved the process from collapse last year, was said to be resisting the pleas.

Senior British officials and political leaders, including the first minister, David Trimble, contacted Mr Mitchell when it became clear yesterday that there would be no breakthrough on the arms issue.

John de Chastelain, the Canadian general charged with overseeing paramilitary weapons, was expected to report late last night that the IRA was still refusing to disarm. In his long-awaited report, due to be handed to the British and Irish governments before midnight, the general was expected to say the provisionals had still not agreed a timetable for disarmament. That would be likely to lead to the collapse of Northern Ireland's power-sharing assembly.

Mr Trimble, who agreed to form the power-sharing executive last year on the basis that the IRA would disarm, made clear yesterday that he expected direct rule to be restored.

"If we don't have the actions necessary to maintain confidence in this process then this process will go into abeyance, temporarily I hope," he said.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, wants to act cautiously for fear of precipitating a walk-out by Sinn Fein, but the government is determined to preserve the position of Mr Trimble, who is admired for his past bravery in facing down hardliners in his party.

Mr Trimble wrote a post-dated resignation to his party last year which will be triggered next week if the IRA fails to disarm. Ministers will hope that suspending the executive would make Mr Trimble's letter void.

Suspension is fraught with difficulties, however, because the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, warned over the weekend that the IRA would boycott General de Chastelain's decommissioning body if the executive was suspended.

Mr Trimble clashed with Sinn Fein yesterday over the agreement they reached last year which allowed the formation of the power-sharing body.

Mr Trimble said a "clear promise" on a start to decommissioning was given by Sinn Fein during Mr Mitchell's review last year.

"We actually jumped first and took a very substantial risk. It's time for other people to be as bold, to take the same sort of risk we did, not to be hiding away."

Alex Maskey, Sinn Fein's chief whip, insisted Mr Trimble had broken the deal by setting February as a deadline on arms.

Seamus Mallon, the deputy leader of the SDLP, implored Mr Adams to use his influence with the IRA to disarm. "You have a responsibility to jump as well," he said. "You agreed it and the understanding was clear in the Mitchell review."

webTitle: Soap's producers defend teenage pregnancy plot

fields.headline: Soap's producers defend teenage pregnancy plot
fields.trailText: Coronation Street producers yesterday defended a storyline involving a schoolgirl pregnancy, saying it would not glamorise teenage pregnancies.
fields.body:
Coronation Street producers yesterday defended a storyline involving a schoolgirl pregnancy, saying it would not glamorise teenage pregnancies.

In a plot line to be shown next month, 13-year-old Sarah Louise Platt will shock her mother, Gail, by revealing she is pregnant.

A spokeswoman for the Granada TV soap opera said the storyline would not be "exploitative" but focus on a girl who makes mistakes. She will be the soap's first schoolgirl mother.

Former cast members and family values campaigners have recently accused the show of introducing controversial storylines to grab back ratings from rival BBC 1 soap EastEnders.

But the spokeswoman said: "It is a fact that Britain has Europe's highest teenage pregnancy figures and Coronation Street is reflecting that and telling the story of one young girl."

A spokeswoman for Family and Youth Concerns said they would rather the soap did not use a teenage pregnancy storyline in case it "normalised" such situations in the eyes of viewers. She added: "It must not encourage teenage sex or show this situation as normal because it is relatively rare."

But a spokeswoman for the family planning information service, the Brook Advisory Centre, said: "There are thousands of families who are facing this problem. You can't just sweep it under the carpet and hope it will go away."

webTitle: Paratrooper Lee Clegg cleared of last charge over death of teenagers

fields.headline: Paratrooper Lee Clegg cleared of last charge over death of teenagers
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Paratrooper Lee Clegg was finally cleared yesterday of criminal wrongdoing over the shooting of two teenage joyriders in west Belfast in 1990, ending a lengthy legal battle.
fields.body:
Paratrooper Lee Clegg was finally cleared yesterday of criminal wrongdoing over the shooting of two teenage joyriders in west Belfast in 1990, ending a lengthy legal battle.

Clegg said last night that he was "overwhelmed" after the Northern Ireland court of appeal overturned a conviction for wounding Martin Peake, who died in the shooting.

The judgment removed the last outstanding charge against Clegg, 31, who was acquitted at a retrial last year of murdering Karen Reilly, who was a passenger in the joyrider's car.

Clegg was originally convicted in 1993 at Belfast crown court of murdering Miss Reilly, 18, and wounding Mr Peake, 17. The two victims were shot by an army patrol on Glen Road in west Belfast in September 1990 when their stolen Vauxhall Astra raced through a security checkpoint.

The paratrooper, who fired four shots at the car, said he opened fire because he feared for the safety of his fellow soldiers. The judge at his original trial convicted Clegg of murder because he fired his final shot through the back of the car when the joyriders no longer presented a threat to the paratroopers.

The Clegg case became one of the most politically sensitive in Northern Ireland when the Daily Mail launched a campaign in 1994 to clear his name.

Under pressure from Tory backbenchers, the then Northern Ireland secretary, Sir Patrick Mayhew, used his powers to free Clegg on licence in 1995, sparking widespread rioting in nationalist areas.

The court of appeal granted Clegg a retrial after new ballistics evidence challenged the evidence used in his original trial. Clegg was acquitted of murdering Miss Reilly last year but was again found guilty of the offence against Mr Peake.

In yesterday's 36-page judgment, read out by Northern Ireland's lord chief justice, Sir Robert Carswell, Clegg was cleared of wounding Peake because of unreliable evidence from an RUC constable.

The judgment said: "In these circumstances we consider that the evidence upon which the conviction has to stand is frail and gives rise to an element of doubt in our minds whether it is being sufficiently clearly proved that the appellant did discharge a shot after the car when it had passed his position."

The judgment attacked the "highly discreditable behaviour" of the paratroopers who were "undoubtedly guilty" of the shootings.

However, it added: "Sympathy for the families of Karen Reilly and Martin Peake in their tragic loss cannot be allowed to deflect a court from reaching a decision based on the law and the facts proved in evidence."

An ecstatic Clegg said last night that he did not want to be triumphalist. "At the end of the day, the shooting was a tragedy that could have been avoided," he said. "Two young people lost their lives needlessly and this fact will remain with me long after the case has been forgotten about."

His mother, Wynne Johnson, welcomed the judgment as the end of a nine-year nightmare for the family. "It's brilliant," she said. "That's it - the ball's finally stopped rolling after more than nine years."

The Sinn Fein president and Belfast West MP, Gerry Adams, condemned the judgment as a "dreadful verdict".

"This is a grievous insult to the people of west Belfast and to the victims' families," he said.

Mr Adams called for the scrapping of Northern Ireland's non-jury Diplock courts and for a wholesale reform of the province's judicial system.

webTitle: BA relaunch brings new fare class

fields.headline: BA relaunch brings new fare class
fields.trailText: British Airways yesterday unveiled a new "upgraded" economy class aimed at winning back high-spending passengers to the struggling airline as part of a £600m relaunch. It will offer passengers an extra seven inches of legroom, wider seats and an in-seat telephone.
fields.body:
British Airways yesterday unveiled a new "upgraded" economy class aimed at winning back high-spending passengers to the struggling airline as part of a £600m relaunch. It will offer passengers an extra seven inches of legroom, wider seats and an in-seat telephone.

Passengers will also be allowed to double the amount of hand luggage, get their own seat-back entertainment and get extra air miles.

Tickets, which will be available in March for BA flights from July, are expected to cost 20% more than the economy fare. The new class is part of a package of passenger improvements to be brought in over the next two years to help the loss-making airline restore its reputation.

The upgraded economy section, called World Traveller Plus, is aimed at business passengers unwilling to pay the full Club Class fare and holiday travellers who are prepared to pay more for extra comfort and leg room. The airline hopes the new class will win back high-spending business class passengers who have switched to competing airlines.

BA chief executive Bob Ayling said: "The £600m investment we are making will ensure that we are the best in the world."

The relaunch also includes a £200m investment in the airline's Club World seats, which BA claimed to be the industry's first business class full-length flying bed. The 6ft long bed is, however, only available to passengers willing to pay £3,244.

webTitle: Palace ballroom to go on view

fields.headline: Palace ballroom to go on view
fields.trailText: The largest room at Buckingham Palace will be seen by paying visitors for the first time during the annual summer opening this year.
fields.body:
The largest room at Buckingham Palace will be seen by paying visitors for the first time during the annual summer opening this year.

At 122ft long by 60ft wide and 45ft high, the ballroom has been the centre of state entertaining since it was built for Queen Victoria and opened in 1856 with a ball to celebrate the end of the Crimean war.

The ballroom is used for receptions, ranging from the Prince of Wales's 50th birthday celebrations in 1998 to the annual diplomatic reception attended by 1,500 guests.

Between 1954 and 1999, 48 heads of state were entertained by the Queen at state banquets held in the room.

More than 2.25m people have visited the state rooms since they opened to visitors in 1993.

fields.headline: Sword death hearing
fields.trailText: A civil engineer appeared at Cheltenham magistrates court yesterday charged with the Samurai sword murder of Andrew Pennington, the Liberal Democrat councillor, and the attempted murder of Nigel Jones MP.
fields.body:
A civil engineer appeared at Cheltenham magistrates court yesterday charged with the Samurai sword murder of Andrew Pennington, the Liberal Democrat councillor, and the attempted murder of Nigel Jones MP.

Robert Ashman, 49, was arrested minutes after Mr Pennington, 39, a key aide to the MP, was killed after being stabbed at the Liberal Democrats' Cheltenham constituency office on Friday.

Mr Jones, 51, suffered horrific slash wounds to his hands and needed 60 stitches following the attack.

Mr Ashman was charged with the murder of Mr Pennington - a county councillor who would have been 40 today - and the attempted murder of Mr Jones on January 28. He spoke only to confirm his name and address during the 12-minute hearing. Three armed police officers stood guard at the back of the court.

He was remanded in custody and will appear again before the court in Cheltenham on February 7.

No application for bail was made.

fields.headline: Lambeth squatters lose case
fields.trailText: Council chiefs yesterday claimed victory in their battle to evict squatters from an historic £6m block of flats.
fields.body:
Council chiefs yesterday claimed victory in their battle to evict squatters from an historic £6m block of flats.

A judge ruled that 53 of the 60 apartments in the mansion block overlooking the Oval cricket ground in south London should be returned to Lambeth council despite many residents having lived there for 12 years or more.

The Oval Mansions complex, a series of eight Victorian tenements, became known as "London's most prestigious squat" after Lambeth's "loony left" regime in the 1970s and 1980s forgot it owned the property. The decision could lead to the squatters being thrown out within weeks, ahead of its £6m sale to property developers. Residents had claimed they could prove continuous possession of their flats for 12 years, so allowing them to claim ownership under "squatters' rights" legislation.

But Judge Roger Cooke, sitting at Central London county court, found most of the estimated 100 residents could not prove their claim and ordered ownership to pass back to Lambeth.

Judge Cooke ruled that six of the flats should be awarded to squatters who had proved their residency. Wrangling continues over one flat.

The decision could lead to the squatters being thrown out within weeks, ahead of its £6m sale to property developers. Residents had claimed they could prove continuous possession of their flats for 12 years, so allowing them to claim ownership under "squatters' rights" legislation. But Judge Roger Cooke, sitting at Central London county court, found most of the estimated 100 residents could not prove their claim and ordered ownership to pass back to Lambeth. Judge Cooke ruled that six of the flats should be awarded to squatters who had proved their residency. Wrangling continues over one flat.

webTitle: Kilfoyle points to core of Labour's problem

fields.headline: Kilfoyle points to core of Labour's problem
fields.standfirst:
Heartlands seen as disillusioned with 'middle England policies'
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The unexpected resignation of Peter Kilfoyle triggered renewed pressure on ministers yesterday to launch initiatives to placate restless core supporters in Labour's heartlands.
fields.body:
The unexpected resignation of Peter Kilfoyle triggered renewed pressure on ministers yesterday to launch initiatives to placate restless core supporters in Labour's heartlands.

Downing Street attempted to take the Liverpool Walton MP's resignation as a junior defence minister in its stride by appointing Lewis Moonie in his place. Mr Blair's spokesman acknowleged the frustrations of junior office and said that any minister is free to opt to speak his mind from the backbenches."It's no big deal," he said.

John Prescott denied that Mr Kilfoyle's resignation was a problem. "We are very sorry to lose him but it is not an embarrassment, it is the choice of people like Peter," he told ITN.

The repercussions may be more serious than outward calm suggest. Mr Kilfoyle did not seek to embarrass ex-colleagues yesterday but did say he would become "a critical friend" of the government.

It prompted backbenchers, ex-ministers and even ministers to demand action because of growing evidence, especially from northern regions, that core Labour voters are disillusioned with policies perceived to be for middle England rather than traditional areas.

Although Mr Kilfoyle, Labour's former north-west regional organiser, spoke intriguingly of "fresh challenges" for the party's heart lands, friends say his dissatisfaction with the government's regional policy - or the lack of it - runs deep.

"I've given three years of striking a compromise and now I will be able to talk about the issues I care about," he told the Liverpool Echo, while being careful not to rule out the prospect of standing as Liverpool's first elected mayor.

Mr Kilfoyle, 53, was always associated with the old centre-right of the party since he was sent to Liverpool by Neil Kinnock to drive out the Militant Tendency in the mid-80s.

Though a moderniser, who signed Mr Blair's nomination papers for leader in 1994 he appears uneasy with Labour's apparent inability to tackle disparities between wealthy and poorer regions, like his native Merseyside. Mr Blair insists that all regions will benefit from his policies - and that Gordon Brown's new deal on jobs and taxes is of huge local importance.

That is not how it is seen in Walton. Merseyside is seething over the government's dithering in commiting itself to providing matching aid for a £844m, six-year European Union programme to create jobs - an Objective One scheme for the EU's poorest regions.

Senior council officials believe hundreds of millions will have to be returned to Brussels unless government departments - in the words of a town hall chief executive - "get their act together ... it's very serious". Doug Henderson, Newcastle North MP and former defence minister who lost his job in the last reshuffle, said that the government had yet to come forward with measures to bridge the north-south divide.

"Heartland Labour support is signalling to the government there needs to be a much tough regional policy so the whole country gets the benefit of economic growth," he added. "It appears that they are still grappling with it and backbenchers like myself will continue to put the pressure on."

Disillusionment in Liverpool runs deeps because the city has England's highest council tax - £1,171 for Band D - along with its highest unemployment rate. Mr Kilfoyle is known to fear Liberal Democrat inroads into Labour's territory and believes the city has been ill-served by Lib Dem control of the council.

Although great strides are being made redeveloping the city centre, Joe Hanson, Peter Kilfoyle's agent, says constituencies like Walton are being forgotten. "I do not think the government recognises the size of the problem. At the end of the day, Peter is going to be far more effective on the back benches."

"Ordinary people are saying the government isn't doing enough on education, health, pensions so why bother voting?" says Bob Lancaster, a manager in Liverpool docks. He was re-elected to the council on a "miserable" turnout of under 20% last year and is seriously thinking about retiring at the next election. "I only had a majority of 40 (over the Lib Dems) and that is ridiculous in a city like this - just shows you how disillusioned people are."

Party HQ at Millbank is already fearful of that problem. Only last week it opened a new office in the city.

Another councillor, Marie McGiveron, former deputy leader of the council, said many core voters were no longer active in the party. It was also having trouble finding people to stand for the city council where Liberal Democrats now have 59 seats and Labour only 27.

webTitle: MP who criticised Dome gets chance at last

fields.headline: MP who criticised Dome gets chance at last
fields.standfirst:
Profile: Lewis Moonie
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Old Labour MPs who are also older Labour MPs will have a spring in their step this morning after learning yesterday that Dr Lewis Moonie had been appointed to fill Peter Kilfoyle's place as junior defence minister.
fields.body:
Old Labour MPs who are also older Labour MPs will have a spring in their step this morning after learning yesterday that Dr Lewis Moonie had been appointed to fill Peter Kilfoyle's place as junior defence minister.

Dr Moonie, who is 53 this month, has been given the job after being passed over at every reshuffle since 1997. It is proof of life after political death. Sociable MPs who occasionally sip a half of bitter in the Stranger's Bar at the Commons also noticed that Moonie and Kilfoyle ( also 53) are superficially similar characters.

Tall and built for the scrum, both are genial, beer and scotch men who also smoke, despite (in Dr Moonie's case) expert knowledge of the medical consequences.

They tell jokes, occasionally malicious ones, and entertain heterodox opinions. The comparison stops there. Peter Kilfoyle is a shrewd and thoughtful man who came up the hard way. An emotional man, he is a natural chum of Mo Mowlam, as his cerebral successor is not.

Dr Moonie is the middle class son of a Dundee accountant, a psychiatrist who specialised in community medicine and got to Westminster in 1987 as MP for Kirkaldy.

A keen golfer and serious bridge player who also used to coach footballers, he does not suffer fools gladly, which probably held him back. If he didn't like the Greenwich Dome, he said so and marshalled arguments to back his points.

Dr Moonie, a father of two sons, got marked down at No 10 as lazy, a claim denied by friends who say "he just thinks faster than most of us". Having shown sufficient independence of mind to have given up all hope of office, he will now have to give up some lucrative medical sidelines.

fields.headline: The trouble with Mo
fields.standfirst:
A year ago she was making history in Northern Ireland. These days she is hosting sandwich lunches for civil servants and battling to keep her bodyguards. Amid fresh reports of a Downing Street smear campaign against Mo Mowlam, Michael White reports on the fall from grace of a political star

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: I rang Mo Mowlam at the cabinet office in Whitehall yesterday. She was not, I can confirm, her usual cheerful self. Cheerful enough by ministerial benchmark standards, but definitely not in the rumbustious mood that has made her Tony Blair's most popular minister.
fields.body:
I rang Mo Mowlam at the cabinet office in Whitehall yesterday. She was not, I can confirm, her usual cheerful self. Cheerful enough by ministerial benchmark standards, but definitely not in the rumbustious mood that has made her Tony Blair's most popular minister.

Popular but vulnerable, proof that a minister can be riding high one minute and tipped for the sack the next. Not since John Moore was being touted as Margaret Thatcher's heir apparent when he took over the department of health and social security in 1987 (and promptly ploughed it by asking for a budget cut) has a fall from grace been so dramatic.

What is going on here? This time last year Mo Mowlam was the People's Political Princess, heroine of that ever-growing lobby, the Campaign for Real Politicians, the ones who let their hair down in public (or take their wig off in Mo's case), who swear a bit, ad lib and don't slavishly repeat the party soundbites on Any Questions.

She was briefly the "obvious" candidate for mayor of London, the one popular enough to beat Ken Livingstone. She didn't want it - too much risk, she wasn't even a Londoner - the story died. But voters still smiled at her the way they rarely warm to politicians.

Since then there has been a long slide to the point where the New Statesman could run a cover story, illustrated by a drawing of the former Northern Ireland secretary as the broken statue of Ozymandias the fallen king of kings in Shelley's poem. "Mo's Fall from Grace" said the headline.

That was January 10. Last weekend it started all over again. "Mowlam is Victim of Whispering Campaign", trumpeted the Independent on Sunday. Her health, her grip, her commitment were all called into question. Coincidentally, meanwhile, the Sunday Mirror had stumbled on the fact that Dr Mowlam (PhD Iowa University) has finally lost a running battle with the security services over the withdrawal of her two bodyguards and special driver, assigned to her ex officio as Our Woman at Stormont.

The issue of her security arrangements has rumbled on since the summer and each time the spooks have backed off - until Thursday, days before the latest decommissioning deadline in Belfast and hours before a swordsman attacked Nigel Jones MP in Cheltenham.

Mo, nowadays cabinet office minister in charge of policy "enforcement", was quoted as saying she was "a bit surprised" by the decision. "I was told that my security [rating] was not high enough," she said.

To many outsiders it looked like malice, as if the nameless whisperers against her had thrown a switch and got Tony Blair to take away Mowlam's policemen. Was this one more calculated slight to add to the growing catalogue? First the undiginified removal from the job she had professed her determination to keep. Then the relegation of her conference speech to a slot that would deny her the limelight grabbing opportunity that she had so successfully exploited before. Now this.

The minister herself is more philosophical. "If it was based on a security assessment and strict criteria I don't mind," she told me yesterday. That, security sources insist, is just what happened. "Protection is not a political plaything," said one official. "The decision is meant to be objective and dispassionate, based on an assessment of the threat to the individual which takes into account all intelligence information that is available."

Whatever the truth behind the security decision, Dr Mowlam admits the whispers hurt. "I was shocked at the vitriol in the Independent on Sunday, but I am not cross or fed-up. Some people are trying to get me out, but I am determined to keep going." The whispers that hurt most are the ones about her health, the brain tumour which laid her low before the 1997 election and won her public admiration for the way she soldiered on.

The whisperers suggested she is still unwell or has not recovered her pre-tumour powers. "I'm more than fine," Mo insists. But recovery takes time and Dr Mo has hardly taken it easy these past three years. The fact that her merchant banker husband, John Norton, lost his job last year and has not found another cannot help. They are currently selling their London house and have been shaken to learn that tumours and unemployment in the mid-40s, even among cabinet members, do not make for ideal mortgage applications.

So who is behind the whispers, and why are they gunning for Mo? Mowlam is convinced there is someone, somewhere in Downing St (not Millbank) trying to get her. Some ministerial colleagues agree. So do some backbenchers. "It's the same problem that Ken [Livingstone] has. They hate people who are popular and have an independent base in the party," one leftwinger said last night.

To which the Blair camp replies: "Not true, we want to bind her in and use her immense popularity." A funny way to do it, sending her to the cabinet office where she has introduced sandwich lunches with up to a dozen fellow ministers to thrash out problems (she had one yesterday) but rarely hits the top of the six o'clock news on TV.

But it was her choice, comes the answer back. It is not true that she was denied the department of health for publicly saying she wanted to stay in Belfast last July. Mowlam aides say she could have had it as late as the October reshuffle - she did discuss it with Blair, his staff confirm - but opted for the broad-brush alternative to get her back into the big picture.

Two rival theories intervene at this point. Mo was disinclined to put in the back-breaking work that the NHS demands, murmer critics. "Look how much less hard she works to master a brief than, say, John Prescott." According to the rival version, Mo the People's Heroine, demanded assurances that the extra money the service needs would be forthcoming - and did not get them. Neither version can easily be confirmed, but each suits the myth-makers.

Mowlam herself does not believe that Blair has lost faith in her. "I get on very well with No 10," she says. From the other side of the locked door which separates her department from Blair's senior sources say: "It's not Tony speaking out against her, not Jonathan Powell [chief of staff], Alistair Campbell [press secretary], David Milliband [head of the policy unit], or Anji Hunter [special adviser], so it doesn't matter does it?"

On this particular Monday the cabinet office enforcer has been busy with what every holder of her office knows is a difficult and elusive brief. Having no department to run with its juggernaut agenda, its special interests and media attention, the cabinet office post has usually been about the less visible business of tweaking the machinery of government and improving civil service performance without damaging their morale.

Nowadays there's more of course - progress-chasing, what Tony Blair calls "joined-up government", sorting out those inter-departmental problems which require rival ministers heads to be knocked together. It has defeated many incumbents, including (lately) David Clark and Jack Cunningham. What does Mo say? She says she's enjoying the job, particularly working on social exclusion - drugs and homelessness, the sort of issues voters would expect Mowlam to respond to with her famous passion and humanity.

Even modernising the civil service? Surely asking us to believe that Mo is enjoying wrestling with the mandarins is stretching our credulity. Not so, she insists. "I quite seriously believe that the civil service as we have known it in the past has an important role in the future. Margaret Thatcher castrated it. If the civil service and values it brings to good government are going to survive into the future we are going to have to work with the civil service and reform it."

Is this sort of talk convincing? Some MPs and officials would dispute it. Mo, they say, is a broad-brush operator, wonderful at wooing voters and pleasing Labour audiences with her informal ways. But she is not a details person, they say, never was, despite the PhD in politics. Hence the irritation of officials and Unionist politicians in Belfast - and some in London. After four months some officials at the cabinet office have started complaining privately about their minister's indecisive habits.

The real trouble with Mo may simply be the obvious one: her virtues are the flip-side of her vices. Long before the brain tumour she had a wayward side to her character, the despair of party briefers who wished her well and also wished she would deliver the government's message on Any Questions as agreed.

"She's not fantastically good at doing what you ask her to do," admits one party official with a smile. Half the people who criticise Mo apologise before they do it. "There again, if you got her to learn the script she wouldn't be the real Mo."

April 1998

Mowlam's relationship with unionists was already fraught by the time of the Good Friday agreement - they saw her as a nationalist sympathiser, and were alienated by her touchy-feely style. She had also fallen out with civil servants in the Northern Ireland office after accusing them of leaking information to wreck the peace process.

February 1999

David Trimble called for Mowlam to be sacked as pressure mounted over paramilitary beatings and unionist unease at prisoner releases.

June 1999

An exasperated Blair travelled to to Belfast to take over negotiations himself. Mowlam had not had full talks with David Trimble for over a year, and was reported to be watching the negotiations on television, having been shut out to pacify unionists.

July 1999

With pressure mounting for her resignation, Mowlam pleaded with Blair to keep her job. She remained in Ulster largely, it was acknowledged later, because of the fragile state of the process and because the PM was unwilling to appear to give in to unionist pressure.

August 1999

Despite intermittent violence, Mowlam ruled that the IRA ceasefire was still holding, prompting unionist fury. Ken Maginnis, the UUP's security spokesman, called her "incompetent".

September 1999

At the party conference, Mowlam was scheduled to speak after lunch, and received only polite applause from a half-empty hall. The previous year she was given a standing ovation.

October 1999

Mowlam was replaced by Peter Mandelson and demoted to the role of cabinet enforcer. "We're fed up continually having to rescue Mo," said one government source.

December 1999

Rumours that Mowlam had sold the rights to her autobiography for £350,000 prompted panic that she was ready to write of her "betrayal".

January 2000

The New Statesman quoted a government aide as saying that Mowlam was "on trial" at the cabinet office. Her personal security was cancelled, despite the fact that other former Northern Ireland secretaries continue to enjoy round-the-clock armed protection. Close colleagues said her morale was "at a new low" after a whispering campaign suggested her battle with a brain tumour had left her "without the intellectual rigour" to hold a cabinet post.

August 1999 Despite intermittent violence, Mowlam ruled that the IRA ceasefire was still holding, prompting unionist fury. Ken Maginnis, the UUP's security spokesman, called her "incompetent". September 1999 At the party conference, Mowlam was scheduled to speak after lunch, and received only polite applause from a half-empty hall. The previous year she was given a standing ovation. October 1999 Mowlam was replaced by Peter Mandelson and demoted to the role of cabinet enforcer. "We're fed up continually having to rescue Mo," said one government source. December 1999 Rumours that Mowlam had sold the rights to her autobiography for £350,000 prompted panic that she was ready to write of her "betrayal". January 2000 The New Statesman quoted a government aide as saying that Mowlam was "on trial" at the cabinet office. Her personal security was cancelled, despite the fact that other former Northern Ireland secretaries continue to enjoy round-the-clock armed protection. Close colleagues said her morale was "at a new low" after a whispering campaign suggested her battle with a brain tumour had left her "without the intellectual rigour" to hold a cabinet post.

fields.headline: The essence of Spice
fields.standfirst: If there's one thing the world needs more of, it's Spice TV. And tonight Geri follows Victoria's initiative with her very own World Walkabout. Surely it's only a matter of time until the others weigh in.  Richard Vine  has some advice for them
fields.trailText: Last month, Victoria's Secrets exposed the inner workings of the celebrity zoo, with Posh trading her gilded cage for a gamekeeper's landrover, patrolling big game like Elton John and, er, David Beckham. But Geri Haliwell has now realised you can do a lot more with a TV show than talk to other famous people. In Geri's World Walkabout tonight (10.20pm, BBC1), she meets unfamous people, proving that fame is no barrier when it comes to taking time out from a whirlwind life to make a documentary. Will Emma and the two Mels find time to make solo documentaries too? We offer some advice.
fields.body:
Last month, Victoria's Secrets exposed the inner workings of the celebrity zoo, with Posh trading her gilded cage for a gamekeeper's landrover, patrolling big game like Elton John and, er, David Beckham. But Geri Haliwell has now realised you can do a lot more with a TV show than talk to other famous people. In Geri's World Walkabout tonight (10.20pm, BBC1), she meets unfamous people, proving that fame is no barrier when it comes to taking time out from a whirlwind life to make a documentary. Will Emma and the two Mels find time to make solo documentaries too? We offer some advice.

There's only one star

Victoria thought she was playing it safe by filling her show with her showbiz pals. But there's a big drawback to this ploy, which Geri has been quick to spot. With Elton John, Ruby Wax and Richard E Grant also in the shot, your celebrity cachet is diminished, not enhanced, and it becomes less about you than it does about them.

Tackle any subject

Street children? The slums of Rio? Eco living? The evils of the papal birth control policy? Political assassination? Concentration camps? You are Spice and you have Girl Power on your side, so don't be afraid to step into any area of life that you want to. Panorama does not have a monopoly on issues.

Make your life work for you

Making a TV show is easy when you've already got an interesting life. Victoria used her time with her celeb chums to fill her show; Geri has taken time out from her busy international schedule to meet the real people of the countries she's been visiting.

Keep interrupting

Again, it's Geri who wins hands down here. With real people there's never a conflict of celebrity auras, and Geri's free to interject with Paxmanesque authority whenever she wants. For example, she interviews Kris Aquino, daughter of assassinated Filipino opposition leader Benigno Aquino and former President Cory Aquino, and gets the lowdown on the changes in her life - from political prisoner's daughter, to exile's daughter, to martyr's daughter, to president's daughter. Just as Kris starts to make a really boring point about living life in the public eye, Geri gets stuck in: "Your life has been like a soap opera hasn't it?" Aquino stumbles to keep up with the charge, but it's a body blow, and we skip to the next item.

Flaunt your lifestyle

Don't miss an opportunity to show off your great life. The scenes from inside Geri's Berkshire mansion, sitting on her succulent sofa, iBook on lap, allows her the opportunity to emote with the rest of the world from her world. And fans get to see where the proceeds from Mi Chico Latino went.

Keep it upbeat

Music, as Spice World proved, can be used to great effect. Geri's World Walkabout is peppered with some really jaunty numbers (though strangely nothing from her opus Schizophonic) which livens up her visit to the rubbish-tip scavengers of the Philippines enormously.

Turn everything back to you

Victoria tried hard here. But again, by listening to her interviewees, and only talking about herself when asked, she really missed an opportunity to let us hear Posh on Posh. No such problem with Geri, who has confidently mastered the Art of Me. When she meets an eco-commune in Wales, she asks them what they feel about the outside world. "We never go near it!" one of the friendly hippies replies. A worried Geri cuts to the chase: "I was wondering if you know me? Do you know that I left the Spice Girls?"

Keep it pop

It's crucial to relate to people in ways everyone can understand. Geri knows this, and that's why she cuts off the Browns, New York parents of a family of five Mormon piano prodigies, in mid-sentence, to tell them they are just like The Waltons. And she's right. The Waltons had lots of kids too.

Bring everyone up to your level

With the Brown kids themselves, Geri caps off the interview by playing them Heart And Soul on one of their grand pianos. "Let's do a plié, that's all I know", she instructs Reginaldo, a young boy from the Brazilian shantytown of Complexo do Alemao who has risen from adversity to win a Bolshoi scholarship.

Use the Spice

Being in the Spice Girls can prepare you for anything. Again, Geri has an advantage here over the other Spices as she knows what it's like to be a Spice and an ex-Spice. She asks the Brown kids what they would do if one was asked to do something without the others. "We'd be happy for them," they unreasonably reply. But Geri knows what it's really really like to be in a group: "You wouldn't feel a slight bit of jealousy? I would!"

While investigating the resurgence of fascism in Germany, Geri visits Sachsenhausen concentration camp, where her Spice experiences again come in handy. "I am now standing in a concentration camp", she says, wiping the tears from her eyes. "This is where they used to incinerate the bodies. I think we've all felt hatred in our lives, sometimes to ourselves and other people," and here's it's hard not to share the pain of being an ex-Spice, "but sometimes you just can't understand it. I can't understand this." Well, even Geri's power to emote has its limits.

fields.headline: The dead zone
fields.trailText: Last week, Channel 5 screened the classic film The Big Chill, in which a group of thirtysomething ex-college buddies meet up at a funeral and discuss how their lives have changed in the intervening years. And this week, Channel 4 begins a series of real-life remakes: six self-contained half-hour programmes following people's funerals.
fields.body:
Last week, Channel 5 screened the classic film The Big Chill, in which a group of thirtysomething ex-college buddies meet up at a funeral and discuss how their lives have changed in the intervening years. And this week, Channel 4 begins a series of real-life remakes: six self-contained half-hour programmes following people's funerals.

It's hard to agree with the producers' contention that Great Undertakings (9pm, Thursday) is broaching the last great television taboo: Robert Winston's BBC series, The Human Body, followed somebody up to and including the moment of his death. However, Great Undertakings does have one unique selling point: we never actually meet the shows' "stars". They are already dead when the programmes begin. Sadly, though, what the living participants have to say about life and death tends to be mundane, the exception being a short monologue by funeral director Mr Freestone which bookends each episode. (Intentionally or not, he evokes memories of Alfred Hitchcock introducing episodes of his television series). What we do get, though, is a glimpse into the lives of a range of ordinary people at - crucially - one of the most vulnerable periods in their lives.

Inevitably, the producers' constraints in "casting" their series limits its scope. Almost all the deceased died of old age (choosing a thirtysomething suicide victim would have presented all kinds of problems, both logistical and moral). This week's programme, for example, follows Phyllis, a Jamaican woman who lived on the White City estate in west London (near BBC TV headquarters - is Channel 4 having a small joke at Auntie's expense?) The most poignant moment comes when her sons talk of the toughness of their upbringing on the estate just before we see their emotions bubble to the fore as they commit their mother to the hereafter. The result is a subtle human drama rather than a monumental piece of TV, but no less valuable a social documentary for that.
