fields.headline: Ghosts of comedy past
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Enter Eric Sykes with goat. It is a stage instruction worthy of Shakespeare.
fields.body:
Enter Eric Sykes with goat. It is a stage instruction worthy of Shakespeare.

I was tempted back to Gormenghast (BBC 2) this week by a star burst of comic talent. It was well hidden. I finally found Martin Clunes, the most mobile mouth in show business, lurking behind a large moustache. Spike Milligan ("He's fallen out of the window!") was quickly defenestrated. But Eric Sykes, deaf and half blind now, came storming triumphantly through with a large goat and a bit of business.

The goat was huge and hairy with horns like sickles, the sort of beast you expect to see leading a regiment down the Mall. Sykes was dangling a small bough over its nose, possibly an olive branch, perhaps its elevenses. Like the regiment, he took good care to stand behind it throughout.

The tale of Gormenghast requires a large number of refractory animals, few of them capable of taking direction. Cats (white and, therefore, almost certainly deaf), a crow (albino), rats (various), owls (man-eating) and, of course, the goat. There is a short but cheerful thesis to be written on this aspect of the production.

I am increasingly surprised and sorry that Gormenghast was not animated rather than acted. It might have been magical.

Escape From Colditz (Channel 4) was curiously appropriate. Colditz, like Gormenghast, is a medieval castle, riddled with hidden rooms, attics, basements, forgotten passages, crypts and chimneys. In both cases any attempt to escape was punished by solitary confinement.

One small Scot was chosen for a snap escape because he could be crammed into a mattress like a dormouse in a teapot. With theatrical flair, an Englishman and a Dutchman improvised German uniforms from Dutch grey greatcoats, cut eagles out of linoleum and, tellingly, passed themselves off as a captain and a first lieutenant. The effect on a highly discliplined force was delightful. They passed through the guard room by shouting "Achtung!" Other ranks sprang to attention, eyes front, and the sergeant, who knew his place, opened the door for them. The armed guard at the gate was slow to salute. Another shout and he jumped to it. I am sure there's a moral in there somewhere.

Toni Luteijn, the Dutchman, is still around to tell the tale. Airey Neave, the Englishman, is not.

Cyning Meadowcroft is the sort of eccentric with whom you would hesitate to share a table in an all-night cafe, but who is the making of any TV programme. The gist of The Day Britain Died (BBC 2) is that Britain seems to be returning to its original elements. Things fall apart, the cement cannot hold. Cyning (an Anglo-Saxon version of his name, Roy) is that unexpected thing, an English nationalist. A Birmingham boy in Wales, he lived in fear of the house being burnt down. Patrick Campbell's celebrated stammer dated from a Irish attempt to do just that.

Try not to antagonise a child. It makes a lifelong impression. Cyning now spends every Wednesday, prime minister's question day, outside parliament waving a flag of St George, crying stertorously "Support the English parliament!" and receiving friendly support from passing motorists ("Send Tony Blair back to Scotland!")

This short series comes from BBC Scotland.

Much the most tantalising moment of Trafalgar Tales (Channel 4), a tiny series about what to put on the empty plinth in Trafalgar Square, was the reminder that in May this becomes the responsibility of the new Mayor. Ah-ha! How do you rate Newton's chances? Meanwhile the Vacant Plinth Advisory Group (chairman: Rumpole) keeps busy and, when possible, a straight face. The people's choice so far is a horse. Just a horse.

"If I hadn't been an alcoholic, I'd be a High Court Judge." Clarissa Dickson Wright on Parkinson (BBC 1).

Spot the flaw in this argument.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Futurama
fields.body:
Futurama

8.30pm, Sky One

The crew of the universe's most inept delivery firm go on a company outing for this second season opener. And where does the Professor choose to take his employees? Yup, on the maiden voyage of the intergalactic cruise ship Titanic, where Bender's lovelife soon enters the DiCaprio zone.

The Big Lebowski

(Joel Coen, 1998)

10.05pm, Sky Premier

A wonderful, wacky Coen brothers comedy that filters a noir plot - complete with kidnap, mistaken identity, greed, sexual attraction, a severed toe - through the confused consciousness of hippy throwback the Dude (Jeff Bridges), aka Lebowski. Helping him navigate the dangerous world of a rich namesake when he'd rather be going bowling is the hilarious double act of John Goodman's Vietnam vet Walter and Steve Buscemi's dopey Donny. John Turturro's cameo as bowling maestro Jesus Quintana is just the icing on the cake.

The Last Seduction

(John Dahl, 1994)

10.30pm, FilmFour

Linda Fiorentino's femme fatale is far, far deadlier than the males in Dahl's dazzling thriller. On the run from husband Bill Pullman (she's ripped him off after his drugs deal), she fetches up in a hick town and finds a fall guy in Peter Berg, who thinks he's struck lucky. The plot is a series of vicious convolutions, and with the late great JT Walsh involved, it's as good as modern noir gets.

Badlands

(Terence Malick, 1973) 11.50pm, Sky Cinema

Malick's brilliant debut paints a vivid picture of two alienated young Americans who become almost innocent killers. Martin Sheen plays Kit, the garbageman who falls for Sissy Spacek's 15-year-old Holly: the union is sealed in blood when he murders her father (Warren Oates). There are hints here of Malick's mystical war film, The Thin Red Line: brutalities committed in stunning landscapes, here the Dakota Badlands; and the inner monologues of people stumbling after the meaning of it all.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The ambiguous official attitude towards children with special educational needs comes under scrutiny in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). The government has set its face against the special schools which many of the children attend, saying that they perpetuate social division. Unfortunately, as Mark Whitaker reports, experience of placing all such children in mainstream schools has not been encouraging.
fields.body:
The ambiguous official attitude towards children with special educational needs comes under scrutiny in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). The government has set its face against the special schools which many of the children attend, saying that they perpetuate social division. Unfortunately, as Mark Whitaker reports, experience of placing all such children in mainstream schools has not been encouraging.

Did the neighbours throw up their hands in horror when William and Frances Nightingale celebrated their Tuscan fling by naming the resulting child Florence? They'd never have got away with it in Italy or France, of course. But Brits have a long and slapdash record of naming their offspring: one poor lad is now going through life as Utensil. Tom Baker looks at the present state of the game in John, Paul, George ... But Not Ringo (9.0pm, Radio 2).

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText:
Bad day
Not a good one for the Tory party's four month old internet service provider which so far has managed to sign up only 1,300 members from a potential party faithful of 350,000. Signing up gives users an email address ending tory.org. Sadly one enterprising but suspect Conservative has registered himself as sleaze@tory.org.

Bad day
Not a good one for the Tory party's four month old internet service provider which so far has managed to sign up only 1,300 members from a potential party faithful of 350,000. Signing up gives users an email address ending tory.org. Sadly one enterprising but suspect Conservative has registered himself as sleaze@tory.org.

Beastly day
Joy unconfined for the Labour party as the Beast of Bolsover Dennis Skinner took his seat in the Commons once more after a few weeks off for an operation. True to form he launched into a fiery attack on incoming BBC director-general Greg Dyke, saying he should concentrate on running the BBC and not his outside share interests. Culture secretary Chris Smith replied: "Can I say first to you how wonderful it is to see you back in such robust form?"

Eyesore of the day
Former Tory minister Nicholas Soames urged a review of "the very unattractive" brown road signs used in England to point out major attractions. The Billy Bunter lookalike pressed junior culture minister Janet Anderson: "Would you see what you could do to come up with a new and different and altogether more handsome colour?"

webTitle: Curb on peers angers Lib Dems

fields.headline: Curb on peers angers Lib Dems
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: A row between Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy over a new batch of working peers for the House of Lords is deadlocked after the government rejected Lib Dem calls for 35 new peerages.
fields.body:
A row between Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy over a new batch of working peers for the House of Lords is deadlocked after the government rejected Lib Dem calls for 35 new peerages.

Government sources last night dismissed as wholly unrealistic Lib Dem claims that, if Labour was to gain an expected extra 50 peers in two tranches, their party should get at least 35. The sources also rejected Lib Dem threats to withdraw cooperation with the government in the Lords, arguing that the move would make little difference. "They don't really cooperate anyway, so I'm not sure what we would miss," the source said.

Lib Dems argue they are being punished by Mr Blair for failing to vote with the government on issues such as the new limits on jury trial. The party leadership, including its leader in the Lords, Lord Rogers, is furious at the government's response.

With the party looking set to be offered only around six places this time round, Mr Charles Kennedy is facing a tough challenge in whittling down a long list of contenders.

One name certain to be put forward by Mr Kennedy is Rupert Redesdale, a former Lib Dem hereditary peer who sacrificed the chance to fight for a place as one of the 92 hereditaries to stay on in the Lords following abolition by the government.

Other places are regarded as still up for grabs, though according to party rules Mr Kennedy must choose from a 50-strong list of contenders elected by activists last year or from the ranks of MPs, with the option to add one name of his own choosing. Insiders last night predicted that Jane Bonham-Carter, the great-granddaughter of Liberal prime minister Herbert Asquith and former Lib Dem communications chief, would be on the list.

Another name being floated is Tony Greaves, a well-known activist on the radical wing of the party who came high up the internal ballot.

fields.headline: Passport officials savaged by MPs
fields.standfirst: Home office admits football fans bill is absorbed in higher fee
fields.trailText: MPs launched last night a savage attack on the fiasco that delayed and ruined the summer holidays for thousands of people applying for passports.
fields.body:
MPs launched last night a savage attack on the fiasco that delayed and ruined the summer holidays for thousands of people applying for passports.

The former home office minister Charles Wardle accused senior management in the home office and passport agency of "not being able to negotiate their way out of paper bag" in handling the crisis that led to tens of thousands of people queueing for hours outside their offices across Britain.

They were furious when they were told that Siemens who installed a hi-tech computer system that processed fewer passports than the present one will pay up only £2.45m of the £12.6m bill for the debacle.

Sir David Omand, the £100,000 a year permanent secretary at the home office, admitted to MPs that "the public will have to pay" for the rest of disaster forcing the cost of a passport from £21 to £28 last month.

The MPs on the Commons public accounts committee - Parliament's spending watchdog - had summoned Sir David, David Gatenby, the former director of the passport agency, Bernard Herdan, the new director, and Gary Pusey, the managing director of Siemens Business Services, to explain what had gone wrong.

Sir David told MPs that the government's much promised efficiency savings from the new system will not start to work until next year and will not have a real impact until 2004.

In the meantime the public will have to pay much higher fees - including recouping the cost of thousands of umbrellas and luncheon vouchers paid out to people queueing for hours in the rain.

Officials also admitted yesterday that the foreign office has also quietly transfered the cost of repatriating football hooligans, visiting British criminals in foreign jails and organising rescue attempts for British citizens kidnapped abroad to the passport fee.

As a result some £9 of the existing £28 now goes to paying for the consul services abroad - the only area not covered is the loan of cash to stranded Britons which is recovered from the people involved.

The most vicious criticism came from Mr Wardle who accused senior management of a couldn't care less attitude which lead Sir David to say "I resent that attitude"

Cross questioning from Mr Wardle revealed that Sir David had thought of sacking the chief executive but had taken no action as he was due to retire last September as the crisis had begun to recede.

Siemens managing director, Mr Pusey disclosed that the company had £1.4bn worth of public sector contracts - two of which, the passport agency and immigration directorate were in trouble. "

"Siemens seem to be the company that keeps people out of Britain and prevents the rest from leaving," Alan Williams, Labour MP for Swansea West, told him.

Alan Campbell, the Labour MP for Tynemouth, disclosed that one of his constiuents had made 424 calls to the passport agency before they could get their problem solves. Others had to travel from the north-east to Liverpool to get their passports in time.

fields.headline: Battery-charged Benn
fields.standfirst: He may be old Labour, but Tony Benn yesterday proved he can be more forward-looking than many of his Westminster colleagues,  writes Lucy Ward.
fields.trailText: He may be old Labour, but Tony Benn yesterday proved he can be more forward-looking than many of his Westminster colleagues,  writes Lucy Ward.
fields.body:
The Chesterfield MP road-tested the Sparrow - a new eco-friendly car billed as the transport of the new millennium - on its first British outing.

The tiny single-seater machine, a bubble on three wheels, has a battery under its bonnet and can be charged from the mains in two hours.

Mr Benn, whose constituency is home to Ecovac Plc, the company responsible for the 65mph top speed Sparrow, said: "I haven't had so much fun since I learnt to fly in the RAF. This morning was the first time I had driven one. I was a bit nervous at first but was able to just get in and drive away."

A spokeswoman said Mr Benn, in true old Labour fashion, had rejected a blue car and asked for a red one.

fields.headline: Lord Halsbury
fields.standfirst: Aristocrat who applied a scientific mind to business and academia
fields.trailText: In 1966, Brunel College of Advanced Technology, at Uxbridge, west London, was designated a university. Its mission was to produce useful and employable graduates, and undertake applied research in the sciences and technology. It was the scientist, businessman and public servant Lord Halsbury, who has died aged 91, who became its first chancellor.
fields.body:
In 1966, Brunel College of Advanced Technology, at Uxbridge, west London, was designated a university. Its mission was to produce useful and employable graduates, and undertake applied research in the sciences and technology. It was the scientist, businessman and public servant Lord Halsbury, who has died aged 91, who became its first chancellor.

The next 31 years showed that an inspired choice had been made. A university chancellorship is largely an honorific office, giving little power but much opportunity to meddle. On matters of university policy, a chancellor does well to speak only when spoken to and then sparingly.

Tony Halsbury was an ideal chancellor. His opinion, given only when sought, was always careful, measured and constructive. But his interest and commitment were boundless. He had an unquenchable thirst for knowledge, and his desire to learn ever more about the university's disciplines made him hugely popular among the academics. He listened carefully to the concerns of students without ever interfering in the decisions which might follow.

His annual graduation address, always delivered extempore, was built round "whatever is on my mind at the moment". Thus we were treated to scholarly, entertaining - and sometimes critical - analyses of British industry, modern management techniques, the two cultures, current parliamentary legislation and, on one occasion, the rightness of the Falklands war.

It was Halsbury who, between 1961 and 1963, was chairman of the committee on decimal currency. Thus did he help prepare the country for the 1971 decimalisation. He argued for the retention of the pound, and it is probably to him that we owe the distinctive design of the 50p piece.

Halsbury was the only son of the second Earl of Halsbury. He was educated at Eton, an experience he thoroughly enjoyed and which provided him with several lifelong friendships, including one with Quintin Hogg (later Lord Hailsham). After Eton, at his father's wish, he spent three years with a firm of chartered accountants and then, at Chelsea polytechnic, took a first-class degree in chemistry and maths. Meanwhile, he earned money as a French and Spanish interpreter. Later, he added Russian, and once even made a speech in Bulgarian.

In 1935, Halsbury joined the firm of Lever Brothers on Merseyside. His discovery that vitamin A was two substances, subsequently named vitamin A1 and vitamin A2, was to him his greatest achievement. Lever Brothers probably appreciated more the speed with which he doubled the profits of the subsidiary company of which he was given charge. He left in 1942 after a dispute about the extent of his involvement with the Home Guard, which he had joined when the army turned him down.

He moved to the Brown Firth research laboratories, converted himself into a metallurgist, and worked on jet engine development until 1947, when he became director of research to the the Decca record company, playing a crucial role in developing vinyl long-playing records. He succeeded to the title in 1943.

In 1949, Halsbury began 10 years as managing director at the National Research Development Corporation, set up originally to protect investors and patents originating in the public sector against unauthorised exploitation. But Halsbury decided that its potential lay in developing public-private sector partnerships- and today's close and fertile relationship between universities and industry owes much to his pioneering work. But he did not lose sight of private sector initiatives, and his championing of laser development by G&E Bradley Ltd, a subsidiary of Lucas Industries, of which he was a director, led to an essential tool of everyday life.

Halsbury made his maiden speech in the House of Lords in 1952, after which he became a frequent contributor to debates, sitting as a cross- bencher. He sat on, and presided over, many committees and public bodies. These included chairing the Science Museum advisory council from 1951 to 1965, the review body on doctors' and dentists' pay from 1971 to 1974 (from which he resigned) and the departmental committee of inquiry into the pay of nurses, midwives, speech therapists and professions supplementary to medicine from 1974 to 1975.

Halsbury's influence on our nation was considerable, but he wore the many honours he received with characteristic modesty. He was totally open, honest and uninterested in status or position, his or anyone else's. He was greatly respected and greatly loved.

His first marriage ended in divorce, and his second wife predeceased him. He leaves a son from the first marriage, and two daughters from the second.

David Neave

Professor Tony Ledwith, president of the Royal Society of Chemistry, writes: Tony Halsbury was a great friend of the society, of which he was an honorary fellow. He was a tireless advocate for science throughout his 80s and well into his 90s.

In the Lords, he spoke on a wide range of legislation relevant to science, and to chemistry in particular, and moved amendments on many subjects, including the food safety bill, and, in 1996, the chemical weapons bill, where he began his speech by recalling that he had listened to a 1924 Lords debate when peers spoke with direct experience of the effect of gas in the first world war.

He also played a key role in the 1990s in hosting part of the highly successful series of the Royal Society's parliamentary link days, which are the largest scientific meetings held in the House. Last June, I presented him with the society's parliamentary award for his contribution to the cause of science.

He spoke from the crossbenches for the last time on the very last day before the summer recess of 1999, speaking both on the food standards bill and later to thank the staff of the House for all their work.

John Anthony Hardinge Gifford, 3rd Earl of Halsbury, scientist and businessman, born June 4 1908; died January 14 2000

fields.headline: Saeb Salam
fields.standfirst: Breaking the mould in Lebanon
fields.trailText: The former Lebanese prime minister Saeb Salam, who has died aged 95, rose above politics by religious label in a career that spanned most of Lebanon's existence as a modern state. He was the last of a generation of politicians who played a role in the process of independence from the French mandate.
fields.body:
The former Lebanese prime minister Saeb Salam, who has died aged 95, rose above politics by religious label in a career that spanned most of Lebanon's existence as a modern state. He was the last of a generation of politicians who played a role in the process of independence from the French mandate.

Born to a notable Sunni Muslim family with a liberal attitude towards religion and the emancipation of women (his sister, Anbara Salam Khalidy, was the first to abandon the veil in public), Salam's father, Salim, was a member of the Ottoman parliament and a leading merchant. Both men had great influence on educational reform, through their control of the Islamic Society for Benevolent Intentions (the Maqasid).

Salam's political career began in 1943 when he was elected as MP for Beirut just before independence. He was prime minister six times, initially for just four days in 1952 under president Beshara El Khoury, before he switched to the opposition, a move that brought President Camille Chamoun to power. After working with Chamoun, Salam later led the opposition to his pro-western politics.

Egypt's President Nasser commanded a considerable following in Lebanon at this time, and Salam supported him against Chamoun (although he later opposed Nasser's interventions in Lebanon). After losing the 1957 elections, he organised the armed rebellion of 1958, during which he established himself as a strong man with a populist following and helped bring General Fouad Chehab to the presidency.

Salam was firmly behind the election of President Frangié in 1970 and formed with him a government of young technocrats from outside the political arena, the first experiment of its kind in Lebanon. He resigned when Frangié refused to dismiss the chief of the army following an Israeli raid on Beirut (led by the present Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak), in which three Palestinian leaders were killed.

In 1982, Salam remained in Beirut during the Israeli siege and contributed to the deal that led to Yasser Arafat leaving the city. He was also a supporter of the 1983 abortive agreement with Israel. While these were not popular stands in his community, they came as the Lebanese civil war, in which he adopted a moderate position, was throwing up a new class of leadership and displacing the traditional, notable political families.

After surviving several assassination attempts, Salam went into exile in Geneva in 1985, playing a key role in the Taif agreement that ended the Lebanese civil war. His return to Beirut in 1994 was celebrated for weeks.

A successful entrepreneur, he had established the Compagnie Aerienne Libanaise (which became Middle East Airlines) in 1945, and was its chairman until 1956. In that year, as minister for oil affairs, he negotiated deals with Aramco and Tapline which led to the establishment of refineries in Lebanon.

Salam was a charismatic figure, whose trade marks were a cigar and a carnation in his buttonhole. He was famous for aphorisms like "one Lebanon not two", his slogan during the civil war of 1976.

He is survived by his wife, two sons and two daughters.

Nedim Shehadi

fields.headline: Friedrich Gulda
fields.standfirst: Gifted pianist on a musical journey from the classics to jazz
fields.trailText: W hen the world was informed nine months ago, on March 28, that the Austrian pianist Friedrich Gulda had died, colleagues and critics lined up to pay tribute to a great musician and eccentric. But only days later, Gulda let journalists know that he was still very much alive and well, and would be playing at a "resurrection party" soon.
fields.body:
W hen the world was informed nine months ago, on March 28, that the Austrian pianist Friedrich Gulda had died, colleagues and critics lined up to pay tribute to a great musician and eccentric. But only days later, Gulda let journalists know that he was still very much alive and well, and would be playing at a "resurrection party" soon. Perhaps he just wanted to test the truth of an injunction he had given against obituaries in a recent interview: "People have thrown so much muck at me while I am alive," he said, "I do not want them to chuck it into my grave as well."

Gulda, who became famous as an interpreter of Beeth- oven, Bach, Mozart and Debussy, but later turned to jazz and to composition, had begun as a classical pianist in his home city, Vienna. He rose through the stages of a pianist's life seemingly effortlessly, winning the prestigious Geneva competition at the age of 16.

He gave his Carnegie Hall debut at the age of 20, and was soon regarded as one of the most important interpreters of the postwar period, travelling the world with his groundbreaking interpretation of the complete Beethoven sonatas, which already showed his distinctively sparing use of pedal, accentuated bass lines, grand legato, and percussive use of the keyboard.

However, like Glenn Gould, who was two years his junior, Gulda quickly became bored and disillusioned with the concert circuit, its rigid programmes, canons and dress codes. Even the compositions of "the great dead" seemed to alienate him, and he turned to ever more eccentric projects.

When awarded the Vienna Beethoven Ring in 1969, he rejected it with grand gesture, one incident of many in a long and tortuous relationship with his home town. He played Mozart in Vienna's holy of holies, the Musik- verein, tapping along with his feet. On another occasion, he and his girlfriend appeared on stage naked for a rendition of Schumann songs on the recorder.

Gulda turned more and more to jazz for musical nourishment. Completely disregarding the printed programmes during classical concerts, he would treat his audiences (who were not always happy about the privilege) to extended improvis- ations in the middle of pieces and to performances of his own compositions. After 1995 he also played regular techno sessions with the Liverpool DJ Vertigo.

Gulda's attempt to launch a second career as a jazz pianist was hindered by the distrust of jazz fans, who were unsure of his motives. In any event, his ambition to scale the fence between "classical" and "popular" music - or to tear it down altogether - failed, largely because he came too strongly from the former. "Jazz," Gulda once explained, "is the music of our day, the only modern, progressive music. Schoenberg is not really new, neither is Bartok, and the experimental composers certainly aren't. They are only trying to cast the past in concrete. Schoenberg does it dogmatically, Bartok with folklore."

Despite these convictions, Gulda never ceased to play classical music entirely, and his recordings of Bach's Welltempered Clavier and Beeth- oven's sonatas from the late 1960s and 70s still belong to the best readings on disc. It seems paradoxical that an interpreter whose style is marked so much by strictness, simplicity and clarity should have insisted so vocally that the only thing that counted was playfulness.

A contradictory artist, Gulda had a troubled relationship with the press. Critics often reacted with hostility to his more experimental work, and showed that they neither could, nor wanted to, understand what he was trying to do. The same was true for a musical establishment that could neither integrate nor dismiss this prodigal son. Never quite able to abandon the concert platform, he found a new generation of enthusiastic listeners for his Mozart playing during the 1980s, even if he did not make it easy for his public. After he had failed to turn up for one of his concerts, he simply stated that he had visited the chess world championship instead. "Suddenly, I found that more exciting," he explained.

Gulda's dress rehearsal for his own death caused a predictably exasperated reaction in the musical world, and when the news of his actual death was announced last week, discreet requests for confirmation were met with the death certificate issued by the local doctor in Weissenbach, Austria, which told the blunt story: Friedrich Gulda died of heart failure on January 27 2000.

Philipp Blom

Friedrich Gulda, pianist and composer, born May 16 1930; died January 27 2000
fields.bodyText: W hen the world was informed nine months ago, on March 28, that the Austrian pianist Friedrich Gulda had died, colleagues and critics lined up to pay tribute to a great musician and eccentric. But only days later, Gulda let journalists know that he was still very much alive and well, and would be playing at a "resurrection party" soon. Perhaps he just wanted to test the truth of an injunction he had given against obituaries in a recent interview: "People have thrown so much muck at me while I am alive," he said, "I do not want them to chuck it into my grave as well." Gulda, who became famous as an interpreter of Beeth- oven, Bach, Mozart and Debussy, but later turned to jazz and to composition, had begun as a classical pianist in his home city, Vienna. He rose through the stages of a pianist's life seemingly effortlessly, winning the prestigious Geneva competition at the age of 16. He gave his Carnegie Hall debut at the age of 20, and was soon regarded as one of the most important interpreters of the postwar period, travelling the world with his groundbreaking interpretation of the complete Beethoven sonatas, which already showed his distinctively sparing use of pedal, accentuated bass lines, grand legato, and percussive use of the keyboard. However, like Glenn Gould, who was two years his junior, Gulda quickly became bored and disillusioned with the concert circuit, its rigid programmes, canons and dress codes. Even the compositions of "the great dead" seemed to alienate him, and he turned to ever more eccentric projects. When awarded the Vienna Beethoven Ring in 1969, he rejected it with grand gesture, one incident of many in a long and tortuous relationship with his home town. He played Mozart in Vienna's holy of holies, the Musik- verein, tapping along with his feet. On another occasion, he and his girlfriend appeared on stage naked for a rendition of Schumann songs on the recorder. Gulda turned more and more to jazz for musical nourishment. Completely disregarding the printed programmes during classical concerts, he would treat his audiences (who were not always happy about the privilege) to extended improvis- ations in the middle of pieces and to performances of his own compositions. After 1995 he also played regular techno sessions with the Liverpool DJ Vertigo. Gulda's attempt to launch a second career as a jazz pianist was hindered by the distrust of jazz fans, who were unsure of his motives. In any event, his ambition to scale the fence between "classical" and "popular" music - or to tear it down altogether - failed, largely because he came too strongly from the former. "Jazz," Gulda once explained, "is the music of our day, the only modern, progressive music. Schoenberg is not really new, neither is Bartok, and the experimental composers certainly aren't. They are only trying to cast the past in concrete. Schoenberg does it dogmatically, Bartok with folklore." Despite these convictions, Gulda never ceased to play classical music entirely, and his recordings of Bach's Welltempered Clavier and Beeth- oven's sonatas from the late 1960s and 70s still belong to the best readings on disc. It seems paradoxical that an interpreter whose style is marked so much by strictness, simplicity and clarity should have insisted so vocally that the only thing that counted was playfulness. A contradictory artist, Gulda had a troubled relationship with the press. Critics often reacted with hostility to his more experimental work, and showed that they neither could, nor wanted to, understand what he was trying to do. The same was true for a musical establishment that could neither integrate nor dismiss this prodigal son. Never quite able to abandon the concert platform, he found a new generation of enthusiastic listeners for his Mozart playing during the 1980s, even if he did not make it easy for his public. After he had failed to turn up for one of his concerts, he simply stated that he had visited the chess world championship instead. "Suddenly, I found that more exciting," he explained. Gulda's dress rehearsal for his own death caused a predictably exasperated reaction in the musical world, and when the news of his actual death was announced last week, discreet requests for confirmation were met with the death certificate issued by the local doctor in Weissenbach, Austria, which told the blunt story: Friedrich Gulda died of heart failure on January 27 2000. fields.trailText: Dick Leonard writes: Willie Hamilton (Obituary, January 26) was far from being a "loner" in the parliamentary Labour party, at least during my brief term in the House (1970-74). With Douglas Houghton and Charles Pannell, he took enormous pains in guiding new Labour members through the tricky shoals of procedure.
fields.body:
Dick Leonard writes: Willie Hamilton (Obituary, January 26) was far from being a "loner" in the parliamentary Labour party, at least during my brief term in the House (1970-74). With Douglas Houghton and Charles Pannell, he took enormous pains in guiding new Labour members through the tricky shoals of procedure.

He was a dedicated House of Commons man, and once shyly confessed to me that his highest ambition was to become speaker, a post for which he was well qualified by virtue of his chairmanship of important committees. It was never on - nor was he ever likely to have been offered ministerial office. His views on royalty, if sometimes maladroitly expressed, deserved more respect than they usually received.

webTitle: Death penalty blocked after unsafe verdicts

fields.headline: Death penalty blocked after unsafe verdicts
fields.trailText: The state of Illinois suspended executions yesterday because 13 questionable death sentences have been overturned on appeal. Opponents of capital punishment hailed the move as a victory for common sense over the pursuit of legal retribution.
fields.body:
The state of Illinois suspended executions yesterday because 13 questionable death sentences have been overturned on appeal. Opponents of capital punishment hailed the move as a victory for common sense over the pursuit of legal retribution.

"There is no margin for error when it comes to putting a person to death," the Illinois governor, George Ryan, said as he announced he would sign no more death warrants.

"Until I can be sure that everyone sentenced to death in Illinois is truly guilty no one will meet that fate."

Mr Ryan called for a special commission to be set up to study Illinois's capital punishment system in light of the 13 cases overturned since the state's death penalty was reinstated in 1977 following an earlier supreme court moratorium. Twelve convicts have been executed in that period.

In one case last year a college journalism class proved the innocence of Anthony Porter, who had spent 15 years on death row and who came within two days of being executed. A court found he had been convicted for murder on the basis of "a tapestry of lies and manipulations".

In recent weeks, charges were dropped against a former Chicago police officer who had been sentenced to die on the basis of testimony by a prison informant.

Mr Ryan said he still supported the death penalty in principle, but had decided on a moratorium. "I found it amazing that 35 people were convicted and put on death row who were defended by attorneys who had either been disbarred or disqualified from being attorneys.

He added: "There's a problem in this system and it needs to be studied and we need to have some answers before we put innocent people to death."

The governor said that of the 300 capital cases in Illinois since 1977 more than half are being retried.

Bill Ryan, the chairman of the Death Penalty Moratorium project, said the moratorium was "a very positive sign and it took courage on the part of the governor".

"It's long overdue," said Jed Stone, a Chicago lawyer who campaigns against the death penalty. "The public lacks confidence in the criminal justice system that results in wrongful convictions of innocent people and the governor is right to say let's study it before we ever again use it."

Of the 37 other US states with the death penalty, only one other, Nebraska, has considered suspending capital punishment. The Nebraska state legislature voted for a moratorium last year, but it was vetoed by the governor.

In most opinion polls, about three out of four Americans say they support capital punishment. But campaigners say that public opinion shifts according to the question asked. They say most Americans oppose executions of mentally retarded convicts and would be less enthusiastic about the death penalty if life imprisonment without any chance of parole was an alternative.

fields.headline: Airline offers relatives little comfort
fields.standfirst:
Nearly 24 hours after a jet crashed off Ivory Coast, the names of the 169 who died were still not known
www.kenyaairways.co.uk Kenya Airways www.airbus.com Airbus
fields.trailText: The security man ordered to keep the victims' families at bay summed up the airline's attitude well enough: "The dead are dead. Let's look after the living."
fields.body:
The security man ordered to keep the victims' families at bay summed up the airline's attitude well enough: "The dead are dead. Let's look after the living."

But no one could tell the relatives gathered at Lagos airport who had survived and who had died after a Kenya Airways airbus 310, destined for Nigeria, crashed minutes after taking off from Ivory Coast on Sunday night.

Only 10 of the 179 passengers and crew survived after the jet plunged into the Atlantic. French soldiers and Ivorian fishermen helped pull the survivors and dozens of bodies from the water. One passenger swam to shore.

The Dutch airline KLM handles Kenya Airways flights to Lagos so it was to the European company that distraught relatives looked for information and solace at Lagos airport. They received little of either.

When the relatives stormed the airline's office after waiting several hours for someone to address them, KLM called the police. Its Dutch managers stationed security guards at the door and refused to talk to anyone. Relatives were left stranded in a corridor.

Tayo Russell had been waiting since 2am for word about her mother and sister. After eight hours, there was still no news. "All we want is for them to tell us what is going on. I've been living in Chicago since 1990. When anything like this happens in America they have a room for relatives and counselling, even if they can't tell you the list of the dead. But here they tell the security to take us away from the office. They don't really feel for you," she said.

A few hours later, the distraught relatives were ushered to the arrivals hall and left to sit on the floor under the gaze of bewildered passers-by. No food or drink was offered. Those asking the airline if they could make a phone call were told to buy a phonecard.

A woman who arrived at the airport wondering why a relative had not turned up broke down on hearing of the crash. She repeatedly banged her head on the stone steps and cried out "I love you, I love you, I love you", until she was carried away bleeding and bruised.

It was left to a Nigerian airport official to plead gently with the other relatives to stay calm. "We are as anxious as you to get the passenger list. At least you will be able to say my brother is dead or my brother is not dead. Just pray and stay calm," he said.

Officials blamed the delay in establishing who was on board the plane on the fact that the flight had been re-routed because of bad weather and convoluted communications which forced information to be transmitted via Amsterdam.

After 12 hours, the relatives were finally offered chairs and soft drinks. The anger was replaced by a growing sense of hopelessness.

Then the news came. An airline official read out a list of seven of the survivors, but said the names of the dead, nationals from at least 23 countries, including Britain, had still not been released.

It was enough. One man walked away with a smile as a great wail went up.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Kosovans held by UN police
United Nations police have arrested 14 Kosovo Albanians they suspect of being behind burglary, robbery and a grenade attack on the Pristina offices of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, the UN said yesterday.
fields.body:
Kosovans held by UN police
United Nations police have arrested 14 Kosovo Albanians they suspect of being behind burglary, robbery and a grenade attack on the Pristina offices of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, the UN said yesterday.

UN police initially detained two men last week in connection with the OECD attack. No one was hurt in the incident. Others were detained in connection with two burglary rings which have been targeting the homes of UN staff. [Reuters, Pristina ]

Suicide guide to be televised
A do-it-yourself suicide programme to be aired on television in Oregon this week has been labelled as "reckless", by one right-to-die organisation.

The programme is based on the book Final Exit by Derek Humphry, which has sold more than 1m copies in 12 languages.

Barbara Coombs Lee of the Portland-based Compassion in Dying Federation, said: "I think it's reckless. It can give people the means to act on impulsiveness." [AP, Portland]

No ban on pencils for Iraq
The UN yesterday denied it has banned the export of pencils to Iraq because their graphite lead could be put to military use. It said pencils are entering Iraq under a UN-authorised programme. [AP, Baghdad]

fields.headline: Iran's reformists face long odds
fields.standfirst: Parliamentary election to test political legacy of president's family
fields.trailText: The contemporary movement Iranians consider as important as the Islamic revolution took root about a half century ago in this desert town. It was here that one Ayatollah Ruhollah Khatami raised a few chickens and, more important, a son who was to become president.
fields.body:
The contemporary movement Iranians consider as important as the Islamic revolution took root about a half century ago in this desert town. It was here that one Ayatollah Ruhollah Khatami raised a few chickens and, more important, a son who was to become president.

Today, the people of this small town known for its elegant wind towers are feeling more than the usual desert heat. In less than three weeks' time, the family's legacy will be tested when Iranians go to the polls in a parliamentary election.

For Ardakan, this referendum is not solely about politics; it is a vote for a family who shaped this region with the religious and social values that many Iranians believe are the essence of the nation.

The Islamic Iran Participation Front's Mohammad Reza Tabesh, the candidate from President Mohammad Khatami's faction, grew up in the family compound. He ate chocolates out of the hand of Mr Khatami's grandmother. He saw the president's father, the district's most prominent theologian, recite the Koran in an enclosed area on their adobe rooftop.

"The next parliament is important. I am a candidate to make sure we will win," said Mr Tabesh. "If you want to see reforms, the parliament must be in harmony with the president."

When Mr Khatami became president in May 1997, he began leading a movement for social and political reform unprecedented in Iran.

"I left my job as an aide to the president to run in the election," said Mr Tabesh. "This is how important we consider this race."

Mr Tabesh's main rival in the race is also part of the family's political history. Ali Akbar Hosseini-Nejad was a family friend. But when Mr Khatami ran for president in 1997, Mr Hosseini-Nejad supported the rival conservative candidate. In doing so, he was thought to have betrayed the family.

Like his switch, the political affiliations of many of the estimated 6,000 candidates running in the February 18 poll are unpredictable.

Some candidates are running as "independents" to gain votes but, in reality, they are conservatives.

The Guardian council, a group of conservative clerics and jurists who supervise the election, has disqualified many prominent reform candidates from the race, hoping to give a boost to the conservatives. This leaves voters with a big challenge ahead.

Whether the reformists or conservatives win a majority of seats will largely depend on the electorate's ability to predict how the candidates will behave in parliament once elected.

As a result, Ardakan residents are concerned about political labelling. Omid Tabatabai, an 18-year-old university student, wants access to the internet in his classroom and believes conservatives are an obstacle to such progress.

"Iran is behind the world. In my university, there is no internet connection, there is no access to the world," Mr Tabatabai said. "In the last election, we voted for Hosseini-Nejad, but this time we won't make the same mistake."

Members of the Khatami family are known in the Yazd province as crusaders for civil rights and religious freedom, even during times when such values were denied to the rest of Iran under the Shah.

The question is now whether they will be able to carry the same message nationwide in defiance of a system stacked against them.

webTitle: Indonesia's president says he will sack top commander

fields.headline: Indonesia's president says he will sack top commander
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Indonesia's human rights commission yesterday formally accused the country's former military commander General Wiranto of "crimes against humanity" during and after last year's independence referendum in East Timor.
fields.body:
Indonesia's human rights commission yesterday formally accused the country's former military commander General Wiranto of "crimes against humanity" during and after last year's independence referendum in East Timor.

The president, Abdurrahman Wahid, four days into a 16-day overseas tour, said that he would sack General Wiranto, who is now coordinating minister for politics and security, as soon as he returned home.

Five other generals were among 33 people named in a wide-ranging report by the state-appointed commission on the destruction wreaked in East Timor after parliament in Jakarta voted to grant independence to the territory last August. The report was submitted to the attorney general.

But some of the investigators expressed doubts whether General Wiranto would ever stand trial.

"Facts show that the civilian and military apparatus, including the police, cooperated with the militias to create an atmosphere that supported crimes against humanity," said the commission chairman, Djoko Sugianto. "These were in the form of mass killings, torture, kidnapping, violence against women - including rape and sexual slavery - forced evacuations and total destruction of property."

Albert Hasibuan, who led the investigative committee, said General Wiranto had committed "sins of omission". He was "fully aware of the human rights abuses that were taking place, but did not take effective measures to stop them".

The other five generals named are army and police commanders who had direct responsibility for East Timor. Others on the list include the former civilian governor Abilio Soares and commanders of the militias created by the Indonesian armed forces created to carry out much of the terror.

The attorney general, Marzuki Darusman, said that he would immediately form an investigative team to pursue the commission's findings. But he did not say how long any investigation might take.

No prosecutions are likely for months, or years, partly because Indonesia's new democratic government has yet to draft or enact legislation to establish the human rights court in which anyone might be tried.

President Wahid said after the commission published its findings: "We have to uphold human rights in Indonesia, whatever the course."

Some conservative Indonesian generals rushed to General Wiranto's defence, denying he had committed human rights abuses in East Timor.

But the military's chief spokesman, Major-General Graito Usodo of the air force, said the military "will not block any investigation in any way". He said: "We will support anything that is recommended by the attorney general."

A commission member, HS Dillion, agreed that the military was unlikely to stage a coup to save the generals implicated in the report.

"This is a new Indonesia," he said. "There's no such thing as 'the' army any more. There are many elements in the army. They do not mind shooting their own generals if they have to." But he doubted whether General Wiranto would be tried.

The East Timorese independence leader, Jose Ramos-Horta, demanded yesterday that General Wiranto be brought to justice. "In this day and age you cannot kill hundreds of people, destroy a whole country and then just get fired," he said.

webTitle: Honey, I blew up the cops

fields.headline: Honey, I blew up the cops
fields.standfirst: Kathy Soliah is a contradiction. Now she is a soccer mom in the suburbs, 25 years ago she was connected to the people who kidnapped Patty Hearst. As she comes to trial,  Duncan Campbell  traces the other members of the revolutionary SLA gang
fields.trailText: A quarter of a century ago, Kathy Soliah was working as a cashier in a bookshop in Berkeley, California. Two high points of her recent life had been playing the title role in Hedda Gabler for a local theatre company and giving a eulogy for the six members of a tiny urban guerilla group called the Symbionese Liberation Army who had died in a police shootout in Los Angeles.
fields.body:
A quarter of a century ago, Kathy Soliah was working as a cashier in a bookshop in Berkeley, California. Two high points of her recent life had been playing the title role in Hedda Gabler for a local theatre company and giving a eulogy for the six members of a tiny urban guerilla group called the Symbionese Liberation Army who had died in a police shootout in Los Angeles.

She was approached by a vaguely familiar-looking woman who thrust a note into her hand which said, "Meet me at the church." After she had done so, she was introduced to another familiar-looking woman. They happened to be the two most wanted women in America: one was Emily Harris, one of the leading remaining members of the SLA; the other was the woman the SLA had kidnapped 18 months earlier, newspaper heiress Patty Hearst.

From that moment when she was first recruited to help the SLA to the moment last June when she was arrested, Kathleen Ann Soliah has been a wanted woman herself. Except she stopped being Kathleen Ann Soliah some time ago. At the time of her arrest she was Sarah Olson, a respectable mother of three teenage girls living with her doctor husband, Fred, in St Paul, Minnesota. Her journey from a revolutionary, supposedly ready to hold up banks, to the soccer mom who likes amateur dramatics and writes cookbooks is remarkable in what it says about America then and now. It has also shone the spotlight once again on her fellow SLA members and what has become of them and their beliefs.

Her trial is due to start shortly. Patty Hearst, who says she bears Soliah no animosity, is likely to be forced to testify against her. The case will reopen a period of confrontational history in America that many on both sides of the political spectrum would prefer to forget.

The core members of the SLA, whose slogan was "Death to the fascist insect that preys on the life of the people" are, of course, dead. A mixture of ex-cons and confused middle-class radicals led by the unbalanced Donald DeFreeze, they perished in a gun battle and conflagration in south central Los Angeles during which 9,000 rounds were fired by both sides. The whole saga was watched live on television by Hearst and her surviving fellow members.

Hearst, who, as she tells it in her book, Every Secret Thing, published in 1982, was raped, threatened and cajoled into joining the group, took the name of Tania and participated in SLA actions including a bank robbery, before she was caught in 1975 and jailed for seven years. Her sentence was commuted by the then president Jimmy Carter and she was released after serving 23 months. Further attempts to have her conviction quashed entirely have recently been made by Carter.

Married to her former bodyguard, Bernard Shaw, who is now the director of security for the Hearst Corporation, Hearst has two teenage daughters, the elder at college, is involved in charity work and has made three appearances in the cult films of John Waters.

What happened to Kathy Soliah will now almost certainly make a film and already there is talk in Los Angeles about who will play her part. But what became of the bit players and the political ideas that formed them?

The FBI would dearly love to know the answer to what happened to Kilgore, Kathy's boyfriend at the time. A young political activist from San Rafael in Marin County, Kilgore escaped the final round-up and has never been caught. He featured on America's Most Wanted, the Crimewatch-style programme, last year at the time of the 25th anniversary of the kidnapping. This appeal led to Olson's capture - she is charged under her new name - but has yet to yield anything on Kilgore.

The word is that he has found himself a quiet family life not unlike that of Olson and is waiting to see what happens in her case before he considers giving himself up. If Olson gets 25 years to life, goes the argument, Kilgore is unlikely to come waltzing out of a farmhouse in Nebraska with his hands up. So far none of his friends have nibbled at the $20,000 reward on offer.

The two most powerful members of the group after the deaths of Donald DeFreeze and the others were Emily and Bill Harris, who then operated under the "reborn" Swahili names of Teko and Yolanda, and were arrested while out jogging at the same time as Hearst was caught.

Bill Harris was jailed for eight years for his part in the kidnapping and subsequent SLA crimes and was released in 1983. He now works as a private legal investigator in San Francisco, is married to a lawyer and is a "soccer dad" who takes his young son to practice. He now accepts that the SLA accomplished nothing.

He and Emily Harris, who was also jailed for eight years, divorced not long after they were released. She had taken a computer course inside prison and has since, without hiding her history, found work in the expanding computer world of Los Angeles where she now lives under a different name. Tracked down by the Los Angeles Times, to whom she spoke on the condition that no new photos were taken and her new identity was not revealed, she said: "I made choices, and looking back now some of those choices were extremely reckless and ill-conceived. But I paid the price. I've moved on."

Two others who have also moved on are Josephine Soliah, Kathy's younger sister, who also helped the SLA when the Harrises and Hearst were trying to flee, and who is now a nurse. She is now married to another who helped them, Michael Bortin, who installs hardwood floors. Bortin describes the case as "like a deranged relative knocking at your door every few years".

Jack Scott, the sports writer and former Ramparts journalist who helped Hearst get across country to a safe house on the east coast when she was on the run, was never charged. He still lives in Berkeley with his teenage son, is suffering from throat cancer and runs a sports medicine clinic.

As to the political legacy of the group, the passage of time has barely changed their status. The SLA were seen then by many on the left, from the Black Panthers to the Free Speech Movement to the French Marxist writer Regis Debray who wrote a letter to the San Francisco Examiner attacking the kidnapping, as crazy and counterproductive. Their first "political act" was the murder of Marcus Foster, a black education official in Oakland who was actually pushing through policies approved by the Panthers to try to improve the educational opportunities for young black students. Because Foster wanted ID cards on campus, the SLA suggested he was clearly a fascist and a suitable target, thus alienating what might have been one of their areas of qualified support. As happened during the same period in Europe with the Baader-Meinhof in Germany, the group had no real base or support and their achievements were largely in their own imaginations.

For the LA police, the issue is straightforward: Soliah/Olson is alleged to have tried to kill some of their own by placing nail bombs under police cars, and the passage of time has not softened their attitude. Far from soft-pedalling the case, they have compiled a heavy dossier of evidence and the trial is likely to last much longer than was initially expected. Permission to televise it has been refused, as the judge said that, for Hearst, it would be like being raped again in public.

The trial, which was due to start on Monday, has been temporarily set back because one of Soliah's legal team has withdrawn for family reasons. But the battle for the hearts and minds of the jurors has already begun in a legal system where people are not inhibited from speculating on guilt or innocence by the bothersome strictures of contempt of court.

A gun shop owner in Olson's home town is selling bumper stickers with the legends: "Fight terrorism, jail Kathleen" and "If it ticks, you must convict Soliah". Olson's own team have a large and idiosyncratic web-site with musings from her brother Lance, details of how to buy her fund-raising cookbook, Serving Time, at $21, and pictures of her supporters in their campaign T-shirts. Her detractors call her as evil as Timothy McVeigh, the Oklahoma bomber, and hope that she is jailed for life. Her supporters believe that she was the product of a particular time - Vietnam, Watergate, black power, the military coup in Chile - when some on the left believe that violent behaviour by the authorities merited violent responses.

Strangely enough, Jim Kilgore, the FBI's current most wanted, probably summed up the feelings of many for the SLA when, as Patty Hearst recalls, he challenged Teko in his pre-private detective days and asked: "What did the SLA ever accomplish? You killed a black man, kidnapped a little teenage girl and robbed a bank. What the hell did that amount to?"

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A garbled paragraph in the report of the trial of Denis Day, jailed for the manslaughter of his wife, in early editions on January 29 (page 11) said that Mr Day's mother-in-law, Mrs Joan Bingham, was a humanities teacher at Pembroke school. This is incorrect; it was Mr Day who taught at the school. We apologise for our error.
fields.body:
A garbled paragraph in the report of the trial of Denis Day, jailed for the manslaughter of his wife, in early editions on January 29 (page 11) said that Mr Day's mother-in-law, Mrs Joan Bingham, was a humanities teacher at Pembroke school. This is incorrect; it was Mr Day who taught at the school. We apologise for our error.

The P&O ferry which capsized in 1987 with the loss of 193 lives was the Herald of Free Enterprise; we wrongly gave the vessel's name as the Spirit of Free Enterprise in an article on page 31, January 29.

The graphic accompanying an article (page 4, January 29) about a plan to construct what would be Britain's tallest building in Birmingham, depicted Lincoln cathedral, in the year 1307, with a height of 525 feet. Whatever claim the cathedral had then, its highest point today is 271 feet.

The poem Jean Metcalfe read in her BBC radio debut (Obituary, page 22, January 29) was by Thomas Nashe; not Thomas Ashe as we said.

We misspelled diphtheria as diptheria in the obituary of Kathleen Hale on page 24, January 28.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Egypt steps on the gas
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Alexandria lights way for modern world energy wonder
fields.trailText: Down below, the desert is receding, replaced by rich, lush fields of an astonishing green where scores of impoverished villagers tend their crops. A helicopter ride down the Nile reveals these fields spreading at least 15 kilometres either side of the mighty river.
fields.body:
Down below, the desert is receding, replaced by rich, lush fields of an astonishing green where scores of impoverished villagers tend their crops. A helicopter ride down the Nile reveals these fields spreading at least 15 kilometres either side of the mighty river.

But, at its mouth, where it flows out to the Mediterranean in an extended delta, Egypt hopes to find a new source of wealth for an economy whose GDP per head is 5% that of the UK: the organic material deposited there over millions of years is now a huge source of natural gas.

The gas, say executives of BG International, the exploration and production arm of the former British Gas, could turn highly polluted Cairo, where early morning smog hangs metres deep over the Nile, into a relatively ecological oasis.

But more than that. Like water, it could be the glue that helps hold together the Middle East peace process. There are tentative plans to establish a regional grid providing fuel and power not just to Egypt but to Israel, Jordan, Palestine and beyond.

BG, active in Egypt since 1989, has found gas in 11 of 12 wells it has drilled, largely in the waters off Alexandria. It estimates the total national reserves at 50 trillion cubic feet but Frank Chapman, president of BGI, says only 19% of the area has been covered by 3D seismic surveys.

The company in early November disclosed it had found gas in significant supplies in a concession 20km offshore from Israel and had won the first concession rights from the Palestinian national authority to search for oil and gas off the coast from the Gaza Strip.

Mr Chapman downplays the scale of the likely finds in the waters off Gaza and Israel compared with the known riches of the Nile delta or the political import of the deal with Yasser Arafat. But even he concedes that prosperity could grow as a result and "that will provide a more conducive environment for peace".

Initially, BG and other western energy groups operating in the region will provide gas for the indigenous markets of Egypt, Israel, Palestine and so on. But the new Cairo government appointed by President Mubarak has recently given the go-ahead for the country to start exports.

Senior western diplomats say the decision could prompt a new wave of foreign investment in an economy noted for its low-value products such as textiles and leather. "Gas is probably the biggest potential swing factor in the economy over the next 10 to 15 years," one says.

Mubarak has set his sights on revitalising the economy - already growing at 5.7% this year, with inflation down to 2.9%. His new petroleum minister, Sameh Fahmy, speaks of gas exports - whether as liquified natural gas or through pipelines - not just to the region and Turkey but to European countries such as Italy and Spain.

Mr Fahmy, a cautious man, is determined to strike a hard bargain with western partners such as BG - which has invested $500m so far and plans to spend a further $1.25bn over the next three years. "Egypt has to attract foreign investment and find export markets to raise its natural gas revenue to $3bn," he says.

Exports, unlikely until three or four years from now, he says, will depend on the price these global players are prepared to pay the state-owned Egyptian General Petroleum Company for its share of the contracts. A new round of bidding for concessions in the south of Egypt is certain to raise prices, too.

He, too, is sceptical about reaching a deal with Israel and its Arab neighbours in the near future over a regional grid. But it is a project he clearly has in mind and, while western observers warn about the competitiveness of the Egyptian industry, they believe it could go ahead.

BG, meanwhile, has joined other partners in forming the Nile Valley Gas Company with EGPC to supply gas to domestic and industrial customers in upper Egypt. Ultimately, it foresees a pipeline stretching as far south as Luxor and the Aswan dam.

In Beni Suef, an older settlement and a burgeoning new town, a privatised cement works owned by the French firm Lafarge has cut costs 20% by switching to gas. The regional governor, Sayeed el-Naggar, foresees gas fuelling eventual out put of 12m tonnes a year as the new town grows.

So far, the overspill settlement from the congested streets of the capital where two-lane highways are fought over by five cars abreast, only 12,000 flats have been built. They are supplied by natural gas.

Mr Fahmy says known gas reserves could supply Egypt's domestic needs for up to 25 years. But it is the export markets, including an energy-starved Israel, that beckon and gas could energise the entire Mediterranean region.

There could even be lessons, Mr Chapman muses, for the new London mayor. BG, with its NVGC partners, has set up Auto Gas, a compressed natural gas vehicle, refuelling and conversion company that aims to supply the bulk of fuel for Cairo's buses and taxis. Wind of its experiences has already reached Whitehall and talks have been initiated about a similar scheme for London.

fields.headline: ARM's earnings beat City forecasts
fields.trailText: Micro-chip designer and stock market darling ARM Holdings yesterday beat City forecasts with a 91% increase in profits for 1999 as it trebled the number of chips shipped and increased its royalty business.
fields.body:
Micro-chip designer and stock market darling ARM Holdings yesterday beat City forecasts with a 91% increase in profits for 1999 as it trebled the number of chips shipped and increased its royalty business.

The Cambridge-based company's shares surged 8% after news that operating margins had risen to 31% in the last quarter from 17% last time and plans were unveiled for a five-for-one share split.

ARM led an effervescent technology sector last year but its share price has underperformed its peers by 7% since January 1 as fears grew about new competition such as the recently launched Crusoe chip in the US. ARM expects the share split - the second since the company floated two years ago - to increase liquidity and reduce volatility of the shares.

ARM has 14,000 shareholders from 1,000 a year ago and investors have benefited from shares launched at 165p but worth £36.86 last night - up £3.11 on the day.

Arm's chairman, Robin Saxby, described 1999 as a "good year" with the number of products carrying ARM chips climbing from 51m units to 175m. He dismissed fears of competition by arguing that ARM now had established a community of partners such as Texas Instruments and Mitsubishi, which gave it a considerable lead.

He said: "We have seen a recent increase in publicly announced entrants to the microprocessor market and in view of the high growth potential of this market it is likely that more will occur in the future."

The explosion in the use of mobile phones has driven early growth at ARM but technology has expanded into new areas including automotive applications such as air bags and braking systems plus digital audio solutions.

Pretax profits were £18m, up from £9.4m and well ahead of analysts forecasts of around £16.5m. Revenues increased from £42.3m to £62.1m, while earnings per share doubled to 8p. No dividend will be paid despite a cash pile of more than £50m.

Morgan Stanley Dean Witter moved the stock to "outperform" from "neutral", while Warburg Dillon Read and ABN Amro remain outright buyers.

One analyst said: "I think what we heard today was very positive. The rise in royalty payments was particularly interesting because they have no operating costs associated with them and can drive up margins strongly."

Morgan Stanley Dean Witter moved the stock to "outperform" from "neutral", while Warburg Dillon Read and ABN Amro remain outright buyers. One analyst said: "I think what we heard today was very positive. The rise in royalty payments was particularly interesting because they have no operating costs associated with them and can drive up margins strongly."

fields.headline: Winterflood profits up 118%
fields.trailText: Winterflood, the market making arm of Close Brothers, yesterday revealed that it had achieved "a substantial increase" in first-half profits.
fields.body:
Winterflood, the market making arm of Close Brothers, yesterday revealed that it had achieved "a substantial increase" in first-half profits.

The sparkling performance at Winterflood forced Close to issue a highly unusual warning to investors that group profits were on track to rise by 118% to more than £72.5m in the first six months of its financial year, ending yesterday.

Winterflood, in which founder Brian Winterflood still plays a major role, was bought by Close in 1993 and will contribute more than £45m - or 65% - to Close's profits in the first half, compared with 32% during the previous period. The statement was issued after a sharp rise in the company's shares on Friday amid speculation about its profits and that it was poised to buy its closest competitor, Singer & Friedlander.

While yesterday's announcement made no mention of Singer, Rod Kent, the managing director of Close, said the company needed to tell the City about the "fabulous story" before the profits are officially published in March.

Analysts said the lack of information about takeover news might explain why the company's shares fell by 22.5p to £11.58 yesterday.

There might also have been disappointment about the lower profits in the asset finance division, which is involved in lending money for one to three-year-old secondhand cars and where prices have been falling in anticipation of a cut in new car prices.

While Winterflood fuelled much of the rise in profitably, Mr Kent pointed out that the corporate finance area had performed well too, and had advised on more takeovers and mergers in the UK last year than any other company - when counted numerically rather than by value.

Winterflood also benefited from the "exceptionally active" trading in smaller firms in which it is market maker.

webTitle: Rover target 'at risk' from DTI price cuts

fields.headline: Rover target 'at risk' from DTI price cuts
fields.trailText: Rover will face an uphill struggle to meet its target of breakeven by 2002 if the government acts to cut the prices car buyers in Britain have to pay, industry sources say.
fields.body:
Rover will face an uphill struggle to meet its target of breakeven by 2002 if the government acts to cut the prices car buyers in Britain have to pay, industry sources say.

The competition commission yesterday delivered its report on car prices to the department of trade and industry.

The report, which has taken 11 months to prepare, is thought to recommend moves to break the manufacturers' control of prices in the UK.

The government, in its attempt to end "rip-off" culture in Britain, is keen to abolish the system which allows manufacturers to charge thousands of pounds more for their vehicles in Britain than elsewhere in Europe.

BMW, Rover's German parent, said yesterday that the British car maker's sales fell 25% last year, while deliveries in the UK were down by 32%.

It blamed the downturn in sales on the strength of sterling and on model changes, and added that fourth quarter sales figures indicated that the decline had been halted.

The Rover workforce fell by 18.8% to 29,884 last year.

Further jobs are expected to go this year as the restructur ing of the company continues. BMW said the downturn at Rover had been offset by record sales of BMW-branded cars and motorcycles and of Land Rover - which was the strongest growing brand in the group.

Rover is still waiting for the European commission to approve £141m of government grants towards the £1.7bn redevelopment of its main Longbridge plant and the development of a new vehicle to replace its medium-sized models. A decision is expected some time in May.

Rover is still expected to report a heavy loss for 1999.

Industry sources said that any enforced price reductions in the UK - which accounts for 40% of Rover's sales - will make it even tougher for the company to return to profit.

A Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders spokesman said it was a popular misconception that car companies were making excess profits in the UK.

"Rover proves that that is not the case," he said. "There is no money to pass back."

He said that the decision by the P&O Stena ferry group to import a selection of cars at lower prices, announced yesterday, was "cherry picking".

"They are not offering a full service and have just picked cars where there is a wide price difference," he said.

"There is no three-year warranty, no trade-in, and so on."

The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders yesterday wrote to Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, urging him to remove the continuing uncertainty over pricing levels by publishing the competition commission's report as soon as possible.

The trade body said customers were putting off the purchase of a new car in the unreasonable expectation of a big drop in prices.

The government said last year that the problem of high car prices in Britain might be solved by abolishing recommended retail prices, separating service and sales operations, and by bringing to an end the block exemption which enables manufacturers to sell though exclusive franchised dealers.

 Nissan Diesel Motor, Japan's troubled lorry manufacturer, said yesterday that it would cut costs by 20% over the next three years. The announcement came as its largest shareholders and bankers were discussing ways of injecting new cash into the business.
