webTitle: Blue Circle gives Lafarge brush off

fields.headline: Blue Circle gives Lafarge brush off
fields.trailText: Lafarge, the agressively expanding French building materials group, is poised to launch a £3.75bn cash bid to take over Britain's leading cement maker, Blue Circle.
fields.body:
Lafarge, the agressively expanding French building materials group, is poised to launch a £3.75bn cash bid to take over Britain's leading cement maker, Blue Circle.

The French group, which bought Redland for £1.8bn less than two years ago, was forced by market rumour and weekend reports to disclose that it was seriously considering an offer for its British rival.

But Blue Circle - labouring under a Malaysian price war which produced a profits warning last autumn - said Lafarge had already suggested a possible price "which would have significantly undervalued the company and did not merit discussion".

The French conglomerate is understood to have come in at 430p a share, valuing Blue Circle, a company which can trace its origins back to 1824, at around £3.5bn.

It is the latest move in an industry that has seen two British groups, Rugby and Tarmac, fall into other hands as cement and concrete producers join forces.

Lafarge, already in the middle of a $256m bid with a partner to acquire one of Egypt's largest cement makers, is expected to come up with a full-scale and increased offer within the next few days, possibly as early as today.

But sources close to the French group cautioned that the cash offer, if and when it comes, would not be substantially higher - and some analsysts expect it to put 450p a share on the table.

Blue Circle, however, was buoyed by other analysts' valuations of 500p, which would make it worth £4.1bn - and vowed to fight to retain its independence and avoid the fate of other chunks of British industry which have fallen into foreign hands.

Its own shares rose more than 20% to close at 414p, still some way off their two-year high of 485p last June but substantially above the low of 285p reached after the chief executive, Rick Haythornthwaite, issued his profits warning in late October.

Shares in its likely French predator dipped by €5 to close at €90.40 as investors took fright at the likely price to be extracted - and as Standard & Poor's ratings agency puts its stock on negative watch because of fears that it would be financially overstretched in buying Blue Circle.

The battle hinges on whether Blue Circle shareholders are more swayed by the prospect of instant cash or Mr Haythornthwaite's pledge to nullify his profits warning via an improved earnings performance, notably in Asia.

He and his advisers believe that the initial 430p approach represents a paltry premium of around 16% on the 370p price seen at year-end, and includes no real bonus for a group valued at 475p for its break-up worth alone.

The word is that Lafarge is in a self-created quandary, prompted by the leaks of its on-off intentions late last week, and that Blue Circle's own strategy as a focused cement maker merits a far greater offer.

Lafarge, it is argued, has no interest in Blue Circle's 48% share of the UK cement market and, instead wants to grab its considerable presence in Asia - even in troubled Malaysia, root of its present financial difficulties.

That is seen as a backhanded endorsement of its own strategy. The British group, industry sources say, is determnined to convince investors that under Mr Haythornwaite it has hit on a sustained programme of cost-savings and productivity gains that will engender shareholder value.

It claims, moreover, to be having success in consolidating the Malaysian market and that its overall strategy will bear fruit in the near future.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Interest worries on both sides of the Atlantic coupled with a general sense of investors' unease over technology stocks and the stability of the American Nasdaq market triggered a fresh sell-off in London, wiping 107.1 points from the FTSE 100 to 6,268.5.
fields.body:
Interest worries on both sides of the Atlantic coupled with a general sense of investors' unease over technology stocks and the stability of the American Nasdaq market triggered a fresh sell-off in London, wiping 107.1 points from the FTSE 100 to 6,268.5.

The Footsie is back to its position three months ago. Yesterday's falls were broadly spread but in terms of raw top 100 points, the 83p fall in BT to £11.82 was worth something close to a third of the overall drop.

Away from the distraction of the NatWest bid, rate worries showed through in just about all the financial stocks. Barclays and Lloyds TSB fell 13p to £14.95 and 20p to 622p respectively, while Abbey National eased 23p to 747p and Halifax retreated 23p to 532p. However, there was said to be some speculative money flowing back into Legal & General late in the session, leaving the shares 4p higher at 147p.

Other prominent risers included BSkyB , up 130 at £14.37, fired by a cocktail of speculation over revived merger talks with Vivendi along with talk of a joint venture with Kingston Communications to provide its digital television services.

Bass rose 11p to 590p, lifted by a reports that it is preparing to offload its brewing interests to South African Breweries.

Among retailers, J Sainsbury ended the session 5p higher at 340p after ABN Amro advised clients the stock was a "buy". The broker also had some kind things to say about Tesco - nevertheless down 2p at 163p - but reduced its rating on Safeway - 4p off at 201p - from "undervalued" to "hold".

Elsewhere Centrica added 3 to 188 after reports that it is in talks with American telecoms group MCI WorldCom about developing a telecoms joint venture.

With the Nasdaq taking a pounding in the US yesterday afternoon most technology stocks were out of fashion for the day. Notably FI Group fell 90p to 625p and merger partner Druid shed 270p at £24.15, while Pace Micro Systems ended the session 50p lower at 780p and Ireland's Baltimore Technology ran back 367p to £65.90.

Filtronic fell 200p to £15.82 after making some cautious comments about its American wireless infrastructure business.

Against all this, engineer FKI managed a 22p advance to 262p while Manchester United was helped by talk that it has finally chosen a new shirt sponsor. After weeks of speculation about potential partners from Emirates Airlines to Yahoo, homegrown Vodafone is said to have landed the £30m deal.

webTitle: Blair backs Camell's historic union deal

fields.headline: Blair backs Camell's historic union deal
fields.trailText: Cammell Laird, the international marine services group reborn from the ashes of Britain's shipbuilding industry, yesterday buttressed its prospects by signing an historic deal with two unions, the AEEU and GMB.
fields.body:
Cammell Laird, the international marine services group reborn from the ashes of Britain's shipbuilding industry, yesterday buttressed its prospects by signing an historic deal with two unions, the AEEU and GMB.

It brings union recognition to the group for the first time in 15 years - since the former British Shipbuilders de-recognised unions in 1985.

The so-called "single table" deal, covering 3,000 employees at several yards, gained the personal backing of Tony Blair who witnessed the signing in Downing Street.

Union sources said this was the first such endorsement by a prime minister for more than two decades and comes as the TUC is reporting a rush to sign recognition deals in advance of full implementation of the new employment relations act.

Buoyed by potential new government subsidies of 9%, Juan Kelly, Cammell Laird chairman, wants to enlist this union muscle to bring specialist shipbuilding back to the Mersey and the Tyne after the group refashioned itself as a ship repair specialist, initially at its Birkenhead base.

Cammell, which yesterday declared a 72% rise in first half pre-tax profits to £8.1m, has joined the team led by French defence contractor Thomson-CSF in bidding for at least one of the two new aircraft carriers for the Navy.

Mr Kelly, who has turned around the group through a series of bolt-on acquisitions, including Gibraltar's sole shipyard, said company growth and increased employees gave rise to the need for a partnership deal with unions. Otherwise, he said, the group would have faced a mix of union and non-union recognition and possibly multi-union negotiation by trade - a key factor in the spat of strikes that brought the original shipbuilding demise.

fields.headline: Meyer International
fields.trailText: Meyer International yesterday joined Blue Circle as a potential takeover victim in the struggling building materials sector. Meyer shares galloped ahead 105p to end the day at 425p as investors leaped to take advantage of good consolidation news in what has been a bombed-out sector.
fields.body:
Meyer International yesterday joined Blue Circle as a potential takeover victim in the struggling building materials sector. Meyer shares galloped ahead 105p to end the day at 425p as investors leaped to take advantage of good consolidation news in what has been a bombed-out sector.

Confirmation of a possible bid for Meyer was given by the London-based company when it admitted it was in talks with a third party which could lead to an offer. Meyer acts as a builder's merchant and is particularly strong in timber products, which it imports and distributes.

This takeover news, on top of the Blue Circle approach from Lafarge, pushed up the value of other companies in the sector such as Wolseley (up 25.25p to 345.25p) and Travis Perkins (up 63.5p to 524p).

The building products area has been hit by expectations of higher interest rates and a slump in construction opportunities. Investors have fled to other areas such as hi-tech where growth opportunities are seen as much stronger. The low valuations given to Meyer and others - made worse in recent weeks by worries about US interest rate levels - has been seen as a buying opportunity by some industry players.

Consolidation has swept the sector since the autumn when Anglo-American made an agreed 585p bid for Tarmac which valued the company at £1.2bn, a 64% premium to the price prior to the bid.

RMC then made a £924m bid for Rugby, a 40% premium on the pre-bid price, and most recently Hanson has made a £1.56bn approach to Pioneer in Australia.

fields.headline: Corus achieves isolated high note
fields.standfirst: Market forces  David Gow
fields.trailText: Many manufacturing companies have weathered the storm unleashed by sterling's strength and hoisted substantial productivity gains and cuts in cost to their mast.
fields.body:
Many manufacturing companies have weathered the storm unleashed by sterling's strength and hoisted substantial productivity gains and cuts in cost to their mast.

The steel sector as a whole, according to its trade body's annual review, bucked a very grim year to show a gross added value per employee of £60,000 - more than double the UK average and almost twice that in computers.

But sterling's strength exerts a malign effect whatever the effort put in. Corus, the mellifluous-sounding and utterly meaningless name given to the marriage of British Steel and its Dutch partner, Hoogovens, simply underlined this yesterday.

Reporting separately, the two Corus members sent a collective shudder through investors as the pound's 8.4% rise this year alone threatened more pain and lower earnings this year than anticipated.

British Steel made a pre-tax loss of £167m in the six months to October 2, largely due to the combined impact of low prices in Europe and sterling - compared with £108m profit a year earlier. Prices, it noted, have recovered firmly but, with the extended new year hols, the pound and "some operational problems", losses continued to be made in the quarter to January 1.

Even the promise of more normal levels of output and further price increases failed to steady nerves and Corus stock eased 2.25p to close at 123.25p. Sentiment was not helped by Hoogovens' reporting of a nine-month pre-tax gain of €117m (£71.5m), significantly below 1998 levels.

Corus investors, however, may take the longer view. After all, as Commerzbank calculated last week, the stock rose from a low of 69p in December 1998 to 179p in the first week of the millennium. With regular and special dividends, "the total return in the 12-13 months to early 2000 was a hefty 225%".

But its analyst, Peter Dupont, noted that 60% of Corus sales are euro-influenced while being UK-sourced and he foresees a pro-forma pre-tax loss of £272m for 1999, the weakest performance of the European steel majors.

Investors cannot expect a repeat of last year's giddying returns.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Car helpline flooded at P&O
P&O last night said it had been "inundated with calls" after unveiling plans to help import and sell cheap cars from mainland Europe via its cross-Channel ferry service. The initiative came as the competition commission delivered to the government a long-awaited report on the price of new cars as controversy rages about "rip-off" Britain.
fields.body:
Car helpline flooded at P&O
P&O last night said it had been "inundated with calls" after unveiling plans to help import and sell cheap cars from mainland Europe via its cross-Channel ferry service. The initiative came as the competition commission delivered to the government a long-awaited report on the price of new cars as controversy rages about "rip-off" Britain.

P&O expects to sell 10,000 cars a year - at prices on average 18% lower than list price - under a scheme organised with Burbank Automotive Holdings and a network of 140 dealers in Holland, Belgium and Germany.

KFC creates 2,000 jobs
Kentucky Fried Chicken is to create over 2,000 jobs in a huge expansion of its restaurants in Britain, the company said yesterday. Some 50 new outlets will open this year, boosting the total to 530.

The new restaurants will mainly be drive-through, each creating around 40 full and part-time jobs. The company said it planned to double its business to over 1,000 restaurants.

Investing hits record highs
A record number of investors put money into investment funds last year, according to figures released by the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds yesterday. Autif said sales of individual savings accounts in December maintained levels set by personal equity plans in their final bumper year.

The figures showed net retail sales of unit trusts and open-ended investment companies had heaped 66% on top of sales figures for 1998 with a total of £14.2bn invested over the year.

Man moves in on UK trucker
German truck maker Man AG yesterday made a £110m offer for UK truck maker ERF from Canada's Western Star Trucks Holdings.

Man will pay £65m for ERF, and will assume an additional £45m in debt from the company.

ERF sold about 3,000 heavy-duty trucks in the last financial year, with most of these going to customers based in the UK. The company had total sales of about £200m with around 900 employees.

US retailers sue Sony
Sony Music was sued yesterday by US retailers amid allegations that the company is forcing record shops to include literature advertising its online services.

The National Association of Recording Merchandisers said it filed suit on behalf of its retail members against Sony Music Entertainment and its parent, Sony Corp of America, to halt what it believes to be the illegal practice of forcing retailers to direct their customers to Sony's online stores.

webTitle: Vivendi knocks on News Corp's door

fields.headline: Vivendi knocks on News Corp's door
fields.trailText: Vivendi, the French media group, yesterday called on Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation to reopen talks on how the two companies might join forces in the wake of the massive AOL-Time Warner merger.
fields.body:
Vivendi, the French media group, yesterday called on Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation to reopen talks on how the two companies might join forces in the wake of the massive AOL-Time Warner merger.

Jean-Marie Messier, Vivendi chairman and chief executive, suggested that the two businesses start again after an attempt to merge BSkyB in which News Corp has a 40% stake and the French group's pay-TV business Canal Plus ended last year. Vivendi has built a 24.5% holding in BSkyB which is being scrutinised by Britain's competition commission.

In an interview in Le Monde, Mr Messier said relations between the two firms were frosty but the two risked being sidelined unless they worked together. "Mr Murdoch found our entrance into BSkyB a little too quick but this man of character shows a great sense of realism," he said.

"The world has changed with the merger of AOL-Time Warner... Following this deal BSkyB and Canal Plus risk having difficulties accessing content which will be more and more rare and more and more expensive. Furthermore the consolidation of the sector will carry on."

fields.headline: Questioning authority
fields.standfirst:
Forget the skirmishes of the London mayoral race. The important battles may occur when the Greater London Authority takes power in July

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Forget the skirmishes of the London mayoral race. The important battles may occur when the Greater London Authority takes power in July.
fields.body:
The Greater London Authority (GLA) will comprise the mayor, a 25-strong assembly, and 250 extra staff costing £26m a year, about 3p per week per average council tax-paying household. The GLA will be responsible for: transport for London (8-15 members); London Development Agency (8-15 members); Metropolitan Police Authority (23 members); and London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority (17 members).

Second only to the question of who will be London's first directly-elected mayor is what he or she will do. The machinery supposed to give the capital joined-up government will outlast the first and many other incumbents.

After the campaigns by the big hitters chosen by the three main parties are fully under way, attention will shift to the selection of the 25 members of the assembly. Londoners will have two votes. The first is for a constituency candidate; 14 members will be elected first past the post. Their second vote is for "additional members" drawn either from lists of those standing in the parties' interests or as independents: 11 seats will be allocated in this category. They are voted for on the same day as the mayor, May 4.

Two months follow for preparation, negotiation and setting up, involving the mayor, members and 400 permanent staff. Then they come together as the Greater London Authority (GLA) to take up their duties on July 3. They will operate from government offices in Marsham Street, Westminster, until their purpose-built headquarters is ready on the south bank of the Thames near Tower Bridge.

With responsibilities in eight fields - transport, planning, economic development, environment, police, fire and emergency planning, culture and tourism, public health - the GLA will in theory take a London-wide approach to planning and delivering services. Political rivalries might drive a wedge between mayor and assembly. Say Ken Livingston became mayor on the official Labour ticket, he might come into conflict with Labour assembly members more loyal to the cabinet's line.

The GLA has been structured to ensure a clear separation of powers between the mayor, who has an executive role, and members, whose role is scrutiny. That is not to say there cannot be a clash of wills; there are bound to be fights as bitter as anything in the Commons or local council chamber. In theory, the assembly has a sort of grip on the mayor. Its members are empowered to examine the mayor's performance, and summon the office-holder for questioning together with officials, 10 times a year. The mayor has to choose a member of the assembly as deputy. And the mayor is bound to report to and consult the assembly.

The GLA also has to live with the 32 boroughs and the City of London corporation. These remain the principal service providers.

However, there is nothing here that a wily mayoral operator, determined to have his or her way, could not get round. Only in budget matters does a mechanism for censure by the assembly clearly exist. The new government of London will have about £3bn a year to spend, mostly on police, transport, economic development and emergency services. The mayor will propose every year how this money gets used. But if the assembly disagrees with the allocation, it can, if two-thirds of members agree, vote down the mayor and come up with an alternative.

However, it is not assembly members - of whatever party - who will form the greatest restraint on mayoral activism. The mayor is more likely to be constrained by government ministers, since most of the GLA's funds come from Whitehall. Downing Street has been very cautious.

GLA spending and performance will be scrutinised by the audit commission. Annual budgets will be set by the GLA for its own operation, and for the four functional bodies (each with its own finance officers) shown in the table. At any time, the mayor, subject to the approval of members, will be able to make transfers between budgets.

However, what really matters here is that reserve powers for several Whitehall departments have been built in. The home secretary, for instance, will be able to fix a minimum level for spending on the police. In transport and economic development, other central government safeguards will operate.

There is one further device which the government has to protect its plans for the London underground. Specifically to stop a rogue mayor (Livingstone?) from dropping its private-public partnership for financing improvements to the tube, John Prescott will not hand over control of transport in the capital until his own department's plans have been fulfilled.

So the new mayor could well spend more time looking over a shoulder to see what the government is about than worrying about opposition cabals in the GLA's committee rooms. Tony Travers of the London School of Economics believes that, as the only significant power GLA members have concerns the budget, "it would be possible for a mayor to exist with very little contact with the assembly."

Travers does not doubt that an incumbent with radical ideas would give rise to lots of conflicts; but censuring the mayor would be another matter.

One weapon the mayor could use to weaken his enemies is the considerable patronage that comes with his office. The new transport body, for instance, will have between eight and 15 members. All will be chosen by the mayor. Assembly members cannot serve on it though there will be outside political allies whose names they might wish to press. The mayor will show his hand in appointments to the new agency in charge of London's development and regeneration. He will appoint all its members, most with a business background; four places will be reserved for assembly members.

On the new metropolitan police authority, the mayoral grip will be even more evident. Of 23 places, 12 will be in the gift of the mayor, but all of these must be from the assembly (the rest magistrates and independent appointees). The only caveat is that, as far as practicable, these appointments must reflect the political composition of the assembly.

Ultimately, the combination of this patronage and a high public profile among Londoners (which will allow the mayor occasionally to resist demands coming from central government) should mean that what the mayor says very largely goes.

webTitle: 'I'm good. There's no point being humble'

fields.headline: 'I'm good. There's no point being humble'
fields.standfirst: For Vic and Bob he was a 50s throwback and a greasy lover. Lately he's been called a misogynist. Mark Lamarr tells  Stuart Jeffries why his critics are wrong
fields.trailText: "I am at my career peak. It couldn't get any better. Last year I had my own series, I played the Albert Hall, I won broadcaster of the year. Never Mind the Buzzcocks was the number one show on BBC2. I had a successful radio show. Now I'm going on tour and I've got my own show on TV. What else could I want?"
fields.body:
"I am at my career peak. It couldn't get any better. Last year I had my own series, I played the Albert Hall, I won broadcaster of the year. Never Mind the Buzzcocks was the number one show on BBC2. I had a successful radio show. Now I'm going on tour and I've got my own show on TV. What else could I want?"

Mark Lamarr pulls on his cigarette. He chain-smokes throughout the interview, keeping the adrenalin up, the edge sharp. What else could he want? The smile fades as he says: "To write funnier jokes."

That old Woody Allen line. In Stardust Memories aliens arrive on earth and Allen asks them: "What's the meaning of life?" "Write funnier jokes," one replies. Good point: for a comic there is nothing more important in life. And, for the moment at least, Mark Lamarr is a comic.

"I suspect that little need to be funny will go. It generally does - very few comics have that sort of longevity - but it doesn't seem to have gone yet. To niggle, that's the important thing for me. Seinfeld said the comic's mind is always active and always irritable, and I think that's true. You're always thinking 'What's the angle here?' "

Lamarr is always trying to work out the angle, both to questions and his own answers. Typically, he will puncture his own rhetoric half way through a reply. Just after happily listing his achievements, for instance, he looks grim: "I've always thought I've got another two or three years on television because I'm relatively successful. But I'm not needed, I know that. Cilla has got a much brighter, more secure future than me. Television is something to do for a little while, then it's back to my job."

He's irritable, endlessly doubting, even self-doubting, as he reckons a comic should be. But hardly the angry young man he's been described as. Before he arrives for the interview, I set aside the obvious questions: what does he look like after he's just washed his hair? Bobby Charlton? A guitarist from Genesis? I wonder which chair he will take. Will he sit opposite, confrontationally? Or alongside, chummily? In fact, he sits at right angles, so that he can monologue into the middle distance. But now and again he will throw a sidelong glance and, between the 50s throwback quiff and the sharp suit, that baby face looks vulnerable, imploring. It seems he wants to be liked. He clearly has his good side: a few days after we meet he has his trademark quiff chopped off for charity.

Here comes one of those glances now. "I lacerate myself all the time. Morally, as a human being, I'm full of guilt. I don't know where that comes from: I wasn't brought up Catholic or Jewish. Even when I do something good, it's never good enough." He looks into the middle distance again, blowing smoke, undermining what he's just said. "I sometimes blow my own trumpet. I'm good - I know I am. There's no point me being humble about it."

Tonight Lamarr is going back to his job, the stand-up circuit. He starts in Swansea; 40 gigs later he'll hit Bedford. A grim way to spend February, March and April? "It's not grim compared with 10 people in a room above a pub in Hackney that I used to play, and be desperate to play. I'd be excited about it all week. I'd be so excited to hitch up to London for no money and sleep on a friend's floor."

That was 15 years ago. The youngest of five children, Lamarr (originally Mark Jones) was born in Swindon in 1966. His mother was a cleaner, his father a maintenance engineer in a cake factory. He left Swindon with a rockabilly quiff, the badge of a kid brought up on estates where you belonged to a tribe or you were nobody, and a desire to spit in the eye of the careers officer who told him his dream of being a journalist was "a little bit far-fetched". He never went to college. "When I was 19, I was performing at university. I was younger than the people I was performing to. It sounds like I'm doing the university-of-life line now, but that's my job - being a comic - and you wouldn't learn how to do it other than by playing at university."

Do you perceive yourself as a working-class bloke with a chip on his shoulder? "Up to a point, yeah. But 'chip on his shoulder' is a reductive term for someone who cares about where they come from. You never get 'chip on your shoulder' about the upper classes - you only get it about black people or the working classes. Yeah, I'm pissed off about things, loads of things. The world isn't perfect. Comics should be poking at things - that's what good comedy is." Poking at things? "If I want to do something about menstruation, then I should be allowed to - more so if that winds women up. I had years of hearing these ridiculous routines from bad women comics. Telling us how easy our life was because we didn't have periods. Really..."

Lamarr is nonetheless amazed to have been accused of misogyny. "In the last month - I swear this is true - I've been called a feminist, a misogynist, gay and homophobic. I can at best be one of those things; I doubt if I'm any of them. But I haven't got the cunning to fight the public perception of me." It's the misogynist jibe that really irks. "People say, 'You've made fun of Caprice and Gail Porter' and I think, 'Well, not only are they not examples of great womanhood, but I've never made fun of them for being women. Ever.' I make fun of people, you know? It would have been sexist not to make fun of Gail Porter posing nude. To treat someone as different and inferior because of their sex - that's sexism. If that's laddism then I am laddish."

Still, there has been a gynaecological theme in Lamarr's stand-up that can come across as a hostile obsession. In his 1997 show he imagined the Queen drunk on gin, posed naked for a photographer with her labia dangling obscenely between her sprawled legs. That would be his dream photo for the £50 note. He also told the story of a woman comic who, during her act, repeatedly walked past a table in a short skirt, while a man hissed: "I can smell your cunt." For a moment, it seemed there might be a revenge punchline coming, the woman getting her own back on the heckler. Instead the heckler's female partner was portrayed as complicit, collapsed in laughter. What Lamarr seemed to like about the story was that the woman comic was trapped, unable to publicly rebuff the heckler (since it had been whispered) and unable to escape the abuse. Why tell such a story?

During a warm-up gig in Northampton for the new tour, Lamarr unleashed some of his new material about British hostility to Europe. "I'd set it up as obviously as I could, saying that in two years we won't be able to wake up with an alarm clock in the mornings, we'll have to have Alpine horns and an oompah band, we'll have to ski down the High Street, have sodomy with our boss, live off Battenburg and shrews and taramasalata. It was very obvious where I was coming from: I was attacking that Little Englander mentality. And people in the audience were yelling: 'Yeah! Bloody right!' I had to stop and say: 'I can't believe you've missed this point. But you have.' " Forty nights of such misunderstandings: it could be a good tour.

Why do people take him for a misogynist and all the other things he protests that he is not? "A lot of the time I think it's a problem with my mode of voice rather than what I actually say. People want to assume that I'm a working-class lager lout and that's fine." Is it? Isn't Lamarr just affecting to be sanguine about something that must hurt? Again, the reflex self-criticism: "I have to accept that, and I do it myself. That's the price of doing what you do in public." You come across as aggressive. "Well, I think I am. But what I always think is, how does that manifest itself? It manifests itself in humour. It doesn't manifest itself in hitting someone. WC Fields used to joke that anyone who hates children can't be all bad. Does that mean he hated kids? It's a joke, for fuck's sake."

Mark Lamarr plays the Grand Theatre, Swansea, tonight, then tours till April. Details: 09068 455484.

If that's laddism then I am laddish." Still, there has been a gynaecological theme in Lamarr's stand-up that can come across as a hostile obsession. In his 1997 show he imagined the Queen drunk on gin, posed naked for a photographer with her labia dangling obscenely between her sprawled legs. That would be his dream photo for the £50 note. He also told the story of a woman comic who, during her act, repeatedly walked past a table in a short skirt, while a man hissed: "I can smell your cunt." For a moment, it seemed there might be a revenge punchline coming, the woman getting her own back on the heckler. Instead the heckler's female partner was portrayed as complicit, collapsed in laughter. What Lamarr seemed to like about the story was that the woman comic was trapped, unable to publicly rebuff the heckler (since it had been whispered) and unable to escape the abuse. Why tell such a story? During a warm-up gig in Northampton for the new tour, Lamarr unleashed some of his new material about British hostility to Europe. "I'd set it up as obviously as I could, saying that in two years we won't be able to wake up with an alarm clock in the mornings, we'll have to have Alpine horns and an oompah band, we'll have to ski down the High Street, have sodomy with our boss, live off Battenburg and shrews and taramasalata. It was very obvious where I was coming from: I was attacking that Little Englander mentality. And people in the audience were yelling: 'Yeah! Bloody right!' I had to stop and say: 'I can't believe you've missed this point. But you have.' " Forty nights of such misunderstandings: it could be a good tour. Why do people take him for a misogynist and all the other things he protests that he is not? "A lot of the time I think it's a problem with my mode of voice rather than what I actually say. People want to assume that I'm a working-class lager lout and that's fine." Is it? Isn't Lamarr just affecting to be sanguine about something that must hurt? Again, the reflex self-criticism: "I have to accept that, and I do it myself. That's the price of doing what you do in public." You come across as aggressive. "Well, I think I am. But what I always think is, how does that manifest itself? It manifests itself in humour. It doesn't manifest itself in hitting someone. WC Fields used to joke that anyone who hates children can't be all bad. Does that mean he hated kids? It's a joke, for fuck's sake." Mark Lamarr plays the Grand Theatre, Swansea, tonight, then tours till April. Details: 09068 455484.

webTitle: Referees summit strives to heal rift

fields.headline: Referees summit strives to heal rift
fields.standfirst: Radical plan to improve relations with players and managers
fields.trailText: The Football Association announced with impeccable timing yesterday an unprecedented agenda designed to clean up the game's image. The move came just a day after referee Andy d'Urso came away from Old Trafford complaining of intimidation.
fields.body:
When a referee comes away from Old Trafford complaining of intimidation it is clear all in football is not right. And yesterday, with impeccable timing, the Football Association announced an unprecedented agenda designed to clean up the game's image.

At the root of a radical eight-point project is a determination to foster a new respect and understanding between players, managers and referees. The sight of footballers, blood vessels bursting, forcing an official to retreat should be a thing of the past.

Yet the issues for discussion are more wide-reaching than that. Everything from the disciplinary process to the use of goal-line cameras and video evidence will be talked about by administrators from every portion of the game. The FA intends to set a timetable in the next fortnight.

Involved in the talks will be those who agreed the agenda yesterday at a meeting convened by the FA. The cast list comprises the FA, the Premier League, the Football League, the League Managers Association, the Professional Footballers Association and the Referees Association. The summit was called after Philip Don, the Premier League referees officer, and David Davies, the FA's executive director, were alarmed at the sight of 11 cautions and a sending off at Aston Villa's game against Liverpool in October. The following day they were struck by the difference in the live Serie A game on Channel 4.

Education will form the centre-piece of talks on how to engender a much-needed respect between players and referees. Referees will be reminded of the importance of communicating on and off the pitch. Footballers will be taught the rules of the game and reminded they are role-models; to clubs will be stressed the importance of discipline.

Andy d'Urso, the referee at Old Trafford on Saturday, and two of his colleagues, Graham Barber and Rob Styles, spoke at yesterday's summit. All parties recognise how hard officialdom has become. The FA knows, if it does not act, recruitment will become far harder in future.

"Referees have often found themselves intimidated," said Gordon Taylor, chief executive of the PFA. "They want a measure of respect and I think that will be reciprocated by the players if they continue to accept the need to bring in a greater degree of man-management; that it does not have to be mandatory that every foul is a caution.

"Having played in the time of Tommy Smith, Norman Hunter and Nobby Stiles I would say there is less of the dangerous tackle from behind or the one that came over your knee. But there is a lot of shirt pulling at corners, feigning injury and so on, things that players from different cultures have brought into the game. It's probably much harder to detect now, particularly as the game is so fast moving."

Don agreed the job was increasingly difficult: "The ever-increasing focus on football, the high rewards for success and the pressure that brings is making the already difficult job of the referee harder than ever. The referees want to achieve respect from players and managers and there has to be a combined commitment."

The suggestions at the meeting was that there is a commitment from referees to the use of video evidence to examine any incidents they miss.

And new technology seems certain to be introduced in England in the near future.

Talking points

 Having one integrated referees' list, ending the existing distinction between Premier League and Football League referees.

 Write a full education programme looking at man-management and communication for referees, and educating all involved in football with the rules of the game.

 Examine how players, managers and chairmen can work together to enforce good discipline and good standards of behaviour.

 Come up with a clear point of view on the use of technology, including goal-line technology

 Clarify the use of video evidence.

 Examine the viability of full-time referees.

 Look at the disciplinary process, the way it is handled and the punishments.

 Examine the FA's speed of response, recognising the need for quick decisions in disciplinary matters.

webTitle: Brown and EU still divided on withholding tax

fields.headline: Brown and EU still divided on withholding tax
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: European Union finance ministers agreed yesterday to explore ways to end the row over a withholding tax on savings, but differences emerged about who would sit on a new high-level group.
fields.body:
European Union finance ministers agreed yesterday to explore ways to end the row over a withholding tax on savings, but differences emerged about who would sit on a new high-level group.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, pledged after meeting colleagues in Brussels that Britain would continue to take measures to combat tax evasion and would "take the work of the group seriously".

Portugal and France announced that they would be appointing the equivalent of a junior minister to the group, while British officials indicated they would prefer technical-level representation to keep the issue low-key.

Mr Brown said it had not yet been decided who would represent the UK on the group, which is supposed to find a solution to the issue by the end of June.

The chancellor insists that the withholding tax, to be levied on all savings income within the EU, would cost thousands of jobs in the City of London and damage the lucrative eurobond market.

Britain says the way forward is for an exchange of information between member states rather than the levying of a tax.

Last year the chancellor rejected a compromise put forward by the European Commission that would require names and addresses of bond holders to be released to other states' tax authorities.

Yesterday, however, Mr Brown's tone was markedly more conciliatory than during the ructions over the issue at December's Helsinki summit.

British officials want the problem settled before the French presidency of the EU in the second half of the year - if only because with the beef issue still unresolved it would be domestically impossible to make concessions then.

Commission proposals would end a system whereby savers resident in one member state can salt away cash elsewhere in the EU - particularly in "havens" like Gibraltar - and pocket the interest tax-free.

fields.headline: Link may herald pan-European bank
fields.trailText: Two of Europe's leading banks yesterday unveiled a "pragmatic alliance" which could pave the way for a fully-fledged pan-European banking institution.
fields.body:
Two of Europe's leading banks yesterday unveiled a "pragmatic alliance" which could pave the way for a fully-fledged pan-European banking institution.

Société Générale, France's number three bank, and Banco Santander Central Hispano, Spain's number one, said they are planning to work together across a broad spread of operations - from retail banking and the internet to asset management and investment banking.

In addition the French bank will buy a stake of up to 3% in BSCH while the Spanish bank will increase its holding in Société Générale from 5% to 7%. The deal also leaves the way open for other banks in which BSCH has stakes, including Germany's Commerzbank and the Royal Bank of Scotland, to take part at a later date.

Philippe Citerne, Société Générale's chief executive, said his bank and BSCH had similar views about the future of the European banking industry. "We don't think banks are going to stay just as they are now. Some day, in five or 10 years time, we will see a real pan-European institution. That's the vision."

But though the two banks see their collaboration as a strategic alliance between equals, in practical terms it will initially be limited to cooperation agreements and specific joint ventures. Mr Citerne insisted that both Société Générale and BSCH were "very, very pragmatic" in their approach.

"We think it is better to check whether [cooperation] works on a day-to-day basis."

"This agreement looks like an engagement, with a view to a merger in the medium-term," said Jean-Baptiste Bellon, analyst at Deutsche Bank.

"The problem is that a merger between equals is not possible," he said.

fields.headline: Quality of Melancholy
fields.standfirst:
The Merchant of Venice
Olivier Theatre, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText:
The Merchant of Venice
Olivier Theatre, London
fields.body:
In moving from the Cottesloe to the Olivier, Trevor Nunn's celebrated production has become as broad as it is long: there's too much protracted business and too much italicised acting in the minor roles. What holds it together is Nunn's cumulative psychological insight and the sterling performances from Henry Goodman as Shylock and Derbhle Crotty as Portia.

On the larger stage some of Nunn's ideas look over-extended. Setting many of the Venetian scenes in a dingy, incipiently fascist 30s clip-joint is ingenious, but it's hard to believe that Shylock would venture into such a dive, and Launcelot Gobbo's debate with his conscience seems incredibly laboured when done as a stand-up routine.

Back in Belmont, the film clips illustrating Portia's previous suitors detract from her own acid verbal portraits and the treatment of Arragon as a ho-ho Spaniard, all clicking heels and flamenco, smacks of the racism the production elsewhere seeks to undermine.

Goodman and Crotty, however, remain as brilliant as ever. What Nunn and Goodman bring out is the way Shylock's revenge is directly fed by his daughter's defection: as Solanio points out, "Let good Antonio keep his day or he shall pay for this." Goodman's Shylock is also a mass of enlightening contradiction: singing Yiddish songs with his daughter one moment, then striking her; in the trial scene, raising his knife to Antonio's chest, then being delayed in the action by his own unstilled conscience. This is a Shylock tortured by his own paradoxical impulses.

Crotty's Portia is also astonishing: instead of the heartless legal quibbler, we get someone who comes up with flesh-but-no-blood argument in a moment of improvised desperation and who is appalled both by Christian severity and by Bassanio's symbolic surrender of the ring. As a result the fifth act acquires a disillusioned melancholy in which you feel, for all the characters, that it will never be glad, confident morning again.

Nunn himself emerges as a deeply paradoxical director. His increasing tendency to invest Shakespeare with a mass of novelistic detail clogs the narrative momentum. The plus side is that he brings to Shakespeare a psychological penetration that here makes the last two acts as moving as I have ever known them. His faults, in short, are inextricable from his virtues: maybe you just have to accept them both.

Box office: 0171-452 3000.

fields.headline: London Sinfonietta
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText: Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
fields.body:
Although Hanspeter Kyburz's five-movement orchestral work Cells was supposed to concern ideas of biological growth and formal freedom, the most striking moments in its half-hour structure were images of dissolution and decay. The fractured stillness of stratospheric harmonics and scarcely perceptible woodwind breaths in the opening movements were hauntingly caught by the London Sinfonietta and Roland Kluttig.

After Simon Haram's primeval multiphonics on baritone saxophone, the fourth movement dispensed with musical progression altogether, as the players rolled pebbles in their hands and brushed fingers against abacuses.

There was a more organic transformation in Thomas Adès's The Origin of the Harp. His sumptuous chromaticism and dense polyphony coalesced into a vibrant shimmer of strummed strings accompanying an impassioned cello melody. Adès himself conducted with pleading intensity.

In Catch, Adès's 1991 quartet for cello, violin, piano and perambulatory clarinet, Timothy Lines captured a moving theatricality when he joined the other players on stage, only to enigmatically exit again. But it was Life Story, a mini operatic scena for counter-tenor, two bass clarinets and double-bass, that properly revealed Adès's dramatic talents. Life Story sets Tennessee Williams's poem of post-coital hotel-room antics, and Andrew Watts relished every word.

However, the real theatre of the concert was reserved for Helmut Oehring and Iris ter Schiphorst's Polaroids for actress, counter-tenor and electronically amplified ensemble. Oehring was born to deaf parents and learned sign language, which the actress Christina Schönfeld used throughout the piece. The self-referential world of her signing found a parallel in Oehring's repetitious sound-world of Hammond organ effects and resonant marimba glissandos. Mixed with the counter-tenor's recitations, Polaroids created a compellingly ambiguous universe of gesture and signification.

fields.headline: Brown hints at rate rise
fields.standfirst: Chancellor expresses concern about economy overheating
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, yesterday gave strong personal backing to further increases in interest rates from the Bank of England as he expressed concern about the risks to inflation from Britain's fast-growing economy.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, yesterday gave strong personal backing to further increases in interest rates from the Bank of England as he expressed concern about the risks to inflation from Britain's fast-growing economy.

Mr Brown took the unusual step of making a public statement on monetary policy in which he dropped a blatant hint that the cost of borrowing should rise in order to prevent the economy from overheating.

Speaking at the monthly meeting of European Union finance ministers in Brussels, the chancellor stressed that the global economy had recovered from the period of sluggish growth in the wake of the Asian financial crisis in 1997 and 1998. He expressed particular concern over booming stock markets and the 150% increase in oil prices over the past 12 months.

Mr Brown handed over day-to-day control of monetary policy to the Bank five days after Labour's election victory, charging it with keeping inflation at 2.5%.

He said yesterday: "There is clear evidence following the instabilities in the global economy over the past two years that growth is strengthening. But global pressures including instability in asset markets and rising oil prices demand that policymakers remain vigilant and act decisively when necessary.

"We in Britain's case will continue to support our monetary authorities in the difficult decisions they have to take to ensure that we remain on track to meet the inflation target and sustain high and stable levels of growth and employment."

Treasury sources said that the chancellor was neither advocating nor predicting interest-rate rises but was instead sounding a cautionary note both about the British economy and global economic conditions. He would back the Bank of England's monetary policy committee whatever it decided, they said.

The Bank has already raised rates three times since the autumn, with the last increase to 5.75% occurring last month. However, the City believes that the strength of the economy has made further monetary tightening inevitable, with the next move likely to come at this month's meeting of the MPC on Thursday week.

Figures released yesterday showed that consumer confidence in Britain had surged to its highest level since September 1997 when the post-election feelgood factor was combined with the effects of windfalls from the conversion of building societies into banks.

Research carried out by GfK Great Britain on behalf of the European Commission indicated that the sharp increase in high street activity around the turn of the year was reflected in a rise in consumer confidence from plus one to plus eight.

The survey showed consumer perception regarding the benefits of making major purchases at the current time rose steeply to plus 31 in January from plus six in the previous month - its highest level since July 1988.

Although January sales would usually produce such inclination, GfK said, the size of the rise in the measure suggested that fears that consumer spending was in danger of overheating might be justified.

Michael Saunders, economist at Salomon Smith Barney Citibank said the latest confidence reading was consistent with retail sales volume growth of 5%-6% per annum. This is similar to the annualised quarter-on-quarter gains in the past couple of months and would, if sustained, suggest that consumer spending growth this year would be well above the consensus expectations.

webTitle: BoS goes to wire with £24.1bn bid

fields.headline: BoS goes to wire with £24.1bn bid
fields.standfirst: Target's investors remain undecided as Scottish rivals engage in last-ditch battle
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland fired off a higher £24.1bn bid for NatWest last night after keeping the City in suspense in a frenetic day during which its Scottish rival raised its bid for the besieged bank by £3bn.
fields.body:
Bank of Scotland fired off a higher £24.1bn bid for NatWest last night after keeping the City in suspense in a frenetic day during which its Scottish rival raised its bid for the besieged bank by £3bn.

In the hours before the midnight deadline by which both Royal Bank of Scotland and BoS had to table their final offers, major investors indicated that they were still undecided which of the three outcomes to back - a takeover by BoS or Royal Bank, or NatWest remaining independent.

However Peter Burt, chief executive of BoS, insisted shareholders had already ruled out independence for NatWest and would resist any situation in which the vote between the two Scottish assailants was split, preventing either reaching the 50% hurdle to take over NatWest. "None of the institutions we have seen have shown any enthusiasm for a split vote.

"I think we will see a cascade effect," said Mr Burt, who fired the first shot in the assault on NatWest four months ago. He said his new bid was £1bn higher than Royal Bank's.

NatWest's board, chaired by Sir David Rowland, will meet this morning to decide whether to maintain their resistance to the two bids, contructed through a complicated mix of cash and shares, and persuade investors to give them another chance to run the bank.

Viscount Younger, the chairman of Royal Bank, which has made no secret of its aim to win the agreement of the NatWest board, said: "I've made it clear to Sir David that my door is open." Bankers struggled to interpret the movement in all three bank's share prices on a volatile day, blaming the uncertainty about the value of the bids on the wait until after the midnight deadline had passed.

NatWest's shares fell by 92p to £11.18, below the value of both bids, Royal Bank's fell by 59p to £10.01 and BoS was 44p down at 620p.

Royal Bank fired off its salvo in the early morning, calling on its largest shareholder, Banco Santander of Spain, to help muster some of the extra £3bn cash it needed to pay for NatWest.

In a complicated deal, Royal Bank offered to pay NatWest investors almost one of its own shares together with a slug of cash of between 400p and 450p and a new "additional value share".

In a battle which has focused on how much "cash" is available for shareholders, Fred Goodwin, the deputy chief executive of Royal Bank, said the new terms of the deal allowed NatWest shareholders to take 514p in cash in addition to Royal Bank shares.

BoS, which revealed the terms of its higher bid after the market had closed, said it could pay NatWest shareholders up to 406p in cash after calling on its financial advisors, Credit Suisse First Boston and Morgan Stanley, to underwrite new loan notes and shares for the bank.

While neither of the Scottish banks was thought to have delivered a "knock-out blow", Mr Burt insisted that he had never been expected to do so and that the onus had been on Royal bank to pull out its "white rabbit".

Royal Bank admitted yesterday that the next stage in the battle was to persuade shareholders to look beyond the cash component of the offers on the table and look at the choice of strategies and management instead.

Sir George Mathewson, chief executive of Royal Bank, which entered the race for NatWest two months after BoS, said: "This is the offer we think is balanced and sensible".

If NatWest survived, he said, the bank would be in "strategic decline".

fields.headline: With heart, plus kazoo
fields.standfirst:
Embrace
The Astoria, London
****
fields.trailText:
Embrace
The Astoria, London
fields.body:
Back when anything Britpop-shaped was guaranteed success whatever its merits, Embrace topped the chart with an album apparently fashioned from Oasis's pub-rock discards. The two northern brothers at the helm, Danny and Richard McNamara, even contrived to be cut-rate Gallaghers, one shooting his mouth off indiscriminately, the other glowering silently behind his guitar. Three years later, they're still mirroring Oasis, matching that band's new "dance" influence with what vocalist Danny calls "our controversial new funk direction" - which isn't funky so much as thinly percussive, as if they'd flicked the samba switch on a cheap keyboard.

The public aren't so easily fooled, however, leaving Embrace to make their London comeback at the modest Astoria rather than a Gallagher-sized venue. It's jammed, though, suggesting that at least 1,500 people in the capital find something of value in Embrace's weighty anthems.

What that is isn't clear till halfway through the show. First you have to digest their flumpy indiewear (not very 00s, those baggy black separates) and tap an involuntary finger as the nagging choruses of All You Good, Good People and Come Back To What You Know drag you along in their ponderous wake. Then, as Danny sways self-consciously to his brother's head-down playing, Embrace begin to weave their insidious spell. They may be shamelessly derivative, with their new album, Drawn From Memory, reviving the 90s before they're even cold, but they do it with a good-heartedness that makes them seem like people you'd like to know.

Each song contains a little homily - the surging singalong One Big Family says it all - that sits uneasily in a rock 'n' roll context, but sounds sincere even at its most platitudinous. Danny further kisses goodbye to any hope of future credibility when he whips out a kazoo, the unlikely main instrument on the recent Hooligans single, and demonstrates why no sullen teenager will ever aspire to be a lead kazooist. He comes across as such a nice chap, sacrificing cool for the integrity of the song, and the place accordingly erupts.

They're Oasis with a heart, wanting only to be liked, and some days that's what you need.

webTitle: How to have a happy appraisal

fields.headline: How to have a happy appraisal
fields.trailText: The trick is not to go to an appraisal thinking it's that time of year of when your boss critises you and gives you ten reasons why you're not going to get that payrise or promotion.
fields.body:
The trick is not to go to an appraisal thinking it's that time of year of when your boss critises you and gives you ten reasons why you're not going to get that payrise or promotion.

A good manager will, over the appraisal period, have identified your strengths and will want to discuss ways in which these can be put the most effective use, to benefit both you and the company.

In other words, the good manager looks forward positively rather than backward negatively.

So, from your point of view, the best plan is to prepare some proposals which ideally use your strengths to the full, and if you're clever, address your weaknesses without having to dwell on them.

This approach shows that a weakness has been identified and a solution provided. It may also take a manager by surprise, give him/her an easier time at the appraisal and hopefully make a reward more likely.

Kate Nicholls via email

fields.headline: Ryuichi Sakamoto
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: * *
fields.trailText: Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.body:
As the godfather of technopop, actor, model and soundtrack composer Ryuichi Sakamoto has reached places other musicians barely know exist. Yet, despite having worked with a list of collaborators that includes David Bowie, Youssou N'Dour and Bernardo Bertolucci, Sakamoto remains a shadowy and self-effacing presence.

Barely visible on the unlit platform, he busied himself with banks of tape machines, turntables and digital keypads. The idea seemed to be to whet his listeners' appetite for the melodic material due later in the show by testing their responses (and possibly their patience) with an apparently random assortment of noises. Snatches of Japanese koto music alternated with chunks of tribal chanting or eerie orchestral strings. What sounded like hiss from a faulty amplifier gradually took on rhythm and shape.

Then Sakamoto slipped across to the piano and plunged into the mainstream of European classical music. His first piece was limpid, delicate and somewhat Satie-esque. Then he grew more "romantic", hinting at the ghosts of Chopin - even Rachmaninov or Schumann.

Words and symbols flashed up on a pair of screens behind him - "a massive bundle of letters sleeps in my arms", "a newborn baby" - but it was hard to discern what they added to the performance. Sakamoto may be a cunning synthesist of concepts and cultures, but for that very reason, it's difficult to pin down what he means.

Perhaps that's what has made him such a successful soundtrack composer: writing music for movies means missing bits out and playing down your own identity. Joined onstage by the string quartet Solid Strings, he played Rain, from his Last Emperor soundtrack, then a piece he composed for Wuthering Heights. The first sounded like a formal exercise in Nyman-esque minimalism, the second was windswept, lush and vapid. Excerpts from his opera, Life, seemed technically assured but lacked intensity.

It was as if Sakamoto had passed through but left no trace behind him. Quite an accurate reflection of his whole career, in fact.

fields.headline: CBI goes into euro retreat
fields.standfirst:
Industry urges Labour to take lead
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The Confederation of British Industry last night washed its hands of the government's faltering euro campaign, saying it was up to ministers to persuade the public about the benefits of UK entry to the single currency.
fields.body:
The Confederation of British Industry last night washed its hands of the government's faltering euro campaign, saying it was up to ministers to persuade the public about the benefits of UK entry to the single currency.

"The government have got to lead on this," Digby Jones, the CBI's new director general, said. "They've got to win the argument."

A spokeswoman for the organisation said that firms no longer believed Britain would enter the single currency in the short term and had told the CBI to concentrate on improving the European single market and breaking down trade barriers.

The CBI's reluctance to be cheerleader for the pro-euro campaign will add to the government's woes over its policy towards the single currency. Over the weekend, Wim Duisenberg, head of the European Central Bank, warned it would be years before Britain was ready to join while a new opinion poll showed anti-euro sentiment at a record high.

The CBI yesterday denied a newspaper report that its support for early euro entry was waning. "The weight of CBI opinion supports the principle of UK membership when the economic conditions are right," Mr Jones said.

A former lawyer, Mr Jones replaced the CBI's previous director general, Adair Turner, two months ago. Mr Turner was an enthusiastic promoter of the euro and since leaving the CBI has joined the board of pro-euro lobby group Britain in Europe. Mr Jones is on its advisory council.

Mr Jones said the debate over the pros and cons of entry was becoming "sterile".

"The debate isn't going to be won, lost or even fought until there is a referendum, which isn't going to be for a while."

Downing Street yesterday sought to play down Mr Jones's comments. "The CBI is the CBI, we are the government. We have got a very clear policy which we have enunciated very clearly," the prime minister's official spokesman said.

"It seems to me perfectly sensible that they want businesses to be focusing on issues such as how British business can maximise the opportunities of the single currency."

Anti-euro campaigners said the government was increasingly isolated in arguing for early entry into the euro.

"The government should now follow the CBI's lead and concentrate on the issues that actually matter to business," said Nick Herbert, chief executive of Business for Sterling.

webTitle: I can't be a temp for ever

fields.headline: I can't be a temp for ever
fields.standfirst: What do you think? Have your say at the Talking shop
fields.trailText: I have been a temp for so long that it is becoming very difficult to get a permanent job as prospective employers tend to assume I have a commitment problem and believe I have missed out somehow by not having progressed in a single role.
fields.body:
The problem

I have been a temp for so long that it is becoming very difficult to get a permanent job as prospective employers tend to assume I have a commitment problem and believe I have missed out somehow by not having progressed in a single role. However I think that my temping has given me adaptability, confidence and a multitude of skills. Interviewers tend to think I'm making excuses! Please give me some ideas on how to overcome my dilemma.

The solution

Getting a permanent post after temping for so long is one of the most common problems faced by temps. It is so easy to get typecast and so hard to break the once a temp, always a temp mould, that I always advise potential career temps (those who see temping as a long-term strategy) to think very carefully about the consequences. However, don't despair, because it is possible to get that elusive permanent post - many temps do.

There are three ways that temps can be successful in making the transition:

1. Temps are often given a long-term contract or permanent position by one of the firms they are temping at. Companies always prefer to hire someone they know and trust rather than having to start a labourious and costly recruitment process. So, start scouting around in your current and future placings and make it clear you would welcome a permanent post.

2. A second way to make the transition is to look for jobs on long-ish contracts rather than permanent posts. An employer may feel more comfortable taking you on a two or three year contract than a permanent one. Once you have completed such a contract, you should find it easier to convince an employer that you have stayability_.

3. The final approach that some temps find works for them is to be much more assertive to potential employers about your desire for a permanent post. State in your covering letter how keen you are for stability and how, whilst you have benefited enormously from temping (citing adaptability, flexibility etc), you feel that you prefer to be committed and loyal to one firm. Repeat this mantra two or three times at the interview. Eventually, some far- sighted employer should snap you up.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

fields.headline: A lament to celebrate
fields.standfirst:
Birmingham Contemporary Music Group/ Nicholas Kraemer
CBSO Centre, Birmingham
***
fields.trailText:
Birmingham Contemporary Music Group/ Nicholas Kraemer
CBSO Centre, Birmingham
fields.body:
Scottish-born Thea Musgrave, often overlooked in the roll-call of the leading British composers of our time because she has lived in the US for more than a quarter of a century, is now in her 70s and is still producing distinctive, shapely works. The latest of them is Lamenting With Ariadne, a 15-minute tone poem for chamber ensemble. On a seashore Ariadne despairingly watches Theseus's departing ship, until the arrival of Dionysus. His insistent energy gradually transforms the mood until even Ariadne is caught up in a whirling celebratory dance.

The scene-painting is vivid and explicit: a solo viola sings Ariadne's mellow laments, while a trumpet impersonates Dionysus. He is first heard offstage, moving closer as the music changes colour and tempo; when he eventually appears he calls to each of the members of the ensemble in turn to join him in his ecstatic dance. It's a simple dramatic device, akin to those Musgrave has used in earlier orchestral scores, but the plotting is so perfect and the proportioning so well judged it works as both a piece of instrumental scene painting and a mini-concerto for the two soloists, the excellent Christopher Yates and Jonathan Holland in this premiere.

Certainly Musgrave's fluent, through-composed piece came as a refreshing change at the end of a programme otherwise made up of sequences of more or less exquisite miniatures. On the positive side there was Judith Weir's undoubtedly jewel-like Airs From Another Planet, and Howard Skempton's alternately hypnotic and endearing Suite From Delicate, extracted from a 70-minute ballet score for the unlikely combination of two cellos and percussion. But Thomas Adès's Sonata di Caccia is one of his least successful scores, while for all its extrovert percussive colours the twisted automata of John Woolrich's From The Shadow never add up to as much as the sum of their parts.

webTitle: Why you will be forced to take a company pension

fields.headline: Why you will be forced to take a company pension
fields.standfirst: Ministers are proposing to force more than a million people into joining company pension schemes.             Phillip Inman and Patrick Sherwen report on the questions the plans raise.
fields.trailText: Ministers are proposing to force more than a million people into joining company pension schemes. Phillip Inman and Patrick Sherwen report on the questions the plans raise.
fields.body:
What is going on?

The government wants to force employees to take out a company pension if their employer has one. Around 155,000 employers have a company scheme, but 20% of their employees refuse to join. Most of them are young and at the lower end of the pay scales.

Why are so many peopled turned off company schemes?

They will be asked to contribute anything between 5% and 8% of their salary towards the scheme, which they think is a bit steep when there are debts and other costs to pay.

But doesn't the company chip in?

Companies usually top up the contribution to around 17% of the employees salary. If an employee is in what's called a final salary scheme, the payment every month of £17 for each £100 of salary is enough to fund a pension worth two-thirds of their salary on retirement. Some companies even pay the whole lot.

It sounds like a good deal

It is. The money paid in each month by the employer is about twice the sum paid by the member of staff. A 25-year-old member of staff on the average salary of £20,000 paying 6% of their salary into a scheme will fork out £1,200 each year less tax relief of 100% (pension payments are paid out of income before tax). If the worker is on a salary of £30,000 by the time they retire, they should receive a pension of £20,000 each year.

Is there a catch?

You must pay the same amount in every month, which makes the company pension inflexible. And some companies make it difficult to transfer the pension contributions to a new employer. Many employers have also dumped their final salary schemes in favour of something called a money purchase scheme. They will often make the same generous payments and build up the same lump sum at the end, but what each individual ends up with will be left to the market.

Don't markets go up and down?

At the time of retirement the company will purchase an annuity that will aim to turn a lump sum of say £200,000 into annual payments of £10,000. If the market is down one month it might only buy a pension of £9,500 or up the next and be worth £10,500. It's pot luck. At the moment, and for the foreseeable future, annuities rates are low. In a final salary scheme the employer must make up any shortfall. In a money purchase pension the employee takes the hit, making them unsurprisingly less popular with employees.

If they are good value overall, why does the government need to force people to take them up?

Over 5.4m adults in the UK said in a recent survey they did not know when they would be able to afford to start a pension. Many of them will be eligible for an company scheme. The government fears that when its new stakeholder pension scheme begins in 2001, employees will be tempted away from their company pensions.

Stakeholder pensions are designed to be low cost and flexible, allowing people to pay in as little as £10 per month without any penalties. Employers would have been forced to offer employees without a pension a chance to join the stakeholder version and administer it for them if they say yes. Young people and those on lower pay scales might have gone for the cheaper option even though they would have missed out on employer contributions. Under the new rules the company scheme will be a must have.

Has it always been like this?

No, it's a case of back to the future. Until 1988 membership of a company pension scheme was a condition of employment.

Why did the government change it then, if it was only going to be changed back again later?

The government, in the shape of Norman Fowler who was secretary of state for employment at the time, felt company pension schemes were a dampener on efficiency. They hindered job mobility. It was thought that someone on a company scheme would be less likely to change jobs than someone with a personal plan, so the hindrance was removed. The economic conditions at the time were also pushing many into unemployment who then found themselves tied to a poor value company scheme which they had been given no choice but to join in the first place.

Did the new regime work?

Not really. The common view is that the change was a serious mistake and paved the way for the pensions mis-selling scandal.

In what way?

The mis-selling scandal revolved round unscrupulous salesmen who persuaded their prey to pull out of their company scheme and adopt a personal pension in its place. In doing so they deprived many of the employer contributions they would otherwise have been in line for.

How many were affected by the mis-selling?

The review is still underway but in the first phase approximately 0.5m cases were unearthed. These people were deprived of £11bn they would have received in company schemes and by the end of last year had been paid £2.3bn in compensation.

So in future I will have to join my company scheme if I am eligible. Can I take out a stakeholder pension too?

This has not yet been decided. The government was expected to release a consultation document on this issue in July but it never emerged. The official reason given was that the cabinet reshuffle got in the way. Pensions industry speculation suggests it was because the contents are likely to cause controversy by preventing employees from taking out both types of provision.

How will the changes affect me in my current job?

It is unlikely that the new rules will be applied to existing employees. This would entail the retrospective introduction of new employment conditions and in theory could lead to redundancies. Consequently, the new rules will almost certainly only apply to those starting a job from September onwards.

Why are so many peopled turned off company schemes? They will be asked to contribute anything between 5% and 8% of their salary towards the scheme, which they think is a bit steep when there are debts and other costs to pay. But doesn't the company chip in? Companies usually top up the contribution to around 17% of the employees salary. fields.headline: Io
fields.standfirst:
Ronnie Scott's, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText: Ronnie Scott's, London
fields.body:
It's been over a decade since Loose Tubes, the collectively-run British big band, called it a day. The Tubes (who brought the world Django Bates, the Argüelles brothers, Iain Ballamy and many others) played an all-original book and their independence blasted fresh air through the UK scene. That legacy hasn't looked like spawning a natural UK-based heir - until now.

With 32 members, many of them symphony players, Io are even bigger - and that part of Ronnie Scott's that wasn't occupied by the band on Sunday night appeared to be mostly occupied by their nearest and dearest. But this wasn't just a party for a bunch of musicians and their families. Though the orchestra's potential jazz-soloist strengths are muted as yet (Bates, Ballamy, Julian Argüelles and others were developed soloists by the 1984 launch of the Tubes), the rich textures and sharp contrasts in the ensemble writing and playing are already remarkable.

When jazz ensembles use string sections, they're often bolted on, politely adding sonorities to the same riffs. This ensemble plays as a cohesive whole, the strings slamming exuberantly into passages written like brass parts, before unfolding more stately classical figures over which a tenor-sax smokily weaves, or languorous sustained chords behind squawky free-improv flute. The riff-writing for the funky parts and the melodies for their shots at Latin jazz were the most predictable parts of a set bustling with surprises, though a propulsive percussion section lifted everything with a beat in it, predictable or not.

But Io's promise was truly revealed in the more open pieces, which often began impressionistically with quiet flute or clarinet figures, or north African cadences over whispering strings, and through which the band would build layers of intertwined lines, the percussion intensifying behind them. A new generation of classical players whose ears are open to jazz's balance of discipline and individual spontaneity gives the ensemble interplay real vitality. As with George Russell's and the late Gil Evans's bands, the effect is to make even the written parts sound newly conceived, and the unjazzlike harmonies set fascinating challenges to soloists.

The show suffered a half-hour hiatus in the second half when a member of the audience went down with a possible heart attack, but the band finally came back with redoubled force.

fields.headline: Media boffin savages AOL chief
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: America Online chairman Steve Case was yesterday forced to defend spending billions of dollars on entertainment and media group Time Warner following criticism that his "dash for content" was an expensive mistake.
fields.body:
America Online chairman Steve Case was yesterday forced to defend spending billions of dollars on entertainment and media group Time Warner following criticism that his "dash for content" was an expensive mistake.

Mr Case, who last month clinched a $140bn takeover of Time Warner, came under fire from the head of the world's leading new media research unit - the computer labs at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who claimed that content would form only a small part of the services needed on the web.

Mr Case, who wants to depose Bill Gates as king of the internet by amassing films and other entertainment, educational material, news and other information sources, was dismissed by professor Michael Dertouzos, who likened the Time Warner deal to a marriage of exhibitionists and voyeurs.

Attacking the hype surrounding the mega-merger, he suggested the future of the net was much closer to the Microsoft boss's vision of better software and finding alternatives to the PC.

"My belief is the content, very important though it is, is only a small part of where it [the Internet] is heading," said Prof Dertouzos. Sharing a platform with Mr Case and Mr Gates at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, to discuss winning strategies to the internet race, the professor suggested Mr Case's aim of using the merger to gain access to new forms of content, including films and magazines owned by the media giant to consumers' PCs, was misconceived.

"If you take all the content, all the TV stations, all the movies ever made, all the trade journals and add it up it comes to less than 5% of the industrial economy. If, on the other hand, you take office work, what used to be called white collar work, that's 60% of the United States economy and 50% across the industrialised world."

The potential to find new ways of processing that information work was much greater than simply delivering new content to PCs and could amount to $4 trillion a year within the next 15 years.

Comparing the AOL-Time Warner deal to a merger between Hollywood exhibitionists and internet voyeurs, Prof Dertouzos said the real challenge posed by technology was how to make existing machines easier to use and to find new ways of digging out complex information in the human brain.

Noting that web searches often produce masses of meaningless information, he said: "It's time we started accessing information by meaning rather than by syntax."

Clearly riled by Prof Dertouzos's comments, Mr Case accused him of deliberately trying to be controversial and insisted that his goal was to encourage greater use of the internet.

On average people spent an hour a day online but the other 23 watching television, reading etc. Merging with Time Warner, whose brands include Fortune magazine, Time and Warner Brothers, would allow AOL to paint on a much broader canvas.

Speaking afterwards at a press conference, Mr Case said: "Ten years ago we had 100,000 customers and nobody, including my parents, knew what I was doing for a living.

"Now everyone understands that the internet is important but the next 10 years are going to be the interesting ones when it goes from being a curiosity to an everyday part of people's lives."

While acknowledging the potential for new devices to deliver information and to build bridges between them and the PC, he predicted that the PC would remain the dominant form of internet access.
